DOC.HEAD: Prisoner Disputes Ties to IRA; Promises to Follow Bail Conditions
DOC.TEXT: An Irish man imprisoned here for seven years in an immigration dispute testified Tuesday that he's quit the Irish Republican Army and would abide by all bail conditions if released. Joseph Doherty, 35, faces a life sentence in the United Kingdom for the 1980 slaying of a British officer. Doherty escaped from a Belfast prison in 1981 and fled to the United States on the orders of an IRA superior. He was captured here in 1983 and has been held in a Manhattan jail since. At a bail hearing, Doherty said he would return to the United Kingdom if his bid for political asylum in the United States fails. ``If I were to go back to face the hangman's rope, I would go back,'' Doherty said during four hours of testimony. ``I would pay my own ticket and gladly go back, go back graciously on that plane with no malice to the United States.'' Doherty has fought extradition to Britain since his arrest. He has acknowledged that the British officer was killed in a gunfight between troops and his four-man IRA unit, but claims the fighting was political and that he would be persecuted if forced to return. U.S. District Judge Miriam G. Cedarbaum is considering a request that Doherty be freed on an $800,000 bail package pending resolution of the asylum request. His say his right to due process has been violated by his lengthy imprisonment. Doherty's plight has become a rallying point among Irish-Americans here. He has been honorary grand marshal of the St. Patrick's Day parade and has a Manhattan street named for him. The courtroom was filled with supporters Tuesday, including three congressman and several local politicians. Cedarbaum sought Doherty's testimony to help decide whether he is a flight risk. The U.S. government, which opposes his release, will present witnesses at a later hearing, after which Cedarbaum will rule. Doherty testified that he resigned from the IRA when he came to the United States and has had no contact with its members. The armed group is fighting to wrest Northern Ireland from British rule and unite it with the Irish Republic. Even if the IRA wanted him, ``I would refuse to go back to them because of my commitment to the court and the provisions of bail and also to these people in the back,'' Doherty said. ``My life is minuscule compared to the Irish-American community.'' However, U.S. Attorney Otto Obermaier sought to discredit Doherty, stressing his use of a false passport to enter the United States and a false Social Security number to get work. A federal appeals court ruled this summer that Doherty has the right to seek asylum here.

DOC.HEAD: Stuart Case Prosecutor Seeks Override Of Attorney-Client Privilege
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The answers to the case in which a man concocted a story about a robber shooting him and his pregnant wife may never be known unless the state's highest court overrules attorney-client privilege. The husband, Charles Stuart, has since committed suicide, and prosecutors are asking the court to force Stuart's attorney to disclose conversations they had before the hoax unraveled. It may provide the only break for prosecutors considering charges against Stuart's brother, who says he was an unwitting accomplice. Attorneys for the Stuart family will contend in hearings set for this week that attorney-client privilege remains intact. And although prosecutors will argue the privilege should be overridden in the interest of justice, some legal observers say that is shaky ground at best. ``There's not much precedent for this,'' said Phyllis Goldfarb, a professor at the Boston College Law School. Carol Stuart, 30, was shot in the head on the night of Oct. 23, minutes after she and her husband drove away from a prenatal class at Brigham and Women's Hospital. Wounded himself, Stuart called police and guided them to his location using his car's cellular telephone. His dramatic, anguished plea for help over the telephone was widely broadcast. Mrs. Stuart died hours after the attack; her prematurely delivered son died 17 days after that. Stuart claimed a black man had kidnapped them, forced them to drive to a deserted area, robbed and then shot them. Many saw the incident as a symbol of urban crime. Then, on Jan. 3, Matthew Stuart went to authorities and implicated his brother in the shooting. Charles Stuart leaped to his death from a bridge the next day. Nearly a year after the crime, the grand jury investigating the case has stalled over whether Matthew Stuart's role was really that of an unwitting accomplice as he claimed. Prosecutors want the privilege broken, in order to learn whether Stuart told his lawyer, John Dawley, that Matthew was involved in a plot to kill Mrs. Stuart and cover up the crime by staging a fake robbery. According to a judge's memorandum, the grand jury was told that Matthew was to meet his brother at a predetermined location Oct. 23 to get items that later would be claimed to have been stolen, and an insurance claim would be filed. The grand jury, according to the report, was told Matthew pulled alongside his brother's car and talked to him, but was not aware his brother was wounded or that Mrs. Stuart was in the car. Matthew told police his brother passed him several items, including a handgun. He said he dropped the gun and a woman's handbag into the Pines River in Revere. The items were later recovered and the gun was identified as the one used to shoot the Stuarts. At a hearing in April, Assistant District Attorney Thomas Mundy said Matthew Stuart was a potential target of the grand jury investigation, and indicated Dawley's testimony could shed light on Matthew's possible role in the case. On Friday, prosecutors will argue before the Supreme Judicial Court that the public interest mandates that Dawley break his deceased client's confidentiality and tell what he knows. ``We are arguing in the interests of justice,'' said Paul Leary, first assistant district attorney for Suffolk County. ``We feel as though there's a compelling interest that if we can gain whatever additional information Dawley may have, justice will be served,'' he added. Nancy Gertner, a lawyer for Matthew Stuart, called that ``a completely uphill argument.'' Goldfarb, the professor, said attorney-client discussions could be disclosed in some circumstances, for example, if their contents were revealed to a third party. ``But I haven't found any cases where it was argued that the public interest overrides the privilege,'' she said. Goldfarb said courts in most states have ruled that attorney-client privileges survived the death of a client and went to the next of kin. Gertner said she doubted the value of Dawley's testimony about his talks with Stuart, even if the privilege was waived. ``Charles Stuart was capable of lying to everyone,'' Gertner said.

DOC.HEAD: Guardsman Celebrate a Birthday on an Army Post
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard is one of the reserve units called up for possible duty in Saudi Arabia. National Writer Fred Bayles is following this small unit of 14 Guardsmen as they prepare for deployment overseas.

When 22 members of the Graham-Harris family assembled to sing happy birthday to the family patriarch, their celebration site was an unlikely one: a bustling Army post preparing for possible war. There was no choice. Two key family members are part of that preparation. Don Graham and Henry Harris are brothers-in-law who belong to the 265th Quartermaster Detachment, a South Carolina National Guard unit getting ready for deployment to the Mideast. The water purification unit has been at Fort Stewart, training hard since Thursday. As a reward, the men got Labor Day afternoon off. So most of the men's families made the two-hour drive from their homes around Allendale, S.C., where the unit is based. Harris' wife, sister and brothers were there. Graham had the biggest turnout, a caravan of brothers and sisters, their children and five of his own seven children. The guest of honor was his father, Earnest Graham, who turned 83 on Tuesday. Don Graham, a 37-year-old construction supervisor, joined the Guard with his brother-in-law 17 years ago. He accepts his assignment to the Mideast with little emotion. ``It's something we got to do,'' he said. He said he is proud of his children and wants to see them grow up. But he said he doesn't spend time worrying about less pleasant possibilities. ``You can't predict life. You could go out the door and get killed,'' he said. ``Something like this makes you appreciate life more.'' Graham and the other unit members couldn't go off post, so they gave their relatives a limited tour of the military complex: an extended visit to the PX and lunch at a fast-food franchise. The families also got a glimpse of the unit's accommodations, a long barracks of cinder block and wood built to sleep 40. The quarters are kindly described as spartan: no water, dim overhead bulbs and little ventilation. It bakes during the day and retains the heat well into the night. The men have spread out over the big barracks, taking bunks in clusters that describe the dynamics of the group. Three sergeants occupy the far end and gather most nights to play guts, an aptly named card game of bluffing and side bets. They play for quarters now, but back in Allendale they are joined by other friends each Friday night for games of much bigger stakes. ``Sometimes we have 10 people sitting around the table,'' said Hullie Cohen, a burly contractor. The men joke with their wives about going to bed at 8 p.m. They make tentative plans to see each other again, depending on the unit's status. What they don't talk about is the Mideast and their likely deployment. The men hardly talk about it among themselves. When they do, it is usually to joke about the heat. Some have suggested landscapers be sent in ahead of the unit to plant shade trees. Others suggest, just a little more seriously, that they sell the water they will purify to the Saudis at prices equivalent to gasoline. In conversations, some say they are eager to go. Others wish they could go back home. There is little mention of political issues. There is an absence of bravado. On their second day of mobilization the unit went to a post orientation meeting with a larger group of Florida reservists called up to work at the post hospital. As the session was ending, a lieutenant colonel asked the 265th to stand up. These men, he told the 200 other reservists, were on their way to the Mideast. ``These are your friends and neighbors just up the road,'' he said. ``This is a great outfit.'' The rest of the hall burst into applause. The 14 men from Allendale exchanged grim, nervous glances. Mostly they looked down at their feet.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Literate Teachers Transforming Classroom Life
DOC.TEXT: Teachers with computer skills are turning their classrooms into models of education reform, tailoring lessons to meet students' individual needs in subjects from French to science, a new study finds. The first-of-its-kind survey of 608 computer-savvy teachers in 576 schools across the country found that many have learned ways to individualize lessons and teach more sophisticated material using computers. The survey, released Monday by the Bank Street College of Education's Center for Technology in Education, found teachers using computers in ways that go far beyond the usual drill-and-practice. More than 9 out of 10 said they use word processors for writing lessons. As many as two-thirds produced ready-made art, and more than 70 percent used terminals for problem-solving programs, drill-and-practice lessons, especially in math, or tutorial programs. More than half the social studies teachers surveyed _ 52 percent _ used computers to construct databases. ``I think that it's very clear that what these teachers have accomplished is exactly the kinds of things people engaged in reform are trying to accomplish,'' said Karen Sheingold, director of the center and co-author of the report with Bank Street researcher Martha Hadley. Eighty-eight percent believe their computer knowledge has transformed classroom life. They have higher expectations of their students, present more complex material and believe their students are gaining better thinking skills. But teachers also complained of having too few computers, printers and other hardware, and scarce time to plan and conduct computer lessons. The report recommended that schools rethink their schedules so that teachers have the time they need. Teachers taking part in the mailed survey conducted in the spring of 1989 taught grades 4 through 12 in all 50 states. They were identified as knowledgeable about computers by computer and software companies and education groups. Spreading the classroom computer revolution is possible, but only if there are enough technology, support and time for teachers to plan lessons, and a school structure in which teachers may experiment with new technology, the report concluded. The Center for Technology in Education operates under a five-year, $4.9 million grant from the federal Office of Educational Research and Improvement.

Copies of the report can be obtained by sending a check for $5, made out to Bank Street College of Education, to Laura Bryant, Bank Street College of Education, 610 W. 112th St., New York, N.Y. 10025.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Nations Agree to Work Together to Clean Up Baltic Sea
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the seven nations on the Baltic Sea have agreed to curb the pollution that has killed a third of life on the sea bed. But the Eastern Europeans say they'll need Western aid for the effort. ``It's a breakthrough for the ecological restoration of the Baltic Sea,'' said Swedish Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson. Carlsson and Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland hosted the two-day conference, which ended Monday with agreement that a comprehensive plan for cleaning up the Baltic would be prepared by the end of next year. Greenpeace International said the conference's declaration was too vague. The environmental organization has already criticized the Baltic nations for aiming too low with their 1988 plan to halve emissions into the Baltic by 1995. Sweden and Denmark already have national cleanup strategies, and the conference was seen as stepping up pressure on the Soviet Union and former East Bloc countries to catch up. Eastern European delegates acknowledged that they have lagged in pollution control, but made it clear they would need Western money and expertise to help end environmentally damaging practices. ``The policy of earmarking meager financing for conservation activities in the past is responsible for this state of affairs,'' said Vatsilu Doguzhiev, deputy chairman of the Soviet council of ministers. Ecological problems ``require an enormous amount of effort and finance,'' he said. According to papers presented at the conference, half of all nitrogen emissions into the Baltic come from Poland. One of the most serious sources of pollution is the Vistula River, which flows into the sea. Several scientific studies have shown that the Baltic is suffocating as phosphates and nitrates flood the sea, encouraging the growth of algae that uses up the oxygen needed by plants and fish. Mazowiecki stressed the need for the cleanup but said his country's involvement may be unrealistic without significant technological and financial support from abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Contractors: Gulf Crisis Not Enough To Turn Arms Sales Upward
DOC.TEXT: Defense contractors at the Farnborough International Air Show say the military buildup in the Middle East will do little to reverse the sales decline caused by the easing of East-West tensions. Industry executives meeting at this week's show to socialize and do business say that despite Iraq's invasion of Kuwait a month ago, long-term defense orders will continue to decrease. Talk of the Persian Gulf crisis fills the blue- and white-striped tents at Farnborough, 40 miles west of London. And there are reminders of the confrontation. The U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf region has deprived the show of its expected star attraction, the F-117A stealth fighter. Beneath a display of Exocet missiles, hostesses in gold-buttoned, red knit suits welcome visitors to the exhibit of Aerospatiale, the French manufacturer of missiles that are in the arsenals of both sides in the crisis. Patrick Mercillon, spokesman for Aerospatiale's tactical missiles division, said the crisis had given the defense industry a psychological boost but the kick has not been felt in sales. Worldwide defense expenditures are expected to drop from $1 trillion to $800 billion by 1999, said a defense spokesman for British Aerospace PLC. Boeing Vice President Philip Condit said the Persian Gulf crisis had made governments more aware of the need for defense flexibility but it would not mean an about-face on defense spending cuts. ``It has given us a broad awareness of the need for military fitness,'' he said in an interview. Ron Howard, chairman of GEC Avionics, sounded more optimistic. ``Overall, the situation in the gulf has had the effect of convincing the world that you cannot walk away from defense commitments as originally thought because of Warsaw Pact detente,'' Howard said. A good outlook for commercial orders is expected to offset drooping defense orders for firms like Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, which supply both defense and civilian markets. Boeing's Condit said fuel price rises have not forced any cancellations or delays of this year's expected record production of 381 commercial planes. A $6 billion order from Asiana Airlines, a new South Korean carrier, was confirmed by Boeing at the air show Monday morning. In the afternoon, Airbus Industrie announced a $350 million deal with the Australian airliner, Ansett. Airbus announced its first profitable year since the European consortium of aircraft manufacturers and engine makers was founded in 1970.

DOC.HEAD: American's Dramatic Escape from Kuwait Reads Like Movie Plot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AMM2 of Sept. 3.
DOC.TEXT: Dick Clay, a burly German-Irish Hoosier with mustache and beer belly, doesn't look much like a Filipino. But he made a daring escape from Kuwait disguised as one _ with fake Philippine documents ingeniously forged by a loyal friend. Clay, 46, managed to slip across the Iraqi-Jordanian frontier last week with 34 Filipino employees by pretending he was one of them. His week-long flight took all the ingenuity of World War II prisoners' flight from Stalag 17. He had to hide for three days in the Iraqi capital _ swarming with Saddam Hussein's secret police and their army of informers _ and tough out a heart-stopping encounter with Iraqi border guards. His one-page travel document was a masterpiece of fakery. A Filipino instrument technician spent 10 laborious days duplicating the Philippines Embassy seal and a creating a long inscription in tiny English characters. The stamp was fashioned from a rubber shower sandal; the black ink was made royal purple by diluting it with milk. On paper, the American construction manager Richard Eugene Clay became Ricardo Erazo. His hometown of Bloomington, Ind., where his wife Claudia and three children were waiting, became Batangas City in the Philippines. ``I was hiding in Kuwait until the Iraqis said they'd hang anyone who helped shelter foreigners,'' Clay said in an interview. ``Then I figured it was time to go.'' That was Aug. 20, almost three weeks after Iraq overran Kuwait. By then, he was ready. Even with his false papers prepared, Clay's appearance posed problems. Filipinos tend to be small and slender, dark-eyed and dark-haired. But Clay's face is a great red expanse of rugged terrain, with a prominent sunburned nose and distinctly European eyes. And he has a large U.S. Navy tattoo on his right hand. He pulled a baseball cap down low over his brown hair, wore large sunglasses and disappeared into a roomy long-sleeved shirt. That didn't help much, but he had no choice. In Kuwait, Clay supervised 500 Filipino and Indian workers at M.W. Kellogg, a U.S. contractor that maintained two oil refineries in the emirate. He accounted for all but four and then prepared to escape himself. Food and water were gathered and stashed away. Exit documents were sought. A route was planned. ``When everything else was ready, I told 'em to go out and steal two buses,'' Clay said. By then, the Filipinos were desperate to leave the gulf state where some had worked for a decade. ``I know of one case where 12 Iraqi soldiers raped a Filipino lady,'' Clay said. ``They killed her brother when he tried to help her. That's a fact. She was still in the hospital when I left.'' Clay left behind $85,000 in the bank and an apartment full of belongings that he doesn't expect to see again. His small convoy made it to Bagdhad after two traffic accidents and some close shaves on the border. At each roadblock, Filipino friends stood in the bus door and passed out his papers. The group was stuck in Baghdad for three days, which Clay spent huddling between the others in a car or hiding in three hotel rooms with 128 others. He rented another bus for the equivalent of $5,000 for the seven-hour drive to the Jordan border. By then, his party had grown by 25 Filipino women. When Clay reached Jordan, he had to spend three days hiding among dozens of real Filipinos under a makeshift shelter at a squalid, desperate camp in no man's land camp past the Iraq border before the Jordanians could process the refugees. There, he sent scouts to find a Westerner. They found Jim Nuttal of Save the Children, who saved Clay. But the tough part was getting out of Iraq. Clay cleared every hurdle, finally garnering the treasured exit stamp on his false travel document. Then, at a last check before entering Jordan, an Iraqi guard stuck his head into the bus. He glared at Clay and said: ``Marine?'' ``Filipino,'' said Clay. The Iraqi took him off the bus for six hours of interrogation. But his friends rallied around him. They piled their luggage across the road, insisting that if Clay was returned to Baghdad, they'd go too. They scuffled with Iraqi guards swinging truncheons. Finally, one woman barged into the border office, wailing that she could not be separated from her uncle. Finally, the stern-faced Iraqi handed back Clay's document and waved him onward. With a trace of a smile, he said: ``Goodbye, Marine.''

DOC.HEAD: Egyptian Soldiers Are at the Front, but It's Far Away
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Egyptian soldiers are in Saudi Arabia, prepared to fight if Iraq invades, but that's a thousand miles from Cairo and life goes on as usual in the teeming metropolis of the Middle East. This is mango and guava season. Decorated carts haul stacks of the fruit into the city. Juice sellers, costumed from the pages of the Arabian Nights, are popular attractions. Hawkers clog crowded sidewalks with illegal tables holding mechanical toys and live tortoises for children, hair bows for mothers. There are evening carriage rides along the Nile for those with the money to pay. American and European teen-agers, summer vacations over, have returned to their favorite haunts: Greasy Burger, Pizza Hut and Roy's Goes Mexican at the Marriott Hotel. Nightly television includes ``Knot's Landing'' reruns. Johnny Weissmuller swings across the screen in ``Tarzan Finds a Son.'' A recent day's outing to the Suez Canal, past dozens of Egyptian military installations, produced one unusual sight: a taxi tooling down the road with a monkey on top. The bases were quiet. A canal-side peanut vendor watched the U.S. Navy battleship Wisconsin and French aircraft carrier Clemenceau steam into the Red Sea heading for the Persian Gulf. He barely glanced at the rest of the convoy. ``I've seen enough ships,'' he said, ``but the helicopter escort was great.'' In Cairo coffeehouses, there is far more talk of how to win peace than how to wage war. ``We all are praying for peace,'' a student said. ``Nobody wants war.'' The tension engendered by Iraq's occupation of Kuwait on Aug. 2, which caused 4,000 Egyptian soldiers and tens of thousands of Americans to be sent to Saudi Arabia, seems remote from most of Cairo's 12 million residents. Expatriate parents speak of frantic telephone calls from abroad urging caution. An American grandfather demanded that his daughter bring his grandchildren home. ``They are home,'' she replied. Life in Cairo surges onward with the same chaos and madness it has possessed through the millennium since the city was founded in 969. Change comes so often and so swiftly to Cairo that talk of a possible Persian Gulf war was diluted from the start by more immediate cares: rising prices for gasoline and food, shortages amd gigantic sales that brought more jostling people than usual to downtown Cairo. August was hot and steamy. Cairo's air quality was lousy. As always, the well-to-do _ including President Hosni Mubarak _ spent the month at the Mediterranean seaside of Egypt's summer capital, Alexandria. Schools and universities will not open for several weeks. Except for the Islamic holy month of Ramadan, when Egyptians party all night and sleep until noon, August is the only time Cairo traffic takes a break. This year, however, there appeared to be more fender-benders than usual. Taxi drivers blamed an influx of drivers from the gulf. ``Kuwaitis can't drive in Cairo,'' one said after swerving to avoid a collision. ``They're not used to so many cars.'' Kuwaiti families stranded by Iraq's annexation of their country are moving from hotels to apartments, becoming part of the calliope that is Cairo. Kuwaiti flags fly from some cars. Others are covered by photographs of Kuwait's deposed emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah. Tired Egyptian workers returning from Kuwait and Iraq, many now penniless, head for their villages in jammed taxis. They carry tattered suitcases instead of the household appliances and electronic goods they had always been able to bring as gifts. Extra security precautions in Cairo are minimal. Since the invasion, the government has kept four truckloads of helmeted riot police near the Iraqi Embassy in Zamalek, a Nile River island opposite downtown Cairo. At first, the trucks stood in relentless sunshine at the treeless front of the embassy, but wearing riot gear in a covered truck is uncomfortable business and the vehicles were moved half a block to the protection of shade trees. Officers sit around square tables, drinking tea and reading newspapers. A single truck is parked outside the Safir Zamalek, a nearby residential hotel owned by Kuwaitis. Security trucks also sit near the embassies of Kuwait and Saudi Arabia several miles away. Farther south along the Nile, less fortunate soldiers spend their hours in hot, rickety trucks of faded blue, halfway between Cairo and the rich suburb of Maadi where many diplomats and wealthy Egyptians live. Outside the downtown offices of Iraq Airways, where long lines of Egyptian workers once waited, two policemen lean against the polished white facade. Another pair yawn through their watch guarding Kuwait Airways offices in a suburban shopping arcade. To old hands, there's nothing new in all this. In 1942, Cairo's cabarets and swinging night life gave no hint that the decisive battle of EL Alamein was raging 150 miles away.

DOC.HEAD: New Law Allows for Arrest of Those With Overdue Books
DOC.TEXT: Drop the novel. Step away from the car. You're under arrest for having an overdue library book. Starting on Thursday your overdue books could land you in police custody. A law signed by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in June would allow the arrest of library scofflaws if they have received notice that their books are 30 days overdue. The law also raises the maximum fine for an overdue book from $50 to $500. Although the law makes no mention of a jail sentence for an overdue book, it allows for up to five years in prison and a fine of $25,000 for the theft of library property worth more than $250. Gregor Trinkaus-Randall, a collection management consultant for the Massachusetts Board of Library Commissioners, said librarians need tough enforcement tools. ``Any library book that is not returned therefore has to be replaced by the library and is money out of the town's pocket that could be spent on other materials,'' he said. The town of Shrewsbury, for example, loses an estimated $12,000 a year in library materials, Trinkaus-Randall said. ``Books are not cheap,'' he said. ``I'm not even talking about rare books. An art book can cost $100 or more.'' David Linsky, a defense attorney in Cambridge, criticized the measure. ``I think the police are having enough trouble chasing down murderers and rapists without having to keep up with people who have overdue library books,'' he said. Trinkaus-Randall said he expects librarians will use discretion in sending police after those with overdue books. ``Most libraries will go through more notification of somebody, giving them the benefit of the doubt,'' he said. ``In most of the cases, they are not going to say on day 31, send the police out.'' Linsky complained that the law allows the arrest of library scofflaws without a warrant, something that can't be done with an offense such as assault and battery. He said the measure is ``absolutely 100 percent unenforceable.'' ``If the police are told by an employee of the library that you have an overdue library book, then the police can arrest you in any public place and put the handcuffs on you,'' he said. ``That's the real horror show of this thing.'' Steven Crawford, a spokesman for Dukakis, said the administration is taking another look at the law ``to determine whether the questions that are being raised are accurate.'' Massachusetts is not the first state to get tough on those who keep library books at home beyond the due date. In Georgia, a woman was jailed overnight when she failed to appear in court to explain why her books were not returned. The woman said she was sure she had returned the books, and sued the county $500,000 last year for being jailed. In Florida and South Carolina, police have also been put on notice to track down those with overdue books.

DOC.HEAD: Black Baptists Weigh Challenge to Gulf Buildup
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest black church, which once censured Martin Luther King Jr. for moving too fast on civil rights, is weighing the first major religious challenge to the U.S. troop buildup in the Persian Gulf. The 7.8 million-member National Baptist Convention U.S.A. Inc. is scheduled to consider at its annual meeting a resolution criticizing the sending of troops. ``We are not fighting over any principle or ideal,'' the Rev. Theodore Judson Jemison, convention president, said at welcoming ceremonies Monday.``Our fighting ... right now is over oil. It's unfortunate America would become involved the way it has.'' The action comes amid criticism that the denomination's new $10 million headquarters in Nashville is too extravagant for a church that has long been accused of being slow to respond to social issues. The church still owes $7 million on the headquarters, which was dedicated last year. ``It (the convention) is a sleeping giant that tends to remain asleep. When it tends to wake up, it is filled with gross overindulgence'' such as the World Baptist Center, said Kane Felder, a professor of New Testamament at Howard University Divinity School. The church is the nation's third-largest Protestant denomination and bills itself as the largest black organization in the world. More than 50,000 delegates from the denomination's 32,000 churches are expected to attend the 110th annual meeting, which runs through Sunday. The agenda includes abortion, AIDS, homelessness and teen-age pregnancy along with the Middle East. It shows the influence of Jemison, who led one of the nation's first boycotts of segregated busing in Baton Rouge, La., in 1953. Under his predecessor, the late Rev. Joseph H. Jackson, the convention followed a gradual approach to civil rights, ousting King from a prominent role in a bitter leadership battle in the early 1960s. Jemison, who sided with Jackson during that fight but then led a movement that ousted Jackson in 1982, has tried to take a more aggressive political stance. While other major religious groups and churches, including the National Conference of Catholic Bishops and National Council of Churches, have been cautious not to criticize the deployment of troops in Saudi Arabia after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Jemison questioned the cost and morality of the action. ``Think of the good that the billion dollars could do for black America and poor white America,'' he said. Jemison is coming under some similar criticism over the new World Baptist Center. Felder said the expense is a ``travesty'' when the church faces such problems as drug abuse and teen-age pregnancy. Others defend the center, the first such headquarters ever built by a black church organization. ``I think it's a good status symbol for our people,'' said the Rev. Allen Stanley, a convention vice president. To some observers, the jury is still out on how well Jemison has realized King's dreams of turning the institution into a force for social change. ``How well this administration has been able to achieve those ends is difficult to assess because so much has been invested in the building of the World Baptist Center,'' said Forrest Harris, director of the Kelly Miller Institute on the Black Church at Vanderbilt University.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Helicopter Tactics Updated in Persian Gulf Crisis
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-three years after they were first used in Vietnam combat, ``hunter-killer'' helicopter tactics are being updated with the latest in night-flying technology and interservice cooperation. As darkness fell Monday over the desert, a small Army OH-58 Scout helicopter loaded with special gear for night operations lifted off from an airbase runway. Just behind it came two of the Marine Corps' newest AH-1 Cobras, the ``Whiskey'' model that has twice the power and three times the lethal punch of its Indochina-era ancestor. Earlier in the day, the pilots sat together for a briefing on the night's two-hour training mission. Together, the pilots from the Army's 82nd Airborne Division and Marine Light Attack Squadron 269 formed a hunter-killer team designed to destroy enemy tanks before the tanks are aware of their presence. The technique was first developed in Vietnam, where army ``pink teams,'' combined a Scout helicopter to find enemy bunker complexes and jungle camps with a Cobra gunship to destroy them with rockets and machine guns. If war with Iraq breaks out, officers said, the technique will be applied to Baghdad's tank formations in the open desert, where U.S. forces expect to have a wide edge in night-vision capability and weaponry. ``This is a perfect environment over here . . . We 're working specifically to fly in that environment, specifically to fly at night, because that is probably what we're going to be called on to do,'' said Lt. Col. Kenneth Hill of Tulsa, Okla., commander of the Marine air unit. The Army helicopters are the result of years of effort to develop an aircraft for special operations in darkness. They were first used for night patrol duty during the Persian Gulf ``Tanker War'' in 1987-88. One pilot told then of hovering within easy view of fishing boats whose occupants were unaware of his presence. ``They never look up,'' he said. The Cobras sitting on the Saudi flightline are the latest models, all less than a year old. Their engines produce about 3,300 horsepower, twice that of the Vietnam version. They carry laser-guided Hellfire missiles and other weapons that were less sophisticated or non-existent in Indochina days.

DOC.HEAD: Jupiter's Great Red Spot May Lose Some of Its Red
DOC.TEXT: Jupiter's Great Red Spot may soon lose some of its red because of a change in the weather on the largest planet in the solar system. A 6,200-mile-wide belt of clouds on the planet is starting to change to its typical dark brown smoggy color, 13{ months after it turned white, astronomers say. When the belt turns brown, its winds start feeding ammonia ice crystals into the Great Red Spot, washing out some of the color. The Great Red Spot is a hurricane almost twice the size of Earth. The cloud belt, or Southern Equatorial Belt, sits just north of the Great Red Spot. Several astronomers from NASA's Infrared Telescope Facility on Hawaii's Mauna Kea volcano and from other observatories around the world reported the change to the International Astronomical Union's Central Bureau for Astronomical Telegrams, an astronomy reporting agency in Cambridge, Mass. Scientists study weather on other planets to understand rules governing weather on all planets, including Earth. In July 1989, British astronomer G.M. Hurst first noticed that the Southern Equatorial Belt was changing from brown to white and growing colder. But during the past two weeks, astronomers observed the cloud belt starting to turn brown and get warmer, according to telegrams sent by the Central Bureau on Aug. 22 and on Wednesday. The belt changes to white when Jupiter's internal heat pushes enough ammonia ice crystals upward in the atmosphere, where winds over 300 mph spread the crystals out to form a white deck of light-reflecting cirrus clouds. The cloud belt changes to brown when violent storms mix Jupiter's atmospheric gases, allowing sunlight to trigger reactions by the ammonia and natural gas. That creates brownish smog in the planet's atmosphere. When the cloud belt turns white, the winds diminish, reducing the amount of ice entering the Great Red Spot and allowing it to turn darker red. The cloud belt faded from brown to white in the early 1970s, then turned brown again in 1974, remaining that way until 13{ months ago. The Great Red Spot faded to dim gray in 1976 but regained its brick red color after the Southern Equatorial Belt turned white last year.

DOC.HEAD: 65 Dead, Thousands Homeless in Flooding
DOC.TEXT: Two weekends of monsoon rains in Manila and the northern provinces have killed at least 65 people, destroying roads and flooding the homes of tens of thousands of people, officials said today. Officials said the flooding in the capital, the worst in nearly two decades, was aggravated by uncollected trash that blocked drainage canals. Emilia Tadeo, a spokeswoman of the Office of Civil Defense, said 30 people died and four others were missing in floods over the weekend. She said most of about 300,000 people whose homes were flooded were evacuated from Manila and seven provinces north of the capital. Mrs. Tadeo said 35 people were killed, including 12 children buried in a landslide, and 27 injured during a heavy downpour a week earlier. Floods destroyed or damaged the homes of about 250,000 people. Two of the latest victims died when tons of garbage crumbled and destroyed their house at a dumpsite in the slum district of Tondo. Thirteen others were buried under a landslide in Nueva Vizcaya province. At least 52 villages in the provinces of Pampanga and Tarlac remained isolated by floodwaters from heavy rains that began Saturday, Mrs. Tadeo said. The army's 51st Engineering Brigade said landslides destroyed an 18-mile section of a highway to Nueva Vizcaya and another 1.8-mile portion was washed away by floodwaters. Five other major northern highways also were blocked by landslides and a bridge in Tarlac province was washed away by a river that overflowed its banks.

DOC.HEAD: Advocates Mildly Encouraged by Souter's First Amendment Views
DOC.TEXT: Defenders of First Amendment rights lament the retirement of Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan but say the views of his prospective replacement, David H. Souter, on freedom of speech and the press are somewhat encouraging. ``No one could conclude he has an ax to grind against the media or against First Amendment claims,'' Henry Kaufman of the pro-media Libel Defense Resource Center said of Souter. ``Arguably, we will get a fair hearing. But he's no Brennan.'' Brennan retired in July after a 34-year career as the high court's leading voice of liberalism. He wrote a 1964 landmark opinion giving the news media broad protection against libel suits by public figures and recently authored opinions barring criminal prosecution of those who burn the American flag in protest. The Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to begin hearings on Souter's nomination Sept. 13. Most of what is known of his views have come from his writings as a New Hampshire state judge. President Bush named Souter to the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston this year. Some who have studied the handful of opinions Souter wrote on First Amendment issues during his seven years on the New Hampshire Supreme Court say they are heartened that Bush didn't choose someone with apparent rigid ideas that could limit free expression. ``I think he's been very balanced on free-press issues,'' said Claudia Haskell of the First Amendment Congress. ``He's in the mainstream.'' However, the advocates said they don't expect Souter to be an ardent defender of free expression if he wins confirmation. Kaufman said Souter's opinions seem to reflect more interest ``in the complexity of the law ... than a passion for the underlying rights at issue.'' Souter's ``decisions seem to reflect a cautious craftsman whose views are not expansive in protecting First Amendment rights,'' said Floyd Abrams, a New York lawyer whose clients include the news media. ``There are so many areas of the law in which someone would want to know Judge Souter's philosophic views that, I think in his case more than most, the exploration of his general orientation may indeed tell more than could be learned from particular cases,'' Abrams said. He added that his conclusions could change after Souter testifies to the Judiciary Committee. Some commentators said they were encouraged that Souter had expressed _ in cases unrelated to the First Amendment _ strong support for Supreme Court precedent. Jane Kirtley, head of the Reporters Committee for Freedom of The Press, said she was pleased that Souter appears to have little inclination to topple key rulings. ``Let's face it, we've got some good court decisions sitting up there right now,'' she said. ``I don't see anything that would suggest (Souter) would be anti-media.'' Here is a summary of Souter's opinions in some First Amendment cases as a state Supreme Court judge: _Souter wrote for the court in 1985 when it reinstated a police officer's libel suit against a newspaper that published a letter to the editor accusing the officer of misconduct. Souter said a jury is entitled to decide whether the letter made factual assertions, or only expressed opinions shielded from libel attack. The ruling, in some respects, seems to have foreshadowed a U.S. Supreme Court decision this year that has the news media worried. It said statements of opinion are not automatically immune to libel suits if arguably they contain factual assertions. _In 1984, Souter wrote for the court in upholding a libel verdict against a newspaper that published an editorial about ``obscene and harassing'' telephone calls. The newspaper was sued by a man, mentioned in the editorial, who was convicted of making harassing but not obscene calls. While the newspaper had published a separate accurate account of the case, Souter said the publication was negligent in printing an editorial referring to obscene phone calls. _Souter dissented from the court's 1988 opinion that permitted a libel suit against Hustler magazine. The court allowed an out-of-state resident to take advantage of a New Hampshire law that a publication may be sued for libel for up to six years after making a defamatory statement. Most states allowed only three years to sue. Souter said the ruling encouraged the ``evil'' practice of forum-shopping and said the state had little interest in protecting the reputation of someone who ``never set foot in New Hampshire prior to trial.'' _Writing for the court last year, Souter barred a supporter of presidential candidate Lyndon LaRouche from attaching a cardboard sign to a tree and lamppost outside city hall in Manchester, N.H. But Souter said the man was free to pass out leaflets there without a permit. _While a trial judge in 1981, Souter ruled in favor of two reporters for the University of New Hampshire student newspaper who said they were trying to protect their confidential sources. The judge barred a murder defendant from forcing the reporters to testify. Souter said the defendant's claim that revealing the sources might point to other suspects in the murder was ``sheer speculation.''

DOC.HEAD: Perpich Faces Crucial Vote of Confidence in Primary
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Rudy Perpich says his major contribution over the last eight years as governor has been to restore confidence in Minnesota. Next week, Perpich himself faces a crucial vote of confidence. Backers say the 62-year-old incumbent is a visionary leader who deserves an unprecedented fourth term, while critics call him ``Governor Goofy'' or say he's simply been around too long. If voters endorse the latter view in the Sept. 11 Democratic-Farmer-Labor primary, former state Commerce Commissioner Mike Hatch will be the party's standard-bearer in November. The race is a dead heat, according to a recent public opinion poll, and political observers say it could turn on any last-minute mistakes by either campaign. In the Independent-Republican primary, State Auditor Arne Carlson holds a 2-1 lead over his closest rival, businessman Jon Grunseth, the party's endorsed candidate. Perpich, who first served as governor in 1977 and 1978 when he completed the unexpired term of former Gov. Wendell Anderson, says Minnesota is in far better shape now than it was when he returned to the office in 1983. ``We are without doubt the No. 1 state in the nation,'' Perpich said during a televised debate with Hatch last week. ``There isn't a state that's better than we are. In 1983, we couldn't compete with South Dakota. Today, we're beating the world.'' Perpich also points to his experience as a plus in the event of a recession brought on by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``We are ready for the oil crisis if it should happen,'' he said. ``We are prepared to ensure that all Minnesotans will have fuel to heat their homes, run their businesses and carry on with their lives. We are also ready if the economy suffers. The state budget reserve will allow us to maintain programs for the people of Minnesota. Our strong and diverse economy will protect people's jobs.'' Perpich, with a boost from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's one-day visit to Minnesota in June after the summit, took his party's endorsement from Hatch, who served as Perpich's commerce commissioner from 1983 through 1989. But the governor's June achievements did not significantly improve his standing in public opinion polls, which continued to show his approval rating at a near-record low. Perpich's summer was marred by developments involving two once-close political associates: ex-Midwest Federal Savings and Loan Chairman Harold Greenwood Jr., who was indicted in connection with the S&L's demise; and former Greater Minnesota Corp. President Terry Montgomery, the governor's ex-chief of staff who faces allegations of sexual harassment and misuse of public funds. Hatch, 41, says Perpich has been distracted lately. He cites the Montgomery and Greenwood affairs and Perpich's disputes with the news media earlier this year over his lifestyle, which led the incumbent to propose selling the governor's mansion and giving up his Lincoln Town Car and driver. ``After eight years, past mistakes and personal vanities become the focus of an administration,'' Hatch said. ``Too many barnacles attach to the ship of state and it simply won't steer straight.'' Providing access to affordable health care for all Minnesotans has been a major focus of Hatch's campaign, and it is the only issue that has sparked a public dispute between the camps. Hatch has called health care policy in the state a scandal, and Perpich has accused Hatch of distorting his record on the issue. The candidates hold similar views on many other issues, with the major exception being abortion. Perpich describes himself as anti-abortion and has said he would sign legislation that would outlaw most abortions in the state. Hatch, who supports legalized abortion, has pointed out the difference in campaign ads, but neither campaign has dwelled on the issue. Perpich and Hatch each was supported by 46 percent of DFLers likely to vote in the primary, according to a Star Tribune-KSTP Minnesota Poll conducted by telephone from Aug. 12-20 among 900 adults. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.3 percentage points. In the Independent-Republican race, the Minnesota Poll found Carlson, 55, with a commanding lead over Grunseth, 44, and former federal prosecutor Doug Kelley, 43, who once served as Sen. Dave Durenberger's chief of staff. Carlson was supported by 46 percent of Republicans likely to vote in the primary, while Grunseth had the support of 24 percent and Kelley of 8 percent. Party leaders have come to Grunseth's aid, claiming Carlson is too liberal for rank-and-file Republicans on the issues of abortion and gun control. Carlson supports legalized abortion and voted for the state's gun control law as a legislator in the 1970s. Grunseth opposes abortion and supports a state constitutional amendment guaranteeing the right to bear arms.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Kill Leader of Peasant Self-Defense Group
DOC.TEXT: Shining Path rebels shot to death the leader of a peasant self-defense group in the central highlands hours after fatally slashing the throat of a teen-ager the nearby provincial capital, police say. Police said Ruso Huamani Alarcon, 40, was machine-gunned to death in a field near his home in Satipo, a rural community about 65 miles northeast of the provincial capital of Huancayo. Huamani Alarcon was the founder of a local self-defense peasant militia that had some 200 members. The group was formed five months ago and is one of many peasant militias organized by the government to combat the Maoist-inspired Shining Path. The peasants are often armed only with machetes, pikes and homemade weapons. On Sunday night, a band of Shining Path rebels forced 17-year-old Gabriel Jesus Gonzalez Orellana from his Huancayo home, beat him and slashed his throat, police said. His body was found with a sign that read `This is how we eliminate all criminals who use the party name to rob. Long live the people's war. Long live the people's committees.'' Nearly 20,000 people have died in political violence since the Shining Path took up arms in Ayacucho in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Now, Muscovites Even Have to Line Up for Bread
LaserPhoto MOSB7
DOC.TEXT: Bread, one of the few foods Soviet consumers have been able to obtain easily, is now in short supply in Moscow for the first time since the early 1960s. Despite a record grain harvest this year, many of Moscow's bread stores were empty on Monday, and there were long lines at others. Some irate consumers blamed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic reforms. ``That's perestroika _ we're not moving forward, we're going backward,'' said Viktor Lyubeznov, a 52-year-old electrician who went to four Moscow bread stores before finding a loaf. ``Now we think freely, we speak freely, but the economic situation is more severe than ever,'' said Irina Samoruppa, 65. Russians have long been accustomed to shortages of fresh vegetables, fruits and meat. They have no microwave foods, and no 24-hour convenience stores. But heavy Russian bread, baked in central factories and sold at subsidized prices, has always been fresh and plentiful. The last time people remember long bread lines was under former Premier Nikita Khrushchev, who was ousted in 1964. If the shortage continues, it will be especially hard on retirees. Some receive pensions of just 30 to 60 rubles ($48 to $96) a month and survive largely on bread, which costs just 15 to 25 kopecks a kilogram (11 to 18 cents a pound). The newspapers Moskovskaya Pravda and Izvestia blamed the shortage on Moscow's bakeries, which they said were unable to keep up with the sudden rise in demand when residents returned from their traditional August vacations. Izvestia said the bottleneck was not the harvest, but Moscow's central bread bakeries, which have changed little since the 1950s, when the population was about half the current 8.8 million. Inside Moscow's Bread Store No. 150, tempers flared Monday as customers accused saleswomen of saving the last few loaves of white bread for themselves. ``Look, comrades, they have more left back there, they just won't sell it,'' one woman cried. ``You don't know what you're talking about, so just be quiet,'' answered a husky saleswoman in a white apron. Outside, along busy Kutuzovsky Prospekt, customers gathered in clusters to commiserate. ``Never in my life have I ever had to search for bread before,'' said Anatoly Znamensky, a 66-year-old retired taxi driver. ``Vegetables, fruit, cheese, butter, meat _ they appear and disappear. But with bread there was never a problem, until now.'' The lack of bread comes on the heels of a summer-long shortage of tobacco that has led to street demonstrations in Moscow and Leningrad, strikes in other Russian cities and a riot in a Ural Mountains city. In addition, gasoline has become hard to find. Hard cheese has virtually disappeared from stores in Moscow. And as school reopened, shelves were bare of the notebooks children are required to use in class. Of all the shortages, however, bread is potentially the most politically troubling, if only because of its historical symbolism. When Lenin returned from exile to lead the revolution in 1917, he promised Communism would bring ``Peace, Land and Bread.''

DOC.HEAD: Electoral Tribunal Rejects Former Dictator's Appeal
DOC.TEXT: Former dictator Jose Efrain Rios Montt has lost another round in his campaign to defy a constitutional ban and run for president. The Supreme Electoral Tribunal, a council that is the highest electoral authority, on Monday rejected Rios Montt's appeal of its refusal last week to allow him to run in Nov. 11 elections. He still can take the case to the Supreme Court and the Court of Constitutionality. In a non-binding opinion last year, the Supreme Court said the constitution prohibited him from running. The 1986 constitution prohibits from running for president or vice president anyone who has held power as a result of a coup, armed revolution or any other action that violated the constitution. Rios Montt, a retired army general, held power for about 16 months after a March 1982 military coup. The military ousted him in an August 1983 coup that installed Gen. Oscar Humberto Mejia Victores. Backed by three conservative political parties, Rios Montt tried to register as a candidate despite the ban, was refused, and began the series of appeals. The deadline for registration is Sept. 12. Rios Montt presided over an army anti-guerrilla campaign fraught with human rights abuses and had 15 convicted leftists executed by firing squad, some of them during a visit by Pope John Paul II. He is seen as a law-and-order candidate and his strong showing in early polls was attributed to the country's increasing crime. President Vinicio Cerezo, whose four-year term expires Jan. 14, cannot run for re-election.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Delegations Seeking Foreign Aid for Gulf Operations
DOC.NOTE: EDS: PARIS precede unlikely for PMS
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is sending two high-level delegations on a global search for billions of dollars to support the economic and military campaign against Iraq. But given the puny response before the missions even left, some observers wondered whether getting the allies to contribute money will prove almost as tough as persuading Iraq's Saddam Hussein to leave Kuwait. To emphasize the importance of the mission, Bush selected two of his closest Cabinet advisers, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, to head the delegations. Brady was leaving today for Paris and meetings with top French officials in a globe-trotting trip that in four days also will take him to London, Seoul, South Korea; and Tokyo. Baker was expected to leave later this week for a whirlwind tour of oil-rich Middle Eastern countries, with later stops planned in West Germany and Italy. The administration has a lot riding on the Baker and Brady plate-passing campaign. Bush hopes to quiet complaints in Congress that rich allies such as Japan and West Germany, who are more dependent on Persian Gulf oil than the United States, are not shouldering their fair share of the burden. Even more importantly, the administration hopes the Baker and Brady trips will provide a dramatic boost to stiffen the resolve of countries to support the trade embargo against Iraq. The administration has not released a figure of how much in financial support it wants, but published reports have put the amount at around $25 billion in the first year. One proposal reviewed by the National Security Council carried a $23 billion price tag, with $10 billion earmarked to ease the financial pain of supporting the embargo for such countries as Egypt, Turkey and Jordan. The rest of the money would go to support the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf region. So far, however, the amount of assistance being offered is far below that level. The administration is worried that without a substantial pool of economic assistance, countries will begin cheating on the trade embargo, thus jeopardizing the main tool that Bush hopes to use to force Iraq out of Kuwait. The president's effort has raised questions about the propriety of a global call for donations to support the U.S. military, with critics charging that it leaves the appearance that American soldiers are up for hire. ``I don't want to leave any impression in the world that we pay for our soldiers and our sailors if we send them into another part of the world only through another country's money,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt. ``This is not a (for) rent military. It's not a mercenary force.'' Leahy said a better approach to take would be to boost taxes if necessary to pay for the gulf buildup. Bush has rejected suggestions that putting pressure on the allies for money to support the U.S. military was improper, and he has received support from other members of Congress who said the allies should be doing more. ``The Japanese have a hell of a stake in this and they ought to pay a hell of a share,'' said Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J. Still, private analysts saw the pledge-seeking missions as a stark reminder of where America's global fortunes now stand. As the world's largest debtor nation, the United States lacks the economic wherewithal to go it alone. ``We are no longer the economic superpower we used to be,'' said Lawrence Chimerine of the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington research organization. ``Our changing role in the world economy is clearly in evidence here.'' In launching the burden-sharing initiative last week, Bush maintained that the ``shape of the post-Cold War world'' was at stake in the gulf crisis. Some analysts agreed. C. Fred Bergsten, a former Treasury Department official in the Carter administration, said Bush's effort could well serve as a prototype for future global cooperation in which the U.S. military would stand ready to preserve peace with financial backing from other countries. ``Some Americans are not going to like that because it sounds like we are mercenaries,'' said Bergsten, who now heads the Institute for International Economics. ``But the fact is that the world is an insecure place and we have the military capability to make a difference.''

DOC.HEAD: Movement of Commodities Said Fairly Normal Despite Mideast Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Rail and barge movements of farm commodities into market channels have been fairly normal this year and should continue in good shape through this fall's big harvest season, an Agriculture Department report says. The Mideast crisis is driving up oil prices, and analyst T.Q. Hutchinson of the department's Economic Research Service said that probably will boost transportation costs in the coming months. ``But, because railroads often hold significant inventories of diesel fuel and obtain fuel under long-term contracts, their costs are partly shielded from short-term fluctuations in fuel prices,'' he said. Rail rates have increased only slightly, reflecting declining railroad operating costs over the past 12 months, adjusted for productivity increases, Hutchinson said. For the third quarter of 1990, the Interstate Commerce Commission has projected costs adjusted for productivity to be down 1 percent from the second quarter. River barge operators will try to pass on higher fuel costs, but competitive pressures may dampen attempts to raise rates. Writing in the September issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine, Hutchinson said the nation's transportation services are expected to be adequate for the remainder of the year. ``However, projected low water flows from the Missouri River mean that navigation will be difficult on the Mississippi River between St. Louis and Memphis this fall,'' he said. Streamflow throughout the huge Mississippi and Missouri watersheds plummeted last year in the aftermath of the 1988 drought and its lingering effects in the northern Great Plains. The Army Corps of Engineers has announced that the Missouri River will be closed for navigation beginning Nov. 1, the same as last year. That will boost the cost of grain marketing for companies that usually depend on Missouri, but it will ``not markedly cramp'' the distribution system's ability to handle demand, Hutchinson said. Looking at operations earlier this year, Hutchinson said the Mississippi River system ``returned to its dominant role in transporting feed grains for export.'' In the first six months of 1990, he said, corn accounted for 77 percent of the downstream traffic on the Mississippi, and soybeans 13 percent. May shipments were a 10-year high for the month. Mississippi water levels were high in the spring, with March readings at St. Louis averaging 138 percent above a year earlier and 13 percent above the month's 44-year average. By July, there was a substantial lowering to 18.6 feet, although the long-term average at St. Louis for July is only 13.4 feet, Hutchinson said. The July 1989 average reading was 1.7 feet. ``Water levels are expected to fall for the remainder of the year,'' the analyst wrote. ``Even so, towboat captains have become experienced with low water conditions, and the new Melvin Price lock and dam complex near Alton, Ill., is expected to greatly reduce the number and length of backups that characterized the past two seasons.'' Hutchinson said that as navigation improved, barge rates to New Orleans dropped from their peaks last December of $12.15 per ton at Peoria, Ill., and $7.05 at St. Louis. By March, those averaged $6.43 from Peoria and $4.92 from St. Louis. ``But in April, rates rose sharply in response to a 28 percent increase in grain volume,'' he said. ``At Peoria, rates advanced 25 percent to $8.06 per ton, and at St. Louis the high was only slightly less, 23 percent, to $6.04 per ton.'' Hutchinson said barge rates on the Illinois and Mississippi waterways declined in May and June and that further reductions occurred in July, according to preliminary indications. Although this year's barge situation has improved, the long-run prospects for navigation on the Mississippi are less optimistic. Hutchinson said that in the 1988 drought year, 60 percent to 80 percent of the total water flow at St. Louis came from the Missouri River. And between 40 percent and 60 percent of the flow came from the Missouri River reservoir system in Montana and the Dakotas. The figures for 1989 are not yet available, he said, but the percentages are believed to be about the same as for 1988. ``Normally, runoff, chiefly from snowmelt, would add 25 million acre-feet of water to the reservoirs each year,'' Hutchinson said. ``But from 1987 to 1989, only 12.5 million to 21.3 million were added annually.'' The forecast for 1990 was 20.5 million acre-feet of runoff for the reservoirs, but Hutchinson said the actual runoff apparently will be somewhat less than that. ``The Corps of Engineers estimates that it will take six years of normal runoff to raise the Missouri River reservoirs to full capacity,'' he said. In June, heavy rains raised the Missouri's level at Kansas City to nearly 20 feet, up 300 percent from a year earlier. But at Sioux City, Iowa, levels in June averaged 16.6 feet, down about one foot from June 1989. Hutchinson said the Corps of Engineers decided to terminate the navigation season on Nov. 1 and reduce the flow of water to about 82 percent of normal, suggesting that water levels will plummet in November. Last November, the river's level at Sioux City averaged 10 feet at the flood gauge, a six-foot drop from October, he said. It seems probable that the flow from the Missouri into the Mississippi this year will be no more _ and probably less _ than in 1989. ``Thus, navigation conditions on the Mississippi between St. Louis and Cairo, Ill., should remain adequate through the summer but could deteriorate early in the fall,'' Hutchinson said. ``Low water might be encountered well before the winter freeze.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Official to Appeal for Famine Relief
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. aid official is flying to Angola this week, hoping to win approval for emergency relief for tens of thousands of people facing starvation because of drought and warfare. The leftist Angolan government has rejected proposals for a cross-border assistance program because of concern that the supplies could contain U.S. weapons for anti-communist rebels. Andrew Natsios, director of the Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance, is expected to arrive in the Angolan capital of Luanda later this week to discuss the issue with government officials. The office is an arm of the U.S. Agency for International Development. Natsios also plans to visit the affected areas, which cover a broad stretch of territory along in the southern part of the country and encompasses both government- and rebel-held zones. Officials believe the potential for a catastrophic famine probably is greater in southern Angola than in any other region of Africa. But the Angolan government's hard-line stance reflects a wariness that the United States, which has been arming the UNITA rebels since 1986, may use a cross-border relief operation to run guns to the rebels. The most likely headquarters for a relief program are neighboring Botswana and Namibia. The Bush administration derided Angola's concerns as ``absolutely ridiculous'' and said any such program would be carried out by a trusted charitable agency, such as the International Committee of the Red Cross. Over the past several weeks, U.S. and United Nations emissaries have failed to convince Angolan authorities to show more flexibility. The famine area has been afflicted both by drought and by prolonged fighting that resulted from a government offensive earlier this year. The administration is prepared to be the major contributor if the Angolan government agrees to an international relief effort, officials said. Angola has been a sore point in East-West relations for years. While the United States has been supplying the rebels, the Soviet Union and Cuba have provided generous backing for the government. Cuba once had 50,000 troops in Angola but has begun a phased withdrawal that is expected to be completed next year. One measure of the mistrust between the Angolan government and UNITA was the breakdown of peace talks last week in Lisbon, Portugal. The negotiations collapsed after government negotiators refused a rebel demand for formal political recognition in advance of any cease-fire agreement. ``This inflexible demand was designed intentionally to scuttle cease-fire negotiations,'' said Manuel Pedro Pacavira, Angola's U.N. ambassador. Angolan authorities contend that the rebels sabotaged the talks in order to win congressional approval for additional U.S. military aid. UNITA President Jonas Savimbi said he was surprised and disappointed that Angolan officials were not prepared to sign an agreement that would bring ``peace and democracy'' to Angola. ``As this was the purpose of this round of talks, their behavior raises doubts about the sincerity of their intentions,'' Savimbi said.

DOC.HEAD: Law Enforcement Becomes Personal for Prosecutor, Sheriff
DOC.TEXT: The prosecutor around here spends weekdays putting people in jail and weekends behind bars himself. The sheriff, meanwhile, has lost his license for driving drunk. Law enforcement has become personal for the top cops in Wyoming County, situated in the coal country of southwestern West Virginia. In Pineville, the county seat that is home to 1,100 of the county's 36,000 residents, nearly everyone knows everyone else, so the legal woes of Prosecutor Paul ``Butch'' Goode and Sheriff Jim Bolt keep tongues wagging. ``My gut feeling is that most people don't like what they hear,'' court clerk Jack Lambert said, calling the situation an embarrassment. At the Pineville Restaurant across from the courthouse, owner Bill Adams disagreed. ``I've known the Bolt family for years. His father was sheriff. His father was chief of police. Him and his brother were raised here. They're good people,'' Adams said. ``Butch Goode _ he was raised within 100 yards of my house. I want to emphasize none of these people are crooks and I still have respect for both of them.'' Goode in May was placed on five years' probation and ordered to serve 12 weekends in jail after he was convicted on federal charges of failing to file tax returns promptly. The charges, for 1982-85, were misdemeanors. Bolt was convicted in state court in June of driving under the influence of alcohol, another misdemeanor. His license was revoked. He faces sentencing Sept. 24. Under state law, misdemeanor convictions do not disqualify public officials from holding office. Bolt and Goode were elected and their terms run through 1992. Goode serves weekends in the Taylor County Jail about 200 miles to the north. He also must pay $49,949 in back taxes and a $10,000 fine. A state Bar Association review that could result in his disbarment is in its early stages. Goode, 52, did not return a call for comment. He said previously that prosecutors singled him out because of his office, not because of the severity of his crimes. Bolt, 37, was arrested in Beckley after he was spotted driving erratically in 1988. A test showed his blood-alcohol level at 0.18 percent, nearly twice the legal limit of 0.10 percent. At his trial, he contended that an intestinal disorder caused him to burp, producing a false reading from a Breathalyzer. He said he hasn't decided whether to appeal. Sitting in his office, Bolt pointed out that he was elected in 1988, after his arrest, and said that he is tired of the attention it has attracted. ``From the press you'd think this was Watergate,'' he said. Bolt can regain his license after he completes a driver training course but he said the lack of a license hasn't hampered his ability to do his job, which includes tax collection. ``Most of my work is done right here in the office or in the treasurer's office,'' he said. ``If I need to go out on patrol, I'll ride with one of the deputies.'' He said that people who supported him before the arrest continue to support him, but that opponents are quick to conclude, ``He ought to have his toes cut off and be hung up by his thumbs.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Spy Satellites Keep Tabs On Saddam
AN AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: U.S. strategists look down every day on Iraq and Kuwait from a squadron of satellites that can spot tank tracks in the desert, listen in on Iraqi military commanders and give B-52 bombers pinpoint accuracy. The round-the-clock data relayed by at least 12 reconnaissance, electronic intelligence, early-warning, meteorological and navigation satellites orbiting high above the Persian Gulf could be decisive if the shooting starts in the confrontation with Saddam Hussein. ``It gives the Americans an astonishing technological edge over the Iraqis, who must find it disconcerting to know they're being watched 24 hours a day like that,'' said Don Kerr of London's International Institute for Strategic Studies. There is at least one electronic intelligence satellite, probably a shuttle-deployed Magnum, that can intercept telephone and radio communications in Iraq and Kuwait, including those from Saddam Hussein's headquarters to his field commanders and on down to inter-unit contacts. Analysts estimate that several smaller White Cloud electronic intelligence, or ELINT, satellites put into orbit by Titan missiles, are being used over Iraq and Kuwait. Their signals are relayed through ground stations to Britain's top-secret General Communications Headquarters in Cheltenham, southwest England, known as the ``Puzzle Palace,'' which is linked to the U.S. National Security Agency in Maryland. ``The capabilities are enormous,'' Kerr said in a telephone interview. As well as satellites, the Americans have access to data garnered by British and Israeli electronic surveillance operations in the Middle East. The British have sophisticated signals intelligence, or SIGINT, facilities on Cyprus in the eastern Mediterranean that intercept radio and telephone traffic around the Middle East. They funnel data back to Cheltenham headquarters for relay to the National Security Agency. All this winds up at the U.S. military headquarters now established in Saudi Arabia to provide an hour-by-hour intelligence picture for Gen. Norman Schwartzkopf, commander of the ever-expanding U.S. military force confronting Saddam's legions. Polar-orbiting ``Keyhole'' KH-11 high-resolution, optical-imaging reconnaissance satellites gave the Americans the first evidence of Iraqi military moves toward Kuwait in late July, several days before the Aug. 2 invasion. Kerr said there is at least one KH-11 photo satellite orbiting as low as 180 miles over the northern Persian Gulf region. It makes several passes a day. A second satellite, believed to be a more advanced KH-12, is also reported to be in operation. These satellites carry 12-foot-long cameras with enormous focal length that Kerr said can take photos ``that provide great detail ... they can count tanks, tents and even people on the ground.'' The images are processed and stored on board as digital signals that are relayed to ground stations in the Pacific and Greenland for relay to Washington. ``The military satellite situation isn't as good as it might have been,'' Kerr said. ``One KH-12 launched by the space shuttle last year broke up in orbit.'' The Americans have a Lacrosse radar-imaging satellite at an altitude of 495 miles, launched by a space shuttle in December 1988. Its radar can produce data in all weather, although its image resolution is not as good as that of the optical-imaging systems. There are believed to be at least six communications satellites operating in support of U.S. forces in the region that give Schwarzkopf direct links to the Pentagon and the White House. ``Units in the field can talk to the Pentagon if they need to,'' Kerr noted. ``And these links are extremely difficult to jam.'' There are Navstar navigational satellites in 12,400-mile-high orbits that are used by U.S. warships to provide pinpoint positioning. Kerr noted that, providing troops have equipment to hook into these systems, ``they're perfect for travelling across the desert, where navigation is difficult because of the lack of topographical features.'' The high-flying B-52 bombers based on the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia, 2,100 miles east of the crisis zone, could be equipped with Navstar links. That would in theory allow them to dump their 30-ton bombloads with great accuracy, although they were used in the Vietnam War to carpet-bomb targets. Kerr said Navstar could give B-52 navigators the capability to ``know their position to within 10 meters (33 feet) ... a great asset in `blind bombing,' which is probably a misnomer now.'' The Americans also have several early-warning satellites that can detect missile launches. Analysts say at least one or two of these systems, in geostationary orbit, are being used to keep watch on Iraq's missile batteries. All these satellites produce a flood of photos and data around the clock that has to be processed before it can be useful. Kerr noted that the workload for U.S. analysts in Washington ``must be enormous. They must be working flat out to sift through this data and analyze it to get as close to real-time intelligence as they can.

DOC.HEAD: Group Critical of Child Care Centers, Homes
DOC.TEXT: The Children's Defense Fund says lax day-care laws in too many states amount to an inexcusable failure to protect the health and safety of the nation's youngsters. A report issued Monday by the private organization urged support for legislation pending in Congress that would provide $1.75 billion in federal funds for child care, require states to develop minimum requirements, expand tax credits for low-income working families, and guarantee parents the right to make unannounced visits. The fund said its national survey of child-care centers and day-care homes found that 13 states fail to require that children in day care be immunized against childhood diseases and 22 states do not require periodic fire drills. Thirty states do not insist that children 18 months and older in licensed child-care centers receive vaccine to protect them from meningitis, and 24 states fail to require such centers to have energy-absorbing surfaces as a safety feature beneath swings, slides and structures on which children climb. The report said four states _ Connecticut, Idaho, Indiana and South Carolina _ failed to require that even one of those standards be met. It said 19 states allow child-care centers to operate with five or more infants per adult, although experts cited by the fund say one person should care for no more than three or four. Thirteen states, it said, allow one person to care for five or more infants or toddlers in family day care. Georgia and North Carolina permit one person in a child-care center to care for up to seven infants, while South Carolina allows eight and Idaho sets the limit at 12, the report said. Thirty-three states allow one person to care for more than 10 4-year-olds. The limit is 18 in Georgia and 20 in Alabama, Florida, North Carolina, South Carolina and Texas, the fund said. The report said more than 6 million children, including more than 2 million who are younger than 3, spend part or all of their day in out-of-home child care. About half of those children are cared for by people providing family day care in their own homes. Most of those children are cared for in homes serving less than six youngsters, the report said. However, it said 22 states exempt family day-care homes from regulation, including inspections, if they care for five or fewer unrelated youngsters. Twenty-nine states fully or partially exempt child-care programs operated by public schools from regulation.
