Although about one-third of child-care centers are operated by religious institutions, 13 states fully or partially exempt such programs from licensing. In 29 states, parents do not have the unqualified right to visit their child's family day-care home unannounced, the report said. That denies parents ``the most meaningful opportunity to detect potential threats to their child's health and safety, or to monitor the quality of care their child receives,'' the fund said. Thirty-five states do not require any type of training for staff in family day-care homes, and 32 do not require specific levels of formal training for teachers in child-care centers, the fund said. It said only three states _ Kentucky, Minnesota and Wisconsin _ require specific levels of pre-service and in-service training for child-care teachers and family day home providers and specify the level of training that providers must receive in each area.

DOC.HEAD: School Officials Tell Disabled Boy: `No Dog in Class'
LaserPhoto PX1
DOC.TEXT: Eleven-year-old Michael Guadiello Jr., who uses a wheelchair because of muscular dystrophy, calls a collie named Ashley his ``independence dog'' and wants it to help at school. Administrators say no canines on campus. Michael has little use of his arms and legs. Ashley is a service dog trained to help with things like opening doors, carrying packages and retrieving dropped objects. The boy had attended special education classes at a school in the Rose Tree Media School District, where the dog was barred by administrators after Michael obtained it in April. District lawyer John Steuerwald said officials objected because Michael's ``educational program did not call for a dog'' and because there were no provisions for the animal's care. The district has no other student with a dog. Complicating the fight to get Ashley admitted to the classroom was a decision by school officials that Michael should be ``mainstreamed,'' or attend class with non-disabled students in his home district of Chichester. The Guadiello family opposes that move. The boy's parents say he needs the special education resources available only at Rose Tree. In addition, the Chichester school is not equipped for wheelchair users. On Friday, the state Department of Education issued a temporary ruling ordering Michael's mainstreaming into Chichester's middle school. Class begins Wednesday. State officials said the school must provide access to the building through such items as wheelchair ramps and offer trained people to help Michael twice a day in using the bathroom. Michael said he was ``disgusted'' that officials think they can put his physical needs on a schedule. He said his ``independence dog'' is all he needs. The boy's father and his wife, Jane, say the decision illegally discriminates against their son. They say that if he were blind, the school would not have barred a guide dog. The family is fighting the dog ban on another level because state law prohibits discriminating against handicapped people who use guide or service animals, and specifically outlaws it in public schools, said the Guadiellos' lawyer, Kyle Burch. The Pennsylvania Human Relations Commission has tried to settle the dispute. The case brought before it is pending and wasn't affected by the state schools ruling, which stands until a hearing Sept. 10. Ashley was trained for almost 19 months at a cost of $7,229, according to Jean King of Independence Dogs of Chadds Ford, which then sells the dogs for $150 to handicapped people like Michael. Mrs. Guadiello said she was disappointed with the state schools ruling and would check Chichester's compliance with the order before allowing Michael to attend. The collie frees Michael from relying on friends and family members for help, his mother said. It is as necessary as Michael's wheelchair and is not a pet, she said. That role is shared by the family terrier and a cat. ``I slept on the floor of Michael's room for 10 years because he was afraid he wouldn't be able to get out on his own if there was a fire,'' said Mrs. Guadiello, as Ashley rescued a dropped pencil for her son. ``But with Ashley here, I'm back in my own room.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Fed Dominated by White Men
DOC.TEXT: A study commissioned by the chairman of the House Banking Committee found that the Federal Reserve has only a handful of women or minorities serving in top policy-making jobs. Despite a 1977 law requiring diversity of membership and public participation on the Fed boards, consumers, labor unions, small business executives and farmers have little representation, according to the committee staff report ordered by Rep. Henry B. Gonzales, D-Texas. Two-thirds of the board of directors for each of the 12 regional Fed banks are elected by commercial banks in each area that belongs to the Fed system. There are only three women among the 72 directors of regional Fed banks selected by commercial bankers in each region and all but two of the 72 are white, the House survey reported. There is one black and one Asian American. There are no representatives of consumer groups or labor organizations among the 72 bank-elected directors. Seventy-seven percent of those directors are either current or former commercial bankers, the report said. The other one-third of the directors are appointed by the seven-member Federal Reserve Board. The report said the Fed, whose members are appointed by the president, has a disappointing record on the question of diversity. Current Fed Governor Martha Seger is only the second woman to serve on the Fed board and there are no minorities. The 36 regional board members appointed by the Fed board are still heavily drawn from the ranks of white males with connections to banking or big business, the report said. Seventy-seven percent of the Fed board's appointments are white and 83 percent are male. Half the Fed's appointments are former bankers, while none comes from consumer organizations or labor unions, the study said. ``Most of the Federal Reserve directors are drawn from the ranks of big business and banking,'' Gonzalez said in a statement. ``You have to question whether people working in the highfalutin world of high finance and business can really understand the impact higher interest rates have on the average workers' purchasing power and job security.'' Federal Reserve spokesman Bob Moore said officials at the central bank had not received the House report and would have no comment until they had a chance to review it. Gonzalez, D-Texas, has been a longtime critic of the Federal Reserve, but his elevation to committee chairman last year has given him a powerful forum from which to direct his attack. The Fed's 12 regional banks are in Boston; New York; Philadelphia; Cleveland; Richmond, Va.; Atlanta; Chicago; St. Louis; Minneapolis; Kansas City; Dallas and San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis View War With Bravado, Fatalism
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqis hardened by eight years of war with Iran seem almost casual about the formidable buildup of U.S. firepower across the border in Saudi Arabia. There is some concern about the embargo on trade with Iraq ordered by the United Nations after Baghdad seized Kuwait, and some suspicions about the causes of the crisis. But there is no smell of war along the noisy, bustling avenues of this ancient capital. Instead, Iraqis willing to talk with Western reporters view the threat of war with a mixture of bravado and Arab fatalism. ``What can I do about it?'' shrugged Mahdi Kathom, a 30-year-old vegetable vendor in central Baghdad. ``If it happens, it is because God lets it happen. There is nothing to do about it.'' ``God willing, our president will solve this,'' said one middle-aged woman who declined to give her name. ``Saddam Hussein is a strong and wise man.'' Many Iraqis question the motives of President Bush in sending troops and warplanes to Saudi Arabia. But a few, speaking privately in this rigidly controlled society, say they are suspicious about their own leader and his reasons for provoking the crisis. Some say Saddam underestimated the U.S. reaction and a few others voice suspicions that he triggered the crisis partly to challenge the Americans and raise his standing in the Arab world. For eight years, Saddam told his people they were fighting Iran for control over the Shatt al-Arab waterway that spills into the northern Persian Gulf. Then, on Aug. 12, just 10 days after the invasion of Kuwait, Saddam acknowledged Iran's claim to shared sovereignty over the waterway that some Iraqis believe they bought with the blood of their loved ones. Saddam's peace overture secured his vulnerable eastern border, freeing troops to confront the U.S. buildup. Some Iraqis say they now wonder why Saddam gave in on the waterway and why he chose to invade Kuwait. But while a few quietly mumble their suspicions, Iraqis who spoke openly defended the invasion and occupation of the country they have long considered a part of Iraq, wrongfully separated from the motherland by British colonial rulers. ``Forget Kuwait, it is a dream. There is no Kuwait,'' said one Baghdad taxi driver. A few Iraqis said they have heard frightening assessments of American military might on foreign radio broadcasts by the British Broadcasting Corp. and Voice of America. But the state-controlled press has focused on dissent in the West against the sanctions and the troop buildup. The Iraqi press also has disparaged the ability of U.S. troops to fight against battle-hardened Iraqis in the desert. Near the center of Baghdad stands the Monument of Saddam's Qaddissiya Martyrs, a tribute to the dead of the Iran-Iraq war, named after Babylon's victory over the Persians in 600 B.C. The marble monument covered with aqua tiles is in the form of two halves of an Islamic dome. It is split to symbolize the Islamic tradition that the dome of the mosque opens to allow martyrs to ascend to heaven. It is one of the many military monuments in Baghdad. Another is made from the wreckage of an Iranian war plane shot down over the city. Madria Nasser Abdul Al-Mishadani, a 40-year-old woman walking near the Qaddissiya monument, said Iraqi women are not afraid their loved ones will be killed in another war. ``The women are not afraid. Aren't we Iraqis? Why should we be scared?'' she asked. ``Why is the United States so upset over the invasion of Kuwait?'' ``The United States had less right to go into Panama than we had to go into Kuwait,'' she added. ``We have tried to get Kuwait back for 30 years.'' A man walking near the monument, 40-year-old Salem Kalaf, said that during the war with Iran people got used to hardships such as the reduced consumption that the U.N. trade embargo might bring again. ``We know about war. We saw missiles hit our homes and our stores. And we lived through that,'' he said. The government indicated it will start rationing the sale of some basic foods in the next few days. But it insisted the measure was a precaution because of the sanctions and not a response to shortages. Some lines have already formed outside bakeries for bread. But while some say privately they are worried about shortages, most Iraqis like Kalaf say publicly they are prepared to endure more hardships. ``I am not afraid. Our country is strong and we can handle this,'' said Mohammed Hussein, a 47-year-old Baghdad resident, who said two of his sons were with the army in Kuwait. ``I want to tell the American people that their president is not listening to us. We want peace,'' said Ahmed Abdallah, a 54-year-old Baghdad resident. ``It appears that most people do not want a war with Iraq. If America is a democratic country, then Bush should listen to what the people are saying.''

DOC.HEAD: First Men in 62 Years Start Class At Colby-Sawyer College
LaserPhoto CR1
DOC.TEXT: Men join the student body at tiny Colby-Sawyer College today for the first time in more than 60 years. Marches, sit-ins and the seizure of an administration building by protesters ensued after trustees voted 22-1 in April 1989 to open the school to men. But a mood of acceptance prevailed as students arrived for the start of the fall semester at the 525-student college, with many women welcoming their 79 new male classmates. Maria Francesconi, a junior nursing major from Cheshire, Mass., said she accepts the change, although she demonstrated against it last year. ``We all had the summer to adjust,'' she said. ``There's a lot less anger here and a lot more excitement now.'' Freshman Dean Heide of Ringoes, N.J., said he's comfortable at his new school. ``My biggest fear was that we wouldn't be wanted,'' he said. ``But after talking to the girls, I'm not worried.'' Colby-Sawyer President Peggy Stock said money worries made the change necessary. ``Looking 10 years down the road at the number of women we would be able to draw from, we said, `We're in trouble.' '' Stock said. ``It was an emotional decision, but it was the right decision for us.'' Colby-Sawyer, which admitted men from 1837 to 1928, plans to have equal numbers of men and women by 1995. Twenty-nine percent of this year's 240 freshmen are men, and 12 of 40 transfers are male. The school had a 120 percent increase in applicants last year and fund-raising also is up, Stock said. Most alumni and students have accepted the change, she said. She added that 91 percent of students scheduled to return did so, and few left solely because of coeducation. Other schools in similar situations haven't had it so easy. At 1,200-student Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., which became coeducational in 1988, some alumni took the school to court to get back their donations. They said they wouldn't have donated if they had known the school planned to admit men. They won, and 56 shared a $127,300 refund. Last year at Mills College in East Oakland, Calif., students crippled the school with protests and boycotts after trustees voted to admit men as undergraduates. Two weeks later the trustees backed down. Some men said they chose Colby-Sawyer because of its size, academic reputation and picturesque campus about 40 miles from Concord, a short drive from ski areas, lakes and mountains. Dan Hancock of Lancaster said he also wanted to be part of history. ``I wanted to be able to look back in 20 years and know I was part of this, that I helped build it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqis Use Population Shift to Intimidate Kuwaitis
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has poured its citizens into Kuwait to try to intimidate local residents and may settle thousands in the captive nation, Kuwaiti government ministers say. The ministers said Monday that Iraq is continuing to pillage their country but added that civil disobedience and some armed resistance has succeeded in making the Iraqi army uneasy about taking over certain areas. Planning Minister Suleiman al-Muttawa claimed Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has bought whatever support he has in the Arab world. The minister accused Saddam of paying billions of dollars to regional leaders, including Yasser Arafat of the Palestine Liberation Organization and Jordan's King Hussein, to take his side. The comments came as the Cabinet of the Kuwaiti government-in-exile prepared for a series of meetings with top Western officials over the Persian Gulf crisis. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd was expected in this southwestern mountain resort today and is to meet Secretary of State James A. Baker III for talks on Friday. Al-Muttawa said Baker would meet with Kuwait's emir, Sheik Jaber Al-Ahmed Al-Sabah, whose government-in-exile set up headquarters in this city after Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2. The minister said the agenda for the talks was not fixed, but he expected it to center on the multibillion-dollar bill for deploying the massive U.S. force in the region. The Bush administration has indicated it expects contributions from West Germany, Japan and the wealthy oil states of the Persian Gulf. Al-Muttawa said Kuwait would make whatever military efforts it could, but added that its most successful means of combating the Iraqis was a civil disobedience campaign. ``The passive resistance is very effective,'' he said. ``There is no cooperation by the Kuwaiti citizens with the invading forces, which is annoying the Iraqis because they thought their soldiers would be welcomed.'' Al-Muttawa said a Latin American-style guerrilla movement was not possible in his country because it has no back country to shelter a large guerrilla force and no real military tradition. ``This is a flat country where anybody who walks along can be picked up miles away,'' he said. But armed attacks have been useful in dissuading Iraqis from entering residential neighborhoods out of fear they would be shot, he said. The planning minister said Iraq was trying to move some of its citizens into residential areas as part of a psychological warfare campaign to convince Kuwaitis that their country is part of Iraq. He said he doubted Iraqi families would want to move into such a hostile environment. Housing Minister Yahia Fahd said there was some concern that Saddam would eventually move hundreds of thousands of Iraqis into the country, effectively outnumbering the Kuwaiti population. The ministers said 240,000 Kuwaitis had fled to neighboring gulf countries and that tens of thousands more were in other Middle Eastern countries, Europe and North America at the time of the invasion. The total number of Kuwaitis is put at about 600,000, but foreign workers brought the country's population up to 1.7 million. Fahd said Saddam's plan was to hold a referendum after large-scale Iraqi resettlement in Kuwait and then claim the Kuwaiti people wanted to be annexed to Iraq, a move decreed Aug. 6. Information Minister Sheik Jaber Mubarak Al-Sabah said the Iraqis in the past few days had dismantled television broadcast facilities, traffic lights and even street lights and carted them off to Iraq. Al-Muttawa said the government had no estimate of the value of goods stolen from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: At This Course, Almost Every Shot is In the Sand
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mark Tucker's tee shot on the dogleg par 4 third hole plopped down right where he wanted it _ in the sand. The next shot was a tough one _ there was little room behind the green and a shot too long would land out of bounds. But Tucker again was near perfect, dropping the ball just to the left of the green _ in the sand. Welcome to golf desert style, where every shot _ or at least every good shot _ lands in the sand. Even the greens _ the locals call them browns _ are sand, packed hard by rollers and made into a clay-like substance by spraying them with the area's most abundant substance next to sand _ oil. A sign at the first hole warns golfers, ``No Spikes Shoes Allowed On Greens.'' You can't play this course with clubs and balls alone. Every player carries a small square of plastic grass, placing it under the ball after every shot to provide a not-so-lush green surface to hit off. Tucker played a round of golf Monday with a reporter who had spotted the course while flying over it in a helicopter. Most golf courses are tucked into the woods or alongside a lake; this one is between a huge military airbase and rows of oil storage tanks. The ``Rolling Hills Country Club'' is one of the many recreation facilities offered to employees of Saudi Aramco, the huge oil company in the northeast Saudi desert. ``It is something else, isn't it,'' Tucker said during a nine-hole round Monday. The complex has 27 holes, split between the East, West and South courses. These course were built in the 1970s but there has been golf at Aramco since not long after the company was established 50 years ago. There's a driving range, too, and a club where golfers, much like their counterparts back in the states, can grab a burger and beer after a round. Here, however, the beer is the non-alcoholic. Tucker, asked to compare desert golf to the game back home, misses the beer more than the grass. ``It's more fun to drive around in the cart with beer'' says the Michigan native, an Aramco land surveyor who now owns a place in Montana he visits for about a month each year. The wind on the Aramco course is fierce; drives that begin straight can get carried 20 yards or more off target. And in a game in which concentration is said to be the key to success, a screaming F-15 takeoff at the airbase down the hill can be more than a bit unnerving. ``You get used to it,'' said Tucker. About the only elements of this golf course that recall other courses of the world are the sandtraps. But even they are a bit different. When Tucker dropped a shot into a trap short of the green he didn't reach for a wedge. The sandtraps here are circled with asphalt, providing a hardenend, ramp-like lip. So Tucker used his putter, slapping the ball into the slope and up onto the green. The shot was unconventional, but effective. ``That's one of our only in Dhahran shots,'' Tucker said with a grin. ``They take practice.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 24,907.64, down 512.79 points, or 2.02 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Drop, Dollar Up
DOC.TEXT: Share prices declined sharply on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday, while the dollar was moderately higher against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 512.79 points, or 2.02 percent, closing at 24,907.64 points. The index shed 557.94 points Monday. The dollar closed at 144.05 yen, up 0.50 yen from Monday's finish. It opened at 143.80 yen and ranged between 143.73 yen and 144.20 yen. Currency dealers said there was little movement on the exchange market in the absence of major market-affecting news. ``But as a whole the dollar is being bought back, especially against European currencies,'' said Masakazu Kimura, a dealer with Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank. Kimura said the trading between the dollar and the European currencies also affected the dollar-yen rate. On the stock market, local news reports that the Ministry of International Trade and Industry would grant oil companies' requests to raise prices because of the Persian Gulf crisis drove share prices down, traders said. But trade minister Kabun Muto told a morning news conference that his ministry will reconsider the decision. ``The market generally remained sagging, due partly to a decline in stock price index futures,'' said a Nomura Securities dealer who spoke on condition of anonymity. Other dealers said the index's slide was promoted on small-lot selling toward the morning close, with many market players taking a wait-and-see position over uncertainties about the Mideast situation.

DOC.HEAD: New Zealand Prime Minister Geoffrey Palmer Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Less than two months before national elections, Prime Minister Geoffrey Palmer resigned today after polls indicated the governing Labor Party would be routed with him at its helm. Labor chose External Relations and Trade Minister Mike Moore to head the government and tackle the daunting task of turning around the party before the Oct. 27 balloting. Palmer took office 13 months ago after defeating Moore in a party vote to replace David Lange as prime minister. The latest polls show the opposition National Party with a 2-to-1 or more lead over Labor, although many voters say they have not made up their minds. Under Labor leadership since 1984, New Zealand has undergone a wide-ranging economic transformation, with many state-owned businesses being sold off. But the electorate is unhappy with the ailing economy: inflation is at 7.6 percent, short-term interest rates at nearly 15 percent and unemployment has reached 7.3 percent. Moore, 41, who in recent months repeatedly denied he would seek to unseat Palmer, told a news conference that New Zealanders wanted a ``new direction'' and that his bid for the leadership ``in no way is a reflection on Mr. Palmer's service to New Zealand.'' Palmer, 48, had denied he would step down as recently as Monday. New Zealand Press Association quoted sources as saying he had support to stay on but that he quit because infighting would have devastated the embattled party. Palmer told reporters he ``may well have had the numbers to remain, but I took the view that to have a leadership contest on a vote would be destructive, it would be divisive, that it was not in the best interests of the collective.'' ``The need for a feeling of unity is paramount at this time, and that feeling of unity will have been restored by my decision,'' he said. Asked if he thought Moore had a greater chance of winning the election, he said: ``I certainly hope that he has.'' Palmer apparently will leave politics altogether. He said he would not seek re-election to Parliament, although he agreed to stay on as environment minister, a non-Cabinet position, through the election. National Party leader Jim Bolger said it was ``quite irrelevant'' who was prime minister going into the election. Many Labor candidates, concerned about Palmer's dwindling popularity hurting their chances for election, have been been running campaign ads without the Labor logo. A Radio New Zealand poll in late July showed the conservative Nationals leading by a 46 percent to 21 percent margin over Labor. However, polls have shown Moore leading all candidates for prime minister and he was the clear choice in a survey of business chief executives. Some political commentators say Labor is in serious danger of losing 20 of the 56 seats it holds in the 97-seat Parliament. The Nationals hold 40 seats in Parliament and the breakaway left-wing New Labor Party has one. The 5-month-old Green Party has been running third in opinion polls. But many voters remained undecided, including many traditional Labor supporters. Opinion polls in some areas have put the undecided vote at 38 percent to 47 percent. Labor took power in 1984, ousting the Nationals. It won re-election in 1987 despite losing some support because of its deregulation policies. Palmer defeated Moore for the prime minister's job after Lange resigned in August 1989 for health reasons. He had undergone heart surgery the year before. Lange's leadership had also been under challenge because of party wrangling over the pace and direction of the former Finance Minister Roger Douglas' program of deregulating the economy. Lange had been one of New Zealand's most popular leaders, particularly earning admiration for his no-nuclear stance in refusing to allow U.S. warships to dock in New Zealand because they would not confirm or deny whether they were carrying nuclear weapons. Both Palmer and Moore represent districts in Christchurch, the largest city on New Zealand's South Island. Moore became the youngest person ever elected to Parliament when he won his first seat in 1972 at age 23. He was ousted in 1975 in Labor's landslide loss, but returned three years later.

DOC.HEAD: Black Protesters Arrested in Atlantic City
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of blacks protesting alleged discrimination blocked a highway into this casino city and threatened to disrupt Saturday's Miss America Pageant. Twenty-three people were arrested. The demonstration Monday on the Atlantic City Expressway delayed thousands of Labor Day travelers on one of the city's busiest days. In meetings with Mayor Jim Whelan last week, the activists had demanded more recreational sites and an end to alleged police brutality. Talks broke off Friday. Among those arrested were the New York City activist the Rev. Al Sharpton and Steve Young, who said they represent The Forgotten Youth of Atlantic City. They promised to shut down the pageant for the first time since it began on the Boardwalk in 1921. ``They might as well close it down,'' said Young, who with Sharpton was charged with inciting to riot. Pageant director Leonard Horn said, ``We intend to proceed as scheduled with all of the events that we have been planning for the past year.'' He cited past protests against the pageant by feminists and striking NBC technicians. The week's events include preliminary contests, a Boardwalk parade Friday and live televised finals Saturday night. The march began in a rundown section a few blocks from the casinos. Chanting to the rap anthem ``Fight The Power,'' the group weaved through the city's ghettos, gathering up supporters in two housing projects. The roughly 250 marchers reached the expressway, where they blocked traffic. Police donned riot gear and shields when eggs and at least one bottle were thrown from a housing project. The crowd marched to the police station, where those arrested were being processed on charges including disorderly conduct and aggravated assault. At least 200 demonstrators waited for two hours for Sharpton's release as police blocked the entrance.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Party Promises Citizens Role in Candidate Selection
DOC.TEXT: The governing party, which has run Mexico for 60 years, has pledged polticial reforms ranging from recognition of churches to citizen participation in the selection of party candidates. ``We have achieved a new democracy,'' Institutional Revolutionary Party president Luis Donaldo Colosio said at a closing speech Monday before 9,000 delegates to the party's three-day 14th National Assembly. The party, known as PRI, has dominated Mexican politics since it was founded in 1929. Its presidential candidates have traditionally been chosen by their predecessors, and only in the past two elections has there been any public discussion on the matter. The government has also refused to legally recognize churches, which may not own land; clergymnen may not vote. Still, anti-clerical laws are widely ignored in this intensely Catholic country and the government has twice played host to Pope John Paul II. In one resolution, the party called for ``separation of religious and political affairs'' and equal treatment of all ``public manifestations of religion.'' But the most important reforms adopted by the assembly dealt with change in the selection of candidates at all levels, giving control over the process to local party organizations. The reforms did not, however, spell out how citizens would participate in candidate selection. The democratic reforms had strong backing from President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who has described such political changes as an essential part of his program to modernize the Mexican economy and political system. Colosio told delegates that the party must adapt to a changing Mexican society and confront the threat of electoral losses. ``From now on, any militant that wants to be a candidate will have to face first the judgement of his fellow citizens,'' Colosio told delegates. In 1988, Salinas won with just over 50 percent of the vote, the smallest margin in party history, and the party suffered its first Senate losses. Leftist parties gained ground in the central part of the country, defeating Salinas in the Federal District and a few states. In 1989, the party lost its first governor's race, conceding victory to the conservative National Action Party in Baja California. The party is preparing for crucial city elections in the state of Mexico, which includes most of the Mexico City suburbs. It is also readying itself for 1991 mid-term congressional elections. In another resolution, membership in the all-powerful Central Committee was cut from 37 to nine, and the influence of party peasant and labor organizations in the committee was reduced. The PRI also appealed to private businessmen to join in the country's efforts at modernization. ``The Mexican entrepreneur,'' the party said, ``must be innovative, take chances and work together with other sectors of society.'' Another reform that brought applause from delegates was a recommendation that ``political trials be instituted for corrupt government officials.'' Outgoing government officials with reputations for corruption have traditionally been exempted from legal action. In the last two administrations, however, several officials have been jailed, the highest of them being the director of the government oil monopoly. Salinas told the delegates he was ``proud to be a member of the new'' party. ``The reforms are not to satisfy our enemies but to create a better society,'' Salinas said. ``Their purpose is to maintain the Mexican Revolution in power; they are changes to win votes democratically; they are changes for victory, not to give away power.''

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Down, Dollar Up in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Continuing pessimism over the Middle East situation pushed prices sharply lower on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today, while the dollar gained against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which fell 557.94 points Monday, shed another 512.79 points, or 2.20 percent, closing at 24,907.64. A light 330 million shares changed hands on the first section, down from the previous day's 360 million shares. Many institutional investors were waiting to see how the Middle East situation would develop, securities dealers said. A series of arbitrage selling, in which traders seek to profit from price gaps between the spot and futures markets, helped accelerate losses in the afternoon, they said. In addition to news reports that crude oil producers would raise prices for Japanese importers, a rumor that fighting between Iraq and U.S.-led multinational forces might flare up within two weeks ``boosted concern'' among investors, said Sachiko Hata, a dealer with Nikko Securities. ``It is a difficult market now,'' Ms. Hata said. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 144.05 yen, up 0.50 yen from Monday's finish. After opening at 143.80 yen, it ranged between 143.73 yen and 144.20 yen. ``The dollar was bought back, mostly for technical reasons, in reaction to yesterday's selling,'' said Masaya Ueno, a dealer with Fuji Bank. Ueno said there were no specific incentives affecting the exchange market. On the bond market, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond edged up to 8.130 percent late today from Monday's close of 8.105 percent. The price slipped to 82.96 points from 83.07. Meanwhile, North Sea Brent crude oil for October delivery was valued at $29.00 a barrel in Tokyo this afternoon, almost unchanged from its closing in London Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Scattered in West; Scorcher Forecast in Southern Plains
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered in the West early today, and a heat wave moved deeper into the nation's mid-section. Elsewhere today, rain fell at Key West, Fla., and in Michigan at Sault Ste. Marie. In the West, there was rain in Salt Lake City and Las Vegas, and thunderstorms were over Casper, Wyo. The heat wave that baked the southern Plains last week was slowly moving eastward into Arkansas and Missouri from southern Kansas and eastern Oklahoma. Temperatures were expected to climb into the 100s in the region. A high-pressure front was keeping temperatures about 15 degrees above normal. Later today, thunderstorms were expected along a cold front extending across Wyoming, Nebraska, Iowa, Minnesota and Wisconsin. Damaging wind with large hail and flooding was possible. Rain also was likely in Florida, Georgia, North Carolina and Tennessee. Muggy weather was expected in the region. The forecast also called for rain in Texas and the southern Rockies. Thunderstorms were likely in the desert Southwest, threatening flooding in the region because of frequent thunderstorms this summer. The nation's high for Monday was 110 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Eight Charged in Subway Slaying of Utah Man Who Tried to Aid Mother
DOC.TEXT: Eight teen-agers accused of stealing to get night club admission money were charged in the subway slaying of a Utah tourist who came to the aid of his mother when she was punched in the face, police said. Five were picked up for questioning at the Roseland Ballroom after the fatal attack Sunday night, Capt. Steve Davis said. The other three were arrested Monday. Killed was Brian Watkins, 22, of Provo, Utah. The former college tennis player was in town with his family for the U.S. Open tournament. He was stabbed once in the chest after intervening when his mother was punched. He collapsed on the subway platform at 53rd Street and Seventh Avenue after starting to chase the fleeing thieves, Davis said. ``Brian jumped in to help me when one of the muggers hit me in the face,'' Karen Watkins said. She was treated for a mouth cut. The slaying reinforced New York's image as a hotbed of urban crime. It was the 18th killing in the city's subways this year. In Watkins' hometown, one homicide was recorded for all of 1989, Provo police records secretary Bobbie Ferguson said. The Watkins family, tennis fans who have visited New York for the past five years to see the U.S. Open, had spent Sunday at the tournament and were on their way to dinner when they were attacked. Their hotel is near the subway station where Watkins was stabbed and the Central Park restaurant they were headed for is located just two subway stops away. Watkins was waiting for a northbound train with his father, Sherwin, his mother, his brother Todd and Todd's wife Michelle, when a group of young men approached, one carrying a knife, another wielding a box cutter. Sherwin Watkins' pants were slashed and thieves took a money clip containing about $200 and some credit cards. One punched Mrs. Watkins in the face. The brothers interceded and one of the men stabbed Watkins, police said. He died later at a nearby hospital. Watkins' father was treated for a leg cut. The dance club is less than a block from the subway station where Watkins was stabbed. Davis said ``most kids who get off at that stop are going to Roseland,'' and that it was ``logical'' to investigate there. Debbie Jaspering, a family friend, said she'd seen the Watkins family at the tennis tournament several days ago, before she returned to Provo. ``They were having a great time,'' Jaspering said. ``They were sitting with the family of Brad Pearce,'' a touring pro from Provo who lost in the first round of the Open. ``My sister and I had been nervous, you know, two women alone in the city,'' she said. ``And this happens to the Watkins, with three men there. It's crazy.'' Manhattan detective Chief Joseph DeMartino said police recovered several weapons, including a cardboard cutter and a folding ``butterfly knife'' believed to be the weapon used to kill Watkins. The motive of the crime was to get money for admission into the night club, DeMartino said. Arrested was Yull Garry Morales, 18, of Queens, who police said stabbed Watkins. Also arrested and booked for investigation of murder and robbery were: Johnnie Hincaipe, Anthony Andersen, Louis Fernando Montiero, Ricardo Lopez, Emiliano Fernandez, all of Queens; Pascual Carpenter, of Long Island and Ricardo Nova, address unknown. All are 18.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf States Giving U.S. Warplanes Unprecedented Access
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 3 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, This source... to UPDATE with Cheney comments today; picks up 4th graf pvs, Because of...
DOC.TEXT: Several smaller Persian Gulf states are shedding a traditional reluctance for close military links with the United States and allowing U.S. combat airplanes on their bases, Pentagon sources say. ``It's very important to the United States that our aircraft be able to operate out of these nations in the Persian Gulf,'' one source said Monday. This source said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was able to negotiate ``a variety of agreements'' with the nations on the Arabian Peninsula during his trip there last month. Asked to comment on the report during an appearance on ABC's ``Good Morning America,'' Cheney said today he would not go ``country-by-country'' in detailing which ones have accepted what U.S. forces, but said all ``are participating to one degree or another. ... The exact degree varies.'' Cheney said some of the countries are sensitive about acknowledging the presence of U.S. forces, but said it was fair to say ``there is more cooperation than there has ever been before.'' Asked whether the presence of U.S. forces amounts to an implicit commitment to also defend those countries, Cheney said, ``I think it does.'' Because of the threat posed by Iraqi forces because of Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait a month ago, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar have allowed U.S. warplanes to operate on their soil. Cheney was able to extend those relationships to include other Persian Gulf states, such as Bahrain and Oman, as well, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The sources did not have specifics on their aircraft deployment. Some nations have allowed for refueling rights, others have allowed for the stationing of aircraft and others have allowed cargo operations. Bahrain has agreed to accept Marine FA-18 attack planes, A-6 attack aircraft, AV-8 Harrier jets and EA-6 electronic jamming planes, The New York Times reported in today's editions. In addition, the United States deployed a ``sizeable number'' of F-16 fighters in the United Arab Emirates, the newspaper reported. Also, the United States has F-15E ground attack planes based in Oman, the Times reported. The United States already has acknowledged stationing a squadron of F-16C fighter planes in Qatar. Cheney reached the agreement with Saudi Arabia to allow for the stationing of U.S. troops on Saudi soil in a meeting with King Fahd just days after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. He returned to the Persian Gulf two weeks after the invasion to help fortify Arab support against Iraq in discussions with the leaders of Bahrain, Oman, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, Egypt and Saudi Arabia. Those countries warmed toward military cooperation with the United States during the eight-year war between Iran and Iraq, when U.S. warships protected Kuwaiti tankers from Iranian attack in the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Three Troopers Hurt, 25 Arrested at Pigeon Shoot
DOC.TEXT: An annual Labor Day pigeon shoot involving birds released from cages was ``American as apple pie,'' one advocate said, but dozens of animal-rights activists didn't agree and clashed with shooters. Three state troopers suffered minor injuries and 25 people were arrested during the 57th Annual Fred Coleman Memorial Shoot at Hegins, 40 miles northeast of Harrisburg. Several fistfights broke out, a skunk was thrown at protesters and a demonstrator kicked out the windshield of a car. Animal-rights activists from Pennsylvania, California, Maryland, Kansas, Illinois, New Jersey, West Virginia, Virginia, Texas and Florida picketed the all-day community fund-raiser, billed as the largest live pigeon shoot in the world. Competitors using shotguns stood about 20 yards from the birds, which were released one at a time from cages. After a group of birds was shot, a group of young ``trapper boys'' ran onto the field to retrieve them. Some birds were only wounded and the children would wring their necks or pull their heads off. Dead birds were collected to be used in fertilizer, shooters said. An estimated 4,800 birds were killed Monday, organizers said. ``This is as American as apple pie and Chevrolet,'' said one burly man, wearing a Jack Daniels baseball cap. ``There's a lot more worse things than this. Go to Saudi Arabia and protest the oil prices.'' ``It's deplorable that these men get their kicks out of this,'' said Paula Murphy, an elementary school teacher from Ashland. Fourteen animal activists with fake blood dripping from their mouths charged onto the field at different times attempting to free the caged birds. Spectators chanted ``shoot'' as state police tried to handcuff the demonstrators. The people who rushed the field were charged with criminal trespass. An additional 11 demonstrators were charged with disorderly conduct. State police spokesman Tom Lyon said police ordered the protesters to leave because ``It was just getting out of control.'' The event has a history of drawing protests and Lyon said 40 officers were assigned and a state police helicopter was called in as an ``extra show of force.'' Community members jeered, shouted obscenities and homosexual slurs at the demonstrators. They said the activists should leave them alone because the shoot is legal. Shooter Jack Keating said the shoot is simply ``killing rats with wings.'' Protesters carried signs that read ``Small Men, Big Guns,'' ``Stop the Slaughter,'' and ``Killing for Fun is Sick.'' Community members retaliated with T-shirts and pickets of their own _ ``Kill them all. Let God Sort Them Out,'' and ``Let Feathers Fly and Freedom Ring.' Seventh-grader Tim Leese wore a T-shirt that said: ``Save a Pigeon. Kill a Protester.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs first item to UPDATE throughout with man saying he now plans charges, still no comment from Wahlberg.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: New Kids on the Block member Donnie Wahlberg scuffled with a fellow airline passenger over a seat, and he could face charges. The 20-year-old pop singer fought with Benjamin Dattner of New York on a Delta Air Lines flight after it left Salt Lake City on Sunday, police and Delta said. The scuffle was ``very short-lived, and it was not necessary for us to land the plane,'' said Delta spokesman William Berry. Dattner was treated for minor injuries at a hospital and initially declined to file charges, authorities said. But later, in an interview with The Boston Globe, Dattner indicated he planned to file charges. ``Nobody, no matter how famous, should be above the law. This guy was an animal,'' Dattner said in a telephone interview from his Manhattan home. Wahlberg, who had been sitting in the first-class section, had gone to visit with members of his entourage in coach. He left briefly, then returned and found the seat he had been occupying was taken by Dattner, police said. A fight broke out in which Wahlberg poked the passenger in the eye and the passenger kicked Wahlberg in the abdomen, police said. Calls to Wahlberg's agent went unanswered Monday and this morning. It was the second Atlanta incident involving the pop group in less than a month. On Aug. 9, a bodyguard for New Kids singer Jordan Knight was arrested after an altercation at a nightclub.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Proposes Drastic Reduction of Kremlin Power Over Economy
DOC.TEXT: Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, has come up with a plan that would give the republics control of their economies and drastically reduce the power of the national government. ``Russia gives the impulse for change to the entire country,'' Yeltsin told his legislature Monday. ``The center can no longer ignore this and discard everything done by us.'' If approved by the Russian republic's legislature, the proposal would dramatically constrict the power of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Yeltsin's rival. Gorbachev's national government would control only a fraction of the planned transition from communism to a market economy. Yeltsin set an ambitious schedule calling for five days of debate in the Russian legislature and a vote on the fundamental reform Sept. 11. That agenda would leave the national legislature in the dust because it does not open its session until Sept. 10. According to a copy of the 250-page plan obtained by The Associated Press, most decisions regarding the economy would be made by the 15 sovereign republics. Under it, Russia would legalize private ownership of land and give away huge numbers of state-owned apartments and residential lots to try to solve critical shortages of food and housing. Since Russia contains half of the Soviet Union's people and three-quarters of its land mass, the national legislature would be unable to ignore a decision by Russia to embark on a more radical reform than favored by Gorbachev. But Yeltsin said Gorbachev is increasingly willing to understand the republic's proposals and act together. A joint Gorbachev-Yeltsin economic commission was scheduled to meet today to try to forge a single plan that could be adopted by both the Russian and Soviet parliaments, Yeltsin said. So far, Gorbachev has favored combining parts of the Russian proposal with a purely economic program suggested by Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. Pravda said today that Gorbachev has appointed Soviet Deputy Prime Minister Lev Voronin to head a task force to deal with the most urgent economic emergencies. The faltering Soviet economy is plagued by shortages of everything from cigarettes to gasoline. Under Yeltsin's plan, the Soviet government's duties would eventually be limited to such matters as defense, strengthening the nearly worthless ruble and providing disaster relief. It would lose the power to tax and would have to rely on dues from the republics. Yeltsin said his program has the support of the other Soviet republics, since it would give them vast new powers. His plan is dubbed ``500 days'' for the time it provides to switch to a market economy. It calls for immediate action on reforms that Gorbachev's government has only mentioned, or postponed years into the future. ``People will be given the opportunity to participate actively in the economy, to buy bakeries, laundries, stores, repair shops and other things that the future state should not bother with,'' said Russian Prime Minister Ivan Silaev in introducing the plan to the legislature. Before the end of the year, the sell-off of such state-owned businesses would begin, the plan said. Apartments and residential lots would be given away or sold for merely symbolic prices. Laws that punish entrepreneurs would be eliminated, the proposal said. Currently, it is illegal to make a profit selling an item manufactured by someone else's labor.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Logging Demonstrators March to Lumber Mill in Last Summer Action
DOC.TEXT: About 600 anti-logging activists confronted 100 counterdemonstrators, but authorities reported no violence and no arrests. The protest Monday was the final one of Redwood Summer, a series of demonstrations by environmentalists who oppose clear cutting and logging of old-growth timber. Logging companies urged their employees and others who back timber interests to ignore the protesters as they marched to a Pacific Lumber Co. mill. But as the demonstrators sang, hoisted banners and chanted, a pro-timber crowd shouted derision of environmentalists and the group Earth First! ``Earth First! go home,'' they yelled. ``Jobs First!'' ``The '60s are over!'' Although some of the demonstrators hollered back, most sat in the roadway, singing anthems such as ``We Shall Overcome'' and ``This Land is Your Land.'' Helmeted police officers stood shoulder to shoulder between the two groups.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Preaches Against Witchcraft in Africa
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II today urged Africa's Roman Catholics to abandon the ``unspeakable crime'' of witchcraft, a practice that threatens the church's foundations on the continent. In his homily at an outdoor Mass on the shores of Lake Victoria, the pope also spoke out against abortion, saying the ``dignity of every human person from the moment of conception until natural death'' must be respected. His sermon came on the fourth day of his seventh visit to Africa, a vast continent with a declining economy and a soaring birth rate that is expected to double its population of 500 million within 20 years. Tanzania's average per capita annual income is only about $200, making it one of the world's poorest countries. Few of sub-Saharan Africa's 48 other nations fare much better. The pope also condemned artificial birth control, calling it ``contrary to the `truth' of married love by which husband and wife become cooperators with god in giving life.'' Concerned about their birth rates and their lack of resources to adequately care for swelling populations, Tanzania and many other African nations actively support birth control programs. John Paul said respect for human dignity also is threatened in Africa by the practice of uchawi, or witchcraft. He said it leads practioners into ``forms of enslavement and false worship.'' He also criticized the traditional African custom of mahari, or a dowry payment by a husband to the family of his bride. In the past, these payments usually took the form of cattle, sheep and goats. Increasingly, they involve substantial cash payments. The pope said there are many ``authentic and praiseworthy human values'' associated with the dowry tradition. But he asked: ``Do not excesses and abuses of these customs lead to attitudes which judge the dignity and worth of persons only on the basis of wealth and possessions?'' The Roman Catholic Church in Africa, only a century old, faces the problem of incorporating traditional practices in the liturgy without overwhelming the faith's traditions and beliefs. The church has gone a long way in recent years in the process of ``Africanization,'' adopting the use of tribal drums, native dance music and language in the liturgy. The pope has encouraged the process while warning that the basic tenents of Catholic faith and teaching cannot be compromised. He has stressed the church's laws on polygamy, superstition and priestly celebacy on his current visit. An estimated 50,000 faithful attended the Mass on a hillside above Mwanza, a relatively prosperous cotton-growing and gold-mining center on the southern shores of the world's third largest lake. Nineteen married couples repeated their marriage vows before the pope. He also gave First Communion to a group of children dressed in white finery. As he neared the halfway point of his 10-day trip, the pope ended the day in Moshi, a farming and resort city on the southern slopes of snow-capped Mount Kilimanjaro, at 18,864 feet the tallest mountain in Africa. His pilgrimage will take him to tiny Burundi on Wednesday, then on to neighboring and equally small Rwanda. He ends his visit on Sept. 10 in the West African nation of Ivory Coast, where he will consecrate a massive $133 million basilica.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Ministers of North and South Korea Begin Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with remarks at dinner, details on demonstrations, car accident, minor editing throughout. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SEL1
DOC.TEXT: The prime ministers of North and South Korea met today and prepared for historic talks intended to ease four decades of military and political tensions. Both expressed hopes for a new era in their relations. It is the highest-level contact between the rivals since the division of the Korean peninsula in 1945, although the prime ministers hold largely ceremonial posts and their roles in policy-making are limited. ``People expect to reap much from the talks,'' South Korean President Roh Tae-woo said today. ``But the task of national unification should take a step-by-step approach, just like eating a bowl of rice one spoonful at a time.'' The visit got off to a bit of a bumpy start. Students in Seoul staged an anti-government demonstration, and the North Korean leader's motorcade was involved in an accident immediately after crossing the border. He was not hurt. Also, the North Koreans had barely arrived when they asked to speak to South Korean dissidents and to visit the families of two clergymen and a student jailed for illegally traveling to the North. The Seoul government has taken a firm stand against allowing its citizens to talk directly with North Korean officials, and it brushed aside the request. ``They should concentrate on the talks,'' said South Korean Unification Minister Hong Sung-chul. At a gala banquet on the eve of the talks, however, all was cordial. ``I am so glad that you have taken the challenge of blazing an unbeaten trail through the thicket to come here,'' South Korean Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon told his North Korean counterpart, Yon Hyong Muk. ``If only we build confidence in each other by meeting again and again, we should be able to generate sufficient heat to thaw the thick ice of distrust,'' said Kang, a soldier-turned-diplomat born in the North who fled to the South before the 1950-53 Korean War. Yon, a Soviet-educated technocrat, said: ``After crossing the border for the first time, I realize it's easy.'' The North Korean was warmly greeted in the lobby of the hotel where talks were to be held. ``Welcome,'' shouted several hundred onlookers outside the hotel. Some waved and applauded. As the premier's motorcade approached the hotel, two students managed to unfold a banner within view, but were quickly shoved aside by police. Eight radical students were arrested trying to take a unification banner to the border, police said. Another 200 radical students staged a violent anti-government clash with combat clad riot police at Seoul's Korea University. ``Down with Roh Tae-woo,'' students yelled, hurling firebombs during a two-hour fight. Police fired volleys of tear gas to drive students inside the campus. Witnesses said the students appeared to avoid chants which might be offensive toward North Korea. No injuries were immediately reported. The North Korean leader escaped injury shortly after he crossed the border when the car in which he was riding was involved in a collision with three other cars on the way to the hotel. The accident occured when a civilian car tried to cut through the motorcade as it drove through downtown Seoul. Two North Korean diplomats riding in separate cars were treated for minor injuries. One car caught fire and the windshield on the third was broken. The meeting marks the first time both sides recognize the legitimacy of each other's governments, South Korean officials say. Previously, North Korea had refused to recognize the Seoul government. Most South Koreans, however, reacted coolly to the talks. South Koreans have been disappointed by repeated failures of the Korean governments to make progress in such encounters. The North Korean delegation included the prime minister, six other official delegates to the talks, 33 aides and 50 North Korean reporters. All wore lapel badges with pictures of North Korean dictator Kim Il Sung. They smiled and waved as they walked across the border at the truce village of Panmunjom, the first group to cross since 1985 and only the third delegation since the end of World War II. Young women in colorful long traditional dresses bowed and children presented flowers. If all goes well, a second round of talks is to be held in North Korea's capital of Pyongyang in mid-October. The border between the Koreas remains the most heavily fortified in the world, with more than 1.5 million armed men on either side. There is no travel, mail or other communication between civilians of the two sides.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Finds Many Would Consider Leaving Massachusetts
DOC.TEXT: Nearly half the residents of Massachusetts would consider moving out of the state if the economy got worse, a poll indicates. Of 436 voters polled Aug. 26 to 30 by telephone, 50 percent said they would not consider leaving if the economy worsens; 47 percent said they would, and 3 percent said they did not know. One-third of those polled for The Boston Globe and WBZ-TV of Boston said they are cutting back on groceries because of the economy, and 30 percent said they worry about losing their jobs. There appeared to be a connection between job-loss fear and consideration of leaving the state. Most of those worried about losing their jobs were young, 18 to 39, and middle-income _ $30,000 to $60,000 a year, and young and middle-income residents were chief among those saying they would consider moving. The poll also found that 61 percent thought the economy would get worse during the next six months, while 15 percent thought it would improve, and 42 percent blamed state policy makers for the state of the economy compared with 24 percent who blamed the downturn on the national economy. The poll was conducted by KRC Communications Research, which said it had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 5 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Customs Service Detains Kuwaiti Vessel
DOC.TEXT: The Customs Service detained a Kuwaiti container ship and was examining the cargo to see if anything was destined for Iraq, officials said today. The ship Al Wattyah was ordered held Monday evening, said Neil Pitagno, a Customs agent based in Newark. ``The vessel has not been seized, it has been detained,'' said Pitagno. ``There are a number of containers aboard that we are interested in.'' He said containers were being checked ``to see if there is any material aboard that is going to Iraq that we want to stop.'' He said the crew cooperated with Customs agents who boarded the vessel, but said some containers might have to be unloaded to determine their contents. ``It will take a while. It is a time-consuming process,'' said Pitagno. The ship's destination was not yet known, he said. The vessel's last port of call was Cadiz, Spain, said Sgt. Charles O'Neill of the Port Newark police. ``My understanding is that they are treating it as an Iraqi ship due to the annexation of Kuwait by Iraq,'' he said. The ship is owned by United Arab Shipping Co., according to Lloyd's Register of Shipping.

DOC.HEAD: Chedli Klibi Resigns as Secretary-General of Arab League
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lead and 2nd graf to ADD reference to Lebanese interim secretary-general. Pickup 3rd, `Assaad el-Assaad...'
DOC.TEXT: Arab League Secretary-General Chedli Klibi has quit, highlighting a split within the organization over the Persian Gulf crisis. League officials said today a Lebanese will act as interim secretary-general. Klibi, 66, a Tunisian, announced his surprise resignation as head of the 21-member body late Monday. He had held the job for 11 years. Assaad el-Assaad, a Lebanese and the 70-year-old doyen of the Arab League's deputy chiefs, will act as interim secretary-general, the officials said. The new secretary-general must be chosen by a two-thirds vote among league members. Klibi's resignation highlights divisions within the Arab League over the gulf crisis as well as the group's decision to move the league headquarters from Tunis back to Cairo, its original seat. Klibi had been the Arab League's secretary general since 1979, when the organization moved to Tunis. He was reappointed to the post in March for another five-year term. The league has been openly divided since its Aug. 10 Arab summit in Cairo over the Persian Gulf crisis, which was precipitated by Iraq's Aug. 2 seizure of Kuwait. The summit condemned Iraq and agreed to send a token Arab force to bolster American troops defending Saudi Arabia from any move by Iraq to seize more territory. Tunisia boycotted the summit, provoking anger from Egypt and Saudi Arabia, the most vocal Arab nations in their opposition to the Iraqi invasion. While more than half the league members took what was viewed as a pro-Western stance, others sided in varying degrees with Iraq. It was Klibi's job to reconcile the two camps. But at a meeting of Arab League foreign ministers last week, Saudi minister Prince Saud al-Faisal was sharply critical of the secretary-general. In addition, Klibi has been caught in a battle over the location of the League's headquarters, which was moved to Tunis after Egypt declared peace with Israel in 1979 and was barred from the League. The decision to move the headquarters back to the Egyptian capital has provoked protests from Iraq. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz criticized the move because of what he called Egypt's ``partial attitude'' against Iraq. Some have charged that Klibi himself has resisted the move to Cairo. A meeting of Arab League ministers has been called for Sept. 10 in Cairo, where the transfer of the League's headquarters back to Cairo will be officially announced.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds One in Four Households hit by Violent or Property Crime
DOC.TEXT: About one in four U.S. households was hit by a violent or property crime last year, a slight increase from the previous few years but still substantially lower than the rate during the 1970s. ``During the last five years, the percentage of households victimized by crime has remained level at about 25 percent,'' said Steven Dillingham, director of the Justice Department's Bureau of Justice Statistics. ``In 1975, when this statistical series commenced, about one in three households was struck by crime,'' he said. The bureau's figures come from the National Crime Survey, which annually interviews members of 49,000 households nationwide to determine crimes against household members who are at least 12 years old. The NCS does not check for murder, because it compiles its information from surveys of victims. The portion of households that suffered from a violent or property crime ranged from 32 percent in 1975 to 30 percent at the start of the 1980s and gradually tapered off to a low of 24.5 percent in 1987, according to the report. The actual percentage of households that suffered a violent or property crime last year was 24.9 percent, up slightly from 24.6 percent in 1988, according to the report released Sunday. The figures include attempted as well as completed crimes. A total of 23.5 million households was victimized by one of the crimes checked: rape, assault, robbery, personal theft, household theft, burglary and motor vehicle theft. A total of 4.9 percent of households experienced a violent crime, with 3.9 percent suffering assault, 1 percent robbery and 0.1 percent rape, the survey found. The year before, violent crime had hit 4.8 percent of homes. Meanwhile, 17.8 percent of households suffered from some kind of theft, 11.2 percent personal theft and 8.1 percent household theft; 5.1 percent suffered from a burglary and 1.6 percent motor vehicle theft. The survey found that, as in previous years, black households, urban households and households with higher incomes suffered a higher percentage of crimes last year. A total of 29.1 percent of all black households suffered from any NCS-surveyed crime _ a slight increase from 29 percent in 1988. And 6.4 percent of them suffered from a violent crime, a decrease from 6.6 percent in 1988. As for households headed by Caucasians, 24.3 percent suffered from an NCS-surveyed crime, up from 23.9 percent the previous year. And 4.7 percent were victimized by a violent crime, a slight increase from 4.6 in 1988. Some 25.5 percent of the households of other races combined _ Asians, Pacific Islanders and Native Americans _ were victimized by an NCS-surveyed crime, down from 27.4 percent in 1988. The percentage of those homes that suffered from a violent crime also decreased to 5.4 percent from 5.6 percent. A separate category for Hispanics and non-Hispanics shows that a greater percentage of Hispanic households suffered an NCS crime last year than in 1988. Last year, 33.8 percent of households headed by Hispanics were victims of an NCS crime, up from 30 percent the previous year. Meanwhile, 7.3 percent of Hispanic households suffered a violent crime, up from 6.5 percent in 1988. The percentage of urban households that have been victims of crime increased from 30.3 percent to 31.2 percent. A greater number of suburban households also were victimized _ up from 23.8 percent to 24.2 percent. At the same time, rural households experienced less crime, with only 17.2 percent suffering compared with 18 percent in 1988. The portion of households with incomes of $15,000 and above that suffered from a crime edged downward last year while crime hit a larger portion of households with lower incomes than it had in 1988. Still, the households with the highest target rate _ 27 percent _ were those with incomes of $25,000 or more.

DOC.HEAD: Israel: If U.S. Forgives Egypt's Debt, Must Forgive Israel's Too
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai said today that if the United States goes ahead with proposals to forgive Egypt's multibillion dollar debt, Israel will demand that most of its debt to the Americans also be erased. Egypt owes the United States $6.7 billion from previous arms sales, and Israel owes $4.6 billion. The two are the largest recipients of U.S. foreign aid. Each year, Israel receives $3 billion and Egypt gets $2.3 billion. ``It doesn't make sense that Egypt gets a waiver and Israel stays out of it,'' Modai told Israel radio. ``It is ridiculous.'' He said he would raise the subject when he visits Washington in two weeks. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said he hoped Israel would receive additional economic aid from the United States. ``It's not a question of cancellation (of debt), but I think that our representatives will ask the United States for finding some ways to solve, to help us solve our economic problems,'' Shamir told reporters today. Bush administration officials say the president is considering forgiving the Egyptian debt as a reward to Egypt for joining the U.S.-led multinational force in the Persian Gulf and taking part in the trade embargo against Iraq. Israel has maintained a low profile in the crisis, reportedly at the request of the Americans who fear an Israeli role could break up the alliance of moderate Arab states against Iraq. Foreign Ministry officials refused to discuss Modai's plans, saying any comments could interfere with Foreign Minister David Levy's trip to Washington. He is to meet Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Wednesday. Modai also said he would demand substantial increases in U.S. aid to help absorb Soviet immigrants to Israel. Some estimates say Israel needs $30 billion to $40 billion to absorb about 1 million immigrants over the next five years. Israel already has asked for $400 million in U.S. loan guarantees to help settle the Soviets, but the request has not been fulfilled because of American fears the money would be used to increase Jewish settlements in the occupied territories. The new demands came after Israel asked Washington for additional advanced weapons, complaining of increased danger from the Iraqis and from new U.S. weapons expected to be supplied to Saudi Arabia. The list of weapons requested by Israel reportedly includes more F-16 warplanes and Apache anti-tank helicopters than previously agreed, as well as two Patriot anti-ballistic missile systems, preferably on lease.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending Posts 0.4 Percent Gain
DOC.TEXT: Construction spending posted a slight 0.4 percent gain in July, the first advance in four months, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said residential, non-residential and government spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $442.2 billion. Construction spending had not risen since a 0.4 percent increase last March. It had fallen 0.9 percent in both May and June and 1.9 percent in April. But today's report showed spending in June was weaker than first reported. The department initially had said spending was unchanged. Analysts have attributed the general weakness to high interest rates, tight lending requirements and, in some areas, overbuilding that resulted in major vacancies. The weakness has been illustrated in recent Labor Department reports showing the loss of 100,000 construction jobs since last fall. The latest report said payrolls fell by 50,000 in July, after seasonal adjustment, for their fifth consecutive decline. Construction spending in July was 3.1 percent above that of the same month in 1989, when it totaled $429.0 billion. Residential spending in July slipped 0.4 percent to $190.5 billion after posting a 3.4 percent loss in June. Single-family spending was down 1.3 percent to $110.2 billion after a 1.6 percent drop a month earlier. Apartment construction fell 1.6 percent to $18.4 billion after a 3.6 percent drop in June. Non-residential spending, led by industrial construction, rose 2.5 percent to $107.5 billion after a 1.8 percent gain the previous month. Industrial building was up a strong 9.3 percent to $22.4 billion. Government spending edged down 0.2 percent to $108.6 billion after rising 0.7 percent the previous month.

DOC.HEAD: Florida, Nevada Voters Nominate Candidates for Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts one graf after the 2nd to update with Florida turnout.
DOC.TEXT: Former Sen. Lawton Chiles faced Rep. Bill Nelson for the Democratic nomination for governor today after a bruising campaign in which Chiles was dogged by questions about his mental stability. In Nevada, Gov. Bob Miller was favored to beat five Democratic unknowns, including a man who changed his name to Rhinestone Cowboy, and win nomination for a full term. Businessman Jim Gallaway led the Republican field of eight. About one-third of Florida's 5.4 million registered voters were expected to turn out. ``Our phones have been busy this morning, and that's a good sign,'' Dade County Elections Supervisor David Leahy said. After Florida's bitter Democratic campaign, Gov. Bob Martinez, a virtual shoo-in for the GOP nomination, savored the damage his rivals did to each other. ``I've gotten what I need out of the Democratic primary,'' said campaign manager J.M. ``Mac'' Stipanovich. Chiles, 60, was questioned about his mental health, age and tenure in Washington during the campaign. He released medical records about his battle with depression and acknowledged taking the controversial drug Prozac to treat it. Nelson's running mate, state House Speaker Tom Gustafson, was widely criticized and finally apologized for suggesting Chiles could be suicidal, and some polls indicated Nelson suffered a backlash from the negative campaigning. Chiles, who retired from the Senate in 1989 after three terms, held a double-digit lead over the six-term congressman in recent polls. He countered Nelson's attacks by pointing to his experience and his self-imposed $100 limit on individual campaign contributions, which he said demonstrated his independence. Nelson raised $6 million to Chiles' $2 million. Chiles and Nelson, who both took part in the Fort Lauderdale Labor Day parade, have promised to work for the Democratic nominee. Democrats are worried, though, because a bitter 1986 primary was credited with enabling Martinez to become Florida's second GOP governor since Reconstruction. Martinez was expected to win the GOP nomination easily against maverick state Sen. Marlene Woodson Howard, who criticized Martinez for his support of a services tax that was later repealed and his anti-abortion activism. In Nevada, Miller, as lieutenant governor, assumed the governor's chair in 1988 when Democrat Dick Bryan jumped to the U.S. Senate midway through his term. Providing a little color was Rhinestone Cowboy, 61. He changed his name from Vernon Hall years ago to promote his line of rhinestone-encrusted Western clothing and is a perennial candidate for posts such as mayor and sheriff. On the GOP side, Gallaway was accused by another contender, builder Charlie Brown, of trying to buy the election with slick TV ads. Gallaway outspent Brown 4-to-1. None of the other Republican candidates mounted a major campaign. A plane crash Monday seriously injured two candidates in Nevada's primary _ Sue Wagner, running for lieutenant governor, and Bob Seale, who is running for treasurer. Seale's wife, Judy, was killed in the crash, authorities said. Five people were aboard the twin-engine plane that crashed after takeoff from Fallon for a Labor Day parade in Carson City. Two aides to the candidates suffered less serious injuries and were taken to a hospital, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Third Countdown for Columbia Proceeding Uninterrupted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf to UPDATE with test director quote today.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Columbia and the observatory inside its cargo bay were pronounced trouble-free as the clock ticked on toward a Thursday launch and NASA's first shuttle flight in more than four months. It is the third countdown for the astronomy mission, which was delayed by fuel leaks in May and telescope problems last week. Liftoff is set for 1:20 a.m. EDT. ``Everybody's very comfortable,'' test director Al Sofge said today. ``We're just proceeding down through the count, business as usual, doing what we do best, no problems.'' Columbia was supposed to have lifted off May 30 with the $150 million observatory, but the launch was scrubbed because of a hydrogen leak. Atlantis was found a month later to have a similar problem, and NASA temporarily grounded the three-shuttle fleet. NASA replaced Columbia's leaky hydrogen lines and rescheduled liftoff for Saturday, but that attempt was abandoned because of communication problems with Astro's 1,500-pound X-ray telescope. The problem was fixed over the weekend. Four of Columbia's seven astronauts are astronomers who will take turns operating Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes round the clock. The X-ray telescope will be managed from the ground. The nine- to 10-day flight will be the first shuttle mission in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. NASA plans to move Discovery to the other shuttle launch pad tonight for a flight in October with the Ulysses spacecraft, which will be sent on a five-year journey to explore the sun's polar regions. That mission will be followed in November by Atlantis' classified Pentagon flight, originally scheduled for July. NASA had hoped for nine shuttle missions this year but so far has flown only three. The last shuttle flight was in April, when Discovery carried the Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. The $1.5 billion observatory later was found to have a flawed mirror that produces blurry images. Astronomers have been waiting 4{ years for the Astro mission. Columbia originally was scheduled to lift off with Astro in March 1986 to study, among other things, Halley's comet. The mission and all others were postponed after the Challenger disaster. On its revamped schedule, Astro will examine some of the hottest objects in the universe, including a supernova and Comet Levy, which is making its first recorded pass through the solar system. The observatory will remain on aboard and return to Earth for possible re-use.

DOC.HEAD: Former CIA Agent Going on Trial in Iran-Contra Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to UPDATE with court proceedings under way.
DOC.TEXT: A retired CIA agent accused of trying to hide his Iran-Contra arms profits from U.S. tax collectors is going on trial in a case expected to lay out the scandal's money trail. Thomas G. Clines, 62, of Middleburg, Va., is accused of under-reporting earnings on his 1985 and 1986 tax returns and failing to tell the Internal Revenue Service about overseas bank accounts. Jury selection began today in federal court. The trial is expected to focus on profits made in the secret network that was run by Reagan administration officials and supplied arms to Iran and the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. Clines, who retired from the CIA in 1978 after a 29-year career, was indicted Feb. 22. If convicted, he could get 16 years in prison and $1 million in fines. ``We thought the case should never have been brought,'' said defense attorney Paula M. Junghans. Prosecutors contend that in 1985 and 1986 Clines reaped about $882,000 in commissions for helping buy and sell arms to Iran and the Contras. Some of the money was kept in a foreign account code-named C.Tea, according to the congressional Iran-Contra report issued in 1987. Clines reported gross income of $265,000 for the tax year 1985 and $402,513 for 1986, the indictment said. Iranian-born businessman Albert Hakim and retired Air Force Maj. Gen. Richard V. Secord, who took part in the arms network also run by Oliver North and former national security adviser John M. Poindexter, are expected to take the stand for the government.
