Clines was a CIA agent in Southeast Asia and was involved in the Bay of Pigs invasion in Cuba. He became director of training in clandestine operations.

DOC.HEAD: Khmer Rouge Says It Won't Attend Peace Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Indonesia's foreign minister. Pickup 10th graf pvs, `Hun Sen...'
DOC.TEXT: In a move that could undermine talks on a U.N. plan to end the Cambodian war, the Khmer Rouge said today it would not attend a peace conference in Indonesia unless the Cambodian prime minister agrees to go. Khmer Rouge leader Khieu Samphan said he had planned to leave for Jakarta on Wednesday but changed his mind after hearing state radio report that Cambodia's Premier Hun Sen would not attend the talks, set to begin Thursday. He said that showed Phnom Penh and Vietnam ``are not sincere in the search of a solution'' and did not accept the U.N. peace plan. Khieu Samphan said, however, he would go to Jakarta if Hun Sen also went. ``If Hun Sen doesn't go, there is no point in having any meeting,'' said another Khmer Rouge official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Fighting will continue, he said. ``Fighting has the aim of forcing the Vietnamese to talk,'' he said. Indonesia's foreign minister, Ali Alatas, said he was disappointed by the threat to the talks, and said he was trying to resolve the problems. ``The whole world is placing its hope on the Jakarta meeting,'' he said. ``Now is the best time to try it. The Cambodian leaders should be able to see this.'' The Khmer Rouge has by far the most powerful guerrilla army because of arms aid from China. Many countries say that despite the group's brutal record when it ruled Cambodia in the 1970s, Khmer Rouge participation in a negotiated settlement is crucial because the guerrillas otherwise would keep on fighting. Prince Norodom Ranariddh, whose guerrillas are allied with the Khmer Rouge, also said today he would not attend for the same reason Khieu Samphan gave. Both Ranariddh and Hun Sen said they were sending subordinates to the Jakarta meeting. Hun Sen had announced he was not attending because Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Ranariddh's father and leader of the three-faction guerrilla coalition, said he was not attending. Son Sann, who leads the third guerrilla group, the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, is expected to participate. The guerrillas are allied in a coalition fighting the government that Vietnam installed in Phnom Penh after invading the country in late 1978. Hopes for a settlement were raised after the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, who back different sides in the conflict, adopted a comprehensive peace plan for Cambodia last week. The members are the United States, the Soviet Union, China, France and Britain. Their plan called for the United Nations to supervise five key government ministries in the period before a general election. A Supreme National Council, comprising representatives of Phnom Penh and the guerrillas, would act as a figurehead government. The Khmer Rouge is composed of fanatical Communists who killed hundreds of thousands of people when they ruled Cambodia from 1975 until Vietnam's invasion. Hun Sen and other Phnom Penh leaders held positions of authority during the Khmer Rouge reign until they defected under threat of purges.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Bishop Joyce Dies at 93
DOC.TEXT: The Most Rev. Robert F. Joyce, the retired Roman Catholic bishop of Burlington, has died at age 93 after a long illness. Joyce, who died Sunday night, was active in the community beyond his church activities. He was the first clergyman elected a trustee at the University of Vermont. ``He bridged various religious groups, educational institutions, health organizations and the rich and the poor,'' said J. Warren McClure, former publisher of The Burlington Free Press. ``His greatest impact on the community was in the area of being open to people of every religion, including those who had no religion,'' said former Mayor Francis Cain. Joyce was ordained a priest in 1923 and served in several Vermont parishes. He was named by Pope Pius XII to head the church in Vermont in 1957. He served as bishop until his retirement in 1972. The diocese didn't know of any surviving relatives. A funeral Mass was scheduled for Thursday at St. Michael the Archangel Chapel at St. Michael's College in Colchester.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Lawyers Discuss Human Rights `Trial' For Bush
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has suggested setting up an international ``people's court'' to try President Bush for defiling Islam and for human rights violations. The state-run Iraqi News Agency said today the idea was discussed by the nation's union for lawyers and human rights association. Hamel al-Rawi, vice chairman of the lawyers association, was quoted as saying that several prominent Arab and non-Arab figures had been contacted to participate in the tribunal. They were not named, nor was any time frame given for such a tribunal. The INA dispatch, monitored in Cyprus, did not give details on specific charges against Bush, except for ``defilement of Islamic sanctities.'' That refers to complaints from various conservative Moslem figures throughout the Middle East over the deployment of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia, the site of Islam's two holiest shrines, Mecca and Medina. Iraq has repeatedly complained that the U.N.-imposed embargo against it, in which the United States plays the largest role, violates international law and human rights by depriving the nation of food and medical supplies.

DOC.HEAD: Riot Fears As Refugees' Plight Worsens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 21 grafs to UPDATE with more aid efforts announced. Pickup 15th graf pvs, `Aid workers...'; edits thereafter to trim
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jordan's crown prince today criticized the international community for doing little to help thousands of Asian refugees from Iraq and Kuwait, some of whom are dying from exposure in the desert. International organizations trying to cope with the refugee flood said more funds were urgently needed to tackle the crisis. An estimated 420,000 refugees, most of them Arabs, have poured into Jordan across the desert since Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Many Arabs have been repatriated, but more than 100,000 Asians _ Indians, Sri Lankans, Bangladeshis, Thais and Filipinos _ remain stranded in Jordan. Some are stuck in a squalid, makeshift camp in the no man's land just inside Jordan because authorities at the border post of Ruweishid, swamped by the human tide, has not been able to process them. The Jordanians have said they cannot let them in until their home governments guarantee aircraft or ships to evacuate them. Prince Hassan, brother of King Hussein, appealed for immediate aid. ``We should not forget that the situation, critical as it is, may be only the tip of the iceberg,'' he told a news conference organized by the U.N. Disaster and Relief Agency. Although much attention has been given to the Westerners trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, little has been focused on the Asians and other refugees. At the desert camp at Shaalan _ 25 miles from Rusweishid, where 41,000 people await transport home _ refugees are dying from exposure in the parching sun and chilling temperatures at night, the aid workers said Monday. One doctor said he feared outbreaks of deadly diseases such as cholera and typhus because of ``non-existent'' sanitation conditions. ``Things are so bad we don't even know how many have died. People are in awful shape,'' said Rebecca Salti, an American settled in Jordan who works with Save the Children. Dick Clay, an American construction manager who spent three days at the camp after fleeing Kuwait disguised as a Filipino, said he thought people would start killing one another over supplies if nothing is done to help them. Hassan said today that the United Nations should be helping, and he appealed to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to appoint a representative to tackle the crisis. ``The plight of these people ... has only evoked the faintest of responses from the world community and from a world press more interested in war scenarios than in humantarian relief,'' he declared. The Office of the U.N. Disaster Relief Coordinator, UNDRO, which is overseeing the international relief effort, said governments had contributed only $9.5 million toward its $60 million appeal. The Geneva-based International Organization for Migration said it needed more than $23 million to help evacuate Asians whose countries were too poor to meet transportation costs from the Mideast. India said today it has chartered aircraft and is exploring the possibilty of hiring ships to bring back stranded Indians. A foreign ministry spokesman said India also has sent food to Amman for the refugees. ``We are trying our best to bring back all those Indians who want to come home,'' spokesman Aftab Seth said. A Virgin Atlantic Boeing 747 departed London today for Amman, where it was expected to pick up 150 British citizens and 250 Egyptians. The flight left with nearly 30 tons of supplies requested by Jordan, including 26,000 blankets, five tons of rice and flour donated by supermarkets, and 2{ tons of antibiotics, solutions to combat dehydration and other medicines. ``King Hussein of Jordan has given us a list of things he needs which is frightening. It goes on for pages,'' said Richard Branson, an airline executive. A U.N. food agency announced today it would provide 3,446 tons of emergency food aid for refugees in Jordan. The $1.9 million food shipment, including wheat flour, canned fish, meat and cheese will be distributed to 120,000 people over 90 days, said the World Food Program. Aid workers at the desert camp have described scenes of violence. In one case, refugees bashed in an Indian woman's face with a water jug. In another, several thousand refugees beat an Indian who volunteered to help relief workers when they suspected him of cheating in distributing tents. Turkey, like Jordan, has received thousands of refugees over the past month since Iraq invaded Kuwait, and refugees described similarly desperate conditions at a camp on the Iraqi side of the Turkey-Iraq frontier. They said at least three Pakistanis, including a woman giving birth, have died. Pakistan's military attache in Ankara, Staff Col. Arshad Setih, called the conditions ``deplorable.'' The Philippines has asked the governments of its Asian neighbors to help evacuate thousands of Filipinos in Jordan, Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus said today in Manila.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Coast Guard Boards Iraqi-Flagged Vessel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with background on other interdiction efforts, details. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Coast Guardsmen boarded an Iraqi-flagged freighter in the Gulf of Oman today in an effort to enforce the international embargo on Iraqi trade, naval and shipping sources reported. It was the first reported case of U.S. forces boarding an Iraqi-flagged vessel since the U.N. sanctions were clamped on Iraq last month to punish Baghdad for invading Kuwait. Last week, the U.N. Security Council authorized dozens of warships in the region to use military force to uphold the sanctions. The shipping sources said the 3,549-ton Zanoobia was laden with tea picked up in Colombo, Sri Lanka, and apparently bound for Iraq. The U.S. warships intercepted the vessel in the Gulf of Oman before it could reach the Strait of Hormuz, the gateway to the Persian Gulf, the sources said on condition of anonymity. U.S. Navy officials in Manama refused to give details of the reported incident. Other reports that the vessel was seized and taken to the Omani port of Muscat could not immediately be confirmed. The only other ship that U.S. forces are reported to have boarded and subsequently prevented from docking was the 91,478-ton Kota Wirama, managed by the Pacific International Lines of Singapore. That vessel was intercepted in the Red Sea Aug. 28, boarded and searched, and then prevented from proceeding to the Jordanian port of Aqaba. Jordan has been one of the weak links in the blockade because of its pro-Iraqi sympathies and its relatively open northeastern border with Iraq. The Pentagon has reported that more than 350 ships of various nationalities have been challenged by U.S. warships in the Persian Gulf and the Red Sea, and at least 10 boarded since the U.N. Security Council decreed the embargo. About four dozen Coast Guard members, trained on boarding vessels in the Caribbean to search for drugs, have been sent out to help the Navy with cases that necessitate boarding to check ship registers and cargo.

DOC.HEAD: War Wounded Hold Government Television Station
DOC.TEXT: A group of handicapped war veterans and mothers of Sandinista soldiers killed fighting Contra rebels occupied the government television network for a second day today to demand higher pensions. About 30 protesters, some in wheelchairs, took over the building early Monday evening and the network went off the air shortly afterward. ``We took over the television plant to pressure the government to increase the pensions,'' Fernando Lopez, national coordinator of the Sandinista war handicapped said by telephone after the takeover. ``They are starving us by offering us a (monthly) pension of just 21 million cordobas (about $21), while on the other hand the government is giving the Contras who demobilized 50 million cordobas ($50),'' he said. The one-time payments to hundreds of former Contra rebels were made Monday by the International Support and Verification Commission. The commission was formed to help oversee the disbanding and relocation of the rebels under an agreement to end their 9-year-old, U.S.-backed war against the Sandinistas and to ensure a peaceful transition of power after the Sandinistas' Feb. 25 election defeat. The Contra payments were part of $40 million in U.S. government assistance for the demobilization and part of a $300 million U.S. aid package for the government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. ``We will stay here until President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro resolves the problem for us,'' Lopez said. Before the takeover, the group had tried to march to Mrs. Chamorro's office to demand a meeting, but it was turned away by police. Presidential spokesman Danilo Lacayo said in a radio broadcast late Monday that he, another aide and television officials went to the station to talk to the protesters but were attacked by people with the veterans. He said police had to intervene but did not say how they were attacked or if anyone was injured. Antonio Ibarra, vice minister of the presidency, said an 81.3 percent increase for 2,000 military pensioners, including the handicapped, was agreed to in a meeting on Friday. The 21 million cordobas includes that increase.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Killer Arranged Murder Scenes to Taunt Police
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf with one graf to UPDATE with university comment on students back in class; SUBS 16th graf, `Defense attorney' to UPDATE with bond hearing scheduled. Police news conference has concluded with no major developments; lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: College students headed back to class today in this fear-stricken town as investigators said the killer stalking young women seemed to be taunting authorities by the way he arranged evidence at the scene. ``In the scene, the set-up, there was a message _ to law enforcement, to whoever,'' police Capt. R.B. Ward said Monday. ``He was very calculated, very methodical in the way the person did things, as well as left things.'' Authorities would not elaborate on how evidence was arranged. Classes for more than 40,000 students resumed at the University of Florida and Santa Fe Community College today after the Labor Day weekend. UF spokesman Larry Humes said at midmorning that a spot check with faculty members showed that a ``vast majority'' of the student body was back in class. Students remained afraid amid warnings that the killer who stabbed four women and a man in their off-campus apartments may still be in their midst. Many students came back armed. University President John Lombardi said 100 of the school's 34,000 students transferred or dropped out. ``I'm really petrified, afraid,'' said Michelle, an 18-year-old freshman from Plantation who refused to give her last name and said she fled town after the bodies were found. ``But I bought some Mace and a baseball bat. I'm prepared.'' The killer stalking trim brunettes slipped in through windows or doors in three attacks within miles of each other, police said. The victims attended either the university or the college and were discovered Aug. 26-28. Three were mutilated. ``He is spending considerable time at the scene. I don't think any of us can say how long. We're each of the opinion it wasn't in and out,'' said Ward, a leader of a 175-member task force investigating the slayings. ``When we walked in, we saw the `play' he had set up for us,'' added J.O. Jackson, lead investigator for the Florida Department of Law Enforcement. The messages weren't written but seemed to be daring police to catch the killer, he said. Police said they have four primary suspects, including Edward Humphrey, a mentally disturbed university freshman jailed on charges of beating his grandmother. The 18-year-old is being held on $1 million bail. Humphrey lived briefly this summer at an apartment complex where two victims were slain and at a dormitory where a third lived, police said. The Gainesville Sun, citing no sources, reported Monday that circumstantial evidence pointing to Humphrey includes that he walks with a limp from an accident and that one victim's leg was mutilated. Police had no comment on the report. Humphrey's fingerprints and footprints and samples of his blood have been taken, police said. His psychiatric records also were seized. His apartment remained under guard over the weekend, while officers continued searching a murky creek near the scene of the most recent slaying. Defense attorney J.R. Russo said he would ask for a reduction in bail at a hearing scheduled for Thursday morning. ``Are we just holding a citizen just because he fits a certain mental psychological profile or do they have specific evidence which justifies a million dollar bond?'' he asked. ``A lot of improper things have taken place.'' Some students said they felt relatively safe because of the security in the dorms and because the slayings were off campus. ``I don't think we should stop our lives because of it,'' said Laura Whitkowsky, 18, a freshman from Port St. Lucie. ``My parents wanted me to come home, but I told them the dorm was the safest place to be.'' Lincoln M. Llopiz of Miami and his wife sold Mace on a street corner near campus Monday. Business for the $7.99 canisters was slow. ``There is more panic in Miami than Gainesville,'' said Llopiz, who brought 17,000 containers but had sold fewer than 10 by early evening. University freshmen Sonja Larson, 18, and Christina Powell, 17, were found slain Aug. 26. The body of community college student Christa Hoyt was discovered the next day. Tracey Paules, 23, and Manuel Taboada, 23, were found dead a day later.

DOC.HEAD: Jazz Singer of 1940s Dies of Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Laura Washington, a smoky-voiced jazz vocalist who sang with Erskine Hawkins' orchestra on Broadway in the 1940s and made the hit record ``I've Got A Right To Cry,'' has died of cancer. She was 64. A memorial service was planned tonight for Miss Washington, who died Thursday. Members of the Birmingham Heritage Band planned to play an old Johnny Mercer ballad, ``Laura,'' in her memory. Miss Washington made her debut at the Strand Theater on Broadway in 1946, the same year she made ``I've Got A Right To Cry.'' She performed in the 1940s as the only woman member of Hawkins' 18-piece band. In New York, Miss Washington met her idol, Ella Fitzgerald, and became friends with another Alabama native, blues singer Dinah Washington. ``Her whole style was similar to Ella's,'' said Birmingham jazz musician J.L. Lowe. Lowe, who discovered Miss Washington's singing talents as a child and later recommended her to Hawkins, said she could have become a jazz legend if she had not left her career in the 1950s to return to Birmingham to raise a family. She did not sing professionally again for more than 25 years, until her children were grown and her husband, Julian Dash, had died. She returned in the 1980s to perform weekends at a downtown club, Grundy's. ``Musicians who remembered her from the old days were astounded to find out she still had that voice, even in her 60s,'' said Lowe. ``Her voice was like an instrument. It was a gift.''

DOC.HEAD: Overnight Fighting Claims 30 Lives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE death toll, ADD Mandela comment. Pickup 12th graf pvs, `In Vosloorus...'
DOC.TEXT: At least 40 blacks were killed in savage township fighting, including 11 who died when soldiers fired assault rifles today on a crowd at a migrant workers' hostel, police said. The latest violence came as President F.W. de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela toured the townships to call for an end to the black factional fighting that has killed more than 550 people in the past three weeks. The worst fighting occurred in Sebokeng, south of Johannesburg, where police said they entered a migrant workers' hostel to investigate the deaths of four men, believed to be township residents abducted by the hostel dwellers. An armed mob of up to 5,000 gathered outside the hostel, saying they wanted to launch a revenge attack on Zulus inside, police said. When the mob refused to disperse, army troops were called in and a ``shooting incident occurred,'' said police Col. Frans Malherbe. He said 11 bodies were found after the mob dispersed. Malherbe said both the police and military were investigating the shooting. Township resident N. Khumalo said the soldiers ``took up a position, cocked their guns _ I thought maybe they wanted to scare the people.'' ``All of a sudden there was shooting. Many of the people ran. Some of the people fell,'' Khumalo was quoted as saying by the independent South African Press Association. Police said 36 people were killed in various clashes today in Sebokeng. They reported four deaths overnight in Vosloorus and Katlehong, southeast of Johannesburg. Witnesses said several more people were killed in the two townships, but the deaths could not be confirmed. They also said they arrested 150 men in connection with the earlier violence in the hostel and confiscated four AK-47 assault rifles. Mandela visited Sebokeng today and said he was ``outraged'' after viewing corpses at the local mortuary. A SAPA reporter following Mandela into the township, Lew Elias, said his vehicle was stoned, overturned and set alight by angry township youths. Elias suffered only minor injuries. In Vosloorus, southeast of Johannesburg, witnesses said Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha movement stoned houses and set them alight Monday night. A similar attack was reported in neighboring Katlehong. Police and witnesses reported 10 deaths in the two townships. In renewed clashes in Vosloorus today, Zulus from a workers' hostel used axes, spears, shovels and other weapons to attack houses. Township residents, some with gas bombs, tried a counterattack on the hostel, but police repeatedly fired tear gas and shotguns to keep the two sides apart. Some women packed their children and belongings in trucks and fled the area. Much of the recent fighting has pitted Inkatha-supporting Zulus living in the hostels against blacks in the townships who back the African National Congress, the country's largest opposition movement. De Klerk, meanwhile, was mobbed by youths and greeted with cries of ``Viva, de Klerk,'' as he toured the huge Soweto township outside Johannesburg. At one stop, he visited a migrant workers hostel whose residents have been involved in the recent battles. ``He's a brave man to come here. He must be a good leader,'' said one man living in the run-down hostel. Afterward de Klerk told a news conference: ``I'm glad we could visit the hostel and that we could see ... circumstances which are absolutely unacceptable.'' De Klerk says the government wants to provide family housing for all blacks, but the current housing shortage makes it impractical to tear down existing hostels for single working men. The ANC and its allies blame the police for fueling the township violence and claim the force has been siding with Inkatha. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok again denied the charges, saying government opponents were waging an orchestrated campaign to discredit the police. Individual policemen may have acted improperly, but the force as a whole has been impartial and prevented the violence from escalating, Vlok said in an interview with government-run television. De Klerk has ordered Vlok to investigate the allegations of improper police conduct. But Mandela said Monday there should be an independent inquiry. A leader of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party said Monday that police should let black factions fight each other instead of facing criticism for trying to intervene. ``The question is why do Mandela and other black leaders not stop their own supporters ... or is it an admission that they have lost control,'' said Moolman Mentz, the party's spokesman for law and order. Mandela has repeatedly refused to meet Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi, an old friend. The ANC says Buthelezi is using the violence obtain a meeting with Mandela and enhance his stature. Buthelezi, meanwhile, says the ANC wants to crush all opposition and is to blame for the fighting. The ANC-Inkatha feud has claimed some 5,000 lives since 1986 in the eastern province of Natal, where most of the blacks are Zulus.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Propose Conference on Persian Gulf, Other Mideast Issues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15 grafs to UPDATE with more Israeli comment. Pickup 14th graf pvs, `Shevardnadze also...'
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze today proposed an international conference on the Persian Gulf crisis that would also take up the Arab-Israeli conflict and the civil war in Lebanon. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir suggested Israel might attend an international conference if invited, but only if discussions were limited to the gulf crisis. In a major foreign policy address delivered in the Pacific coast city of Vladivostok, Shevardnadze also said Sunday's superpower summit in Helsinki, Finland, would mark ``a major milestone on the road toward resolving the crisis in the Persian Gulf.'' He repeated Moscow's condemnation of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and appealed anew for a resolution by diplomatic means rather than military force. The text of his speech was distributed by the official Tass news agency. ``For the first time in history, the international community has acted with ... unanimity and firmness in response to aggression and in seeking to eliminate its consequences,'' Shevardnadze told an international meeting on Asian relations. ``But it is essential to pursue our objective through non-military means and in a way that would remove the military presence of other countries,'' he said. In proposing the international conference on the Middle East, Shevardnadze linked the Persian Gulf crisis to the conflict between the Palestinians and the Israelis, as well as the civil strife in Lebanon. ``Presumably, Israel's agreement to its (a conference's) convocation could exert a positive influence on the overall situation in the Middle East and on efforts to defuse the crisis in the Persian Gulf,'' the Soviet foreign minister said. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has proposed that a pullout of his troops from Kuwait be contingent upon an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied territories. The United States and Israel rejected the plan. If Israel were to participate in the conference, Shevardnadze said, ``The Soviet Union ... might take a fresh look at the issue of Soviet-Israeli relations.'' The Soviet Union and Israel have not had diplomatic relations since the 1967 Middle East War, although both countries have been moving closer in recent months. In Jerusalem, Shamir said Israel would consider participating in the Soviet-proposed international conference, although Israel has been careful to avoid any direct involvement in the gulf crisis. ``I still haven't received this proposal. After we hear it and we examine its details, we will decide,'' Shamir told reporters. However, he reiterated the Israeli refusal to discuss the Palestinian question at such a forum. Israel has vehemently opposed previous Soviet-backed ideas to hold an international conference to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict, including the Palestinian issue. ``We have our position about an international conference around the solution of the Israeli-Arab conflict. We will not participate in such an international conference,'' Shamir said. Shevardnadze also said such a conference should not delay efforts by the United Nations to achieve a peaceful settlement in the Persian Gulf. He blamed the ``great powers'' _ a reference to the Soviet Union and the United States _ for supplying arms in the region. ``Unless peace comes to the Middle East, we shall continue to pay a huge price for its wars,'' he said. ``It is time that we acted now in the interests of the world's integrity.'' Shevardnadze, who traveled later to Tokyo, also proposed that all foreign ministers from Asian countries meet in Vladivostok in the autumn of 1993 to discuss issues relating to the region, Tass said. He said the details could be discussed at an upcoming session of the U.N. General Assembly.

DOC.HEAD: Former S.C. State Legislator Pleads Guilty
DOC.TEXT: The most influential of five state lawmakers charged with taking bribes pleaded guilty today to a federal corruption charge. Former state Rep. Robert Brown, who resigned his seat one day before a grand jury indicted him Aug. 24, entered the plea before U.S. District Judge Falcon B. Hawkins. Brown, former chairman of the House Labor, Commerce and Industry Committee, was the first of the five indicted legislators to appear before a federal judge. The five were indicted as part of a 16-month-old federal investigation. The bribe-taking charge carries a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison and a fine of $250,000. Neither Brown nor prosecutors would comment immediately on whether they had made a plea bargain that would affect Brown's sentence. Court officials said Brown will remain free on bond during a pre-sentencing investigation that would take three to six weeks. Brown was charged with taking a $2,000 bribe from lobbyist Ron Cobb, who was working for the FBI in a videotaped operation. The indictment accused the 34-year-old Democrat of voting for and promising to work ``behind the scenes'' for passage of a bill that would have allowed voters to decide whether to permit pari-mutuel betting in South Carolina. Brown's committee passed the bill in March 1989. The full House never considered the legislation later that year or in 1990. In late July, shortly after news of the investigation broke, Brown, who had served in the House since 1983, filed an amended campaign report that disclosed he had received $2,500 cash from Cobb in either April or May. The reports were due in June. At the time, Brown denied he took the money in exchange for his service or his vote. ``I've never taken a dime with strings attached,'' he said. Rick Lee, a Republican who resigned his Senate seat a week ago, is scheduled to appear before a federal judge Sept. 10. Lee has said he will plead guilty to accepting a $2,000 cash bribe from Cobb. State Reps. Robert Kohn, Luther Taylor and Danny Winstead, along with Brown and Lee, were indicted under the Hobbs Act, a federal law banning acceptance of money or gifts in return for votes or favors. Winstead also was indicted on a second charge of obstruction of justice. All five defendants were required to plead innocent last week because federal magistrates cannot accept guilty pleas. Kohn, a Republican who has said he will not seek re-election, and Taylor, a Democrat, have been suspended from the House. Winstead, a Republican, resigned his seat on Aug. 23. Taylor, indicted on six counts, faces a maximum sentence of 120 years in prison and a $1.5 million fine if convicted. Winstead faces a total of 30 years in prison and a $500,000 fine if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: African Military Force Wins Control of More of Capital
DOC.TEXT: A five-nation African military force moved today to expand areas of the capital under its control, and a few fishing boats ventured into the city's port to sell fish to Monrovia's hungry residents. About 3,000 soldiers from Ghana, Nigeria, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Gambia landed at Monrovia's port Aug. 24 under orders to end the eight-month tribal war that has left at least 5,000 people dead. The troops have been attacked by rebels loyal to Charles Taylor, but were welcomed by President Samuel Doe and a rebel faction led by Prince Johnson. The African force has ``done extremely well and better than anybody expected,'' said a Western diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. The African troops were mobbed by Monrovia residents, who have been isolated from the outside world for more than two months. Water and electricity were cut off and most food stocks exhausted. Little fighting was reported today, and the commander of the force, Ghanaian Lt. Gen. Arnold Quainoo, left for consulations with the Gambian president, Sir Dawda Jawara. Jawara is president of the Economic Community of West African States, which dispatched the force to Liberia. Jawara was to meet with officials of Burkina Faso, whose government has criticized the intervention and been accused of intervening on the side of Taylor's rebels. Taylor has vowed to destroy the five-nation force, and declared himself president of Liberia. But his forces have been unable to dislodge troops loyal to Doe in Monrovia's eastern suburbs. Johnson, who split with Taylor after the rebel invasion of Liberia Dec. 24, managed to fight his way into Monrovia but also failed to drive Doe from his heavily fortified mansion. Doe's troops and Johnson's men appeared to be largely observing a truce that began the day the West African force landed. Reports from Lagos, Nigeria, said Nigeria was sending additional arms, equipment and medical supplies to the five-nation force by ship today. The United States, meanwhile, continued to evacuate foreigners on a first-come, first-served basis from its embassy in Monrovia, said an embassy official who declined to be further identified. A contingent of U.S. Marines guarded the embassy. Evacuees were flown by helicopters to U.S. warships off the Liberian coast, and then on to Freetown, Sierra Leone for flights to Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Six Spectators Injured in Bathtub Race
DOC.TEXT: A bathtub on wheels that reached speeds of nearly 50 mph went out of control on a curve during a race and injured six spectators, newspapers reported Tuesday. The incident occurred Monday during an annual race down a mountainside in this Tuscan town. The race was suspended. Corriere della Sera said eight tubs were entered, each equipped with steering wheel and brake. The pilot of the runaway tub was also slightly injured, the newspaper reported.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Kills Policeman with Pistol
DOC.TEXT: A 4-year-old boy shot to death a policeman who jokingly invited the youngster to demonstrated the use of his pistol, a government official said Tuesday. The incident occurred Sunday when the officer, Somboon Jandpuchong, asked young Peerapong Suwannarin to bring his 11mm pistol as he was leaving the boy's house. The policeman jokingly asked the boy to demonstrate the use of the pistol and the youngster aimed at Somboon, pulling the trigger, said the provincial governor, Surat Thani. Somboon was visiting the boy's father and had apparently laid his pistol on a bed while inside the house. The governor said the boy was not arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Leaf Campaign Launched to Help Koalas
DOC.TEXT: Half a million gum leaves are being collected as part of a campaign to help the koala, whose population is at an all-time low in Australia. The Australian Koala Foundation national headquarters will dry the leaves, imprint ``I SAVED A KOALA TODAY'' on each, and mount them on pins to be sold on Oct. 20, National Koala Day. A foundation spokeswoman, Ann Sharp, said the last official koala count in 1986 turned up 400,000 of the animals in Australia. Scientists believe the figure was highly inflated because many may have been counted more than once. Decimated by shooting _ 3 million pelts were exported to the United States in 1921 _ koalas are now suffering from urban sprawl into their natural habitat along Australia's east coast. ``The need for help has never been greater,'' Ms. Sharp said. ``A half a million gum leaves is a hell of a lot. But we know the public won't let us down. We can use most of what people rake up and burn during their weekend gardening.''

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Floods Leave 50,000 Ethiopians Homeless
DOC.TEXT: Floods caused by torrential rains left more than 50,000 people homeless and destroyed this year's crop in southwestern Ethiopia, it was reported Tuesday. The Ethiopian News Agency said the flooding along Sudan's border occurred last week after the Baro river and several of its tributaries broke their banks. The news agency said the floods also disrupted electricity, water supplies, and telephone services in Gambella, a provincial town on the banks of the Baro. Tiwat Paul, the secretary of the ruling Workers Party of Ethiopia in the region, said 300 Gambella residents and 50,000 peasant farmers in the region lost their homes. Tiwat said the floods also threatened a nearby Sudanese refugee camp. The camp, run by the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, is home to about 300,000 people who have fled civil war and periodic famine in southern Sudan.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Apartheid Newspaper Folds After 2{ Months
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The anti-apartheid Daily Mail newspaper published its final edition Tuesday, ending a 2{-month effort to establish itself in Johannesburg's competitive morning newspaper market. In a front-page commentary titled ``Gone, But Not Gone Forever,'' the newspaper said its sister publication, the Weekly Mail, would continue to publish every Friday. A company spokeswoman said some Daily Mail employees would be shifted to the 4-year-old Weekly Mail. The Daily Mail, launched June 20, was a strong anti-apartheid voice in the city's saturated morning newspaper market. There are five remaining morning newspapers _ four English and one Afrikaans _ and several weekly newspapers. Reports that the Daily Mail needed more money began circulating last week. According to news reports, the newspaper had a circulation of about 14,000 and needed 25,000 to break even. ``We have not raised the money needed to continue publishing the daily and will now revert to publishing only the Weekly Mail,'' said Tuesday's commentary. It said the Weekly Mail's circulation exceeded 30,000. ``We can only express dismay that the press remains in the hands of so few people who have so much power over the industry and so much control over what South Africans may or may not know,'' the commentary said. ``This newspaper was a brief experiment to try and change the situation; its suspension does not bode well for attempts to create a more diverse press, an absolute precondition for a democratic country.''

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll From Typhoon Abe Rises to 88
DOC.TEXT: At least 88 people have died in two coastal provinces that were battered by Typhoon Abe, an official report said Tuesday. Abe, which landed Friday in south Zhejiang province, rampaged through Shanghai, China's most populous city, then headed back out to sea Monday afternoon, the China Daily reported. The death toll in Zhejiang now stands at 65, with 839 injured, 660,000 stranded by floods and 40,000 left homeless, the report said. Half the province's land area and one-fourth of its population _ or 10 million people _ were affected by Typhoon Abe. It was reported to be the worst typhoon to hit the province in 34 years. In neighboring Jiangsu province, 23 people diede and hundreds were injured, mostly by collapsing buildings, the paper said. An earlier report said three people died in Shanghai, China's largest commercial and industrial city. It was not clear if the three were included in the latest death toll of 88.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending Up Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Construction spending edged up 0.4 percent in July for its first gain in four months, the government said Tuesday, but analysts expect the industry to remain weak through the end of the year. The Commerce Department said spending on residential, non-residential and government buildings totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $442.2 billion. Analysts had said the weakness in the construction industry was due to consumer caution, high interest rates, tight lending requirements and, in some areas, overbuilding. ``Iraq made things worse,'' said David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. Construction spending had not risen since a 0.4 percent increase in March. It fell 0.9 percent in both May and June and 1.9 percent in April. But the latest report showed spending in May and June was even weaker than first reported. The department initially had said spending in May was down just 0.3 percent and in June was unchanged. Labor Department employment reports further illustrate the weakness. The department has said construction employment has declined for five straight months, including the loss of 50,000 jobs in July, after seasonal adjustment. Payrolls have fallen by 100,000 since last fall. Residential spending in July fell 0.4 percent, to $190.5 billion, its fourth consecutive drop, including a 3.4 percent loss in June. Single-family spending was down 1.3 percent, to $110.2 billion, for its fourth straight decline, including a 1.6 percent drop in June. Apartment construction fell 1.6 percent, to $18.4 billion, after a 3.6 percent drop in June. It has fallen for three months. ``The new structure component will continue to move down, certainly through the end of the year,'' Seiders said, adding that the report implies strong performance only in additions and alterations to existing structures. ``This is what we usually see in down cycles,'' he said. ``People just add on to houses.'' Non-residential spending rose 2.5 percent, to $107.5 billion, after a 1.8 percent gain the previous month. ``The only truly bright spot is the industrial component,'' which was up 9.3 percent in July, Seiders said. ``But the permit information ... has been weakening and we expect this part of the market will lose its momentum.'' The other two major non-residential components _ office buildings and other commercial construction such as shopping centers _ remains weak, Seiders said. Government spending edged down 0.2 percent, to $108.6 billion, after rising 0.7 percent the previous month. Overall construction spending in July was 3.1 percent above that of July 1989, when it totaled $429.0 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Will Ask Congress to Forgive Egypt's Military Debt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has decided to ask Congress to forgive Egypt's entire $7 billion military debt because of its leadership in standing up to Iraqi aggression, the White House announced today. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said forgiving the debt ``recognizes the strategic importance of Egypt'' in the multinational effort to enforce the United Nations' trade embargo against Baghdad. ``It is a symbol of our appreciation'' for the role played by Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, Fitzwater said. Bush consulted with congressional leaders before making the decision, Fitzwater said. Waiving Egypt's military debt _ largely amassed through U.S. arms sales to Cairo _ requires an act of Congress. Another $6 billion in non-military Egyptian debt to the United States would not be affected, Fitzwater said. The announcement came after Bush met with his Cabinet for a post-vacation briefing on the Persian Gulf crisis. He hinted that other packages for other countries in the region helping enforce the embargo, including Israel, might be forthcoming as well. ``We think we will be able to put together a rather sizeable package of support for Middle Eastern countries that are in need as a result of this'' effort against Iraq, Fitzwater said. Meanwhile, Fitzwater indicated that the president might expand his trip next weekend to meet Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to include a visit to another country on the way home from Helsinki, Finland. Bush will leave Washington on Friday night for the one-day summit with Gorbachev on Sunday. Fitzwater said that the summit would follow the flexible pattern set by the two leaders in their initial meeting last December at Malta. Fitzwater had no details on where Bush might stop on the way home from Finland. After the Malta summit, the president addressed NATO allies in Brussels. The White House official said the principal goal of the hastily arranged Helsinki summit was ``sowing unity and support by the two superpowers for the common objective of stopping Saddam Hussein.'' Although Soviet support for the U.S.-led military effort to enforce the trade embargo against Iraq has been lukewarm, Fitzwater said, ``I find no area of disagreement'' with the Soviets on the current Persian Gulf crisis. Fitzwater, meanwhile, denied there was a dispute with the government of Saudi Arabia on which nation controls the decision to launch a U.S. military offensive. ``It's a consultation process,'' Fitzwater said. ``We have an excellent working relationship with the Saudi Arabian government,'' he added. Fitzwater, meanwhile, confirmed news reports that U.S. Coast Guardsman had boarded an Iraqi-flagged freighter _ loaded with tea _ in the Gulf of Oman in an effort to enforce the international embargo. ``The ship was ordered to divert. It did not divert. It was then boarded and now has diverted. We don't have information now on where it's being diverted to,'' he said. The spokesman acknowledged that some goods have been trucked into Iraq across the Jordanian border. But, he characterized this as a minor broaching of the embargo and said it was ``not a problem for the overall effectiveness of the sanctions.'' Fitzwater, summing up the status of Americans who remain trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, said there are 2,000 American citizens left in Kuwait, of which 1200 are women and children. In Iraq, there are still 250 Americans, about half of whom are women and children, Fitzwater said. About 100 Americans were brought home over the weekend. Earlier today, Bush met with his Cabinet for a post-vacation briefing on the gulf crisis. The president, returning to the capital just five days before he holds his third summit with Gorbachev, also was dispatching two top aides to solicit donations from wealthy allies to cover expenses of the U.S. military operation in the gulf region. ``We are going to have to expect more cooperation from the 22 countries that are participating in this effort,'' Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today. Rostenkowski, who returned from Saudi Arabia Monday night, also said on ``CBS This Morning'' that Americans are ``just going to have to recognize the fact that sacrifice is going to be necessary. ... I think we're going to have to raise revenues, cut spending, be a little more prudent about the way we spend our defense dollars.'' Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., appearing with Rostenkowski, echoed the call for more international support. ``We've got to focus on a number of things and one is the burden-sharing issue. We must get more of our allies there, in greater numbers.'' Levin said the morale of U.S. troops ``is very, very high.'' But he said they are in an ``extraordinarily difficult environment'' and are getting ``no mail yet, no newspapers, no cigarettes. We're going to have to worry about rotation and relief for some of our forces.'' A delegation of 22 House members returned to Washington on Monday night after touring the Persian Gulf region and inspecting the U.S. military operation that has been rushed in since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Rep. Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., the House majority leader, told reporters at Andrews Air Force Base, Md: ``All of us left here with the conclusion that the president's action was a correct action. All of us come back believing that is the case.'' But, Gephardt added, ``We need more help, especially from our NATO allies, to have troops on the ground with ours.'' He said the bipartisan delegation also ``firmly believes that the financial burden of supporting multilateral military deployments in the Persian Gulf area must be shared equitably.'' Baker leaves Thursday for Saudi Arabia and the gulf region to solicit financial contributions to bolster the U.S. effort and also to provide economic assistance to countries hard hit by the embargo against Iraq. He also planned stops in West Germany and Italy. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady was setting out on a similar mission today to Paris, London, Seoul and Tokyo. Bush announced last week that he wants to enlist the wealthy nations of the world to help pay the $1 billion per month in U.S. costs for military might mustered against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Uprising Marks 1,000 Days
DOC.TEXT: When an army truck broke down recently in the middle of this West Bank town, Palestinian teen-agers sprang into action. ``They trashed it,'' said an Israeli army officer who witnessed the scene. ``They broke every window, smashed every door and fender.'' The incident was a reminder that the Palestinian revolt against Israeli occupation, though eclipsed by the gulf crisis, persists as an angry war of stones and empty bottles against well-armed Israeli troops. The uprising, known in Arabic as the ``intefadeh,'' marks its 1,000th day Wednesday. The PLO-backed underground leadership of the revolt called for the anniversary to be marked with protest marches under the banner ``Intefadeh until a Palestinian state.'' That goal remains illusive for the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, and the character of the struggle is changing amid a more restrained Israeli military policy and the impact of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Palestinian support for Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein has disappointed the United States and other Western nations that tried to mediate the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. ``There's no doubt that Israel is reaping political gains from the gulf crisis,'' said Ghassan Khatib, a Palestinian professor from this town just north of Jerusalem. ``There are fewer pressures on Israel from the United States to start a dialogue with the Palestinians,'' Khatib said. ``There is no more talk about Israeli violations of human rights in the occupied territories.'' Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Tuesday dismissed reporters' questions about the anniversary. ``It doesn't have any impact on the progress of the Jewish people and the Jewish state,'' Shamir said. Since the revolt began in December 1987, a total of 728 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians. In addition, 255 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israel. Forty-seven Israelis have died. In recent months, according to both Palestinians and Israeli army officials, there has been a marked slowdown in the uprising. Under Defense Minister Moshe Arens, the army since June has reduced its forces in heavily populated areas and tightened firing rules, sharply reducing Palestinian casualties. In the past three months, 11 Palestinians have died from Israeli army gunfire. In the same period last year, the toll was 77. ``It reflects more experience by the army in handling the situation,'' said an army spokesman, who cannot be identified by name under military rules. ``Troops are positioned so there is less friction with the local population.'' Meanwhile, the Palestinian side shows signs of fatigue from the almost weekly general strikes ordered by uprising leaders and forced closures by the army. ``Our business barely feeds our family,'' said Zaki Musleh, a 60-year-old carpenter with a shop on Ramallah's Palestine Street. ``No one has any money.'' Musleh's shop, like many others, is short one worker. His 28-year-old son Bassam is in army custody, one of more than 910 Palestinians held without charge or trial under military ``administrative detention'' rules. Some 9,015 other Palestinians also are in jail, charged or awaiting trial or sentenced for anti-Israeli crimes, the army says. Palestinians remain resilient despite the revolt's failure to achieve its main political goal of getting the Israelis out of the territories they seized in the 1967 Middle East war. Palestinian journalist Daoud Kuttab said he believes the main achievement of the intefadeh has been a change in Palestinian attitudes. ``Palestinians are no longer thinking as an occupied people. They are thinking as a people resisting occupation,'' he said. ``That is why the uprising will continue.'' In Ramallah's Kadura refugee camp, 29-year-old truck driver Ziad Zmekna points to greater international awareness of the Palestinians' plight as another gain from the uprising. Zmekna's life is a measure of Palestinian determination. One of his brothers is jailed, another is hiding from authorities, and Zmekna himself has lost his driver's license for failure to pay income taxes to the Israelis. He points to a photo on his wall, the wedding portrait of a Palestinian friend killed by Israeli troops last year. ``The intefadeh will continue for our martyrs, it will continue for us,'' Zmekna said. ``This is our national duty.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Isolate Gene that Causes Osteoarthritis
DOC.TEXT: The National Institutes of Health announced today that scientists have isolated the gene responsible for osteoarthritis, a painful, crippling disease that affects about 16 million Americans. Dr. Darwin J. Prockop of Philadelphia's Thomas Jefferson University and Dr. Roland W. Moskowitz of Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland led the scientists who isolated a flawed gene that normally helps make collagen, a protein that strengthens joints. The scientists studied genetic material from 19 members of a three-generation family and found that the faulty gene was affecting the family members as young as 16. Osteoarthritis leads to a wearing away of joints and serious cases of severe crippling. It can affect the hands, feet, hips and knees. Identifying the gene, officials said, may lead to new treatments and even prevention. ``Understanding genetic mechanisms underlying osteoarthritis may give us the potential to intervene early in a painful, disabling disease,'' said Dr. James O. Mason, assistant secretary of health.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Propose Mideast Conference to Cover Israel, Iraq, Lebanon
LaserPhoto TOK3
DOC.TEXT: The Soviets on Tuesday proposed an international conference to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, the Arab-Israeli dispute and the Lebanese civil war. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir reiterated his opposition to discussing the Palestinian issue at an international conference, but he welcomed the idea of a conference on the Persian Gulf. A spokesman for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declined to say how hard he will press the issue at the summit with President Bush on Sunday. ``The Soviet president intends to discuss ... ways of defusing the Persian Gulf crisis, and he believes that all efforts, including those of a mediator, are viewed positively in the Soviet Union,'' presidential spokesman Vitaly N. Ignatenko told a news conference. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze proposed the conference earlier in the day during a speech in Vladivostok, in the Soviet Far East. Shevardnadze said the summit in Helsinki, Finland, ``will mark a major milestone on the road toward resolving the crisis in the Persian Gulf.'' But he said that ``after one more look at the situation, we still have come to the same conclusion'' that an international conference on the Middle East is necessary. He stressed that in the meantime, efforts to bring about a settlement of the Persian Gulf situation under U.N. auspices should continue. The Soviet Union voted for a U.N. Security Council embargo against Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and has given lukewarm support to U.S. Navy actions to enforce the sanctions. This is a departure from the Kremlin's historic stance. In the past, it shipped arms to militant Arab states, including Iraq; was hostile to Israel; and supported the Palestine Liberation Organization. Shevardnadze criticized the previous arms sales to Iraq, which ended after the invasion, and said the Soviet Union might re-examine its relations with Israel. But he also linked solution of the Persian Gulf crisis to the Palestinian issue, as well as to the civil war in Lebanon. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein at one point proposed that a pullout of his troops from Kuwait be contingent upon an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied territories. The United States rejected the plan. ``At this point in time, there is a growing awareness ... that a complex of problems involving the Arab-Israeli conflict, the fate of the Palestinians and the tragedy in Lebanon awaits its resolution in the Middle East,'' Shevardnadze said in his speech, which was carried by the state news agency Tass. ``Presumably, Israel's agreement to its (a conference's) convocation could exert a positive influence on the overall situation in the Middle East and on efforts to defuse the crisis in the Persian Gulf,'' he said. ``For its part, the Soviet Union ... might take a fresh look at the issue of Soviet-Israeli relations,'' Shevardnadze added. The Soviet Union and Israel have not had diplomatic relations since the 1967 Middle East War, although both countries have been moving closer in recent months. In Jerusalem, Shamir said in response to the proposal: ``On the subject of the Persian Gulf, yes.'' He continued: ``We have our position about an international conference around the solution of the Israeli-Arab conflict. We will not participate in such an international conference.'' Israel has vehemently opposed Soviet ideas to hold an international conference to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict. Ignatenko, while declining to disclose what proposals Gorbachev might make at the summit, read a statement saying that: ``The president of the U.S.S.R. attaches great importance to the forthcoming Helsinki meeeting.'' ``Mikhail Gorbachev will use this meeting as a continuation of contacts to maintain the spirit of the Malta meeting, and the Washington meeting,'' he said referring to summits last December and June. ``It is going to be a working meeting to discuss a great host of international topics and bilateral relations,'' he said. Gorbachev and Shevardnadze are to travel to Helsinki on Saturday evening and return on Sunday night said Ignatenko, denying rumors the summit might last an additional day. The two leaders will address a joint news conference at the conclusion of their talks, he said. ``The agenda of the meeting will include discussions of the crisis in the Persian Gulf. The president of the U.S.S.R. and the Soviet leadership have their own information about state of affairs in the Persian Gulf area and this issue is under discussion with leaders of the Persian Gulf and Arab states, as well as Western European countries with whom we maintain ... close relationships,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Receives Highest Rating from Bar Association Screening Panel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 4-5, The president, with White House reaction.
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter today received the highest rating from the American Bar Association's judicial screening panel, the Justice Department said. Souter received a unanimous ``well qualified'' rating from the American Bar Association's Standing Committee on Federal Judiciary, according to a letter from the panel to the Justice Department. Souter, a former member of the New Hampshire Supreme Court, was nominated by President Bush in July for the vacancy created by the retirement of Justice William Brennan. ``The president is pleased to receive this news and looks forward to a speedy confirmation,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. ``We'd like to see hearings start as soon as possible, and hopefully, he'll be in place for the new court,'' Fitzwater added. Souter received a similar ``well qualified'' rating earlier this year when he was nominated for a seat on the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston. He took the federal bench last spring but has not heard any cases. The 15-member ABA committee rates judicial nominees either ``not qualified,'' ``qualified'' or ``well qualified'' but applies different standards to evaluate candidates for district, appellate and Supreme Court judgeships. The Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to open hearings on Souter's nomination on Sept. 13. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh hailed the ABA's decision, saying it confirmed that ``President Bush has selected a man of superb intellect and qualifications. ``I look forward to a speedy confirmation by the United States Senate,'' Thornburgh said. In 1987, four members of the ABA panel dissented from the committee's finding that Judge Robert Bork was ``well qualified'' for the Supreme Court. These members found Bork, then a federal appellate judge, to be ``not qualified'' for the high court while a fifth member voted ``not opposed'' to Bork's confirmation. Bork's nomination was turned down by the Senate following a bitter fight led by a coalition of civil rights and abortion rights activists.

DOC.HEAD: Chiles' Bid for Florida Governor Nomination Tops Primary Slate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Florida polls close at 7 p.m. EDT; Nevada at 10 p.m. EDT; material below the dash will stand.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Nevada Primary
LaserPhotos TP1; MLB1
DOC.TEXT: Former Sen. Lawton Chiles, who quit politics saying he was burned out but then launched a comeback attacking big-money politics, sought Florida's Democratic gubernatorial nomination Tuesday against Rep. Bill Nelson. Republican Gov. Bob Martinez, showing a dramatic comeback in recent polls, faced four GOP challengers led by state Sen. Marlene Woodson Howard. Martinez needed more than 50 percent of the primary vote to avoid a runoff. In Nevada, Acting Gov. Bob Miller, who inherited his job without being elected two years ago, was heavily favored over five Democratic challengers. Eight Republicans competed for the gubernatorial nomination, led by Jim Gallaway, a relative newcomer to the state who said Miller had shown ``a total lack of leadership.'' Heading to a general election both parties consider a political watershed for Florida, voters also faced primaries for four state Cabinet races that included impeached former federal judge Alcee Hastings' bid for the Democratic nomination to oppose Republican incumbent Secretary State Jim Smith. Hastings, removed from the bench by U.S. Senate trial after he was acquitted by a jury of bribery charges, faced ex-Klansman John Paul Rogers and former newspaperman Jim Minter. Two counties had controversial referendums. In Broward County, voters were considering whether to approve an ordinance protecting homosexuals against discrimination. In Sarasota, voters were deciding whether to order a two-year moratorium on growth.

Republicans have been on a roll in Florida, giving George Bush his biggest vote total in 1988, electing Republican Connie Mack to replace Chiles as senator, and grabbing an unprecedented 11-8 lead in the congressional delegation. Democrats said Martinez, whose negative ratings have been high, offered them a chance to turn things around. But a statewide television blitz emphasizing Martinez as a law-and-order governor and family man helped him move to nearly even with Chiles in polls released last week. Republicans hope to hold the governor's mansion and grab command of the state Senate in November, putting them in position to control redistricting in 1992 that will include at least three new congressional seats in this fast-growing state. Chiles, 60, said he entered the race last April because he felt the campaign was being dominated by big money. He voluntarily limited donations to $100 each, rejected political action committee contributions, and said he took his inspiration from Eastern Europe's revolutions. Chiles said rejecting big money will allow him to govern unencumbered by special interests, and he hoped the movement could spread nationally. But Chiles, a moderate with one of the highest reputations in politics for ethics, was dogged by questions about his mental health. He retired from the Senate when his third term ended in January 1989, saying he was burned out. At the time he was chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. He later was diagnosed as depressed and began using the drug Prozac. He stopped using it early in his campaign, but resumed taking the anti-depressant last month. His running mate is Kenneth ``Buddy'' MacKay, former three-term congressman who narrowly lost to Mack in 1988. Nelson, 47, claimed to have more energy and vision to lead the state. The Melbourne congressman, known for a 1986 space shuttle mission, began planning his gubernatorial bid nearly three years ago. He was the Democratic front-runner until Chiles' surprise entry in April. Initial polls gave Chiles a 50-point or more lead over Nelson, but the congressman came back with an aggressive effort that claimed Chiles was too vague, lacked energy, and wasn't as pure on ethics as believed. Nelson's campaign suffered a late setback when his running mate, state House Speaker Tom Gustafson, was widely criticized and finally apologized after suggesting Chiles might be suicidal. Martinez, 55, only Florida's second Republican governor since Reconstruction, was hurt his first year by backing a sales services tax he later helped repeal. He also stirred controversy last year by calling a special legislative session for what turned out to be an unsuccessful effort to further restrict abortion. Chiles and Nelson favored abortion rights, as did Martinez opponent Woodson Howard. The Broward referendum was opposed by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Miami and by critics who warned its passage would bring more gays and AIDS to the country. In Sarasota, supporters said a two-year moratorium on new structures would give time to improve services and address other problems of growth; opponents said a halt would put thousands out of work and damage the economy.

DOC.HEAD: Two Inmates Captured After Breaking Out of Prison Where Noriega is Held
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with details of capture, show that car was not used; picks up 8th graf pvs, ``Many inmates...'' ^By TRACY FIELDS
DOC.TEXT: Two inmates at the prison where Manuel Noriega is being held dodged bullets to scale a fence and escape through the woods behind the institution, but they were captured early today, a prison officer said. The ousted Panamanian dictator, under constant watch by a guard posted outside his specially built cell at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center, wasn't involved. Omar Fernandez of Miami and Charles Carew of Brockton, Mass., were spotted climbing a fence late Monday night, said prison spokesman Charles Davis. ``Our perimeter patrolman fired on the inmates and claims he hit one on the shoulder,'' Davis said. Police and prison authorities surrounded the complex and searched with dogs and with helicopters, one of them equipped with infrared lights for night vision. Prison officials said the two were traveling together but were captured separately on foot about 3 miles from the prison about 3:30 this morning. The dogs first tracked down Carew, 28, on a four-lane road southeast of the institution, but Fernandez, 24, got away, said associate warden Mike Stone. An hour later, police found Fernandez about two blocks away in a small subdivision, Stone said. The two escapees suffered minor cuts from the prison's razor wire and one was bitten by a dog, Stone said. Carew, awaiting trial on cocaine possession charges, and Fernandez, charged in a bank robbery, apparently intended to make off in a sports car police believe was left for them in the prison parking lot with the keys inside. But the car would not start, authorities said. Many inmates at the medium-security prison 25 miles from Miami are allowed relative freedom inside the wooded, 48-acre compound. The prison was built for 425 inmates but now holds more than 1,100. Last year, security was tightened after an unsuccessful helicopter escape bid by drug smuggler Barry Kramer. The pilot and Kramer, a former powerboat racing champion serving life without parole, were injured when the chopper crashed into the exercise yard fence on takeoff. Since 1981, there have been three successful escapes from the prison, Davis said. One prisoner, wearing makeup and his wife's clothes, walked out the door with visitors. Another, caught two years later, hung onto the undercarriage of a bookmobile. The third inmate briefly made it out hiding in a trash bin. He narrowly escaped being crushed.

DOC.HEAD: Better Mousetrap? Nah, Better Spitballs
DOC.TEXT: Class clowns around the country are returning to school armed with a new tool for teacher torture: ``Spit Wads,'' a high-tech version of the old-fashioned spitball. ``You can't stand in the way of progress,'' inventor Ted Skup said, tongue in cheek. ``It sounds simple, but try developing one,'' said Skup, who created the wads after a year's worth of sticky, slippery research. So what does this invention mean to the average underachieving student with $1.29 to spend? No more telltale straws or messy clumps of unused, well-chewed paper, for one thing, because you don't spit ``Spit Wads,'' you toss them. You get a quarter-ounce of a light blue non-toxic compound, enough for several traditional-size spitballs. The material is described as a polymeric improvement on the original spitball that won't stain when stuck. ``I threw a lot of stuff at the walls which never came off when I was developing this,'' said Skup, 38, of Schererville, Ind. ``There's still a lot of marks on my wall.'' Skup came up with the idea during a lunch break from his job as a refinery worker. After a year's worth of experiments with every glue, paste and adhesive he could find, Skup produced the space-age spitballs and trademarked the ``Spit Wads'' name for the gum-like clumps. ``I was lucky to get that,'' he said proudly. ``That's my own personal trademark for the next 20 years.'' Skup brought his creation to an old soccer-playing buddy, soon-to-be financial backer Scott Hicko. Both vividly recall that day of destiny this past March. ``Once I threw it against the wall and it stuck, I sold him. You don't need a big presentation when the guy starts laughing for an hour,'' said Skup. ``I've seen products all my life, been in business for 20 years, and seen a lot of gimmicks. Something hit me with this _ nostalgia, maybe the old troublemaker in me,'' said Hicko. Hicko is not the only one with a misspent youth; Skup quickly announces he was voted class clown in high school. Both were surprised the product has been as popular among adults as with children. ``It touches something in everybody. Everybody knows what a spit wad is,'' said Hicko. ``I mean, we thought our market was 7 to 12 year olds. We go into corporate offices and they go nuts _ everybody is flicking 'em at pictures of the boss.'' Groups dedicated to policing the school system said it was too soon to assess the impact of the spitball of the '90s. ``This is the first we've heard of this. We'd have to get a little more information,'' said Stacey Moore, spokeswoman for the National Parents & Teachers Association. ``I sure can't recall any product like that.'' But Skup is hopeful his product will soon become as popular as the Pet Rock or the mood ring. ``There hasn't been a good fad in a really long time. I mean, Bart Simpson and the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles?'' asked Skup. ``We're hoping to jump in with something really off the wall.''

DOC.HEAD: FDR's Yacht Restored as Floating Museum
DOC.TEXT: President Franklin D. Roosevelt's yacht, often called ``the floating White House,'' is on its way to becoming a floating museum. The 165-foot Potomac has had numerous owners, including Elvis Presley. It once chased Prohibition rum runners and finally was docked for alleged drug trafficking. Now, it's being restored by the Potomac Association for the latest owner, the Port of Oakland, with careful attention to detail. ``It has to be as close as possible to what the president had,'' said Syrell Sapoznick, a spokeswoman for the association. Project manager Dan Holdgate has the paneling to the pilot house in his garage where he works on it during evenings and weekends. He spent 200 hours refurbishing a dish rack of Honduran mahogany and when a search for special hand cranks came up dry, Holdgate made them himself and had them chromed. ``There's nobody else to do it,'' Holdgate said. Paul Harless, a Navy veteran who served as a petty officer on the Potomac from 1940 to 1942, is the source of much detail. He even recalled the size of the sandbox for FDR's dog Fala: 18 inches high, 3 feet square and filled two-thirds with sand. ``The dog had the run of the ship, but it wasn't a favorite of the crew,'' Harless said. The boat originally served as a Coast Guard cutter, and pursued liquor smugglers. Congressmen and heads of state met with Roosevelt on the ship after he took it as his personal yacht in 1936. He broadcast one of his fireside chats from the ship. It also served as a personal retreat for Roosevelt, an avid fisherman and former assistant secretary of the Navy who called boats his avocation. The state of Maryland bought it for use by its governor at the end of World War II and it later went into private ownership. In 1980, it was linked to drug trafficking and seized by the Customs Service. While impounded at Treasure Island, the boat hit pilings and sank in about 30 feet of water. The Port of Oakland bought it for $15,000 in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Westerners Arrive From Baghdad Aboard Iraqi Planes
DOC.TEXT: Scores of Western nationals, including 135 West Germans, arrived in the Jordanian capital today aboard two Iraqi Airways jetliners. The first flight, which landed at Queen Alia International airport, brought 170 foreigners, mostly Arabs and Asians. There was one Englishwoman among them, Georgina Rose, with her two children, Jemeela, 18 months, and Sheherazade, 6 months. Rose is married to an Iraqi citizen. The second plane, which landed two hours later, had 135 West Germans, plus some New Zealanders, Irishmen and some other Western citizens, according to airport officials. A British embassy official said 45 Britons were expected on a third flight. A U.S. Embassy spokesman said there would also be a number of Americans on the plane, but added that he was not sure how many. The arriving westerners were taken immediately to the airport transit lounge and reporters were not allowed to speak to them. Airport officials told him that they would leave for Frankfurt, West Germany later in the day on a Lufthansa jetliner. Earlier today, a British-organized convoy of about 300 women and children left Kuwait to drive across the desert to Baghdad, and authorities said a planeload of Westerners might be allowed to leave for Jordan on a U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways flight. Meanwhile, Iraqi authorities said the United States was to blame if captive foreigners went hungry as a result of food shortages caused by the international economic sanctions against Iraq. Iraq has said that Western women and children trapped by the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait will be permitted to leave, but Western men are being used as human shields to protect Iraqi installations against potential attack. More than 700 Western hostages _ women, children and a few ailing men _ have left, but the departures of others have been complicated by Iraq's refusal to allow foreign airlines to land in Baghdad and by long delays in processing their exit permits by Iraqi authorities. About 11,000 Westerners are now believed stranded in Kuwait and Iraq. Some evacuees have traveled across the desert to Jordan in the scorching summer heat. The British-organized convoy left Kuwait at dawn today, British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd told reporters in Ta'if, Saudi Arabia, where he was meeting with the deposed Kuwaiti government. They were headed for Baghdad in seven buses and a car, he said, and hoped to travel out of Iraq from there. The foreign secretary said 148 women and 150 children were on the 500-mile trip. In Britain, William Waldegrave, the second-ranking official in the Foreign Office, put the figure at 148 women and 155 children. A Foreign Office spokesman said later that the convoy had been organized for British citizens, but it was not known whether some people of other nationalities were traveling with the group. The Foreign Office had estimated earlier that the bus convoy would take 10 to 12 hours to reach Baghdad. Waldegrave, however, noted that a previous convoy from Kuwait needed 28 hours to complete its journey. ``Our hopes are that we can then get exit visas for them and probably, on what the Iraqis are saying at the moment, we would have to hire an Iraqi airplane perhaps to fly them to Amman, or perhaps straight home if we can,'' Waldegrave said in an interview with BBC radio. A Virgin Atlantic Boeing 747 arrived today in Amman, carrying relief supplies for Jordan, which has been overwhelmed by a human tide of Asian and Arab refugees from Iraq and Kuwait. In Jordan, the flight was to pick up 150 British citizens and 250 Egyptians who had left Iraq and Kuwait, the airline said. It was not clear when those people had gotten out of Iraq. West Germany said 98 of its stranded women and children have arrived in Baghdad after an overland trip from Kuwait on Monday. Twenty-four Italians also made it by road to Baghdad, where sharp shortages in food supplies were reported in recent days. Iraqi authorities say foreigners are sharing the deprivations imposed on Iraqis because of the U.N.'s economic sanctions against Iraq. An Iraqi Foreign Ministry spokesman said thousands of expatriates were going hungry because of the food shortages. The official Iraqi News Agency quoted the spokesman as saying a number of foreign governments had asked to send food to their nationals trapped in Iraq, but that they were prevented from doing so by the United States ``which is insisting on tightening its inhuman blockade.'' ``Therefore, we deem it necessary to explain that Iraq is in no way responsible for the starvation of these people as the United States shoulders full responsibility for their agony,'' the unidentified spokesman said. The dispatch was monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus.

DOC.HEAD: Deborah Norville Says She's Pregnant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to include writethru designation. LEADS with one graf to CORRECT time element.
DOC.TEXT: ``Today'' co-host Deborah Norville told viewers this morning that she's pregnant and her baby is due in March.
