Norville, who in January became Bryant Gumbel's co-host on the NBC show, is married to Karl Wellner, a Swedish businessman who is in the auction business, according to NBC. Norville, 32, didn't say how long she planned to continue working, or how much time she might take away from the show after her child is born. The ``Today'' show has been struggling in the morning ratings, and NBC revamped the program in June by adding Joe Garagiola, Faith Daniels and Katie Couric to the team of Norville, Gumbel, Willard Scott and Gene Shalit. Norville was added to the lineup last summer in a series of changes that led to the departure of co-host Jane Pauley in December. The network announced Friday that Garagiola would be off for four weeks to have elective surgery for an undisclosed medical problem.

DOC.HEAD: More Foreigners Flown Out of Iraq; Baghdad Demands Food for Foreigners
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with two flights carrying foreigners arriving in Amman. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has asked Western countries whose citizens it holds to urgently send food for them, increasing concern that Saddam Hussein may not intend to free all remaining women and children hostages as promised. The request was yet another sign that Iraq is feeling the crunch from the trade embargo ordered by the United Nations after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Iraq also suspended payments on its foreign debt on Monday. More Westerners made it out of Iraq today. Two Iraqi Airways jetliners carried in Amman. The first flight brought mostly Arabs and Asians, but one Englishwoman and her two children were aboard. The second plane carried 135 West Germans, plus some New Zealanders, Irishmen and some other Western citizens, according to airport officials. A British embassy official said 45 Britons were expected on a third flight. A U.S. Embassy spokesman said there would also be a number of Americans on the plane, but added that he was not sure how many. In the Persian Gulf waters, meanwhile, U.S. Coast Guardsmen boarded the Iraqi-flagged freighter Zanoobia in the Gulf of Oman today in line with the tightening embargo on Iraqi trade, naval and shipping sources said. It would be the first reported case of U.S. forces boarding an Iraqi-flagged vessel since the U.N. embargo was imposed on Iraq last month. Also today, Jordan's crown prince criticized the international community for doing little to help thousands of Asian refugees from Iraq and Kuwait, some of whom are dying from exposure in a squalid makeshift camp in the desert while they await transport home. In the Soviet Union, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze proposed an international conference on the gulf crisis that would also take up the Arab-Israeli conflict and the civil war in Lebanon. In a major foreign policy address, Shevardnadze also said Sunday's superpower summit in Helsinki, Finland, would mark ``a major milestone on the road toward resolving the crisis in the Persian Gulf.'' In another development, Iraq suggested setting up an international ``people's court'' to try President Bush for defiling Islam and for human rights violations. The state-run Iraqi News Agency said today the idea was discussed by the nation's union for lawyers and human rights association. The West looked in vain over the weekend for large-scale, follow-up flights after hundreds of Western and Japanese women and children were allowed to leave on Iraqi jetliners on Saturday. But a convoy carrying about 300 British women and children left Kuwait City just after dawn heading for Baghdad, where they hoped to continue overland to Jordan or fly home via Amman, British officials said. Some of the evacuees have acted as human shields at strategic Iraqi sites on orders of Saddam, who last week said women and children would be allowed to leave. About 3,000 Americans _ a third of them women and children _ were among 21,000 Westerners initially trapped in Iraq and Kuwait by the invasion. On Monday, the Iraqi News Agency quoted remarks made by Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, to President Cornelio Sommaruga of the International Committee of the Red Cross regarding foreigners inside Iraq. ``Suffering as it is from the effects of the international siege, Iraq will not be responsible for their suffering resulting from the shortages in food supplies,'' Aziz said. He urged countries with large number of citizens in Iraq to ``take urgent measures'' to send those citizens food supplies. Iraq rescinded landing rights for foreign charters into Iraq to pick up foreign nationals, and some sources said Baghdad was seeking to swap hostages for trade, apparently in an attempt to poke holes in the embargo. Japan's Kyodo News Service said Iraq was asking Tokyo to bend the embargo in exchange for freeing Japanese hostages. In Paris, the Foreign Ministry indicated Iraq had set conditions unacceptable to France in return for landing rights that would allow a French plane to repatriate 200 women and children. In Baghdad earlier today, Western diplomats were negotiated frantically with officials at Iraq's Interior and Foreign Ministries to obtain exit permits for a group of 138 foreign women and children who want to leave on the Iraqi Airways flight, diplomatic sources and airline officials reported. One Western diplomatic source said 24 Americans are among those trying to leave on that flight. The others are Britons, Canadians, Italians, French and Irish nationals, he said, but could not provide a breakdown. In Baghdad, an official at the U.S. Embassy said the Iraqi pane was chartered by the U.S. government. Late Monday, an Iraqi Airways jumbo jet carrying Iraqis stranded in Britain by the crisis left London for Baghdad. An airline official said 195 passengers were aboard. More than 100,000 Asians _ Indians, Sri Lankans, Bangladeshis, Thais and Filipinos _ remain stranded in Jordan. Some are stuck in a squalid, makeshift camp in the no man's land just inside Jordan because authorities at the border post of Ruweishid, swamped by the human tide, has not been able to process them. Crown Prince Hassan, brother of King Hussein, today appealed for immediate aid. ``We should not forget that the situation, critical as it is, may be only the tip of the iceberg,'' he told a news conference. On Monday, the Iraqi News Agency quoted Mohammed Mahdi Saleh, acting minister of commerce and finance, as saying Iraq had suspended payments on its foreign debt, estimated at $30 billion to $35 billion. Most of that is owed to the United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union, West Germany and Japan for purchases of weapons, technology and food. The news agency quoted Saleh as saying the debt suspension would have adverse effects on countries and companies ``incapable of withstanding the current situation.'' He was referring to the economic woes faced by poorer countries that count on trade with Iraq to generate critical foreign exchange. Also Monday, President Bush ended his often-interrupted, 3-week-long vacation in Maine, and returned to Washington to prepare for the hurriedly arranged summit on Sunday with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The Persian Gulf crisis will be a major item on the agenda. Bush summoned his Cabinet for a briefing on the crisis, and two congressional teams ended a first-hand look at the situation in the region. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze today urged the formation of an international conference on the Persian Gulf crisis and said Israel's attendance would be important, the official Soviet news agency, Tass said. Shevardnadze, speaking in Vladivostok on his way to Japan, said Moscow could reconsider Soviet-Israeli relations if Israel agreed to join such a conference, Tass said. The Soviets severed diplomatic ties with Israel after the 1967 Middle East war. Secretary of State James A. Baker III is expected in Saudi Arabia on Friday for talks with officials of the Kuwaiti government-in-exile. The talks probably will focus on the cost to the United States of the military operation. The U.S. treasury secretary, Nicholas Brady, was to set out on a similar mission today _ with Paris, London, Seoul and Tokyo as destinations. The United States has deployed about 60,000 troops and dozens of fighter planes in Saudi Arabia, mostly along the border with Iraq and Kuwait in response to a perceived Iraqi threat. There is also a growing international naval armada in the region. Besides Saudi Arabia, several smaller Persian Gulf states are allowing the United States to base combat aircraft on their soil. Bahrain, Oman, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar have shed a traditional reluctance for close military ties with America, Pentagon sources said Monday. In a related development, Turkey's government said Monday it will seek parliamentary approval to send troops abroad and allow foreign troops to be stationed in Turkey.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Arrested Connection with 1986 Disco Bombing
DOC.TEXT: Police have arrested an Arab on suspicion of complicity in the 1986 bombing of the La Belle disco that killed two U.S. soldiers and one Turkish woman, a justice official said today. Cornel Christoffel, spokesman for the West Berlin judicial authorities, said that a man he identified only as Ali C. had been detained in East Berlin on Aug. 27 on suspicion of aiding and abetting murder. The powerful early-morning blast April 5, 1986 in the packed disco, a popular night spot with U.S. solders stationed in West Berlin, also left more than 200 injured. The bombing led to the U.S. air raid on Tripoli and Benghazi in Libya, after U.S. officials claimed that Libya was involved in the brutal attack.

DOC.HEAD: Officer's Name Tag Deflects Bullet
DOC.TEXT: An off-duty policeman was caught in a drive-by shooting, but escaped with only a scrape when his name tag deflected a bullet. Officer Thomas Thompson was working as a security guard in a bar. A car drove by and he noticed a passenger roll down a window and begin firing a pistol at a group of people outside the bar. Thompson tried to close the bar's front door and was hit a glancing blow in the chest by a bullet. But the bullet ricocheted off his metal and plastic name tag, said police spokesman Steve Cole. He suffered only a scrape. ``I think that little name tag helped him. It took some of the impact out,'' said Police Officer Luis Hernandez, who was working as a guard Sunday with Thompson. Another man suffered a leg wound. A man and a juvenile were charged with two counts each of attempted first-degree murder.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Forces Join Arab Maneuvers
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Kuwaiti army brigade started maneuvers Tuesday with other Arab forces deployed in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait's defense minister said. The minister, Sheik Nawaf Al-Ahmed al-Sabah, said several thousand more troops from the Iraqi-occupied emirate, along with air force and navy units, will join Operation Desert Shield in the next few weeks. He said Kuwait had not put its forces on alert before Saddam Hussein's tanks invaded Aug. 2 because the government had been lulled by Iraqi assurances no invasion was imminent. Had they been on alert, Kuwait's 20,300-member armed forces could probably have held out for about four days, he said. As it was, the Kuwaitis were overwhelmed within hours. Sheik Nawaf said Kuwait was fielding about 7,000 troops. Half of those started maneuvers Tuesday with the joint Arab-Islamic forces under the command of Lt. Gen. Khaled Bin Sultan of Saudi Arabia. The rest are with the Gulf Cooperation Council's rapid deployment force known as Peninsula Shield based in northern Saudi Arabia. The GCC is made up of Saudi Arabia, Oman, Bahrain, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait's government-in-exile, which has set up headquarters in Saudi Arabia. Sheik Nawaf said a team of French technicians was expected in the kingdom soon with spare parts for the Kuwaiti air force's 15 surviving Mirage F-1 jet fighters. The fighters scrambled the morning of the invasion and flew to Saudi Arabia after engaging Iraqi forces, he said. Kuwait lost 13 military aircraft _ eight Mirages, two helicopters and three A-4 Skyhawk ground-attack fighters _ during the invasion because they were in maintenance hangers when Iraqi warplanes bombed the air base at Kuwait City, the minister said. He said a number of Skyhawks were with Kuwaiti forces in Saudi Arabia and will join the Mirages under Saudi command. Kuwait had 24 A-4s before the invasion. Other ministers said 24 Kuwaiti helicopter gunships and transports were taken out of the emirate. Most of the Kuwaiti navy, which consists of eight fast attack boats with anti-ship missiles and a score of coastal patrol boats, escaped. They will join the swelling armada in the Persian Gulf region preventing cargo ships from breaking U.N. economic sanctions against Iraq. Sheik Nawaf said about 200 Kuwaiti military men were captured in the invasion, most of them enlisted men. He gave no casualty figures. Iraq poured about 10 percent of its 1 million-member army over the border and now has 170,000 troops in Kuwait, he said. At the time of the invasion, only 25 percent of the Kuwaiti armed forces were on duty because the attack came on a Thursday _ the start of the Moslem weekend. ``I felt sad. I wished I'd been ready,'' Sheik Nawaf said.

DOC.HEAD: Students Take Novel Approach to Holiday Weekend
DOC.TEXT: They sat down to computer terminals at 6 p.m. Friday and 48 hours and thousands of sentences later they got up, proud authors of embryo novels. The seven participants in the First Annual Labor Day Weekend Writing Marathon could boast that they spent the end of their summer vacation by writing a book _ or at least a rough draft. ``It was way past my wildest expectations,'' Westfield State College English professor Stephen Sossaman said Tuesday. ``We had seven students who took the project very seriously for the entire 48 hours. They really didn't do anything but write, except for occasional naps.'' The novel activity, designed to give students a chance to unleash their creativity, was inspired by a contest Sossaman read about in which professional writers competed against each other to turn out a book in a weekend. Three women and four men showed up at Bates Hall with sleeping bags, toothbrushes, change for pizza, computer discs and imaginations. They didn't bring notes or outlines. Sossaman suggested that they each pick a genre to help them get going, such as horror or science fiction. ``I thought a genre novel is a lot easier to write than the great American novel,'' he said. For hours at a stretch the clacking of keyboards was the only sound in the room. ``It's hard to describe how energizing this experience is even though the sleeping was a bit tough,'' Sossaman said in a telephone interview. Sophomore J.A. Marshall, who got started with the sentence ``He put on the dark black gloves and stared at himself in the mirror,'' said he switched from science-fiction to a psychodrama while tapping out his novel outline. ``It was a wonderful experience. We were able to have such a great block of time to throw into a project,'' he said. ``The thing was, you'd start to run out, you'd come to a point where the fear would start in, the writer's block would start in and you'd look around you and you'd see everybody else was still going,'' he said. When it was all over at 6 p.m. Sunday, each one ``more or less'' had a novel outline. Sossaman had just about finished a pulp novel on Vietnam combat. ``Everyone wrote quite a bit. No one expressed disappointment. Obviously you can't write a novel in a weekend, but they made some progress,'' he said. Sophomore Angela Collette, who almost finished an untitled novel tracing the history of two girls growing up, said she didn't regret giving up any beach time. ``You've had all summer to lie by the pool,'' she said. ``I meant to write this summer instead of just wasting away.'' Students and Sossaman said they hope to be back next year. ``Some people think I was crazy to do this but ... I like the idea of creative intensity,'' Sossaman said.

DOC.HEAD: American Workers' Productivity Rebounds 1.5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The productivity of American workers improved for the first time in more than a year, climbing in the second quarter at an annual rate of 1.5 percent, the government said Tuesday. However, analysts said the rebound was still well below the level needed to significantly boost Americans' living standard. In addition, figures showing steep labor cost increases heightened analysts' concerns that the nation's inflation problems are worsening, especially in light of the Middle East oil crisis that threatens to push inflation higher. ``It exacerbates the situation, no question about it,'' said Elliott Platt of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. ``Even before the Iraqi situation, the U.S. economy was facing an entrenched, underlying labor cost inflation of between 4 and 5 percent. That doesn't allow for any profits,'' added Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. The 1.5 percent rise in non-farm productivity _ defined as output per hour of work _ was the first increase since productivity climbed 0.5 percent in the final three months of 1988, the Labor Department said. The rebound was a departure from productivity's poor performance in recent months. Productivity declined 0.3 percent last year, the worst showing since output fell 0.9 percent during the 1981-82 recession. It had plunged 1.9 percent during the first quarter of this year, the government said. During the April-June period this year, there was no increase in the number of hours worked. Sinai called that a sign that employers weren't hiring new workers or letting employees work more hours. ``The productivity increase is being eked out by squeezing down on labor,'' Sinai said. ``It still shows an anemic performance for U.S. productivity growth. What businesses are doing in light of ... an anticipated recession is to cut back on jobs and hours worked.'' Hourly labor costs, a major inflation measure for businesses, shot up at an annual rate of 5.8 percent for the second quarter of 1990, far above the 3 percent rise for all of 1989. Meanwhile, unit labor costs, a key gauge of future price inflation, rose 4.3 percent for the second quarter, compared with a 3.3 percent rise during all of 1989. Increased productivity, or getting each worker to produce more for each hour he or she works, is vital to increasing Americans' standard of living without inflation, many economists believe. Tuesday's report provided revised figures on the second quarter of 1990. The 1.5 percent revised increase was slightly below the 1.6 percent increase first reported by the Labor Department. In the manufacturing sector, productivity increased 4 percent, or double the 2 percent rise for all of 1989, Tuesday's report said. Unit labor costs in that sector rose 2.2 percent, the same as the 2.2 percent increase during all of last year. Total business productivity, including farming, rose 1.7 percent for the second quarter, compared with a 0.2 percent drop for all of 1989. Since 1982, productivity growth has averaged 1.4 percent a year, a slight improvement over the 1.2 percent average growth rate in the 1970s but far below the 3.3 percent rate of increase posted in the two decades after World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Sun And Sand Take Toll On U.S. Gear
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.DATELINE: EAGLE FORWARD BASE CAMP, Saudi Arabia (AP)
DOC.TEXT: The harsh conditions of the Saudi desert are taking a toll on U.S. military equipment, affecting simple mechanical gear as well as sensitive high-tech equipment, from M-16 rifles to weapons guidance systems. The warships patrolling the waters around the Arabian peninsula are also have problems, officers and maintenance crews said. ``When you buy a stereo, what do the instructions say?'' Marine Gunnery Sgt. Tate Ingles of Miami asked during a recent interview. ``They say you should keep it away from heat, dust and vibration. You put the same electrical gear in the Saudi desert, and, well, there you have it.'' Because of the heat and sand, weapons systems that rely on sensitive electronics and computers could be troublesome to operate if extended hostilities broke out, technicians say. At Eagle Forward, a base camp for Apache gunships and other helicopters of the 101st Airborne Division's air assault brigade, the soft Saudi sand blown by the desert wind is the big headache. ``It's unbelievable. It gets everywhere,'' a maintenance crew member said. Crews are flushing out the Apache engines with water every day to rid them of the sand. The powdery sand also finds its way into transmissions and gears that turn the rotors, forcing more frequent maintenance on those systems as well. ``Hovering around in the desert is going to be very hard on the engines,' said Maj. Greg Maisel, of Laredo, Texas, the executive officer of a Marine attack squadron. Helicopters are being fitted with radiator filters much like the black wraps often seen on fronts of sports cars. ``We were having a lot of overheating problems because of sand clogging the radiators,'' squadron leader Lt. Col. Don Cody said. ``We think the filters have fixed that.'' The sand scours the paint from rotor blades, exposing metal that glints in the sun, making the helicopters easier to spot. Sand is the reason the Air Force is cutting the time between its routine maintenance. Tests and routine adjustments made every 100 hours are now being done every 60-75 hours, an air force official said. One persistent problem is sand clogging air-intake valves of jet engines. Much like the Apaches, the engines of Air Force and Navy planes, on the ground and aboard carriers, are being flushed with water daily. A Marine sergeant cleaning his automatic rifle noted: ``Sometimes I'm not sure it would fire if I needed it to. We train in the desert, but I've never seen anything like this.'' Tanks need more frequent filter cleanings and track flushing and higher viscosity oil. Radiators need to be checked constantly to prevent overheating. The sand cakes on headlights and windshields and can get into the fuel supply if proper care is not taken. Weapons systems protected from the sand can't escape the scorching sun. Within days of arriving here, 82nd Airborne units were reporting dead radios because wires were burned out or fused by the heat. One officer in the division said Monday that parts for the radios and other equipment being damaged are getting hard to come by. ``We're short quite a few things,'' said the officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``I'm sure we'll get them eventually.'' Meantime, ingenuity is helping. On Tuesday, two 82nd soldiers were at a Safeway supermarket in a Saudi town, cleaning it out of sponges and cloth. A vehicle containing several TOW anti-tank missiles and other weapons exploded at an 82nd motor pool Monday and the men suspect heat was a factor. The equipment problems are frustrating, but the maintenance crews try to keep a sense of humor. ``Some officer says, `Hey, my radio don't work,''' Ingles said. ``I tell him: `Sir, if you'd been sitting out here under a magnifying glass in 130-degree temperatures all day, you wouldn't work either.'''

DOC.HEAD: Solar Plane Has Its Ups and Downs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5, `It's really...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with pilot's comments.
DOC.TEXT: The pilot of the first aircraft to fly from California to the East Coast using solar power today called off his attempt to complete his trip by flying to the site of the first powered flight. Northeast wind in excess of 20 mph forced Eric Raymond to cancel plans to fly his ultralight craft the remaining nine miles from the farm where he landed Monday to the First Flight Airport next to the Wright Brothers Memorial at Kitty Hawk. After announcing his plans, Raymond and his wife, Aida, went windsurfing. Reached later by phone, Raymond said wind gusting to 35 mph Tuesday was ``five times too much'' to fly in. He said he feels ``great'' at having completed the transcontinental trip. ``I don't see the significance of flying the last nine miles,'' he said. ``Tomorrow, he'll set up the plane for anybody who wants to see it and then head home to California,'' said Nancy McWilliams of Kitty Hawk Kites, a hang-gliding school and store that has been the headquarters for the final portion of the trip. Sam Raymond, the pilot's father, said he's glad to see the trip is over, although his son wanted to achieve his goal of flying to Kitty Hawk. ``There's a little bit of disappointment that he didn't get to the exact landing point that he wanted,'' the elder Raymond said. Raymond had frequently faced weather problems during his month-and-a-half trip. His aircraft, the Sun Seeker, depends on sunshine and favorable wind. Solar cells produce power for its electric motor, which is used for takeoffs and landings. After takeoff, the plane rides thermals, columns of rising warm air, like a glider. Weather forced Monday's landing at the farm near the small coastal town of Spot. ``No. 1, low visibility'' was the problem, said the elder Raymond. ``It got down as low as 600 feet and it was raining and a storm was building. The breezes from the ocean were actually pushing him back inland.'' Raymond, 33, first took off July 16 from Desert Center, Calif., about 200 miles east of Los Angeles, beginning his quest to prove an ultralight aircraft partly powered by solar energy could cross the United States. Two days after the journey began, the 198-pound craft was damaged in an aborted takeoff from Lordsburg, N.M. The Sun Seeker, Raymond and his ground crew returned to Lake Elsinore, Calif., for repairs. Raymond manufactured and sold hang-gliding equipment there until six months ago, when he devoted himself to the Sun Seeker project. The Sun Seeker had better luck after taking off again from Desert Center on Aug. 2. Raymond, a former national hang gliding champion, had hoped to reach his destination Sunday but was delayed by strong head wind. He logged only 18 miles Friday when he landed at Virginia Tech Airport at Blacksburg, Va., about 25 miles northwest of Roanoke, Va. Raymond flew 124 miles Sunday before landing in Currituck, in North Carolina's northeastern corner, said expedition spokesman Jack Whitehouse.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-South Africa, Bjt
President Greeted Warmly in Soweto
DOC.TEXT: Cries of ``Viva, de South Africa's president Tuesday when he made an unannounced trip to this sprawling black township southwest of Johannesburg. It was F.W. de Klerk's fir Klerk!' greetedst visit to Soweto since he became president last year. His predecessor, P.W. Botha, was the first South African head of government to enter the country's largest township, a traditional hotbed of black unrest. Since his inauguration, de Klerk has promoted reforms to end the apartheid system of racial segregation and has opened talks with the African National Congress on sharing power with the black majority. On Tuesday, he received a warm welcome in the townshsays Milt Berger, a public relations man who once worked for Steeplechase and now represents Astroland, Coney Island's only multiride park. And things got worse. When Steeplechase owner Frank Tilyou died in 1964, the heirs wrangled about Steeplechase's operation until, Berger says, ``for peace and harmony's sake'' they sold it. The buyer was developer Fred Trump, father of Donald. ``He wanted to put up some big seaside condo development,'' Berger said. Down came the pavilion of fun, and with it the end of a legend. But Trump couldn't get the building variance he needed to construct residential housing in an area zoned for amusement. The '60s rolled by and Steeplechase sat vacant. The city condemned it in 1969; after a court battle Trump reportedly received $4 million for the 12-acre parcel. About the same time, the city condemned blocks of red-brick bungalows once used as summer homes. With the '70s came plans to build public-housing projects. ``The city had this vision that they would round up a lot of low-income people from the city and bring them out to Coney Island, to this paradise,'' says developer Bullard, ``and that once here all of their problems would be over because they'd be in paradise.'' Tall, boxy buildings sprang up. Whites fled. Stores closed. The vacation trade died, nearly taking the entire community with it. When the urban renewal projects began, Mermaid Avenue was a thriving business center with over 400 retail stores. Today, there are 39. Coney Island, says Ann Weisbrod, vice president of the city's Public Development Corp., was ``the victim of government good intentions.'' Now the city has a new slate of plans to revive Coney Island, among them Bullard's proposed $350 million Steeplechase Park and a 14,000-seat Sportsplex to be used for college and high school events. The proposed new Steeplechase, covering 25 acres, would be a three-tier park with 65 major attractions, 14 theaters and a $3 million renovated version of the Parachute Jump. There are also plans to renovate the subway stop, repave local streets, rebuild bridges leading onto Coney Island and turn Stillwell Avenue into a pedestrian mall. The city has committed $20 million to the project. ``That's just about enough to build the parking garage,'' says Bullard. If all goes well, Steeplechase could open in 1993. If approved, the Sportsplex project, which is still in the development stage, could be operating by 1995. ``You'll never be able to recapture the glory days of old Coney Island,'' says state Sen. Marty Solomon, who represents the area. ``But these projects are giving an awful lot of hope to an area that hasn't had any for a long, long time.''

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Government Will Foot the Bill For Kuwaiti Exiles
With AM-Gulf-Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The deposed Kuwaiti government Tuesday promised to pay compensation to more than 150,000 of its citizens living in exile as a result of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Before the invasion on Aug. 2, Kuwaitis enjoyed one of the world's highest per capita incomes, estimated at about $20,000 a year. Despite the reported looting of Kuwait's financial institutions by Iraq, the oil-rich government that was led by Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah still has an estimated $100 billion in assets available to it outside the occupied nation. There are an estimated 150,000 Kuwaitis living in Saudi Arabia and the government-in-exile's official radio station reported Tuesday that Kuwaiti heads of families there will receive a monthly allowance of $320. Separate monthly payments of $160 will be provided to other family members above the age of 21, with half that amount going to those younger. In addition, families of five or less will get monthly housing allowances of $400, while those of more than five will get $530. Family heads will also receive a one-time cash payment of $1,330, said the radio announcement, broadcast from somewhere in Saudi Arabia. Kuwaiti exiles in other gulf countries will be paid according to the cost of living there. No mention was made of Kuwaitis living outside the Middle East. The emir and his government are now based in exile in the Saudi Arabian mountain resort town of Taif. They decided on the living subsidies at a Monday Cabinet meeting, the radio said. Prior to the Iraqi invasion, 1.8 million people lived in Kuwait, but only 800,000 were citizens of the nation. The remainder came from more than 100 nations to bolster the labor force. Most did menial jobs or worked in the construction industry. Foreigners also served with the military and police. The government announcement said if non-Kuwaiti military personnel are ``at the front,'' their families will receive a stipend of $450 a month. The same amount is being given to each Kuwaiti national on active duty in the military. Half of the 7,000 Kuwaiti troops that are still active are serving with a joint Arab-Islamic forces under Saudi commmand. The rest are part of the Gulf Cooperation Council's Rapid Deployment Force, also based in Saudi Arabia. The government announcement said Kuwaitis put up by the Saudi government in schools, stadiums and other public facilities had to move to permanent lodgings to become eligible for the allowances.

DOC.HEAD: Lawrence A. Cremin, Educational Historian, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Lawrence A. Cremin, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian who spent 23 years writing a definitive trilogy on American public education, died Tuesday. He was 64. Cremin died of a heart attack, according to a statement from Teachers College, Columbia University. Cremin, a New York City resident, was president of Teachers College from 1974 to 1984 and was the Frederick A.P. Barnard Professor of Education at the college. Since 1985, he was president of the Chicago-based Spencer Foundation, whose major priority is educational research. He was a member of the foundation's board of directors since 1973. Cremin also was a founding member of the National Academy of Education and served as its president from 1969-73. Cremin won the Pulitzer Prize for history in 1981 for ``American Education: The National Experience, 1783-1876,'' the second volume of a three-volume history of U.S. schools from colonial times through 1980. The final volume, ``American Education: The Metropolitan Experience 1876-1980,'' was published in 1988. His most recent work, published last spring, was ``Popular Education and Its Discontents,'' which offered philosophical answers to the question of how U.S. schools developed as they did. He argued that the current school crisis stems not so much from the ``mediocrity'' of schools or educators, but from outside forces that are overburdening schools with more and more demands. At the time of his death, Cremin had been working on a biography of educational pioneer John Dewey. Survivors include his wife, Charlotte, daughter Joanne of New York City and son David of Los Angeles. The funeral will be private. Plans for a memorial service will be announced later.

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates Fall
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in Tuesday's auction to their lowest level in several weeks. The Treasury Department sold $9.2 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.39 percent, down from 7.49 percent last week. Another $9.2 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.36 percent, down from 7.48 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.23 percent on Aug. 6, and six-month bills averaged 7.31 percent on Aug. 13. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.64 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,813.20 and 7.75 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,627.90. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 7.85 percent last week, down from 7.93 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: White House Still Hopes for $50 Billion Deficit Reduction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 1991 in last graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Tuesday it's still aiming for a $50 billion reduction in next year's deficit, but is willing to listen to proposals for a smaller target. Budget negotiators will resume their deliberations in private Friday at Andrews Air Force Base in suburban Washington, staying closeted there until Sunday in the hope of forging an agreement, said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``We still believe that we need to get a $50 billion reduction in the first year and $500 billion over five years,'' Fitzwater said. ``We still believe that deficit reduction is important, that it's crucial to maintaining economic growth.'' Some lawmakers have suggested the steep costs of the big U.S. military build-up in the Persian Gulf, as well as the impact of rising oil prices on an already sluggish economy, may force them to scale back the goal of trimming $50 billion from next year's deficit. ``We're willing to talk about it and that's what we're going to the table to do,'' Fitzwater said when asked about the possibility of a lower target. The White House, he said, will have a budget proposal to put on the table at Andrews and it expects the Democrats to do the same. Both sides need to face ``the hard decisions,'' Fitzwater said. The Democrat-led Congress opened talks with the White House in May on reducing the deficit, but the negotiations came to a temporary halt in early August with little progress evident. Bush agreed June 26 that ``tax revenue increases'' were necessary. But even after he broke his no-new-taxes vow and the Republicans tentatively pushed forward a package of tax increases, the Democrats refused to propose a matching package of cuts in entitlement programs and other spending. Bush met with his Cabinet on Tuesday, and budget director Richard Darman outlined the sequester scenario looming over the government unless a budget agreement is reached before Oct. 1, the start of the 1991 fiscal year. Federal agencies are girding for possible layoffs. Fitzwater reiterated that Bush will not sign legislation forestalling a sequester or softening the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction targets unless he and the Congress reach an overall spending accord. The White House and congressional delegations _ led by Darman and House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. _ will resume their talks Friday, spending the entire weekend at the base. Bush will leave Friday night from Andrews for his summit Sunday in Helsinki, Finland, with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Fitzwater said if the weekend budget negotiations succeed, Bush will meet with the top leaders of Congress to ``hammer out a final agreement.'' Under the Gramm-Rudman law, there will be automatic across-the-board cuts in many federal programs beginning Oct. 1 unless the projected deficit is $64 billion or lower. The latest estimate from Darman's office is that the 1991 deficit will be $169 billion, or $231 billion if the costs of the savings and loan bailout are added in. Higher oil prices and escalating Pentagon costs are likely to produce even more red ink.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Backs Greater Business Role in Improving Education
DOC.TEXT: Businesses should play a greater role in improving schools by investing more dollars and personnel to boost quality and prepare students for the workforce, a nationwide poll said Tuesday. The Roper Organization poll, commissioned by an affiliate of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, found 96 percent of Americans with children in public school, as well as 91 percent of all Americans, are concerned about the quality of education in their communities. Three-quarters of those polled agreed that public schools are failing to prepare students for jobs now available. Sixty-three percent said most students will lack skills for jobs in the future. Most of the 1,003 adult Americans polled over the telephone last month were receptive to the involvement of business in local public education. Ninety-one percent said it is a good idea for business to provide equipment to schools, while 6 percent thought it was a bad idea and 2 percent didn't know. Eighty-five percent want business to pay the cost of putting in a course to teach certain technical skills, while 12 percent were against the idea and 3 percent didn't know. Eighty percent said business should give employees time off to teach a course in the school system, compared with 15 percent against and 4 percent undecided. Seventy-two percent called on business to take the lead in improving community schools and 65 percent wanted business leaders to run for school boards. ``It is interesting to note that the American public considers the business community the education safety net for the nation,'' said Edward Donley, chairman of the chamber's Center for Workforce Preparation and Quality Education. ``Business clearly has been given the mandate to lead the way to better public schools and to help education in general,'' said Donley, Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association, agreed that businesses should become more involved in public schools but warned against an inclination to avoid key issues that affect the quality of education. ``Where was business when President Bush vetoed the family and medical leave act, ... where was business during discussions about national health care ... or expanding preschool. These health-care issues are (important) to kids learning,'' said Geiger. ``Businesses can't just pick and choose where they will get active,'' he said. The Roper poll was designed to reflect public opinion with a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Traditionalists Dominate Russian Party Congress
LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.NOTE: EDS: ADDS 2 grafs at end with Polozkov comments at news conference.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reform program is ``on the brink of collapse,'' a leader of the Communist Party's traditionalist wing told 2,500 delegates at a Russian party congress in the Kremlin on Tuesday. Ivan K. Polozkov, first secretary of the Communist Party in the Russian Republic, drew vigorous applause from the delegates, a group that includes many generals and career party officials who are believed to harbor reservations about Gorbachev's policies. Gorbachev sat on the podium at the front of the hall, remaining virtually silent through a day of speeches that often contained scathing criticism of his leadership, though without mentioning him by name. Some of the day's strongest applause went to Ivan Vtorushin, a worker from the Siberian city of Tyumen, who called for ``returning the nation to 1985,'' the year in which Gorbachev assumed power. ``No matter what slogans are used, a policy resulting in falling living standards and bloodshed is against popular interests,'' Vtorushin said, referring to the Soviet Union's accelerating economic problems and ethnic strife. The delegates are meeting this week to complete the process of creating a separate Russian branch of the Communist Party. Until this year the Russian Republic, the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 constituent republics, did not have its own party organization. Communists living in Russia were simply members of the Soviet Party, headed by Gorbachev. The first meeting of the new Russian Communist Party, held in Moscow in June, was dominated by traditionalists and was widely viewed in the Soviet Union as an effort by them to gain influence and public support. Since June, three reformist delegates have resigned their seats in the congress because of its domination by traditionalists. Another reformer, economist Otto Latsis, announced at Tuesday's session that he was resigning in protest from a committee drafting the party's platform. Reformists also made some other moves on Tuesday, such as calling unsuccessfully for the resignation of the 55-year-old Polozkov. But for the most part, the session was again dominated by traditionalists. In his hour-long keynote address, Polozkov urged delegates to counter the ``deliberate discrediting of the Communist Party and the socialist choice as a whole.'' He said the country's economic crisis, caused by the Soviet people's psychological unpreparedness for a market-based system, ``is, in the final analysis, putting perestroika on the brink of collapse.'' His comments echoed complaints expressed Monday by Muscovites who stood in line across the city to buy bread, which had been one of the few foods Soviet consumers could obtain easily. It is now in short supply across Moscow for the first time since the early 1960s, despite a record grain harvest. Izvestia and Moskovskaya Pravda blamed the shortage on Moscow's bakeries, which they said could not keep up with demand. ``That's perestroika _ we're not moving forward forward, we're going backward,'' said Viktor Lyubeznov, one frustrated shopper Monday. Among other speakers at the Russian party congress was the head of the KGB in the Moscow region, Vitaly Prilukov, who lamented the ``atrophying of power'' in the Soviet Union and said the national party had ``willingly allowed anti-socialist structures to seize the initiative.'' Despite the complaints, Polozkov said later at a news conference that he is ``convinced there is no going back'' to the way things were before Gorbachev. ``The delegates ... are just wondering what's happening, with five years of perestroika and no improvements,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Nunn Relaxes Anti-Abortion Position
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Sam Nunn of Georgia has relaxed his long-held anti-abortion position and now says he believes the abortion decision should be left ``to the informed conscience of the mother'' in most cases. Nunn, frequently mentioned as a potential Democratic presidential candidate in 1992, said he favors prohibiting abortion only when the fetus is viable, or capable of living outside the womb. In a letter to be sent to constituents who write him about the abortion issue, Nunn wrote: ``I favor leaving the decision prior to viability to the informed conscience of the mother, and prohibiting abortions after viability except in cases where the life of the mother is threatened.'' In the past, Nunn was a supporter of proposed constitutional amendments to overturn the Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion. Nunn was not available for comment Tuesday. His press secretary, Scott Williams, said the senator's shift on abortion did not signal any change in Nunn's announced position that he has ``no plans at this time to seek the presidency.'' In the letter, Nunn said he still considers abortion ``a tragedy and an act of great moral consequence that should be strongly discouraged except in cases of rape or incest, or when the life of the mother is endangered.'' But he said laws prohibiting early abortions cannot be enforced because legalized abortion has been the law of the land since the 1973 Supreme Court decision. ``I do not believe that large segments of the American people and the medical profession will accept or obey a law making early-term abortions a criminal act after all those years,'' Nunn wrote. ``The law can only accomplish so much, and with respect to abortion, I believe the only enforceable line the law can draw is to protect the unborn child when it is clear an independent life is involved,'' Nunn said. But, he added, ``I hope we have not reached the point in this country when anything that is not prohibited by law is considered morally and ethically acceptable.''

DOC.HEAD: Number of Consumers With Delinquent Loans Rises
DOC.TEXT: The number of consumers 30 days or more behind on their bank loan payments increased in the April-June period after falling the previous two quarters, a trade group said Tuesday. The American Bankers Association said a survey of 800 banks showed a delinquency rate on consumer loans of 2.55 percent, up from the 2.46 percent in the first quarter and far above the 2.30 percent rate of a year ago. The group's chief economist, Robert H. Dugger, said that credit delinquencies are ``indicative of what's happening in the rest of the economy.'' ``The current delinquency rate, even though up somewhat, is still considered moderate. Consumers have been slowing their spending for several quarters, and are expected to remain cautious,'' he said. The delinquency rate includes seven types of closed-end consumer loans: personal; two types of auto loans; mobile home; recreational vehicle; property improvement, and home equity. The District of Columbia reported the lowest delinquency rate with 1.22 percent, followed by Arizona with 1.24 percent and then Nebraska with 1.38 percent. The states with the worst rates were New Hampshire with 5.99 percent; Massachusetts with 5.03 percent; Puerto Rico with 4.85 percent; and Connecticut with 4.81 percent. The delinquency rate for open-ended home equity credit lines, which are tracked separately, was virtually unchanged at 0.75 percent, compared with 0.79 percent in the first quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Freighter Boarded By U.S. Sailors, Forced to Divert
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Navy and Coast Guard sailors boarded an Iraqi-flagged freighter in the Gulf of Oman early Tuesday as it was sailing to an Iraqi port with a cargo of tea. The sailors planned to stay on the ship, the Zanoobia, and escort it to another port, the officials said. Thirteen hours after the boarding, U.S. military sources said officials had not yet designated where the freighter would go. After Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, the U.N. Security Council endorsed an economic embargo against Iraq and subsequently approved the use of force to back it up. The 3,549-ton freighter was first challenged by radio by the USS Goldsborough when it reported it was bound for the Iraqi port of Basra with a cargo of tea. Navy officials, reading from a Pentagon announcement, said the boarding took place after the vessel refused orders from the Goldsborough to either return to its port of origin or proceed to a non-prohibited port. Shipping sources in the region had said the vessel, en route from Sri Lanka, was stopped before it could reach the Strait of Hormuz, the gateway to the Persian Gulf. ``The team met no resistance and they will remain aboard the ship until it reaches its due destination,'' the Pentagon statement said. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the U.S. Navy stopped and boarded the tea-laden Iraqi-flagged freighter in the Gulf of Oman as part of the trade embargo against Iraq. ``The ship was ordered to divert. It did not divert. It was then boarded and now has diverted,'' the spokesman said. ``We don't have information now on where it's being diverted to.'' Tuesday's incident was the first publicly acknowledged boarding by U.S. forces of an Iraqi-flagged vessel since the U.N. embargo was clamped on Iraq last month. But U.S. military sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, indicated that might not be the case. They said Pentagon listings show more than 450 vessels have been challenged by radio by U.S. warships and that ``less than 20 had been boarded, and less than five diverted.'' When pressed as to whether other Iraq-flagged vessels were involved, they said the records were not broken down by nationality. The only other ship publicly reported to have been boarded by U.S. forces _ and subsequently prevented from docking _ was the 91,478-ton Kota Wirama, managed by the Pacific International Lines of Singapore. That vessel was intercepted in the Red Sea on Aug. 28, boarded and searched, and then prevented from proceeding to the Jordanian port of Aqaba. Shipping executives said the vessel was suspected of carrying chemicals destined for Iraq. Warning shots were fired across the bows of two Iraqi-flagged tankers on Aug. 18 when Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was visiting the area. The two tankers were empty.

DOC.HEAD: Transcontinental Solar Flight Completed
LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: He didn't make it to historic Kitty Hawk, but pilot Eric Raymond on Tuesday celebrated the first transcontinental flight in a solar-powered plane: by going sailing. ``I hope this will help enlighten people to the potential of solar power and alternative energy sources,'' Raymond said of his 2,467-mile flight. Raymond, 33, said winds prevented a Kitty Hawk landing but were good for sailboarding. Raymond's Sun Seeker ultralight aircraft was safe from the wind in a shed at the farm he landed Monday, nine miles short of the Wright Brothers Memorial. ``If I had an hour more time Monday I could have made it in,'' Raymond said as he relaxed on a beach not far from Kitty Hawk, where the Wright brothers pioneered powered flight. Low visibility, rain and unfavorable wind forced him to land at the farm near the community of Spot, about 500 yards from Currituck Sound, which separates the mainland from the offshore barrier island where Kitty Hawk and Kill Devil Hills are located. The Sun Seeker depends on sunshine and favorable wind. Solar cells produce power for its electric motor, which is used for takeoffs and landings. After takeoff, the plane rides thermals, columns of rising warm air, like a glider. Raymond said Tuesday's 35 mph northeasterly gusts would create turbulence around the trees surrounding the airstrip at the Wright Memorial. ``I wouldn't want to land there with more than 10 or 12 mph winds,'' he said. Raymond said the trip ``took a bit longer than I expected but that's because it was against the wind. I expected to have prevailing westerlies but instead it was more easterly.'' Two weeks was Raymond's goal for completing the trip but wind and weather delays stretched the trip to 32 days, including 23 days in the air. He took off from Desert Center, Calif., about 200 miles east of Los Angeles. Raymond said the rigors of flying and the attraction of the beach and good sailboarding weather were enough to call him off work for a day. He said he liked sailboarding because ``you have a clean, endless source of energy. You can wind surf at 30 mph all day long. I like anything that's natural like that that doesn't pollute.'' He said he would set his plane up for people to see Wednesday before driving home to California. His father, Sam Raymond, said he's glad the trip is over, although his son wanted to achieve his goal of flying to the monument. ``There's a little bit of disappointment that he didn't get to the exact landing point that he wanted,'' the elder Raymond said. Raymond first took off July 16 from Desert Center to prove an aircraft partly powered by solar energy could cross the United States. Two days later, the 198-pound craft was damaged in an aborted takeoff from Lordsburg, N.M. The Sun Seeker, Raymond and his ground crew returned by land to Lake Elsinore, Calif., for repairs. Raymond manufactured and sold hang gliding equipment there until six months ago, when he devoted himself to the Sun Seeker project. The former national hang-gliding champion took off again from Desert Center on Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Of Stranded Asians Fight For Bread And Water
With AM-Gulf-Rdp
LaserPhoto AMM5
DOC.TEXT: More than 40,000 ragged Asian refugees from Kuwait and Iraq fought for bread and water Tuesday in a sweltering desert camp as Jordanian troops struggled to impose order. ``We're fighting because we're hungry and thirsty. If they don't move us out of here soon we will all die,'' complained Ahmed Saed, a white-bearded Pakistani. Hani Tamini, a sturdy young man of about 30 from Bangladesh said: ``I've had no food today, none yesterday and very little the day before that. It's better to die rather than fight like this for a scrap of bread.'' Another man wailed: ``I've been trying for three days to get some food for my children and wife and I haven't been able to get any.'' The camp is in the baking hot desert at Shaalan between the Iraqi frontier and the Jordanian border post of Ruweishid, 50 miles inside Jordan. It is used as a staging post for the tens of thousands of Asians, most of them penniless, fleeing Kuwait. They have been allowed to cross into Jordan but are not allowed through the border post because Jordan wants guarantees the refugees' governments will repatriate them. Jordan, burdened by an $8 billion national debt, has been swamped by more than 420,000 refugees since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The nation's social services are strained to their breaking point. Crown Prince Hassan, who visited the camps two days ago, accused the international community Tuesday of not doing enough to help Jordan or the refugees. He told a news conference in Amman that ``the situation may soon become critical'' for the people he called ``the downtrodden of the earth.'' More than 100,000 impoverished Asians are stranded at Ruweishid and the makeshift desert camps. Food is scarce. Some people have died. At Shaalan Tuesday, thousands of men and women pushed and scuffled beside a large trailer truck from which Jordanian officials and soldiers were trying to distribute food rations _ a round piece of flat Arab bread, one tomato and one cucumber per person. The crush was so great the frazzled soldiers began flaying the refugees with belts and sticks, yelling at them to stop fighting and get in line. But again and again, as soon as some semblance of a line was formed, there was a fresh rush on the food truck as the thousands of people at the back of the line, screaming and stretching out their hands, stampeded to get closer before the food ran out. It went on for hours. When the pandemonium subsided, refugees scavenged in the sand for crushed remnants of bread, tomatoes and cucumbers. ``It's not easy to control people who are hungry and thirsty,'' said Suleyman Bakr, one of five Jordanian doctors manning a medical tent. ``We need more food, more water, and better organization. But what's needed more than anything is to get these people to their countries as soon as possible,'' he said. Most of the refugees are from Bangladesh, Pakistan, India, Sri Lanka, the Philippines and Thailand. About a quarter of the people at Ruweishid are jammed into small army tents. Most lie on the sand with little protection from the sun. Some refugees have been in the camp for nearly two weeks. There is little sanitation. ``It would have been better to stay in Iraq and face death there, rather than die in this terrible stink hole in the desert,'' said one Bangladeshi.

DOC.HEAD: ABA Panel Gives Souter Highest Rating for Professional Qualifications
DOC.TEXT: The American Bar Association's judicial screening panel Tuesday gave Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter its highest rating for professional qualifications to sit on the nation's highest court. The well-qualified rating is ``reserved for those who meet the highest standards of integrity, professional competence and judicial temperament,'' according to the guidebook followed by the 15-member Standing Committee on Federal Judiciary. The committee vote was unanimous, the panel said in a letter to the Justice Department. The rating is expected to give a boost to Souter's nomination, scheduled to be taken up Sept. 13 by the Senate Judiciary Committee. Still, Souter is expected to be questioned closely about his judicial philosophy, and senators are expected to try to probe his views on the landmark 1973 ruling that legalized abortion. Souter received a similar well-qualified rating before being confirmed earlier this year to sit on the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston, but the ABA panel applies different standards for Supreme Court nominees. As part of the most-recent ABA study, two teams of law professors at Stanford and Northwestern universities reviewed Souter's legal writings as a New Hampshire Supreme Court judge and New Hampshire state attorney general. Another review was conducted for the ABA by a group of lawyers headed by former solicitor general Rex Lee, now president of Brigham Young University. The legal writings of Souter, a Rhodes Scholar who graduated from Harvard Law School, provide few clues to his thinking on such pressing issues as abortion. But conservative groups have expressed satisfaction with President Bush's choice. The chairman of the ABA panel, Ralph I. Lancaster Jr., told Deputy Attorney General William P. Barr of the rating in a brief letter released by the Justice Department. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, attending a law enforcement conference in Seoul, South Korea, issued a statement saying the rating confirms that Bush ``has selected a man of superb intellect and qualifications.'' The White House also welcomed the ABA's seal of approval. ``The president is pleased to receive this news and looks forward to a speedy confirmation,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. Arthur J. Kropp, president of the liberal People for the American Way, said the rating ``comes as no surprise.'' ``Souter's technical qualifications were never in question,'' Kropp said in a statement. ``What the Souter nomination will turn on is his judicial philosophy, which the ABA's rating does not account for.'' People for the American Way, which helped defeat Robert Bork's nomination for the Supreme Court three years ago, plans to issue a report on Souter's record at the outset of the Senate hearings. The ABA ratings have been a source of controversy in the past. The panel split in 1987 over Bork, with 10 members voting to rate him ``well qualified'' while four others found him ``not qualified.'' Another member voted ``not opposed'' to Bork. The Senate defeated Bork's nomination after a bitter fight led by a coalition of civil rights and abortion rights activists.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Uprising Marks 1,000 Days
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Retransmitting a0554 to correct slug.
DOC.TEXT: When an army truck broke down recently in the middle of this West Bank town, Palestinian teen-agers sprang into action. ``They trashed it,'' said an Israeli army officer who witnessed the scene. ``They broke every window, smashed every door and fender.'' The incident was a reminder that the Palestinian revolt against Israeli occupation, though eclipsed by the gulf crisis, persists as an angry war of stones and empty bottles against well-armed Israeli troops. The uprising, known in Arabic as the ``intefadeh,'' marks its 1,000th day Wednesday. The PLO-backed underground leadership of the revolt called for the anniversary to be marked with protest marches under the banner ``Intefadeh until a Palestinian state.'' That goal remains illusive for the 1.7 million Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, and the character of the struggle is changing amid a more restrained Israeli military policy and the impact of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Palestinian support for Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein has disappointed the United States and other Western nations that tried to mediate the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. ``There's no doubt that Israel is reaping political gains from the gulf crisis,'' said Ghassan Khatib, a Palestinian professor from this town just north of Jerusalem. ``There are fewer pressures on Israel from the United States to start a dialogue with the Palestinians,'' Khatib said. ``There is no more talk about Israeli violations of human rights in the occupied territories.'' Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Tuesday dismissed reporters' questions about the anniversary. ``It doesn't have any impact on the progress of the Jewish people and the Jewish state,'' Shamir said. Since the revolt began in December 1987, a total of 728 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians. In addition, 255 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israel. Forty-seven Israelis have died. In recent months, according to both Palestinians and Israeli army officials, there has been a marked slowdown in the uprising. Under Defense Minister Moshe Arens, the army since June has reduced its forces in heavily populated areas and tightened firing rules, sharply reducing Palestinian casualties. In the past three months, 11 Palestinians have died from Israeli army gunfire. In the same period last year, the toll was 77. ``It reflects more experience by the army in handling the situation,'' said an army spokesman, who cannot be identified by name under military rules. ``Troops are positioned so there is less friction with the local population.'' Meanwhile, the Palestinian side shows signs of fatigue from the almost weekly general strikes ordered by uprising leaders and forced closures by the army. ``Our business barely feeds our family,'' said Zaki Musleh, a 60-year-old carpenter with a shop on Ramallah's Palestine Street. ``No one has any money.'' Musleh's shop, like many others, is short one worker. His 28-year-old son Bassam is in army custody, one of more than 910 Palestinians held without charge or trial under military ``administrative detention'' rules. Some 9,015 other Palestinians also are in jail, charged or awaiting trial or sentenced for anti-Israeli crimes, the army says. Palestinians remain resilient despite the revolt's failure to achieve its main political goal of getting the Israelis out of the territories they seized in the 1967 Middle East war. Palestinian journalist Daoud Kuttab said he believes the main achievement of the intefadeh has been a change in Palestinian attitudes. ``Palestinians are no longer thinking as an occupied people. They are thinking as a people resisting occupation,'' he said. ``That is why the uprising will continue.'' In Ramallah's Kadura refugee camp, 29-year-old truck driver Ziad Zmekna points to greater international awareness of the Palestinians' plight as another gain from the uprising. Zmekna's life is a measure of Palestinian determination. One of his brothers is jailed, another is hiding from authorities, and Zmekna himself has lost his driver's license for failure to pay income taxes to the Israelis. He points to a photo on his wall, the wedding portrait of a Palestinian friend killed by Israeli troops last year. ``The intefadeh will continue for our martyrs, it will continue for us,'' Zmekna said. ``This is our national duty.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
Brady Asking Allies to Share in Cost of Anti-Saddam Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5 grafs new material for 5th graf pvs, Brady met
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady expressed optimism as he began a global search Tuesday for billions of dollars in international assistance to support the campaign against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``The diplomatic and military branches are well in place. What needs to be put in place now is the economic branch,'' Brady told reporters aboard his plane, adding that he was looking forward to a ``most successful trip.'' Brady was leading one of two high-level delegations dispatched by President Bush to ask America's allies to help defray the cost of the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf and to provide assistance to allies hurt by the trade embargo against Iraq. While previous reports have put the possible first-year price tag for the assistance package at $25 billion, officials traveling with Brady indicated the final amount could go higher. Brady met first with French Finance Minister Pierre Beregovoy and then with French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas. Speaking to reporters at the French Foreign Ministry, Brady called the discussions ``very successful.'' But neither Brady nor Dumas would say whether any agreements were reached on America's request for added financial assistance. But Brady did say, ``We were very pleased with (Dumas') reaction.'' ``There is diplomatic support, there is military support and now we have the job of providing economic support,'' Brady said before departing. Following the Paris meetings, Brady was to fly to London for talks Wednesday with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. In a trip that will span 30 time zones over four days, the Brady delegation was also scheduled to meet with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. On Wednesday, Secretary of State James A. Baker III will leave Washington on a similar pledge-seeking mission first to the oil-rich countries of the Middle East and later to West Germany and Italy. The Bush administration has a lot riding on its fund drive. It fears that without a substantial flow of economic assistance in the form of cash, loans and loan guarantees, Third World nations especially hurt by the loss of trade with Iraq will violate the embargo. The administration is counting on the trade embargo to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait without using American troops to force a rollback. Officials speaking to reporters on Brady's flight from Washington to Paris said that a critical need was to get commitments for $10 billion or more to provide assistance to Turkey, Jordan and Egypt, the three countries in the Middle East suffering the most economically from a loss of trade opportunities with Iraq and other turmoil in the region. One official, who spoke on the condition his name not be used, said the United States was seeking whatever resources were needed to help the three countries. ``You have got to finance that one way or the other,'' he said. In addition, the official said, the Brady mission would be discussing support for the U.S. military buildup, which was costing an estimated $46 million a day. Congressional critics have pressed Bush to get commitments to defray the impact on the U.S. budget deficit of defending the Persian Gulf oil resources, especially from such economic powerhouses as Japan and West Germany. Bush and other members of the National Security Council reviewed a proposal last week that carried a $23 billion price tag over the first year with $10 billion of that earmarked to ease the economic pain for countries supporting the trade embargo and the other $13 billion going to the U.S. military to pay for such costs as transportation, housing and fuel. Other reports have put the figure at $25 billion, but the official traveling with Brady said any number cited now would very likely be revised upward, given the changing nature of the situation. The official said that other Third World countries, including the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe, as well as nations such as Brazil and the Philippines, would likely receive economic assistance from the international package being assembled. The money would be used to compensate them for the rising world price of oil, the official said.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Fire on Blacks, At Least 40 Dead in Latest Township Battles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 23 grafs to UPDATE with Mandela addressing crowd, meeting with Vlok, confirmation of journalist's arrest. Pick up 22nd graf pvs, `De Klerk made..'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JOH1
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers fired on thousands of angry blacks Tuesday and rival gangs fought with axes, knives and spears as at least 40 people were killed in township violence. The violence came as President F.W. de Klerk and African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela visited black townships near Johannesburg to call for a halt in fighting that has killed more than 550 people since Aug. 12. The government has imposed emergency restrictions and sent elite army units to the townships, but fighting between Zulu followers of the conservative Inkatha movement and other blacks loyal to the ANC raged for a fourth week. In Sebokeng, a pre-dawn clash killed four people at a migrant workers' hostel, police said. The victims were believed to be township residents abducted by hostel dwellers. About 5,000 township residents angered by the killings gathered at the hostel, police said. When the mob refused to disperse, army troops were called in and a ``shooting incident occurred,'' said police Col. Frans Malherbe. ``The bodies of 11 persons were found after the mob dispersed.'' South African newspaper photographer N. Khumalo told the South African Press Association that ``people came toward (the soldiers) waving their hands, saying `peace, we are not fighting.' Some of them even sat down.'' The troops ``took up position, cocked their guns _ I thought maybe they wanted to scare the people,'' Khumalo was quoted as saying. ``All of a sudden there was shooting. Many of the people ran. Some of the people fell.'' The shooting marked the first time soldiers have been involved in a clash that has resulted in a loss of lives since they were deployed last month in the townships. In March, police opened fire on black demonstrators in Sebokeng, killing at least five and wounding more than 150. A judicial inquiry criticized police for the killings, saying gunfire was unjustified. Malherbe said both police and military were investigating Tuesday's shootings. A later police report Tuesday put the Sebokeng death toll at 36, with the other killings occurring in sporadic clashes near the hostel and adjacent areas. Police said more than 150 people were arrested. Black crowds also stoned journalists in Sebokeng and burned one reporter's car. A soundman for WTN, a British television agency, was arrested in Vosloorus after being told to leave the area, WTN bureau chief Vincent Francis said. WTN deputy bureau chief Vincent Francis said the soundman, Brian Green, told the bureau over a mobile telephone he was leaving when police assaulted and detained him. A police spokesman said any alleged assault would be investigated. Police also reported three deaths in Vosloorus and one in Katlehong in overnight street clashes. Both townships are southeast of Johannesburg. Rival factions continued to skirmish Tuesday in Vosloorus with axes, spears and other crude weapons. Police fired tear gas and shotguns to keep the groups apart. Mandela visited Sebokeng on Tuesday afternoon and said he was ``outraged'' after viewing bodies at a mortuary. The ANC deputy president repeated his accusation that police fueled the violence by siding with Inkatha fighters. But he also said police arrested more than 100 Inkatha supporters, including youth leader Themba Khoza. He later spoke in Xhosa to a crowd of township residents and appealed for calm, then met with Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok. Neither man issued a statement afterward. On Monday, Mandela called for an independent investigation of police actions in the townships similar to the one that followed the Sebokeng shootings in March. De Klerk has ordered Vlok to investigate the charges of police bias. He and other officials have said some individuals may have acted improperly. Vlok said Tuesday that government opponents were waging an orchestrated campaign to discredit the police. De Klerk made his first visit as president to the Soweto township southwest of Johannesburg, where more than 100 people have died in factional fighting. Youths mobbed the president and shouted ``Viva, de Klerk!'' At one stop, he visited a migrant worker hostel where recent battles have occurred. De Klerk later told a news conference conditions in the hostels were ``unacceptable'' and that the government would spend millions of dollars for housing and education in the townships. The ANC-Inkatha feud has claimed about 5,000 lives since 1986 in the eastern province of Natal, where most of the blacks are Zulus. The fighting spread to Johannesburg area townships this month. Mandela and Zulu leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi have been criticized for failing to stop the carnage. Buthelezi has called for a meeting with Mandela, but the ANC has refused. Mandela said Monday the problem could not be solved by individuals.

DOC.HEAD: Tourist Slain: A Nightmare Underground
DOC.TEXT: The New York City subway system has a new advertising slogan: ``We're coming back, so you come back!'' Brian Watkins, an annual visitor from Provo, Utah, came back once too often. He was waiting in a midtown Manhattan station Sunday night when a group of youths robbed his father and punched his mother. Watkins fought back, and one of the youths stabbed him to death. Eight teen-agers were arrested Monday and charged with murder and robbery, police said. Watkins' slaying was one more disaster for the nation's largest subway system, which began the century as an engineering marvel and seems destined to end it as a social disaster. The blood stain in the Seventh Avenue station had faded Tuesday, but not the disgust over what had happened there. Like Watkins, Dockery Clark of Greensboro, N.C., also came to New York for the U.S. Open tennis tournament. She said she had been mugged in the station next to the one where Watkins died. ``Two guys jumped me, beat my back and stole my watch and bracelet,'' she told the Daily News. ``My boyfriend saw (Mayor) David Dinkins (at the tournament), walked up to him, and told him his city is a cesspool.'' Carolina Brani, another Open spectator, lives in Milan. But she was clear about one thing: ``I know the subway is never safe. Day or night, there is no difference.'' Crime is rising throughout New York City, and rising even faster in the subways. Last year, subway felonies increased 18 percent, while reported major crimes rose 4 percent in the city as a whole. Watkins' slaying was the 18th this year in the subway system, versus 20 in all of 1989, and robberies are up 29 percent. The fact that less than 3 percent of all city crime occurs in the subways is of scant comfort to most riders. ``People are not moved by statistics,'' said Thomas Reppetto, director of the Citizens Crime Commission, a privately financed citizens group. ``Too many things have happened down there to too many people.'' Brian Watkins was no victim-in-waiting. He had ridden the subways many times before; he was in the company of four other people, including two men. It was not that late _ midtown at 10:20 p.m. is as busy as some cities at noon _ and the station at Seventh Avenue and 53rd Street is not one of the more dangerous. To many, the brazen attack on the Watkins family merely confirms a visceral sense of subterranean danger. Most stations are dirty, smelly, noisy and dimly lit. The Transit Authority has closed station newsstands, reduced token booth hours and cut off-hours service on some lines. The agency's police department has been nagged by scandals, and in August it ran out of money in a special city fund for paying overtime for police officers on subway robbery patrol. ``For a lot of people, to go down into a cavern is a little frightening, no matter what,'' said Reppetto. ``But when they see homeless people living there and disorderly people, they feel that things are not under control.'' After steadily increasing for several years, ridership has declined. Only about a quarter of city residents ride the subway each day, and to many such a trip has become virtually unthinkable. A few years ago then-Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward admitted his wife had never taken the subway. During the past five years graffiti has been vastly reduced. Trains are more punctual, and the Transit Authority has several billion dollars to spend on further improvements. ``The level of service used to be intolerable,'' said Gene Russianoff, a mass transit advocate. ``Now it's tolerably bad.'' But many riders, past and present, feel that what really makes the subways dangerous are some of the people in them, people as callous as the ones who allegedly attacked the Watkins family and then headed off to the Roseland ballroom for some dancing. ``There are a lot of proposals out there for improving safety in the subways,'' said Russianoff. ``I'm afraid none of them would have helped Mr. Watkins.''

DOC.HEAD: Mexico to Sell Unleaded Gasoline Along Major Tourist Routes
DOC.TEXT: Pemex, Mexico's oil monopoly, will this month begin selling a new unleaded gasoline at more than one-third of the country's 3,200 gas stations, the official news agency Notimex reported Tuesday. The new gasoline, to be sold along major tourist routes, has one-fifth the amount of lead contained in the widely used Extra grade of gasoline, the report said. The 12 routes include the Tijuana-Cabo San Lucas area; Nuevo Laredo-Mexico City; Mexico City-Acapulco; Mexico City-Oaxaca; and Mexico City-Ixtapa. The agency said use of the new unleaded gasoline will be mandatory in cars made in Mexico starting next year but is not suitable for use in pre-1985 models. Pemex said it has spent $345 million to produce and distribute the new fuel. In most areas the cost will be the same as the Extra grade, with prices higher along the U.S.-Mexico border.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Arrive For Talks With Yeltsin, Gorbachev
LaserPhoto MOSB7
DOC.TEXT: A delegation of U.S. senators led by Sen. Robert Dole met with Boris N. Yeltsin on Tuesday and discussed arms control, taxation and the shortage-plagued Soviet economy.
