Dole, R-Kan., and his fellow Republican senators planned to meet Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Kremlin on Wednesday before returning to the United States. Yeltsin, the president of the Russian republic, is locked in a struggle with Gorbachev over the pace of reform in the Soviet Union. He expressed interest in talking with the senators about several issues, including arms control and taxation. ``We here in Russia are just beginning to tackle these issues,'' Yeltsin said as the meeting began. ``It would be interesting for us to know your points of view and what you would advise.'' Yeltsin made reference to his republic's effort to wrest more control over its affairs from the central Soviet government led by Gorbachev. ``We are beginning to have some doubt about whether the legislation for things like taxation by the central government is the right one,'' he told the senators. ``So we're going to pass our own laws.'' Dole was joined on the trip by fellow Republicans John Warner of Virginia, Alfonse D'Amato of New York, Connie Mack of Florida, Don Nickles of Oklahoma, Steven Symms of Idaho and Jake Garn of Utah. Dole mentioned some of the topics on his agenda during a brief airport news conference. ``We're very interested to see how the economic reforms are coming along and also to get the views of Mr. Gorbachev, in particular, on the crisis in the gulf,'' he said. Dole also spoke about this weekend's upcoming summit in Finland between Gorbachev and President Bush. He said the superpowers should coordinate their efforts in the Persian Gulf to avoid misunderstandings. ``My view is there's probably some Soviet apprehension about the buildup of U.S. forces'' in the gulf, Dole said. ``Thus far the Soviets have been very cooperative and supportive. ``Whether or not President Bush will make a direct appeal to Mr. Gorbachev about additional military force on behalf of the Russians, I don't know,'' he added. ``But it should be a very candid discussion, because so far it's pretty top-heavy American in the gulf crisis.'' Warner added: ``We shall also discuss with Mr. Gorbachev the status and the role of the Soviet military advisers that were in the gulf with Iraqi forces just before the invasion, and as far as we know, are still there. ``News reports are that they had no role in the invasion,'' he added, ``but we want to hear that directly from President Gorbachev.'' The Soviet Union has 193 military advisers in Iraq and it has said they are under contractual obligation to continue training Iraqi soldiers to use, maintain and repair their Soviet-made weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Begins in Retrial
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection began Tuesday in the retrial of three men accused of riot in the 1986 Howard Beach attack in which a gang of whites chased a black man to his death. William Bollander, 21, and James Povinelli and Thomas Farino, both 20, were convicted of riot two years ago. But those convictions were overturned by an appeals court, which ruled the trial judge made errors that hurt the defense. That trial was the second stemming from the Dec. 20, 1986, death of Michael Griffith, 23. Griffith and two other blacks were attacked after they walked into the predominantly white Howard Beach section of Queens when their car broke down. A gang of whites chased Griffith onto the Belt Parkway, where he was struck by a car and killed. Three teen-agers were convicted of manslaughter in the first trial. There will be some similarities with the two earlier cases: victim Cedric Sandiford is expected to be the key government witness, and defense lawyers will argue their clients were not part of the mob that attacked the blacks. The appeals court ruled that state Supreme Court Justice Thomas Demakos erred when he refused to give the jury the option of convicting the three on the lesser charge of disorderly conduct. Demakos will preside over the retrial.

DOC.HEAD: North Prosecutor Asks Appellate Panel to Reconsider Ruling
DOC.TEXT: Iran-Contra prosecutor Lawrence E. Walsh sought a rehearing Tuesday of the split federal appeals court decision that set aside former White House aide Oliver L. North's three felony convictions. The independent counsel petitioned the three-judge panel, which voted 2-1 to vacate North's convictions, to reconsider its decision and suggested that the full 12-member court hear the case. In a tartly worded petition, Walsh accused Circuit Judges Laurence Silberman and David Sentelle of incorrect legal analysis and ``a plain misreading of the record'' of North's trial to reach their decision. On July 20, they ordered a ``witness by witness'' hearing to determine if the evidence against North had been influenced by the testimony he gave Congress about the Iran-Contra affair under a limited grant of immunity from prosecution. That so-called ``use immunity'' grant barred Walsh from using North's testimony as evidence in a criminal prosecution. But Walsh called the panel's order ``an unwarranted extension of use immunity protection'' that was ``particularly unjustified'' because his office took special precautions to ensure that prosecutors were not exposed to North's testimony. The restrictions on the use by prosecutors of immunized testimony ``do not extend to the independent conduct of third-party witnesses, particularly witnesses who testify on the basis of personal knowledge,'' Walsh said. To meet the appellate judges' requirements, it would be necessary ``to probe the psychological processes of each witness, many of whom are irrelevant to the conviction,'' Walsh said. Quoting from the dissenting opinion of Chief Judge Patricia Wald, Walsh said the hearing would make ```virtually impossible' the criminal prosecution of a person who provides public immunized testimony.'' The former National Security Council aide was convicted of aiding and abetting the obstruction of Congress, altering or destroying NSC documents and accepting an illegal gratuity _ the construction of a security fence around his home. North was fined $150,000 and ordered to perform 1,200 hours of community service. If allowed to stand, the appellate court decision also jeopardizes the five felony convictions of Poindexter, who was sentenced to six months in prison for lying to Congress about covert assistance to the Nicaraguan Contras and the sale of U.S. arms to Iran. Walsh also attacked the panel's reversal of North's conviction for destroying or altering government documents. The panel held that the jury should have been told it could consider the fact that North thought he was not acting illegally when he destroyed documents. This reasoning, ``effectively places government records at the mercy of officially directed coverups,'' Walsh said. Walsh could have bypassed the appellate court and gone directly to the Supreme Court to seek reinstatement of North's conviction. But he chose a more cautious approach of returning to the appellate court and seeking reconsideration of its decision. He needs the votes of seven judges to win a rehearing of the case by the full court. Walsh apparently calculated that he could win the votes of three new members of the court appointed by President Bush in addition to four liberal judges who were appointed by President Carter. Silberman and Sentelle are among a group of five conservative judges appointed by President Reagan.

DOC.HEAD: Billy & Christie Offer Lyme Disease Prevention
DOC.TEXT: Oh, that Christie Brinkley. Cover girl, married to Billy Joel, mother of a beautiful daughter _ and now she's figured out a way to fight Lyme disease. Brinkley is raising guinea hens on her Long Island estate, and she believes the fowl are eating the deer ticks on her land. The ticks are carriers of potentially fatal Lyme disease, which has struck Suffolk County harder than any other county in the state this summer. When the actress-model told Rep. George Hochbrueckner about the hens on patrol, the congressman quickly seized the (photo) opportunity. Brinkley and Joel will soon be hosts to the congressman and a team of researchers who want to determine if the deer tick population is lower on the celebrity property than at the neighbors' homes. The New York Democrat said the researchers also will take some of the hens back to a laboratory to see if the animals can tell the difference between dog ticks and deer ticks. Brinkley told Hochbrueckner she noticed the number of deer ticks dropped after she let the hens wander around the property. Hochbrueckner said the guinea hens are used in Africa to keep ticks out of barnyards.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Returns after Engine Fire Spotted
DOC.TEXT: A Northwest Airlines DC-9 apparently had an engine fire while waiting to take off for Dallas on Tuesday, and the plane returned to the gate without incident. The 54 passengers and five crew members were uninjured, and disembarked at the gate. Northwest spokesman Bob Gibbons said Flight 693 was taxiing to a line of planes waiting to take off from Detroit Metropolitan Airport about 1:30 p.m. EDT when pilots on a plane behind noticed smoke and what may have been flames coming from the left rear engine. The crew can't see the rear-mounted engines. ``The aircraft is equipped with a mechanism that allows the crew to discharge a fire retardant chemical into the engine compartment,'' Gibbons said. Passengers were directed to other flights and mechanics checked over the engine.

DOC.HEAD: DOD Awards Jet Contract for Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Corp. received a $140 million advance acquisition contract to build 40 F-A-18 Hornet jet aircraft for the government of Kuwait, the Pentagon announced on Tuesday. The contract covers equipment purchases that were worked out several years ago under the foreign military sales program, a Pentagon spokesman said. The work is to be performed by the McDonnell Aircraft Co. in St. Louis, Mo., and is expected to be completed in September 1993, a Pentagon statement said. ``This was worked out some time ago. The contract has just finally been signed,'' said Pentagon spokesman, Navy Lt. Cmdr. Ken Satterfield. The contract involves two versions of the aircraft, 32 F-A-18Cs and eight F-A-18Ds, the statement said. A separate contract, also being awarded to McDonnell Douglas, covers a $5.4 million order for the technical publications for the Kuwait F-A-18 aircraft. The F-A-18 is a multi-role jet that performs both fighter and attack roles. The overall cost of the program is around $1.2 billion, Satterfield said. Despite the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the program is going forward because ``the government of Kuwait still exists'' and in the hopes it will regain its territory from Iraq, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Driver Arrested After Backfires Attract Police Attention
DOC.TEXT: Police who scrambled to find a gunman after a flood of callers reported gunshots got their man _ but it turned out to be a car. The reports that shattered the Labor Day calm in this small coastal town turned out to be backfires from Wayne Elliott Richards' ill-tuned old red Chevrolet. About 40 people called to report what they thought were gunshots. It turns out Richards, 21, is going to need a lawyer as well as a mechanic. Police didn't find any weapons when they caught up to him. But they arrested Richards for investigation of speeding, evading an officer and failing to provide proof of insurance.

DOC.HEAD: Mechanical Critter To Prowl Virginia Woods
DOC.TEXT: A new vehicle with legs and feet instead of wheels is being developed to prowl forests, a mechanical Big Foot the Agriculture Department said Tuesday will soon undergo field tests. The vehicle ``will soon be strolling about the woods of southwest Virginia'' near Blacksburg, home of Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, one of the machine's developers, the department said. Products technologist Robert Koeppen of the Forest Service said the machine could solve some forest management problems while helping protect forest ecosystems. Currently, forest managers depend on rubber-tired vehicles, which can cause soil compaction, rutting or damage to vegetation, the agency said. Wheeled vehicles also are limited by terrain that is too rough, steep, wet or soft. The machine, called ``the robotic walking vehicle,'' may alleviate such problems. For example, it can move sideways, a maneuver Koeppen said may help drastically reduce damage to forest soils and vegetation. A public unveiling of the machine has been scheduled for Sept. 11 at Virginia Polytechnic, with field tests to begin later this month. The tests will include the machine's performance on level, mountainous and simulate low-lying wetland terrain.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Leader Says Group Will Not Attack U.S. Targets
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian guerrilla leader Abul Abbas said Tuesday his group will not attack U.S. targets in the Middle East unless American forces strike at Iraq. ``Our interests lie in a peaceful settlement of the gulf crisis,'' he told reporters at his heavily guarded headquarters in downtown Baghdad. ``For the time being, we don't want to give the Americans an excuse to launch an attack against Iraq,'' he added. ``But if the Americans wage a battle, it will be a fierce one and all their interests in the region will be within our reach.'' The guerrilla leader, whose real name is Mohammed Abbas, heads the Palestine Liberation Front, a small, radical group within Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization. The group was behind the October 1985 hijacking of the Italian cruise liner Achille Lauro in which an elderly American passenger, Leon Klinghoffer, was murdered. The PLF also mounted an abortive seaborne raid on Israel in May, which led President Bush to suspend the U.S.'s 18-month dialogue with the PLO. Western governments have been preparing for terrorist attacks by Arab militants aligned with Baghdad since U.S. forces and their allies rushed to the aid of Saudi Arabia following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Abbas, sitting below a large poster showing him with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, said he expects the Americans to use ``some of their stooges'' in the region to attack American targets and then blame it on Iraq. He said the Americans would use that ``as a pretext ... to strike Iraq.'' He said Palestinians back Saddam because he stood up to Israel and its Western allies. He said Saddam's Aug. 12 proposal to leave Kuwait if Israel withdrew from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and the Americans left the Persian Gulf ``is the first time the Palestinian issue has been linked to the world's need for energy and oil.''

DOC.HEAD: Romanian President Criticizes U.S. for Blocking Assistance
DOC.TEXT:
President Ion Iliescu on Wednesday accused the United States and other Western countries of waging an economic war against Romania by blocking loans to the financially strapped country. Iliescu made his remarks to Romanian television during the second day of an official visit to Yugoslavia. He said certain American interests, which he did not name, dictated U.S. policy toward his country. Pressures have been exerted on Western banks to make them withhold loans to Romania, Iliescu said, without going into specifics. This represents ``an economic war impossible to understand,'' he said. ``Romanians have no illusions as to Western aid,'' Iliescu said. He added that Romania might find more beneficial economic cooperation with countries of similar size and interests. In contrast, he noted that the West gave preferential treatment to Nicolae Ceausescu, the Communist dictator toppled and executed in December, despite his repression of his countrymen. Iliescu was alluding to the Most Favored Nation trading status granted by the United States to Romania for years as a reward for Ceausescu's relative independence _ particularly in foreign policy _ from the Soviet Union. Exports of countries with Most Favored status are subject to lower U.S. tariffs. Romania lost its Most Favored Nation status in 1988 when Ceausescu still held power. Last week, Senate Minority Leader Robert Dole, R-Kan., visited Bucharest with a Senate delegation. Dole insisted Congress will have to be satisfied that Romania's human rights record is ``exemplary'' before restoring its Most Favored Nation status and allocating large-scale aid. Dole said he was concerned about mass arrests made after anti-government demonstrations, delays in issuing passports and the continuing state monopoly over the mass media.
The United States and the European Community froze all but humanitarian aid to Romanian in June. Romania has the weakest economy and lowest living standards in the East bloc. The aid cutoff was in response to a two-day rampage by loyalist miners who answered Iliescu's call for help in putting down violent anti-government protests. The miners beat up journalists and pedestrians and raided the offices of anti-government parties. Iliescu, a former senior Communist official who broke with Ceausescu, has repeatedly stated his commitment to democracy and economic reform. Iliescu's National Salvation Front came to power during the revolution that ousted Ceausescu. The Front won an overwhelming victory in May's multiparty elections. Opposition leaders suspect Iliescu and other key figures in the front of continuing to harbor communist sympathies.

DOC.HEAD: Intelsat Alleges in Suit That Martin Marietta Botched Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Martin Marietta comment, subbing 3 grafs for grafs 5-6 pvs, Martin Marietta ... launch.
DOC.TEXT: Intelsat, the international satellite organization, has filed a lawsuit seeking $400 million from rocket builder Martin Marietta for a launch that left a $145 million satellite in a useless orbit. The suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Baltimore, accuses Martin Marietta of miswiring its Titan 3 rocket and botching the March 14 launch for which Intelsat paid $115 million. Martin Marietta has said a wiring problem caused failure of the satellite and its attached booster rocket to separate from the Titan 3 when they reached orbit. As a result, the satellite could not be sent on to its duty station 22,300 miles above Earth, where communications satellites operate, The satellite, which Intelsat had not insured, will be a total loss unless it gets a boost. A space shuttle crew will try to rescue the satellite next year, costing Intelsat another $90 million or so. Martin Marietta attempted a pre-emptive strike against Intelsat in July, asking the federal court to declare that its only legal only responsibility was to provide a replacement launch. Elliott Miller, Martin Marietta's director of corporate relations, said Intelsat's suit had no merit and that Intelsat had had an opportunity to buy insurance but declined. ``Under the launch services contract between Martin Marietta and Intelsat, the relationship of the parties for risk of loss is clearly set forth,'' he said Tuesday. ``The contract provides that Martin Marietta is not liable for the satellite failure to achieve orbit.'' The Intelsat suit alleges Martin Marietta miswired the launch vehicle ``so that the payload did not and could not separate from the launch vehicle in response to commands sent by the Martin Marietta flight computer and computer software.'' The Titan 3 is designed to carry one or more payloads. On its first mission in December 1989, it put two satellites into orbit. Electrical signals were routed to separate first one satellite and then the other. The same wiring was in place for the Intelsat launch, which had no satellite in the No. 1 position. As a result, the separation command never reached the satellite that was on board. ``Martin Marietta has acknowledged that the launch failure was caused by this obvious, and readily avoidable, error,'' the Intelsat suit said, adding that the rocket builder showed ``manifest reckless indifference'' to Intelsat's interests. Martin Marietta launched a second satellite for Intelsat in June without a problem. In its suit, Martin Marietta said it might have to go out of the commercial launch business if it were made to pay damages. ``The very viability of Martin Marietta's commercial launch services business is dependent on a determination of its rights under the contract,'' it said. But in its countersuit, Intelsat noted that Martin Marietta was considering dropping out anyway, having told its stockholders in an annual report that production of Titan 3 rockets ``will depend upon the market for heavy-lift launch vehicles.''

DOC.HEAD: Milwaukee Students Take State Money to Private Schools
LaserPhoto MI1
DOC.TEXT: When buses rolled up Tuesday at schools throughout the city for the start of another academic year, nearly 400 students embarked on a new journey: to private schools with taxpayers' help. The experimental Milwaukee Parental Choice Program, eventually expected to help send 1,000 poor Milwaukee students to non-sectarian private schools, survived two court challenges led by the state's chief education official. The debut drew raves from parents whose children qualified, including single mother Yvette Harris, who attended a private school as a child but could not afford the same for her three children. ``For my 12-year-old to go to a private school, it's really a privilege for us. They were always praised for a quality education. I couldn't afford the tuition at all,'' said Ms. Harris. She enrolled her eldest, Jamal, in seventh grade at Juanita Virgil Academy and Josh Jr., 4, and Angelica, 3, in preschool under the program, which pays up to $2,500 for each child's tuition. The state vouchers completely covered the tuitions, said Ms. Harris, who attended a parochial elementary school in Chicago. The program's funding is deducted from the operating budget of the Milwaukee Public Schools system, which has about 98,200 students. Families not more than 75 percent above the federal poverty level, which allows a $12,000 annual income for a family of four, are eligible. Parents receive state vouchers that are redeemed by the schools. The plan's chief sponsor, state Rep. Polly Williams, greeted pupils at Urban Day elementary school, where more than 100 new students enrolled with the help of the state. The school has a total enrollment of 500. Ms. Williams, a Democrat, said the program gives hope to poor students who suffered in crowded public schools that reinforce the cycle of poverty. ``These kids are getting something out of these schools they can't get in the public school system. Every child who walks through those doors is expected to achieve. It's going to make a difference in the lives of a lot of children,'' she said. Among the school's new students was Antonio Johnson, an eighth-grader. ``I'm going to try to do the best I can do,'' he said. The Legislature authorized $2.5 million for the program _ enough for 1,000 students _ but only 390 were registered in private schools by Tuesday. The eight participating private schools said they were forced to reject hundreds of students because of limited classroom space and teaching staff. Urban Day administrator Zakiya Courtney said the school lost students in recent years because of rising tuition, which now costs $3,300 a year. ``Private school has basically been afforded to those who can afford it. If a low-income parent couldn't make the sacrifice, they couldn't do it. We advocated for this program,'' she said. More than 300 students applied at the school under the program, but most were denied entrance to retain average class sizes of 20 students, said Courtney. Although the program was praised by Gov. Tommy G. Thompson and the Bush administration, State Schools Superintendent Herbert J. Grover opposed it, saying it undermined public schools. Grover joined a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the program on the grounds that the private schools were private endeavors and therefore ineligible for state funds. Dane County Circuit Court and a state appeals court rejected the suit. Critics argue that the private schools are not accountable to the state. The National Association for Advancement of Colored People, which also joined the lawsuit, said the program helps only a few students while ignoring the thousands who will remain in public schools. ``It's crazy to talk about 1,000 students when you've got 64,000 or better students in the Milwaukee Public schools who need help,'' said Felmers Chaney, president of the NAACP's Milwaukee chapter. Proponents counter that the program may encourage public schools to improve. Plans that allow parents more choice on where to send their children to school have gained momentum in the last five years. Minnesota and Iowa were among the first to offer tax credits to parents sending their children to private schools. Wisconsin's voucher system is the nation's first will likely be expanded in Wisconsin and duplicated through the nation, Ms. Williams said. ``Public schools are shaking in their boots. They're terrified. They don't know how they're going to stop the movement,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Nearly 2,000 Bodies Found at Secret Mass Grave in Sao Paulo
DOC.TEXT: Authorities on Tuesday uncovered a clandestine mass grave containing the remains of an estimated 1,700 bodies _ mostly poor people but also some political foes of Brazil's former military dictatorship. The skeletons were packed in blue plastic bags and buried in an unmarked section of the hillside cemetery of Perus, a working-class suburb of Sao Paulo, the country's largest city. Officials found the bones while checking up on what had happened to remains of paupers who died with no identification in the early 1970s. ``Up to 50 of the dead could be former political prisoners and opponents of the (1964-85) military regime,'' Luis Eduardo Greenhalgh, deputy mayor of Sao Paulo and a human rights activist, told The Associated Press. He said at least six already had been identified as ``disappeared'' political activists, presumably killed by the dictatorship. Greenhalgh said others may have been victims of police-backed death squads that summarily executed suspected criminals in the 1960s and '70s. Cemetery director Antonio Pires Eustaquio said most of the dead were paupers buried in 1971-72, whose identities were unknown at the time. By law, such remains must be unearthed and placed in a bone depository after three years, Eustaquio said. He said, ``Cemetery records showed the removal took place but did not indicate what had been done with the remains. I investigated and discovered the mass grave.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Said Ready to Present Radical Economic Reform Program
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, under pressure from rival reformers like Boris Yeltsin, personally will present a sweeping economic plan to the Soviet parliament as early as Monday, a spokesman said Tuesday. Gorbachev apparently has abandoned a moderate plan drafted by Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. Instead, he will present a plan drafted in large part by Stanislav Shatalin, a reformer who sits on Gorbachev's Presidential Council, said presidential spokesman Vitaly N. Ignatenko. Shatalin's ideas were embodied in a reform program presented to the parliament of the Russian federation on Monday. Ignatenko and other Gorbachev aides say Gorbachev and Yeltsin, the president of the Russian federation _ largest of the 15 Soviet republics, agree on the general shape of the reforms. A moderate plan presented last spring by Ryzhkov was rejected by the national parliament after the proposal touched off a run of panic buying, and he was drafting another moderate approach for presentation this fall. The decision to bypass the premier this time ``does not mean that Ryzhkov is no longer trusted by the president,'' Ignatenko said at a news conference. The parliament of the Russian federation was expected to approve Yeltsin's proposal next Tuesday. The soonest Gorbachev could present his own plan to the national parliament would be at the opening session scheduled for Monday, the day after he was due back from a summit in Helsinki with President Bush. Ignatenko skirted the issue of whether Gorbachev would in fact embrace the plan presented by Yeltsin, saying, ``There is a general consensus now that the program approved by Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev should serve as the basis of future economic reform.'' He said that each of the Soviet republics would have a chance to consider the proposed reforms. ``A single program will be submitted for them to approve, based on what we call the Professor Shatalin plan,'' Ignatenko told a news conference. But he did not specify whether he expected the Russian federation _ which includes half the Soviet people and two-thirds its land mass _ to approve the Shatalin plan before Gorbachev has a chance to offer it for national consideration. Asked how Gorbachev and Yeltsin would reconcile their plans, Ignatenko said there were only three main areas of disagreement: ``The rate or pace of reform, the sequence of the reforms, and the reform price-setting machinery.'' Although those disagreements appear major, Ignatenko said, ``There is no great difference between the two programs. They are not antagonistic or irreconcilable.'' He said the differences were ``very fine points that should be taken care of within the next few days. Our union republics will receive the program for discussion and approval. Every union republic is entitled to develop along its own lines and to amend those programs as they see fit.'' Copies of neither the Yeltsin plan nor that under consideration by Gorbachev were available to the Western press. Members of the Russian parliament said they had not yet seen a full copy of the 250-page report presented by Yeltsin on Monday. However, a version seen by The Associated Press said that it would relegate to the central government, headed by Gorbachev, only those powers given to it by the 15 republics. The Kremlin would lose its power to levy taxes and would have to rely on dues from the republics. But the central government would retain responsibility for defense, strengthening the currency and disaster relief. Members of a visiting American delegation that met Tuesday with a top Gorbachev economic adviser, Nikolai Petrakov, said the central leadership also was leaning toward such a plan. It would entail creation of a central bank, similar to the U.S. Federal Reserve, to control the currency supply.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Discuss Arms, Too, With Gorbachev, May Brief NATO on Way Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates, naming Brussels, inserting new 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: Next weekend's U.S.-Soviet summit will give Presidents Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev a chance to prod slow-moving conventional-arms talks as well as forge ``an even stronger bond'' of opposition to Iraq's Saddam Hussein, administration officials said Tuesday. Bush also is considering adding add a stop in Europe to brief NAT0 allies on his way back from Sunday's superpower summit in Helsinki, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Administration officials said planners were focusing on a Monday session in Brussels. Originally, Bush planned to return directly to Washington from the capital of Finland. But Fitzwater said the president would like to be able to brief allied leaders on the summit if possible, just as he did after his meeting last December with Gorbachev at Malta. After that earlier summit, Bush stopped briefly in Brussels to brief NATO. ``There is some discussion about whether we need to make another stop,'' Fitzwater said. ``Pack another pair of underwear,'' he added in an aside to reporters who cover the president. Bush, on his first day back from an often-interrupted three-week vacation in Maine, met with his Cabinet and other top advisers to discuss the upcoming summit. ``A new foundation for world order is being built and the spadework begins in Helsinki,'' Fitzwater declared. ``It is somewhat ironic that the prospect of war is forging a new blueprint for world peace. Both leaders will want to apply some new brushstrokes to this emerging picture.'' Most public attention has focused on what the two leaders might say on the subject of Iraq's invasion and continuing occupation of Kuwait. But arms talks also were sure to be discussed. Although negotiations on troop reductions are moving along well, officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity said there still are serious problems in negotiating reductions on cuts in aircraft and artillery. Both countries hope to wind up the Conventional Forces in Europe (CFE) pact in time for November's planned 35-country Paris summit of all European nations plus the United States and Canada. ``The two presidents will not be negotiating details of this agreement,'' Fitzwater said. ``But they will be attempting to add the impetus that will assure that that agreement is ready to sign and that the summit can be held.'' The two leaders will also likely discuss progress on a treaty to reduce long-range nuclear weapons. But officials said those talks appear to be moving along smoothly, and less of a push is needed for them than for the conventional arms talks. Soviet economic reforms will also be on the agenda, Fitzwater and other officials said. In particular, Bush is expected to bring up a study by the International Monetary Fund _ commissioned at last July's economic summit of industrial democracies in Houston _ of Soviet needs, the officials said. Bush and Gorbachev will also discuss regional hotspots, including Cambodia and Afghanistan, officials said. Still, officials stressed that the main purpose of the summit was to provide a highly visible show of superpower solidarity in bringing pressure to bear on Saddam to end his month-old occupation of Kuwait. ``This summit should provide an even stronger bond of unified opposition to Saddam. It also offers an important opportunity for both leaders to assess superpower interests in the post-Cold War period,'' Fitzwater said. The administration announced on Tuesday that Bush will ask Congress to forgive Egypt's $7 billion military debt to the United States and was looking at possible aid packages for other Middle Eastern nations that have helped out in enforcing the embargo. In all, 22 nations have contributed equipment or troops or both to the U.S.-led military effort to enforce the embargo. Bush will leave Washington Friday night, meet with Finland's President Mauno Koivisto on Saturday and then devote most of Sunday to his talks with Gorbachev. These include a morning session, a luncheon, an afternoon session and a joint news conference. ``We envision that a good deal of time will be spent on the Persian Gulf in these meetings,'' Fitzwater said. White House advance teams went to Helsinki Monday night to begin meetings with their Soviet counterparts on logistics. The White House had no immediate reaction to Tuesday's proposal by the Soviets for an international conference to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, the Arab-Israeli dispute and the Lebanese civil war. Gorbachev seems likely to bring that proposal up at the weekend summit, however. As to Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's assertion that the summit ``will mark a major milestone on the road toward resolving the crisis in the Persian Gulf,'' Fitzwater said: ``We agree with the Soviets that it will be important and constructive.'' Fitzwater likened the structure of the Helsinki summit _ Bush's third meeting as president with Gorbachev _ with last December's three-day summit in Malta in the Mediterranean. ``President Bush liked the unstructured agenda nature of the Malta summit. We will attempt to approximate that again in the Helsinki summit. He intends to preserve a considerable time for general discussions,''

DOC.HEAD: Son of Toppled Romanian Dictator Being Treated for Cirrhosis
DOC.TEXT: Nicolae Ceausescu's youngest son is being treated for cirrhosis of the liver as a court considers his role in dozens of deaths during the December revolution that resulted in the downfall of his dictator father. Nicu Ceausescu, who faces charges of ``complicity in genocide,'' celebrated his 39th birthday Saturday with relatives coming to his bed at Fundeni Hospital. Police guarded his door. ``The personnel treat me most carefully,'' Ceausescu was quoted as saying Tuesday by the state Rompres news agency. Lucian Buligescu, head of the hospital's liver department, said he hoped for ``considerable improvement'' in his patient's condition, which is attributed to alcohol problems. He said Ceausescu felt depressed. Ceausescu, former Communist Party chief of Sibiu, 150 miles northwest of Bucharest, allegedly ordered the shootings of townspeople who rose up against his father. He is also charged with illegal possession of firearms. Eighty-nine people died in Sibiu as the army and anti-Ceausescu activists fought against secret police troops loyal to the dictator. The younger Ceausescu, who was said to be a heavy drinker, suffered a stab wound to his liver on Dec. 22, the day of his arrest. His father and mother, Elena Ceausescu, were executed on Dec. 25. Sentencing is expected this month.

DOC.HEAD: Former Nationalist Spy Pilots Return Home
DOC.TEXT: Two former Nationalist air force pilots who were captured during spy missions for Taiwan and U.S. intelligence returned home Tuesday, more than 25 years after they were shot down in China. Yeh Chang-ti and Chang Li-yi were greeted at the airport by their families and former colleagues. ``It's nice to be home again,'' said Yeh. Yeh and Chang, both in their early 60s, have told reporters they wished to regain their status as majors in the air force to serve the country. Defense Minister Chen Li-an said Tuesday the two men's military status could not be restored because of their age. Chen said, however, his ministry would provide necessary compensation for Yeh and Chang. Military officials said they welcomed the pilots' return. Both Yeh and Chang were members of the ``Black Cat'' squadron, a secret unit of Taiwan's air force formed in 1961 by selected combat pilots. The now defunct squadron's missions were to fly U.S.-made Lockheed U-2 reconnaissance aircraft over China to gather military information for the Central Intelligence Agency and the Nationalist government in Taiwan. The Nationalists, driven to Taiwan in 1949 by Communist forces in China, had vowed to rule mainland China again. The United States switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1979. Yeh was shot down in 1963 while flying over Jiangxi province in eastern China, and Chang was downed in 1965 on a special research flight over northern China. They were captured and sentenced to forced labor, but were released from China in 1983. However, their request to return home was rejected as Taiwan authorities regarded the release as a Chinese propaganda move. The two then stayed in the United States with the help of the CIA. Yeh is a resident of Houston, and Chang lives in Washington. Four Nationalist pilots were killed during spy missions over China and six others died in accidents during training in the United States before authorities disbanded the squadron in 1974.

DOC.HEAD: Austria Restricts Travel by Poles; Sends Troops to Hungary Border
DOC.TEXT: Austria said Tuesday it was reimposing a visa requirement for Poles and sending troops to the Hungarian border to help stem an influx of East European refugees. The Interior Ministry said Polish citizens would once again need visas to travel to Austria. The visa requirement takes effect on Friday and will be in force for six months. The Polish Foreign Ministry issued a brief statement expressing ``regret and surprise'' over Austria's decision. In retaliation, the Foreign Ministry announced it was introducing a visa requirement for Austrians for the same period. Austria has not required visas from Poles since 1988. It was the only visa-free travel destination in Western Europe for Poles besides West Berlin, which will also change its regulations following the Oct. 3 German unification. Austria now finds itself facing a growing influx of East Europeans over the past few months, particularly Poles and Romanians who endure severe economic hardships at home. Austria says that with the exception of some Romanians, most of the new arrivals do not qualify for refugee status because they no longer face political persecution at home. The main Traiskirchen refugee camp south of Vienna is currently accomodating 2,000 people _ double its capacity. The transfer of refugees to other facilities is slow. In an effort to prevent Romanians and other East Europeans from illegally crossing the Hungarian-Austrian border, Austria said it would send 1,500 soldiers in the next two days to the border region to assist customs officials. Chancellor Franz Vranitzky said the troops would be deployed for an initial period of 10 weeks. Interior Minister Franz Loeschnak said Monday the soldiers would be limited to patrolling the border and would only use their weapons in self-defense. The government said that if necessary soldiers may also be dispatched to patrol the borders with other Eastern European countries. Austria is also bordered by Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia. In its statement, the Polish Foreign Ministry admitted some Poles have engaged in illegal trade or work in Austria, but stressed that such phenomena ``cannot be a basis for making a decision limiting the freedom of travel of all citizens of both countries.'' Polish Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski also criticized the Austrian decision. ``It is discrepant with our policy aiming at introducing a full freedom of movement of people in Europe,'' Skubiszewski said in an interview for an evening radio newscast. Austrian authorities had threatened to restore the visa requirement for Poles earlier this year. In an effort to meet Austrian concerns, Poland imposed strict customs controls and invited Austrian customs officials to join their counterparts at Polish border crossings. Foreign Ministry spokesman Wladyslaw Klaczynski noted that more and more Western countries were lifting visa requirements for Hungarians and Czechoslovakians. But he said no Western country was currently planning to do the same for Poles. Klaczynski said the Austrian decision amounted to ``a kind of discrimination against Poles.'' ``We do not deny that it has its cause but this cause does not justify such a decision. We should aim at removing barriers not at erecting them,'' he told The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Teachers Strike in Four States; New Orleans Strike Threatened
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `College professors ..., and 11th graf, `At the ..., and ADDS two grafs at end to include reference to University of Bridgeport. No pickup. ^By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Teachers went on strike Tuesday in school districts in Michigan, Washington, Rhode Island and Pennsylvania, and New Orleans teachers voted to strike in two weeks unless their demands are met. College professors walked out in contract disputes at Wayne State University in Detroit and Temple University in Philadelphia. A strike continued at the University of Bridgeport in Connecticut. In all, the strikes disrupted education for a total of about 60,000 students in Saginaw, Mich., Yakima, Wash., and outside Seattle and Everett, Wash. School openings are also threatened at three smaller districts in Cheboygan, Mich., North Kingston, R.I., and Ligonier, Pa., where school starts Wednesday and teachers have gone on strike. Those districts have a total of about 10,000 students. A strike in New Orleans, where school started Tuesday, could affect about 85,000 pupils. Teachers there overwhelmingly approved a strike pledge for Sept. 17 in a voice vote Tuesday morning. They want the school district to pay more of their health insurance bills and raise the salaries of teachers' aides. The teachers dropped a demand that their own salaries be raised. In Yakima, school officials said they would show videotaped lessons to the 12,000 pupils affected by the strike. Teachers urged parents to keep their children at home during the strike. The Yakima teachers struck despite a restraining order from a judge, who prohibited them from striking, picketing or engaging in ``other acts disruptive to the normal school process.'' ``We are not afraid,'' said Melanie Mitchell, president of the teachers' union, the Yakima Education Association. ``We made a decision which we are committed to, and the district is not going to scare us back into the classroom.'' The union said the sticking points in contract negotiations included class size, evaluation of teachers and special education issues. The district characterized the remaining contract points as money issues. The other Washington strikes affected 22,500 pupils in the Lake Washington School District in the Seattle suburbs of Kirkland, Juanita and Redmond; and 9,100 pupils in Mukilteo, south of Everett. At the three colleges, Wayne State, Temple and Bridgeport, administrators pledged to hold classes without the striking instructors. ``The university will be open,'' said President Peter Liacouras at Temple, which has an undergraduate enrollment of 31,000. University spokesman George Ingram said some classes were held Tuesday, but others had to be canceled for lack of teachers. Similarly, Wayne State administrators said they would try to hold classes this week despite a strike by the American Association of University Professors, which represents 1,500 instructors, or about 35 percent of the faculty. Wayne State has an enrollment of 30,000. Faculty members turned down annual raises of 5 percent at Temple at 4.8 percent at Wayne. At the University of Bridgeport, which has an undergraduate enrollment of about 4,000, college President Janet Greenwood said replacement workers _ including faculty _ had been hired to keep the school ``fully operational.'' The strike by all three campus unions began Saturday, but maintenance and cafeteria workers stayed on the job while students moved in during the weekend. Classes begin Wednesday night.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Gulf States Giving U.S. Warplanes New Access
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs `Ships carrying ...' to CORRECT spelling to Stuart, sted Stewart
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney confirmed Tuesday that the United States has deployed combat aircraft in several smaller Persian Gulf states as part of the buildup of forces to protect Saudi Arabia. He conceded that those aircraft deployments amount to a committment to defend the countries involved. The announcement came as additional combat-ready forces continued to flow into the Persian Gulf region. Ships carrying a Marine expeditionary unit from Okinawa, equipped with a squadron of assault and cargo helicopters, have arrived in position near the Saudi peninsula. Pentagon spokesman Lt. Col. Stuart Wagner said the 2,200-man unit left Okinawa several weeks ago. Meanwhile, Pentagon sources said the Persian Gulf nation of Bahrain had agreed to accept American F-A-18 jets _ which can either fight other warplanes or attack ground targets _ along with A-6 bombers and AV-8 Harrier jump jets. Those planes are flown by the Navy and the Marines. Also, F-16 air-to-air fighters have been deployed in the United Arab Emirates and F-15 ground attack jets in Oman, the sources said. Those planes are flown by the Air Force. The United Arab Emirates had announced several weeks ago that it had agreed to accept U.S. KC-130 cargo and transport planes, while Qatar announced last week it would allow American F-16 fighter jets that had been stationed in Spain to be positioned on its territory. Cheney, in an interview on ABC-TVs ``Good Morning America,'' declined to specify exactly which Persian Gulf nations had agreed to station U.S. aircraft on their soil. But he confirmed that attack planes and bombers had been positioned in nations along the southern shore of the Persian Gulf, the location of Bahrain, Qatar, Oman and the United Arab Emirates. ``The exact degree of participation by each of them varies and there are obviously also some sensititivities on their part in terms of extent to which they are willing to acknowledge their cooperation,'' Cheney said. ``But I think it would be fair to say that there is more cooperation from those Persian Gulf states today than there has ever been before in terms of our mutual security efforts in the region.'' In another interview on CNN, Cheney said the bombers and war planes were ``not only deployed in Saudi Arabia, but in some of the other nations in the region who are friends and allies of ours'' and who were cooperating in Operation Desert Shield, the deployment of forces to protect Saudi Arabia from Iraq. The secretary noted that most of those nations in the past have refused to accept any U.S. military presence but now all are helping out. Some permit transport aircraft, some permit combat aircraft, and ``in some places we have access arrangements or naval arrangements. They are cooperating to one degree or another,'' he said. Cheney said he was able to negotiate the variety of agreements during his trip to the region last month. Asked whether the presence of U.S. forces amounts to an implicit commitment to also defend those countries, Cheney said, ``I think it does.'' Those countries warmed toward military cooperation with the United States during the eight-year war between Iran and Iraq, when U.S. warships protected Kuwaiti tankers from Iranian attack in the Persian Gulf. The Marine expeditionary unit is capable of conducting commando operations and contains a helicopter element including a variety of AH-1 Cobra gunships, CH-53 Sea Stallion assault choppers and CH-46 Sea Knight transport helicopters.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi TV Censors Saddam Hussein Warning to Foreigners in Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 11th graf pvs, `Walker said...,' to UPDATE with boradcast giving TV crew member's recollection of what Saddam said; INSERTS 1 graf after penultimate graf, `Jackson returned...,' to UPDATE with White House praise for Jackson.
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein warned he would regard foreigners hiding in Kuwait as spies, but Iraqi censors cut the ``dire threat'' from his interview with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a producer said Tuesday. The deletion was the second case in four days of Iraqi censorship of U.S. television reports from Baghdad, despite the Iraqi president's recent attempts to use television to justify his Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait. On Monday, Iraqi censors blacked out part of an NBC report that showed foreign hostages. ``NBC Nightly News'' aired the report, including the sudden blackout the censors imposed near the end of the piece as it was being transmitted via satellite from Baghdad. Earlier, Iraqi censors cut eight to 10 minutes from Jackson's interview Friday with Saddam, according to Av Westin, executive producer of ``Inside Edition,'' a syndicated series that paid for Jackson's trip to Iraq last week. ``The dire threat was that anybody who did not turn themselves in within 10 days would be treated as a spy,'' Westin said. ``It was that they would be treated as spies and dealt with as spies ... that was eliminated from the tape.'' But Saddam made no threats of harm to them, said Kenneth Walker, a former ABC News correspondent who accompanied Jackson on his 90-minute interview with the Iraqi president. Walker said the warning came in the context of Jackson's questions about foreign women and children in Kuwait. He quoted Jackson as telling Saddam several times that these foreigners may not know of Saddam's previous offers to release them or were too terrified to surrender to Iraqi forces. After Jackson urged Saddam to jointly appear with him on Baghdad TV to announce a specific plan for the release of foreign women and children, Walker said, ``Saddam finally said something like: `Well, I have good feelings for children. But if these people do not come forward, they will be regarded as spies.' '' Walker said Saddam did not make clear if he were speaking only of the women and children or of male foreigners, but that it could be assumed he was referring to all three categories. However, in a Tuesday broadcast of ``Inside Edition,'' Walker, after checking with two American colleagues were with him during Jackson's interview, quoted Saddam as saying of foreigners in Kuwait: ``Any adults who don't come forward now will be treated as spies.'' Walker and Westin said the censorship wasn't discovered until Monday night, when the staff of the syndicated ``Inside Edition'' was editing tapes of Jackson's interview. Another missing portion, Westin said, involved Jackson's questions about providing fuel, water and medicine for Americans trapped at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. The embassy has defied Saddam's order to close. Walker said Jackson's interview was taped by three TV crews from Iraq's state-run television facilities. The tapes that proved to be censored were given to Jackson's entourage a day after the interview, he said. There had been no conditions set for the interview, and was there no warning that censorship would occur, he said. Jackson's meeting with Saddam came three days after the Iraqi leader was interviewed by CBS anchorman Dan Rather. Iraqi TV crews also taped that interview, but cut nothing from it, CBS spokeswoman Donna Dees said. ``Inside Edition,'' which paid $125,000 for Jackson and his 14-member entourage to go to Iraq for the interview and other reports, was to start a four-part series on the trip Tuesday. Jackson returned to Washington from Iraq on Sunday with 47 freed Americans who had been held hostage in Iraq and Kuwait. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater praised him Tuesday, saying President Bush ``is pleased by Jesse's success in bringing back Americans and we're grateful he (Jackson) was able to make those arrangements.'' Jackson's own ``The Jesse Jackson Show'' is to premiere this month. That show is syndicated by Warner Bros., a rival of King World, which syndicates ``Inside Edition.''

DOC.HEAD: Illiteracy and Child Abuse Top Contestants' List of Concerns
DOC.TEXT: Illiteracy and child abuse most concern this year's Miss America contestants, each of whom must choose an issue to emphasize if she wins the pageant. The top concerns also include, in order of preference: care for the elderly, drug abuse, physical fitness, the environment, arts in education, volunteerism, cancer education and motivating youth. Each of the 50 contestants must list three topics and promise to focus on one if crowned Miss America 1991 on Saturday. The requirement was first made last year and Miss America 1990 Debbye Turner chose ``motivating youth to excellence.'' Miss Georgia Darla Michele Pruett promised to promote literacy, saying ``poverty and crime are all part of illiteracy.'' Miss Tennessee Dana Brown said she chose child abuse because she worked with victims. ``I've seen hopeless situations,'' she said. ``It's a problem no one is willing to discuss. People think there's nothing they can do, but there is something they can do.'' Other contestants chose issues that affected them or their families. Miss Pennsylvania Marla Wynne said she would promote cancer education and prevention because cancer struck 11 members of her family, including her mother. ``I almost felt obligated to stop this,'' she said. Miss Nebraska Michelle Ebadi, the daughter of Iranian immigrants, hoped to boost American's awareness of those of other ethnic groups. Miss Louisiana Linnea Marie Fayard, whose father gave a kidney to her uncle, wants to encourage organ donation. Miss Arizona Kimberly Hoskins said her grandparents made her aware of the problems facing elderly Americans. Miss Arkansas Karissa Rushing, a ballet dancer for 15 years, said she hoped schools would emphasize arts education. ``I'm not saying everybody should love opera or participate in ballet or theater,'' Miss Rushing said. ``But it does teach children critical thinking and how to come up with new ideas.'' Others said the environment deserved special attention. ``Let's look at our responsibility here,'' said Miss Michigan Victoria Fair. ``It's our obligation to preserve the earth. We just can't hop on Mars.''

DOC.HEAD: Precede NICOSIA
25 Americans Among 109 Western Detainees to Arrive from Baghdad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with arrival of 25 Americans among nearly 300 Westerns on flight from Baghdad, details, quotes. No pickup. CHANGES byline
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-five Americans were among nearly 300 Western women and children to arrive here Tuesday from Baghdad on three Iraqi Airways planes. The last flight to arrive just before midnight (5 p.m. EDT) brought 150 people, including the 25 Americans, 44 French, 36 British, four Australians and two Canadian women and children. They had been detained in Iraq and Kuwait since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. One of the flights that arrived earlier in the day included 135 West Germans among its passengers, and the other brought 170 people, mainly Arab nationals. A total of 175 Western nationals were expected to leave Amman early Wednesday aboard a Virgin Atlantic airlines jumbo jet. The jumbo had landed in Amman a few hours earlier with 30 tons of food and other supplies for the tens of thousands of Asian evacuees from Kuwait stranded in squalid camps in Jordan. ``We heard there was a potentially catastrophic problem in Jordan with young and old people dying and we had to do something before it was too late,'' Richard Branson, the British owner of the airline who flew in on the jet told reporters on arrival. Shortly after his arrival, Branson and his crew were thanked by Jordan's American-born wife Queen Noor, who went aboard the plane. ``We are grateful, we desperately need all this,'' the queen told Branson, pointing at sacks of wheat slung on top of the scarlet first-class seats aboard the plane. ``We will get this to the really desperate areas and this kind of action that you've done is tremendous help,'' she added. Branson said later he ``was upset'' because he made 200 seats available to one Asian embassy to fly evacuees out of Amman, but a bureaucratic foulup meant the seats went unused. He said he had provided the United Nations with a list of airlines and planes available for charter for a massive airlift to fly home the estimated 100,000 impoverished Asian nationals stranded in Jordan. Mothers emerged from the planes with sleeping infants and shouldering older children who looked confused. ``I feel great,'' said a young American, George Issa, wearing a football jersey. Asked what he thought of Baghdad, American Taleb Subah said, ``Better than Kuwait, I tell you that.'' ``Kuwait was a living hell,'' said the Davenport, Iowa, teen-ager. ``You go to sleep on bombing and you wake up to it. ... It is like Vietnam. I saw dead people all over, they throw them in the trash.'' An elderly American woman refused to say anything, except, ``I am so tired.'' She kept walking past reporters. Most people were taken directly from the arriving airliners to the VIP lounge at the Queen Alia airport, where counselors and diplomats talked to them. Asked if she had been afraid, Sheila Russell, from Northampton, England, said, ``I never saw an angry man.'' But when asked if she was happy to leave, she answered, ``I left my husband behind.'' Another British woman, Belinda Quinn, seemed overjoyed at her release. She said, ``I kept thinking every minute that the plane (departure) will be canceled.'' One woman was asked what she would remember of it all? ``Just the gunfire and the explosions,'' she said, declining to give her name. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said last week he would allow Western women and children to leave, but not the men. More than 700 Western detainees _ women, children and a few ailing men _ left aboard two Iraqi Airways flights on Saturday. Some evacuees also have traveled across the desert to Jordan. But the departures of others have been complicated by Iraq's refusal to allow foreign airlines to land in Baghdad and by long delays in processing their exit permits. About 11,000 Westerners are now believed stranded in Kuwait and Iraq. Earlier Tuesday, hundreds more Westerners headed across the desert in buses hoping they too would be able to catch flights from Baghdad to freedom. The bus convoy, carrying about 300 Britons, left occupied Kuwait on Tuesday and was headed for the Iraqi capital. The British-organized bus convoy left Kuwait at about 5:25 a.m., British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd told reporters in Saudi Arabia. The foreign secretary said 148 women and 150 children were on the 500-mile trip, traveling in a convoy of seven buses and a car, he said. In London, a Foreign Office spokesman put the figure at 150 women and 156 children. William Waldegrave, the British Foreign Office's second-ranking official, had estimated the convoy would take 10-12 hours to reach Baghdad. But he noted a previous convoy from Kuwait took 28 hours.

DOC.HEAD: Studies Look At How Fatness, Fitness and Television Effect Children
DOC.TEXT: Two new studies of obesity and high blood pressure among children produced advice that sounds a lot like the admonitions of a strict parent: Watch what you eat and quit watching so much TV. Doctors studying a group of poor children in New York concluded that the children's blood pressure depended in part on how much they weighed and exercised. Bad childhood habits could carry over to cause high blood pressure or heart disease when the children grow up, the researchers warned. ``There is evidence cardiovascular disease originates during childhood,'' said the New York study, which is published in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. A second study, a review of national data by the Harvard School of Public Health and Tufts New England Medical Center, found that the more television obese children and adolescents watch, the less likely they are to lose weight. ``Diet, exercise and restriction of television viewing and other sedentary activities all appear necessary to halt the fattening of America,'' said that report, which was published in Wednesday's edition of the Journal of the American Dietetic Association. The New York study was the first to examine the separate and combined effects of fitness and fatness in young inner-city children, said Bernard Gutin and his colleagues at Columbia University. Over the last five years, the researchers studied 216 children ages 5 and 6 recruited from clinics, day-care centers and a hospital. The children, 91 percent of whom where Hispanic, came from poor families. Researchers took the children's blood pressure, tested their aerobic fitness on a treadmill and assessed their obesity by measuring their bodies and skin folds, the report said. It concluded that much of the difference in their blood pressures related to how fat and how fit they were. While previous studies have shown that obesity and lack of fitness contribute to cardiovascular problems in adults, ``it has never been shown before in children this young,'' said Gutin, professor of applied physiology and education at Columbia University's teachers college. ``We think of blood pressure as something we worry about as adults, but it seems we have to worry about it when children are young,'' he said in a telephone interview Tuesday. ``Children are probably suffering damage to their coronary arteries even now.'' The Harvard study on television viewing grew from a second review of national data collected between 1963 and 1980. That data showed obesity increased by 46 percent among children and adolescents through the years, though calorie intake hadn't risen proportionally, said dietician Lilian W.Y. Cheung. She and other researchers went over the data again, focusing on 1,900 children living throughout the United States, said Cheung, director of the Harvard Nutrition and Fitness Project. The chance of becoming fat increased 1.3 percent for each additional hour of television viewing daily, the report said. And the chances a youngster could be ``cured'' of obesity decreased 6.3 percent with each additional hour of television viewing daily, the report said. It defined cured as reducing weight to a desired level and keeping it off for five years. Previous studies have shown that watching television promotes obesity partly because it takes people away from more active pursuits. Also, television commercials encourage people to eat high-calorie foods, the study said.

DOC.HEAD: Cars and Other Vehicles Recalled for Too Much Pollution
DOC.TEXT: Mitsubishi Motors Corp. is recalling about 92,000 cars and 75,000 trucks and utility vehicles sold for failure to meet federal exhaust pollution standards, the Environmental Protection Agency announced Tuesday. The cars involved are the 1987 Mitsubishi Mirage and Dodge Colt and Plymouth Colt models equipped with the 1.5-liter engine. The other vehicles are 1986 and 1987 models equipped with the 2-liter engine _ 1986 Dodge and Plymouth Colt Vistas with four-wheel drive and two-wheel-drive Dodge Ram 50 and Mitsubishi trucks, and 1987 Dodge and Plymouth Colt Vistas with four-wheel drive. The Dodge and Plymouth models concerned are manufactured by Mitsubishi. The agency said routine testing discovered that the cars emit more than the permitted about of carbon monoxide, and the trucks and utility vehicles emit too much carbon monoxide and unburned fuel. Owners will be asked to schedule appointments at Mitsubishi or Dodge and Plymouth dealers for modifications _ installation of a new valve in the pollution control system of the cars and changes in the fuel systems of the trucks and utility vehicles. Mitsubishi owners will be notified first and Dodge and Plymouth owners later, the EPA said. Owners of the trucks and utility vehicles will be asked to leave them with the dealer for a full day because of required adjustments that can be made only after a warm engine has cooled, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: African Force Intervenes to save Ghanaian
DOC.TEXT: The five-nation African military force intervened Tuesday to save a foreigner who forced his way out of a fast-moving car driven by armed men. The incident sent journalists diving for cover when one of the car's occupants chased their Ghanaian hostage on foot and opened fire. Soldiers of the West African task force, who were camped nearby, disarmed the gunman and took him into custody. It wasn't known immediately whether the gunman was from a faction of rebels battling to take control of Liberia. There was little fighting in the city as the task force moved cautiously Tuesday to expand areas of the capital under its control, and a few fishermen ventured into the city to sell fish to the capital's residents. Monrovia residents said incidents like Tuesday's were common, but in most cases the victims were unable to escape their executioners. The commander of the force, Ghanaian Lt. Gen. Arnold Quainoo, left for talks with Gambian President Sir Dawda Jawara, who had dispatched the troops to oppose rebel forces under Charles Taylor. Troops loyal to President Samuel Doe and a rebel splinter group led by Prince Johnson appeared to be observing a truce that began the day the West African force landed April 24. Reports from Lagos, Nigeria, said Nigeria was shipping additional arms, equipment and medical supplies to the five-nation force on Tuesday. Jawara, who heads the Economic Community of West African States, also was to meet with officials of Burkina Faso, which has criticized the intervention and been accused of supporting the rebels. About 3,000 soldiers from Ghana, Nigeria, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Gambia landed at Monrovia's port in April under orders to end a civil war that has left at least 5,000 people dead since last December. When they arrived, Monrovia had been isolated and without water and electricity for two months. There was almost no food. The African troops have been attacked by rebels loyal to Taylor, but were welcomed by Doe and Johnson. Taylor has vowed to destroy the five-nation force, and declared himself president of Liberia. His forces have been unable to dislodge troops loyal to Doe in Monrovia's eastern suburbs. Johnson, who split with Taylor after the rebels invaded Liberia from the the neighboring Ivory Coast on Dec. 24, also reached Monrovia and failed to drive Doe from his heavily fortified mansion. The United States, meanwhile, continued to evacuate foreigners from its embassy in Monrovia, said an embassy official who declined to be further identified. A contingent of U.S. Marines guarded the embassy. Evacuees were being taken to Freetown, Sierra Leone, for flights to Europe.

DOC.HEAD: House Leaders Advocate Using Reserves in Combat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 6-7: ``Pentagon spokesman,'' with Pentagon comment
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Democratic and Republican leaders of the House Armed Services Committee suggested Tuesday that the administration send Reserve combat units to join active military forces in the Middle East. Committee chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., and the ranking Republican, Rep. Bill Dickinson, R-Ala., said deploying reservists in combat roles would provide an important test of their capabilities and the wisdom of relying on Reserve forces as part of future defense planning. ``We want to see ... how good the combat units are,'' Aspin said at a news conference. ``This is a test for the future. President Bush's callup of Army Reserves has been confined to support roles, backing up active-duty combat forces in Saudi Arabia. Aspin and Dickinson spoke separately, a day after they returned from a four-day tour of the Middle East as part of a 22-member delegation. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams, questioned by reporters about the Reserve issue, declined to say what recommendations are before Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Williams said there has been ``a lot of discussion about what might happen down the road,'' but no decision has been made. It is expected that it would take at least 90 days to train Army combat reservists. A member of a separate delegation of senators arriving at Andrews Air Force Base near Washington from a Saudi tour said late Tuesday afternoon the question of the use of reserve combat units would be raised when lawmakers meet President Bush on Wednesday. ``There's concern that we're putting all this money into combat reserves and yet they're not being called up,'' said Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, a member of the Armed Services Committee. Aspin said defense planning for the post-Cold War period has been based in part on an assumption that Reserve units could be used in any medium- to large-scale troop deployment. However, he said, military officials are reluctant to use Reserves in combat roles. He said military leaders, including those in Saudi Arabia, are skeptical about the use of Reserve combat forces, citing three- or six-month limitations as one reason. But Aspin said that military estimates that combat reservists would require up to 60 days training may be too pessimistic. The Reserve callup has been for only a three-month period, but Aspin and Dickinson said Congress may need give Bush broader authority to call up reservists and National Guardsmen for up to a year's service. Lawmakers returning from their trip to Bahrain, Egypt and Saudi Arabia and an inspection of U.S. military operations expressed widespread support for Bush's response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Some said the crisis will prompt a new look at how U.S. military dollars are spent as the nation comes to grips with growing budget problems. The overriding concern among lawmakers was the level of participation by other nations in Operation Desert Shield and the campaign to deter Iraqi aggression. ``I call on our NATO countries to take a more active role, with men on the ground,'' House Republican Leader Bob Michel of Illinois told reporters. The lawmakers' comments came as congressional and White House negotiators prepared for a four-day, closed session on reaching a deficit-cutting agreement to solve the budget crisis. The session begins Friday. In addition, the full House is scheduled to take up a $283 billion defense bill for fiscal 1991 starting Monday, with planned cuts in the Strategic Defense Initiative and the B-2 stealth bomber on the agenda. Throwing a wrench in plans to cut Bush's request for $307 billion in defense spending for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 is the White House estimate that it will cost $1 billion a month to foot the bill for Operation Desert Shield. Lawmakers said the U.S. presence would likely last at least two or three months, and Rep. Sonny Montgomery, D-Miss., told reporters that ``even if we get Hussein to settle down ... we might have to keep some multinational force over there.'' Asked how the United States could pay for U.S. forces, Montgomery, a member of the House Armed Services Committee, suggested reducing the planned purchase of some weapons while eliminating others. In its version of the defense bill, the House Armed Services Committee halted production of the B-2 bomber at the 15 currently in production. At nearly $865 million each, it is the costliest airplane ever built. The panel also stripped nearly $2 billion from Bush's request of $4.7 billion for SDI, popularly known as Star Wars. In a report on the trip, House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said additional money must be provided in this fiscal year as well as the next to support the U.S. military presence in the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Government Announces $66 Million New Bedford Harbor Cleanup
DOC.TEXT: A New York company has agreed to pay $66 million toward cleaning up New Bedford Harbor, where industrial pollution has forced closing of lobster and fishing grounds, the federal government announced Tuesday. Officials said the payment _ part of a settlement between the government and AVX Corp. of New York City _ is one of the largest such payments in the history of the Superfund. The decade-old fund was set up to attack the nation's worst cases of hazardous waste pollution. AVX was one of five companies accused in a federal complaint filed in 1983 of contributing to the pollution of New Bedford Harbor by releasing PCBs, or polychlorinated biphenyls, from manufacturing plants near the harbor. PCBs have been found to cause cancer, and their use has been restricted. A call to AVX headquarters for comment Tuesday evening rang unanswered. The complaint alleged that the PCBs damaged the harbor's natural resources, including 18,000 acres of beaches, fishing and lobstering grounds. Part of the $66 million settlement will reimburse the government for money it has already spent at New Bedford, home to one of the nation's biggest commercial fishin fleets. ``Settlements such as this are the backbone of the Superfund program,'' said U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Administrator William Reilly in a news release. ``EPA is committed to an aggressive policy of making those who pollute pay for the cleanup. We will continue to use every enforcement mechanism available to bring about more settlements and more private party cleanups.'' The money is to be paid to the EPA, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the state. From 1947 through 1973, AVX owned and operated what is now known as the Aerovox plant. AVX recently merged with a Japanese firm, EPA spokesman Jim Sebastian said Tuesday. Studies by the Environmental Protection Agency in the 1970s revealed high levels of PCBs in fish and shellfish in New Bedford Harbor. As a result, officials closed a 10-square-mile area of the harbor to lobstering and closed a smaller area to fishing for bottom-feeding species. They remain closed. The government has reached an agreement in principle with two other companies named in the original complaints, Aerovox Inc., of New Bedford, and Belleville Industries Inc., a dissolved company, officials said. The terms of the settlement are to be presented in federal district court this fall. A trial date of March 4, 1991, has been set for the two other companies named in the complaint, Federal Pacific Electric Co., of Delaware, and Cornell-Dubilier Electronics Inc., of New Bedford. New Bedford Harbor is an urban tidal estuary at the head of Buzzards Bay, 50 miles southeast of Boston.

DOC.HEAD: Indians Urge Monument to Warriors Who Fell at Little Big Horn in Montana
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf: ``A memorial,'' to RESTORE dropped words ``would cost about''
DOC.TEXT: American Indian leaders urged Congress on Tuesday to approve a memorial to the warriors who fell at Little Big Horn while Virginia officials urged a national commission to help preserve Civil War battlefields. ``We need to honor our warriors who gave their lives,'' Carol Gipp of the National Congress of American Indians told the House Interior Committee's subcommittee on national parks and public lands. The appeal came as Indians, conservationists and others crowded the hearing room to plead for approval of favorite bills before Congress adjourns next month. A memorial to the warriors who fell in the 1876 victory of the Sioux over Lt. Col. George Custer and a detachment of the 7th Cavalry Regiment would cost about $2.1 million, the National Park Service has estimated. The service is supporting the memorial, as yet undesigned. The memorial would be adjacent to the monument to the 7th Cavalry which was erected on Last Stand Hill on the Montana battlefield in 1881. It bears the full names of Custer and each of the 224 other men in his command. Custer was a temporary general with the Union Army during the Civil War but reverted to lieutenant colonel afterward, the rank he held in 1876. Susan Shown-Harjo, president of the Morning Star Foundation representing the Cheyenne and Arapaho Tribes, said the names of the cavalry troopers on the monument has given them ``dignity in death.'' ``Our people who died there are referred to as hordes of Indians along with the cavalry who are named,'' she said. The number of Indian dead is unknown, but the National Park Service says no more than 100 are believed to have been killed in the battle. Virginia officials and historic preservationists urged approval of a national commission on civil war battlefields to help shield a number of sites from development as the suburbs outside the nation's capital spread southward. Mayor Elizabeth G. Helm of Winchester pointed to estimates that employment in the Dulles Corridor outside Washington would grow more than 1,000 percent and the homes of those joining the labor force most likely would be in central Maryland and the northern Shenandoah Valley. ``This same area is heavily steeped in history and tradition but we have tended to take this heritage for granted,'' she said. ``We have assumed that it will always be with us for future generations.'' ``Our ancestors provided beautifully for large and splendid Confederate and national cemeteries but no one anticipated the growth that has obliterated many of the battlefields,'' she added. Also urging action were Reps. Jim Olin, D-Va., and D. French Slaughter Jr., R-Va., as well as historic preservationists who are urging quick action by the government before suburban sprawl gobbles up battlefields. Dr. James Gardner, deputy director of the American Historical Association, however, opposed the plan. If approved, he said, ``greater and greater amounts of money will be pushed into this aspect of our history to the exclusion of others.'' He said preservationists ``should not be so preoccupied with Civil War battlefields.'' ``We need to pull back from this Civil War focus and take a broader view of American history,'' he said.
