DOC.HEAD: More Bittersweet Homecomings for Americans From Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: A new wave of Americans has begun returning home after fleeing Kuwait, and as with previous hostages, their joy is tempered by the knowledge that others remain behind. ``It feels great,'' Rhonda Kilgore said Monday after she and her three young children arrived at her mother's home in Raytown, Mo., a suburb of Kansas City. Yet Ms. Kilgore _ who asked to be identified by her maiden name only _ said she worries about her husband, who had to stay behind. Ms. Kilgore, five months pregnant and suffering from anemia, was among 46 Americans with medical problems who were allowed to fly back to the United States with the Rev. Jesse Jackson on Sunday. ``We have to thank Jesse Jackson for all of it,'' she said. ``If it wasn't for him negotiating with Saddam Hussein, I don't think any of us would have gotten out of there.'' She said she hopes her husband, who is Jordanian, will be able to escape through Jordan and join the family in the United States. Sandi Abdilkareem is another American who married a Jordanian. And while she and her four children arrived to a joyous greeting by relatives in Seattle on Monday night, her husband, David Abdilkareem, remains in the Middle East. The Abdilkareems drove 500 miles across Iraq to escape Kuwait, Mrs. Abdilkareem said. She said her husband chose to stay behind. ``He wanted to stay,'' said Mrs. Abdilkareem, who moved to Kuwait about 12 years ago with her husband. ``Everything we worked for is back there. If everything calms down, I hope one day to go back.'' Mrs. Abdilkareem, whose father, Gary Marquardt, lives in Gig Harbor, Wash., said she decided to return to the U.S. five days ago, when Hussein promised that American women and children would be allowed to leave. ``We said we'd better take the chance, before something else happens. The next morning, we were ready to go,'' she said. The family drove from their home in Ahmidie, Kuwait, to Baghdad. Although they were stopped and checked several times by Iraqi officials, they were allowed to go on to Baghdad, where they stayed four days before boarding a plane, Mrs. Abdilkareem said. ``Me and my husband drove with no problem,'' she said. Mrs. Abdilkareem credited Jackson with getting her plane off the ground on Sunday. The flight was canceled at the last minute, but she said Jackson persuaded Iraqi authorities to allow it to leave. Ms. Kilgore was able to leave directly from Kuwait, although she said there were some tense moments before her departure. It was last Friday, she said, when word came from the U.S. Embassy to get to the airport in 10 minutes. On the way there, a soldier stopped the car and asked where they were going. Her husband said they were bound for the airport, and when the soldier asked his wife's nationality, he replied she was American. ``He just kind of hesitated like he didn't know what to do,'' Ms. Kilgore said. ``Three seconds just seemed like a lifetime, waiting for his decision.'' The soldier waved them on, but the ordeal was far from over. There were no American Embassy officials at the airport, and when one of the other Americans called to check, they found out that Jackson was still negotiating with Saddam Hussein for the release. They were told to be patient, but it meant a wait of more than eight hours. ``The airport was full of Iraqis,'' she said. ``I was scared to death. We thought maybe if the negotiation doesn't go through all of these Iraqis have us.''

DOC.HEAD: Turkish Columnist Who Criticized Islam is Slain
DOC.TEXT: A prominent columnist for a leftist weekly who wrote critically about Islam was shot to death Tuesday, police said. Turan Dursun, 56, who wrote for the popular publication Yuzyil, was slain shortly after he left his house, said Istanbul police chief Hamdi Ardali. Ardali said there were no witnesses. No details were immediately known, nor were there any claims of responsibility. However, Dursun's colleagues at the magazine said he had been receiving death threats because of his columns, which criticized Islam. His column titled ``Religion Education'' harshly criticized Islam and its holy book, the Koran. Dursun was a mufti, an interpreter of Islam, by education and he was also the author of a book titled ``This is Religion.'' Dursun's killing was similar to the death of Istanbul daily Hurriyet's columnist Cetin Emec in March. Emec was killed by gunmen in front of his house. A group calling itself the Union of Turkish Islamic Commandos claimed responsibility. Kemal Ataturk, founder of modern Turkey, established a secular state in place of Islamic law more than six decades ago in this predominantly Moslem country. Many Turks have been increasingly concerned by the recent spread of Islamic fundamentalism. Before Yuzyil started publishing five weeks ago, Dursun was writing for 2000'e Dogru. Yuzyil inherited the staff and columnists of 2000'e Dogru, which was shut down by the government for its detailed coverage of Kurdish unrest in southeastern Turkey in June.

DOC.HEAD: Classes Resume; Police Revisit Crime Scenes with High-Tech Device
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf pvs, `Lt. Sadie...,' to ADD that police won't say exactly what laser device does; SUBS grafs 20-21, `A university...the bond,' to UPDATE with one suspect facing new, unrelated charges in another jurisdiction and police adding another name to their list of `prime suspects.' Pick up 22nd graf pvs: `Asked why...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: Most University of Florida students returned to their classes Tuesday after a week of mourning for five slain college students. But some have begun adding an off-campus gun course to their academic load. Investigators revisited the scenes of the five killings with a new laser device to search for additional evidence. As fearful and apprehensive students returned from the Labor Day weekend, police warned that the killer may still be in their midst. ``We do not have a timetable on an arrest, warrants or fruition of this case,'' said Lt. Spencer Mann, an Alachua County Sheriff's Office spokesman. Larry Humes, a University of Florida spokesman, said although exact figures were not available ``our feeling is the majority of the students are back.'' Many are frightened, however. Since the killings, about 60 people have signed up for a gun-safety course offered by Beckwith Indoor Pistol Range. That compares to three-four students a week normally taking the $35 class. ``It's been crazy,'' instructor Joe Parker said Tuesday. The three-hour course teaches how to shoot in self-defense. ``Safety is heavily stressed,'' Parker said. ``We don't want them hurting themselves or another innocent person.'' Firearms are not allowed on the University of Florida campus. The university doesn't offer any martial-art self-defense classes but is considering them, said Martha Varnes, a spokeswoman with the University of Florida Police Department. The bodies of University of Florida freshmen Sonja Larson, 18, and Christina Powell, 17, were found Aug. 26. The body of Santa Fe Community College student Christa Hoyt was found the next day, while the bodies of Tracey Paules, 23, and Manuel Taboada, 23, were found Aug. 28. On Tuesday, investigators returned to the three murder sites with a laser device invented by a Hattiesburg, Miss., dentist, Dr. Michael West. Lt. Sadie Darnell, a Gainesville police spokeswoman, said the laser may be able ``to pick up information not apparent to the naked eye.'' But police refused to say exactly what the device does. Ms. Darnell said investigators will take any help offered _ even information from psychics and people who have reported dreams. Of 20 binders full of initial investigative reports, 11 represent such information and do not require follow-ups, she said. Only four or five notebooks contain investigative leads of the highest priority. The three chief investigators of the slayings told The Gainesville Sun that they believe the killer left behind a message at three crime scenes last week. ``In the scene, the setup, there was a message _ to authorities, to law enforcement, to whoever,'' said Capt. R. B. Ward of the Gainesville Police Department, and one of the men in charge of the murder investigation. ``We have come to the conclusion he was very calculated, very methodical in the way the person did things _ as well as left things,'' Ward said. Police have said they have eight suspects in the case. On Tuesday, Gainesville police said Stephen Michael Bates, a Lakeland short-order cook, is one the top suspects. He has been held in the Polk County Jail on $100,500 bond since his Aug. 29 arrest in an unrelated assault case. Polk County authorities have said they doubt Bates, 30, is the killer but his fingerprints have been sent to the task force investigating the slayings. Also Tuesday, new charges were filed against another of the ``primary suspects,'' Edward Humphrey, in an unrelated case in another jurisdiction. The Indian River County Sheriff's Office announced it had issued warrants for Humphrey in the armed burglary and attempted sexual battery of a woman two years ago. In a statement, sheriff's spokeswoman Theresa Woodson said the victim saw a newspaper photograph of Humphrey over the weekend and identified him as her attacker. Humphrey, 18, a university freshman, remained jailed jailed in an unrelated beating in another city. He, was being held in the Brevard County Jail in Sharpes on $1 million bond for allegedly assaulting his grandmother. Public Defender J.R. Russo planned to ask a judge Thursday to reduce the bond. Asked why he believed his client had not been arrested in connection with the Gainesville case, Russo said ``it would seem to me you would need some amount of probable cause.'' The task force has taken Humphrey's fingerprints and footprints, samples of his blood and his psychiatric records. His Gainesville apartment remained sealed under police guard Tuesday as a search continued on the grounds around it. Police will not say when or if they will seek a search warrant for the apartment. Humphrey lived briefly this summer at an apartment complex where Taboada and Miss Paules were killed and at a dormitory where Miss Powell lived.

DOC.HEAD: More Labor Unrest Threatens Government in Nicaragua
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with TV station returning to the air, minor editing. Pickup 9th graf pvs, `Police had...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA1
By DORALISA PILARTE
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Widows, orphans and disabled people from Nicaragua's civil war occupying the state-run TV station rejected a government offer Tuesday to negotiate pension demands if they first left the building. The station returned to the air Tuesday afternoon although the dispute continued. ``Not one step back!'' chanted about 200 people in front of the National Television System master controls building when they heard the government offer. The slogan, a standby of the leftist Sandinistas, pointed up the tension between the conservative government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and the Sandinistas. The confrontation raised the possibility of a public sector strike similar to those that crippled the nation in May and July. About 70 people _ survivors and war wounded, including those in wheelchairs _ invaded the TV station Monday evening, broadcast a short message before the transmission signal was cut off, and locked themselves inside the building. By Tuesday, someone had placed a small red-and-black Sandinista flag on the roof. Fernando Lopez, national coordinator of the Organization of Handicapped Revolutionaries, led the takeover. ``During the 10{ years of Sandinista government, our pensions were re-evaluated 35 times, and during the last four months of this government the pensions have been devaluated 35 times,'' he said. Lopez sat in his wheelchair Tuesday under a banyan tree across the street from the TV building, chatting with reporters. The station returned to the air by transmitting directly from its downtwon studios to transmission facilities, bypassing a master control unit occupied by the protesters. ``While the negotiations between the government and the wounded continue, enjoy our programming,'' the station's press chief Luis Mora told viewers. However, a civil war veteran in the master control unit told The Associated Press that negotiations had not yet begun. Police had cordoned off the area but were mostly gone Tuesday. They confiscated three pistols. The Sandinistas, defeated in Feb. 25 elections by Mrs. Chamorro coalition, had governed since overthrowing the Somoza family dictatorship in 1979. The Sandinistas later fought a nine-year civil war with U.S.-backed Contra rebels in which 30,000 people were killed. Lopez said the Chamorro government offered pension increases ranging from $3.35 to $22 a month. But weekly devaluations quickly erode pay increases. ``I told them it was a mockery to us,'' Lopez said. ``They said they would get back to us, and nothing happened. That's why we took this over.'' He said his group wants at least $66 a month in gold cordobas, a new currency that trades officially on par with the dollar and is supposed to be devaluation-proof. Bank workers were negotiating salary raises with administrators Tuesday after threatening a strike. Alberto Mercado, coordinator of the National Federation of Communications Media, told The Associated Press that TV workers had not joined the takeover, but supported the action. Mercado said the Sandinista Workers Syndicate will meet Sunday to discuss whether Sandinista labor groups would join talks the government has proposed. Protesters grew even more bitter Tuesday when they learned that demobilized Contras received $50 on Monday to help them start anew as civilians. It was part of an aid package to Nicaragua approved by the U.S. Congress this year. Labor unrest by Sandinista unions has plagued the Chamorro government since its inauguration April 25. Mrs. Chamorro's wants to decentralize the economy, stop large state subsidies, and trim public payrolls to control inflation and increase production. But those measures have meant increased unemployment, lower salaries and higher prices for food and basic services. Many families have had to cut back on rice and beans, the basic Nicaraguan diet.

DOC.HEAD: First State Legislator Pleads Guilty in Pay-For-Vote Investigation
DOC.TEXT: The most influential of the five lawmakers accused in a bribery sting pleaded guilty Tuesday and agreed to cooperate with federal prosecutors. Robert Brown, 34, a Democrat and former chairman of the House Labor, Commerce and Industry Committee, admitted accepting $2,500 in bribes from a lobbyist _ working for the FBI _ in exchange for supporting a bill to allow pari-mutuel betting on dog and horse racing in the state. If approved, the bill would have put the gambling issue on the November ballot. The 7-year lawmaker resigned his seat Aug. 23, the day before he was indicted under the federal Hobbs Act, which forbids lawmakers from accepting money or gifts in exchange for votes or favors. Brown pleaded guilty to one corruption count in U.S. District Court before Judge Falcon B. Hawkins. After his hearing, prosecutors released a grainy black-and-white videotape showing the FBI sting operation that led to the indictments of Brown and four other state lawmakers. The videotape showed an April meeting at which Brown accepted $2,000 from Ron Cobb, a lobbyist who was recruited by the FBI. The money was exchanged on a yacht at Hilton Head Island. FBI special agent Michael Clemens testified that Brown later accepted $500 from Cobb here. Clemons testified that Cobb first approached Brown in January. The agent quoted Brown as saying he wanted money in exchange for his support, telling Cobb: ```I think you know where my motivation is.''' When Cobb asked Brown to name an amount, Brown said he wanted ``the biggest number you can get,'' Clemens testified. In late July, shortly after news of the investigation broke, Brown filed an amended campaign report disclosing that he had received $2,500 cash from Cobb. He denied then that the money was a bribe. U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel said he would recommend a sentence of about 3 years in exchange for Brown's cooperation, which is to include testimony against his colleagues if necessary. The maximun penalty is 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. A sentencing date has yet to be set. Brown, who is free on bond, declined to comment after the hearing. Rick Lee, a Republican who resigned his Senate seat last week, is scheduled to appear before a federal judge on Monday. Lee has said he intends to plead guilty to accepting a $2,000 bribe from Cobb. State Reps. Robert Kohn, Luther Taylor and Danny Winstead all face similar charges. Winstead also was charged with obstruction of justice. Kohn, a Republican who has said he won't seek re-election, and Taylor, a Democrat, were suspended from the House pending resolution of the charges. Winstead, a Republican, resigned his seat last month. The indictments capped a 16-month FBI investigation in alleged corruption in the state Legislature. The gambling bill was approved by Brown's committee last year, but never came up for a full House vote. The full Senate also failed to vote on a similar bill.

DOC.HEAD: Charter Flights, Convoy Raise Hopes of Evacuation Speed-Up
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq raised hopes Tuesday for speeding up the evacuation of stranded Western women and children by allowing two charter flights to leave Baghdad and a bus convoy to take Britons out of Kuwait. Two Iraqi Airways Boeing 727s chartered by West Germany and the United States flew nearly 300 foreigners, mostly women and children, to Amman, Jordan on Tuesday. Western diplomats said a third jetliner, chartered by France, would leave Baghdad for the Jordanian capital on Wednesday. The Canadian Charge d'Affaires Dale Carl said Canada had chartered an Iraqi Airways Boeing 707 to fly 175 Westerners _ all but 30 of them Canadians _ from Kuwait City to Baghdad and then on Thursday to Ankara, Turkey. He said Iraq had promised to issue exit visas at the Baghdad airport. The United States hoped to arrange its own charter to carry Americans out of Kuwait within days. Iraq President Saddam Hussein said last week he would allow Western women and children to leave, but not the men. More than 700 Western detainees _ women, children and a few ill men _ left aboard two Iraqi Airways flights on Saturday. Some also have traveled across the desert to Jordan. But the departures of others have been complicated by Iraq's refusal to allow foreign airlines to land in Baghdad and by long delays in processing exit permits. About 11,000 Westerners are now believed stranded in Kuwait and Iraq. The American charter on Tuesday carried at least 138 passengers, including 25 Americans, 44 French and 36 British nationals, as well as four Australians and two Canadians. Its departure from Baghdad was delayed for 4{ hours because of technical problems with the aircraft, Iraqi authorities said. A second plane had to be substituted. ``I have to assume there were technical problems and assume there was no ill will,'' said one Western diplomat. The West German charter included 135 West German nationals among its passengers. Also Tuesday, a convoy carrying 306 British women and children in seven buses and one car left Kuwait in the morning to make the grueling drive across the desert to Baghdad, a British diplomat said. ``We are pretty sure that they're on their way out,'' said the diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``When they arrive we will start processing their exit visas, their travel documents.'' British diplomats said they hoped to arrange a charter flight direct to London, or failing that to Amman, for the Britons in the convoy. ``We just want to get them out,'' said the diplomat. ``If there is no charter then we will send them out in batches on regularly scheduled commercial flights to Amman. As a last resort we will move them out by convoy to Jordan.'' The BBC World Service began carrying announcements late Monday advising British women and children about the bus convoy. The embassy also used a system of volunteer wardens to get the word out to Britons in hiding. The women and children were told to gather at a shopping center parking lot, and to bring plenty of water along for the 400-mile drive up the Tigris River basin to Baghdad. Western diplomats in Baghdad described the situation in occupied Kuwait as grim since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion and have been pushing to speed the evacuation of women and children. They are not sure how much longer their countries' diplomats in Kuwait can hold on to assist people in leaving. Diplomats who have rejected Iraqi demands to move to Baghdad are stranded in their embassies with the power and water cut off and food supplies diminishing. A Norwegian diplomat in Iraq said the Norwegian Foreign Ministry has instructed Ambassador Hans Wilhelm Longva and the two remaining staff members to leave the embassy in Kuwait City on Thursday and travel to Baghdad. On Monday, Western diplomats said Iraq had complicated evacuation plans by rescinding landing rights in Baghdad for foreign jetliners. The Iraqis linked their decision to the denial of landing rights abroad to Iraqi planes under the U.N. trade embargo. Baghdad said evacuees must be flown out on chartered Iraqi Airways planes. The Canadian charter would be the first full flight of evacuees from Kuwait City to Baghdad. On Saturday, the Rev. Jesse Jackson arranged to fly about 30 Americans out of Kuwait to connect with a special evacuation flight in Baghdad. More than 2,000 Americans, including an estimated 1,400 women and children, are unaccounted for in Kuwait and thought to be in hiding. Iraq has said that Western men cannot leave as long as a threat is posed by the massive U.S.-led military buildup across the border in Saudi Arabia. Naji al-Hadithi, director-general of the Iraqi information ministry, said ``thousands of foreign guests'' have been relocated at potential military targets ``to make the Americans think twice about attacking.'' Iraq has warned it will hang any Kuwaitis caught harboring Westerners. But a diplomatic source said Tuesday that the Kuwaiti resistance has countered the Iraqi threat by warning it will kill anyone who turns in people harboring Westerners.

DOC.HEAD: Allende Reburied With Honors in Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with riot police blocking march after ceremonies, 92 arrested in clashes. Pickup 5th graf pvs, `We express...'
DOC.TEXT: Chile unearthed the remains of former Marxist President Salvador Allende from a humble grave Tuesday and reburied his body in the capitag Victims of Millions

The savings and loan crisis has been in the headlines for several years now, but for most Americans, it has amounted to a troubling, but distant, scandal. Recently, more and more people are feeling the effects as the fallout trickles down to Main Street. This first of a three-part series, ``S&Ls on Main Street,'' examines how the mess is taking its toll across the country on once-unlikely targets.

Jean Shoults was careful to pick a stable neighborhood with solid home values when she moved her family here two years ago. But a single government decision may cost her $25,000 in home equity. ``You think you're buying the American dream and it turns into a nightmare,'' Mrs. Shoults said. ``We are savings and loan victims.'' She's not alone. Across the country, more and more people are finding they, too, are S&L victims. Small businesses can't find loans. Subcontractors get stiffed on payments. Real estate markets are in ruins, neighborhoods tied up in government red tape. Home buyers like Judy and Dave Crenshaw in Colorado Springs, Colo., battle through three mortgage companies, and lose out on one home, before finally getting a deal approved. You wouldn't expect a small Phoenix gold and jewelry store to be affected by the S&L debacle, or a small advertising agency to end up a victim. But the S&L mess has forced its way onto Main Street. It has eliminated jobs, crushed real estate values and weakened an already weak economy by crimping lending. All this before the tax bite, estimated at about $20 per family each month over the next 30 years. ``It's catching up to us quickly,'' said David Wyss, chief financial economist at DRI-McGraw Hill. ``People are beginning to see more and more that we're all victims.'' For years, the crisis had little impact for millions of Americans because federal deposit insurance protected their accounts at savings banks, shielding Main Street from the $500 billion fiasco. Now, however, changes made by Congress and regulators, along with the restructuring of the industry, are affecting the economy, contributing to the nation's ``credit crunch'' and possibly helping push a sluggish U.S. economy closer to recession, economists say. The construction industry, which is struggling nationwide, is particularly hard-hit by problems associated with S&Ls, which traditionally have been the chief source of financing for home building. Demand is down, but changes ordered by regulators also have helped curb building loans, and analysts say banks and S&Ls are reluctant to make any real estate loan that might be labeled risky by regulators. ``Builders live on credit,'' said Dean Crist, research economist for the National Association of Home Builders. ``So what this has done is cut them off completely.'' That sets off a chain reaction that ends on Main Street. Home buyers say they've had a tough time finding financing, and sellers have been battered by the lack of buyers. The huge amount of empty real estate has depressed prices. Spring Valley Construction found itself an inadvertent victim of the S&L mess. The company built much of Stonebridge Ranch, a giant S&L-financed development north of Dallas. When the S&L went bust, Spring Valley still was owed several hundred thousand dollars for work it already had done. ``We don't get paid, so our subcontractors don't get paid. It ends up with the guy that works for a living,'' Jim Duffy, Stonebridge's vice president of operations. The S&L crisis is impacting Main Street in many other ways:

Joan Leff gets teary thinking about her future. She, too, is a victim _ but she's more a victim of the risk-taking of high-flying S&L executives unleashed by the deregulation of the industry. Ms. Leff, an office manager at a California retirement home, took all the money she had _ $90,000 from a divorce settlement _ to a local savings bank, Lincoln Savings & Loan, to buy a certificate of deposit that would give her monthly interest to help pay her rent. Instead, a salesman talked her into a bond that paid slightly higher interest. Ms. Leff thought the bond was safe and insured, just like a CD. It wasn't. The bond turned out to be a junk bond in Lincoln's parent company, American Continental Corp. American Continental defaulted on the bonds, which have been basically worthless since April 1989. Some 22,000 investors, most in California, bought $250 million worth of them. Investors in Illinois and other states have similar complaints about other S&Ls. Unable to pay her rent, Ms. Leff moved into a cheap one-bedroom apartment, where she still lives. ``The loss was almost worse than the loss of my marriage,'' she said. Bondholders and the state of California have sued American Continental and its former chairman, Charles Keating, claiming fraud in the bond sales. American Continental and Keating have denied any wrongdoing. But Ms. Leff finds little comfort in any lawsuit. ``It's not like I invested in penny stocks or pork bellies or even the stock market,'' said Ms. Leff, the office manager at a retirement home. ``I thought a bank would be safe.''

Gary Homsey didn't get in a financial bind because of S&L borrowing, or even S&L accounts. He runs his own advertising agency in Dallas that specializes in financial institutions, and the S&L crisis has made for some tough times. His biggest client, Murray Savings, spent $1 million a year on advertising. But Murray went bust, and was taken over this year by another S&L, which had its own advertising agency. And as the number of banks and S&Ls shrinks nationwide, finding new clients is a daunting task. ``Anytime you lose a big account, it's tough,'' Homsey said. ``Consolidation in the S&Ls has made it very difficult for a lot of small businesses.''

Michael Kay seemed even farther removed from the thrift debacle. He sells jewelry at a strip shopping center in north Phoenix, and until recently, business was good. But Kay had to pack up the gold and jewelry store and move it a mile down the street, which cost his business $50,000. His shopping center fell into the hands of government regulators and lost most of its tenants. No tenants, no traffic. Other Phoenix stores in the chain were growing, but Kay saw business decline. ``The trickle-down process is severe (in the S&L crisis),'' said Kay, who had been at the Bell Tower Village four years. ``These kind of centers are just neglected.'' Bell Tower Village is slated to be auctioned off by the government this fall.

Jean Shoults, the Arlington, Texas, woman in danger of taking a $25,000 hit on her home equity, believes her neighborhood is beginning to feel the crisis in an even newer way _ fallout from government decisions. The fashionable, wooded area, Parker Oaks, has gone to court trying to block the Resolution Trust Corp., the government agency charged with disposing of S&L properties, from selling the remaining 108 lots to a tract-home developer. The builder, Centex Corp., has proposed building Fox & Jacobs brand homes for $48 to $60 a square foot, Parker Oaks residents say. Most of the homes in the neighborhood are worth at least $70 a square foot, even at today's depressed prices, and deed restrictions on the land were designed to ensure continuity throughout the neighborhood. Putting cheaper tract homes next to larger custom homes would depress the value of the larger homes, as well as violate deed restrictions the Parker Oaks homeowners thought protected them, residents contend. The neighborhood has asked a federal court to block the sale. RTC officials declined comment because of the pending court case, but Fox & Jacobs President Richard Sconyers said his company's plan meets the deed restrictions and ``is fully compatible with what's out there.'' Residents disagree, and they've added a new decorative accent to their well-to-do neighborhood: huge protest signs and banners attacking the RTC. ``It ruins us as far as housing value goes,'' said Mrs. Shoults. ``The biggest investment you make is in a house. This represents just about everything we've got.''
DOC.HEAD: Next: S&Ls and Real Estate Woes
DOC.TEXT: Scott McCartney is the AP's Southwest Regional Reporter, based in Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: Griffiths Says She Won't Lead Convention Floor Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 10th graf may offend some readers.
DOC.TEXT: Lt. Gov. Martha Griffiths, who was dumped from the election ticket amid hints that at 78 she was too old for a third term, said Tuesday she supports the governor anyway. ``Yes, I'll vote for the governor. I support the governor. I support the Democratic Party,'' Griffiths said, promising she won't fight Gov. James Blanchard at next week's state Democratic convention. ``The governor has spoken and I will object to a floor fight,'' she said. Blanchard dropped the lieutenant governor as his running mate Aug. 24, saying the No. 2 slot should be filled by someone who could ``take over the heavy responsibilities of being governor.'' He refused to elaborate, and has yet to name a replacement. Griffiths, who originally was furious, said Tuesday that she and Blanchard have ``kissed and made up.'' But her husband, Hicks Griffiths, said he might support the Republican candidate. That delighted supporters of Republican candidate John Engler, who last week chose a 66-year-old former Mother of the Year and state senator as his running mate. The GOP candidated for lieutenant governor is Sen. Connie Binsfeld, who has been in politics since 1975. She was honored by the Michigan Mothers Association in 1977 as Mother of the Year. Engler insisted his decision had nothing to do with the Blanchard-Griffiths furor. But in announcing her selection, he stressed that Binsfeld is qualified to take over as governor if something should happen to him. Griffiths on Tuesday raised the issue of sex and discrimination, noting that nobody objected to the re-election campaign of her fellow Democrat, Secretary of State Richard Austin, age 77. The lieutenant governor briefly described a meeting she had with Blanchard last week to explain a published report of her apparent reference to him as a ``son of a bitch.'' She said she told the governor she meant the reference to politicians in general, rather than to him specifically. However, she dodged a question about whether Blanchard falls into the same category as those other politicians. ``You be the judge,'' she responded.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Day Traffic Toll Totals 463
DOC.TEXT: A total of 463 people were killed nationwide in traffic accidents over the three-day Labor Day weekend. The National Safety Council, based in Chicago, had estimated before the holiday that between 400 and 500 people would die on the nation's streets and highways. This year's toll was higher than the 431 deaths recorded over the same three-day holiday weekend in 1989. California had the highest death toll among the states this year with 68, followed by Texas with 33, Florida with 22 and Mississippi with 18. Alaska, Hawaii and the District of Columbia reported no holiday traffic deaths, and three states _ Maine, Vermont and North Dakota _ reported only one each.

DOC.HEAD: Gov. Buddy Roemer Ends Marriage
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer and his estranged wife, Patti, were granted a divorce Tuesday. Roemer, 46, and his former wife, 36, separated a year ago. The Mrs. Roemer was in court with her lawyer, Lewis Unglesby, when Family Court Judge Anthony Graphia issued the divorce judgment. The governor didn't appear. The decree granted the divorce under terms of a ``private contract signed between the parties on April 6, 1990.'' The Roemers were married in 1973 and have a 10-year-old son, Dakota. Gov. Roemer has an older son and daughter by a previous marriage. In a joint statement issued by the governor's press office, the couple said: ``After a year of separation, we are deeply saddened that our marriage cannot work, but sometimes bad things happen to good people. Although our marriage of 16 years has ended, we remain friends, viewing each other with respect, love and honor. ``We deeply appreciate the understanding and respect for our privacy and for our struggle that our friends and the public have shown,'' the statement continued. ``Thank you.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Payola Case Against Record Promoter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th graf pvs, `His trial...,' to ADD information on federal law on `payola.' Donald Re is cq in 13th graf.
DOC.TEXT: The federal ``payola'' case against record promoter Joseph Isgro was thrown out of court Tuesday by a judge who accused proscutors of ``outrageous government misconduct'' in withholding testimony. U.S. District Judge James Ideman said prosecutors deliberately withheld from the defense contradictory statements by a key witness against Isgro. The independent promoter was hired by record companies to persuade radio stations to play their songs. Prosecutors allege that Isgro gave payola of cash and cocaine to employees of stations in Texas and California in return for playing certain songs. The decision also threw out the case against Isgro's two co-defendants, convicted cocaine dealer Jeffrey Monka and former Columbia Records executive Raymond Anderson. Isgro was being tried on 57 counts of racketeering, failing to report the payments to the Internal Revenue Service and other charges. His trial had been called the radio and record industry's biggest payola case in 30 years. It featured testimony about cocaine and cash stuffed into album jackets and audio cassette cases delivered to radio station executives. Under a 1960 federal law, failing to disclose paying or receiving ``payola'' on income tax returns is illegal, but the actual payment is not a violation. The key witness whose statements were at issue in the dismissal motion was Dennis Di Ricco, a former Internal Revenue Service agent convicted of tax conspiracy and obstruction of justice in San Francisco in 1989. Isgro's lawyers discovered last week that Di Ricco testified in his own behalf in that trial. They got a transcript of the testimony and found that it contradicted what he told a grand jury that indicted Isgro. In the San Francisco case, Di Ricco denied any involvement in payola activities with Isgro. In his testimony against Isgro before a Los Angeles grand jury Di Ricco claimed involvement. Ideman declared a mistrial and ordered the indictment dismissed. ``The court finds there has been outrageous government misconduct in this case,'' the judge said. Friends of Isgro cheered and congratulated him in the courtroom. He had few words outside court. He said he was ``relieved and happy.'' ``Everything the judge said was absolutely true,'' said defense attorney Don Re. ``The government was willing to win at all costs and it got its hand caught in the cookie jar.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney William Lynch said, ``It's regrettable the judge made that decision. We believe he is wrong and we will appeal.'' Ideman ruled last week that Justice Department prosecutors improperly withheld from the defense Di Ricco's prior testimony. Ideman said then that prosecutors violated a long-established rule requiring disclosure before trial of any witness statements that would tend to help a defendant prove his innocence. Prosecutors admitted in a written brief that they didn't give the defense a transcript of Di Ricco's prior testimony. But they denied that they intended to hide anything. Di Ricco wasn't sent to prison on his conviction because he agreed to cooperate at Isgro's trial.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia's Third Countdown Trouble-Free, NASA Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf pvs, `Nasa is...,' to UPDATE with Discovery being moved out to launch pad.
DOC.TEXT: NASA enjoyed a calm, uneventful countdown Tuesday as the space agency moved closer to its third attempt to send Columbia on an astronomy mission and its first shuttle flight in months. Columbia is scheduled to lift off at 1:20 a.m. Thursday with seven astronauts and the $150 million Astro observatory. ``Everybody's very comfortable. The firing room is very calm,'' said test director Al Sofge. ``We're just proceeding down through the count, business as usual, doing what we do best, no problems.'' NASA's first attempt to launch Columbia with Astro ended six hours before the scheduled May 30 liftoff when hydrogen leaked during fueling. The next countdown was halted Thursday after engineers lost contact with one of four telescopes inside Columbia's cargo bay. The communications problem with the X-ray telescope was corrected Sunday, allowing NASA to begin counting down once again. ``We've had our share of problems. I figure it's time to have something go right for Astro,'' said project manager Bill Huddleston. The latest delay required a slight juggling of Astro's observing schedule, said Arthur Davidsen, principal investigator of Johns Hopkins University's ultraviolet telescope. Astronomers now will be able to observe Jupiter, which was too close to the sun as of last week, Davidsen said. But an important quasar _ the brightest one, in fact _ has moved too close to the sun and will not be visible to Astro until late fall. ``We don't want to delay that long,'' Davidsen said. Scientists have been waiting for years for NASA to send up the observatory, which will study ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted from some of the hottest objects in the universe. About 150 objects will be observed during the nine- to 10-day flight, including a comet that is making its first recorded pass through the solar system. Astro had been scheduled for a ride on Columbia in March 1986, but the Challenger disaster two months earlier put all missions on hold. Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes will be operated round-the-clock by the four astronomers aboard Columbia. The X-ray telescope will be managed by computer commands sent from Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. It will be the first scientific mission in five years dedicated entirely to scientific research. Astro will remain in the cargo bay and be returned to Earth for possible use on a future mission. Columbia will be the first shuttle to fly since the entire fleet was grounded by hydrogen leaks this summer. A month after Columbia's leaks were discovered, Atlantis was found to have a similar problem and its July flight delayed. NASA has since replaced Columbia's hydrogen lines and rescheduled Atlantis' secret military mission for November. ``We're looking for a success,'' Huddleston said. ``We have all expectations that we're going to have a success.'' NASA last launched a shuttle in April. Discovery's crew successfully placed the Hubble Space Telescope in orbit, but the $1.5 billion telescope later was found to have a defective mirror that produces blurry images. NASA is wasting no time getting its shuttle program back on track. The space agency began moving Discovery out to the other shuttle launch pad Tuesday night to await an October flight with the Ulysses satellite. The four-mile trip was expected to take about six hours, ending early Wednesday. It will be only the third time both pads at Kennedy Space Center have been occupied. The last time was in April, when Columbia was rolled out for the Astro mission and Discovery was waiting to lift off with Hubble. The other time was just before the Challenger accident. NASA must launch Discovery between Oct. 5 and Oct. 23 to take advantage of Earth's alignment with the sun and Jupiter, otherwise the mission will have to wait 13 months. Ulysses is being sent on a five-year journey to explore the sun's poles.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Sub to Investigate What Could Be Debris From United Jet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT that Pacific Command is multi-service command sted Navy.
DOC.TEXT: A Navy submarine will investigate and possibly retrieve what searchers believe is debris from a United Airlines jet on the ocean floor near here, the military said Tuesday. Nine people died when a cargo door and a large chunk of fuselage tore away from the Boeing 747 shortly after takeoff from Honolulu International Airport last year. In July, an unmanned submersible using sonar located metallic objects 14,000 down and 90 miles south of Honolulu, including a large piece roughly the size of the 10-by-10-foot cargo door. After reviewing information on the debris field, the National Transportation Safety Board decided to call for further investigation, said Lt. Cmdr. Sandy Stairs, a spokeswoman for Pacific Command, which is responsible for all U.S. forces in the area. The NTSB has said recovering and analyzing the door could lead to better airline safety rules. The search is expected to begin Sept. 15. The submarine, named the Sea Cliff, is a 31-foot, 58,000-pound craft able to operate at depths up to 20,000 feet. It carries a three-member crew. The submarine and its support ship are capable of retrieving objects from the ocean floor, Stairs said. Stairs said searchers will take pictures of the debris and let authorities decide whether it is worth retrieving. The Sea Cliff left San Diego on Tuesday and is expected to arrive at Pearl Harbor on Sept. 11, Stairs said. United Flight 811 carried 355 passengers when it left Honolulu for New Zealand on Feb. 24, 1989. The cargo door opened at 22,000 feet, tearing away a section of fuselage. Nine people were swept to their deaths and five other suffered serious injuries. The crew managed to return the jet to Honolulu. The NTSB inquiry determined that faulty design of the locking mechanism probably caused a cockpit light to falsely indicate the door was locked. The agency blamed United, Boeing Co. and the Federal Aviation Administration for failing to correct problems with the door.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Talks of New Security Structure for Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 7-10: ``In such,'' Baker speculates on U.S. presence in region and cost estimate.'' ^With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Tuesday the Bush administration is giving preliminary thought to creating a NATO-type organization to deal with future security threats to the Persian Gulf. At the same time, Baker said Iraq has been restored to the list of countries which the United States accuses of engaging in international terrorism. Testifying before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Baker was asked by Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., about ways the United States might confront future security challenges in the Persian Gulf. Solarz expressed particular concern about the presence of chemical and biological weapons in the Iraqi arsenal. ``I think we will have to give consideration to working with others to create a new security structure for the region,'' Baker said. ``I think that's likely to be required even if there is a pullback (by Iraq) from Kuwait. ``It is conceivably possible ... to come up with a security structure that would make it so clearly to the detriment of any subsequent leader, or even the present leader, to use or contemplate using (chemical or biological) weapons that there would be very little risk that they would be used. Such a structure would be aimed at ``constraining'' aggressors such as Iraq, Baker said. He recalled that NATO was able to deal with Soviet expansionist ambitions during the Cold War. In such a structure, ``Certainly we ought to play some role, and therefore there would be some presence, some continuing presence there,'' Baker said. ``Maybe it wouldn't be a ground force presence,'' he continued. ``Maybe it would be a naval presence. I mean, these are questions that are going to have to be addressed down the line and they're questions that are going to have to be studied considerably.'' For about 40 years, the United States has maintained warships in the Persian Gulf, sometimes only a small number, and a fleet in the Mediterranean Sea. ``We would not like to have to repeat'' the U.S. buildup, Baker said _ a buildup he estimated would cost $6 billion by the end of the year. Baker told the committee that Iraq was restored to the terrorism list after Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz said that Iraq was free from any moral obligation to proscribe acts of terrorism against American, British or French interests. Iraq had been on the State Department list of countries that engage in state-supported terrorism but was removed from that list as part of a general accommodation between the two countries during the early 1980s. The other countries on the list are Syria, Libya, Cuba, North Korea and Iran. Restoring Iraq to the list was largely a symbolic measure. Membership on the list means the country in question is not entitled to certain economic benefits, including agricultural credits. In Iraq's case, there are no benefits to be suspended because of the embargo the United States imposed on Iraq after its takeover of Kuwait. A U.S. official, explaining the move, said ``we are deeply cvoncerned over growing ties between Iraq and international terrorists. Particularly disturbing is the movement of terrorist groups and their leaders to Baghdad and calls issued through the Iraqi news agency for attacks on American interests.'' Specifically, the official, who requested anonymity, said Abu Nidal and Abul Abbas, leaders of Palestinian factions, operate from Baghdad. Abu Nidal is suspected in the bombings of Rome and Vienna airports in December 1986. Abul Abbas reportedly was involved in the attempted assault May 30 on Tel Aviv beaches. The abortive attack prompted the Bush administration to suspend its talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization. Abul Abbas also is connected by the State Department office to counter terrorism with the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro in 1985. Baker said he believes that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein may be willing to pursue a negotiated settlement once the global economic embargo has greater impact. He added, however, that Saddam is showing no such disposition at present. ``We would like to see this matter resolved by peaceful means,'' Baker said. ``We do not believe in our heart of hearts that Saddam Hussein is prepared to move forward on the diplomatic track.'' Baker was accorded a generally friendly reception by House members during his first appearance on Capitol Hill since the Gulf crisis erupted five weeks ago. Virtually all committee members praised Baker and the administration for the way in which they have managed the crisis. Baker reaffirmed that the United States continues to seek a complete withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait and the restoration to power of the deposed Kuwaiti leadership. He said the United States should not be willing to compromise on those demands. ``We can't have negotiations on what the future government of Kuwait should or could be,'' he said. He did not rule out, however, the possibility that territorial or other disputes could be negotiated ``once there is a complete, full and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait.''

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Continues Reserve Call-Up
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS last graf to add Rhode Island to list of National Guard units deploying
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon has called up 678 reservists from the Air Force, Army, and Navy since Saturday to support Operation Desert Shield, it was announced Tuesday. The secretary of the Air Force has called: _709th Military Airlift Squadron, Dover Air Force Base, Del., to support C-5A transport planes with 239 reservists. _312th Military Airlift Squadron, Travis Air Force Base, Calif., to support C-5A and C-5B transports, with 230 reservists. The secretary of the Army has ordered 20 reservists to active duty, linguists from the 337th Military Intelligence Battalion. The reservists are in three companies: B Co., East Point, Ga.; C Co., Melbourne, Fla., and D Co., Charlotte, N.C. The Navy has called 189 individual reservists to serve with various units that have been called to active duty, the Pentagon said. Through Aug. 31, 8,871 reservists were called to active duty. The Army called 4,292 reservists; the Navy, 2,584; the Air Force, 1,723; and the Coast Guard, 272, a spokesman said. In addition, Air National Guard units announced the pending departure of 100 members of Missouri's 139th Tactical Airlift Group, 60 members of Delaware's 166th Tactical Airlift Group and 100 members of Rhode Island's 143rd Tactical Airlift Group to overseas bases to support the buildup in the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Proposes Easing of Tensions with North Korea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with eight grafs to UPDATE with South Korean proposal on easing tensions, details. Picks up graf 5 pvs, `The premiers...' with minor editing thereafter to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SEL1,SEL9
DOC.TEXT: South Korea asked North Korean delegates Wednesday to agree to a proposal on easing tensions between the two enemies that includes recognizing the others' sovereignty, free travel and gradual arms reduction. The South's eight-point proposal was based on its conviction that lesser agreements must precede talks on unification of the peninsula, divided in 1945. North Korea believes the two Koreas can only establish trust if they agree to the major issues of arms cuts and reunification. The South's proposal came at the opening session of the first-ever premiers talks between North and South Korea, the highest level conference between the two rivals in 45 years. ``Should the authorities of both sides persist in confrontational and hostile attitudes, inter-Korean relations will never be improved,'' said South Korean Prime Minister Kang Yoon-hoon. Kang, speaking first at the meeting, also proposed the two governments work jointly to locate family members separated by the Korean War. An estimated 10 million Koreans were separated from family members during the 1950-53 conflict. Kang said multi-faceted exchanges and cooperation between the two sides should include free travel across the border during major holidays, economic and trade cooperation, reconnection of broken railroad, highway, mail and telephone service lines, and recognizing the others' existence. He suggested the two sides jointly develop tourist resources and create a North-South tourist route in the beautiful eastern coast called the Diamond Mountains, a haven favored by all Koreans. North and South Korea opened two days of formal prime ministers' talks Wednesday at 10 a.m. (9 p.m. EDT Tuesday) with the seven-member official delegations of both sides sitting across from one another at a table in main ballroom of the headquarters hotel. The premiers smiled and shook hands across the table. When photographers yelled for them to repeat the action, they stood for about a minute clasping hands. North Korean Prime Minister Yon Hyong Muk, wearing a Communist Party Kim Il Sung badge, waved briefly to onlookers and took his seat on the north side of the table. The South Korean premier sat on the south side. In a relaxed atmosphere, the two premiers exchanged small talk about the previous evening's dinner and movie and whether each had slept well. Kang apologized for a traffic accident in Tuesday's arrival motorcade in which two North Korean diplomats were injured. When he inquired how they were feeling, one of the delegates said he needed treatment for his back and the other, who injured his jaw, said he had trouble eating. Talks Wednesday and Thursday are to focus on easing military and political confrontation and launching multilateral exchanges, subjects general enough to cover almost anything either side wants to talk about. By holding talks, Communist North Korea gives tacit recognition to the legitimacy of the South Korean government it has steadfastly refused to recognize. South Korea has recognized the North only in its call that the two nations submit separate applications for United Nations membership. South Korean Prime Minister Kang calls the talks thawing ``the thick ice of distrust.'' Kang said Tuesday the talks ``will be the perfect opportunity to erect a glistening milestone in our long march to cast off the shackales of division and unify the land.'' South Korean officials have cautioned against hasty expectations, saying the talks are only a significant first step of a long road toward peace and unification. North Korean radio, monitored in Tokyo, warned Seoul to approach talks ``with a sincere attitude ... and cease from spoiling the atmosphere of dialogue.'' The 90-member North Korean delegation crossed the border Tuesday for a four-day visit that ends Friday and includes two movies, a stage show and sightseeing. The premiers have opposing ideology, but otherwise much in common. Both have roots near the North Korea-Manchurian border. They're both in their 60s, were appointed premiers in 1988 and are ranked high in their government hierarchy though their policy-making roles are limited. The Korean peninsula was divided into the communist North and capitalist South in 1945 and the two nations fought a three-year war. Relations between the Koreas are hostile and the North Korean delegation is only the third to visit in more than 40 years. Earlier Tuesday, about 200 radical students yelling anti-government slogans and hurling more than 500 blazing firebombs battled riot police at Seoul's Korea University. Eight students were arrested for trying to take unification banners to the border crossing. Radicals and dissidents are demanding immediate unification and the withdrawal of about 43,000 U.S. troops, positions supported by North Korea. Soon after their arrival, the North Koreans asked to visit the families of South Korean dissidents jailed for illegally visiting the North, but the government indicated the request would be rejected. The North Korean prime minister is staying in a $1,500-a-day Royal Suite at a luxury hotel near the Olympic Stadium, site of the 1988 Summer Games.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of Aug. 27-Sept. 4:
DOC.HEAD: Saudis Open Doors to Foreign Media
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia has opened the floodgates to more than 250 reporters, turning coverage of the U.S. troop deployment into what one journalist called ``a media war.'' ``It's phenomenal,'' Ray Wilkinson, Newsweek's Cairo-based correspondent, said Aug. 27. Wilkinson had a visa request pending for 18 months before he was granted one. ``I never thought I would see the U.S. military in Saudi Arabia, and I never thought I would see us here like this.'' Saudi officials, speaking on condition they not be identified, said the change in government policy came from the highest levels and was partly in reaction to pressure from the United States. ``They know public opinion is important,'' one official said of the Saudi leadership. Most reporters have been given month-long visas. One Saudi official said major news organizations may be given a permanent presence in the kingdom. The arrival of hundreds of journalists prompted the U.S. Defense Department to disband its 17-member media pool Aug. 26, two weeks after the first journalists arrived in the country. Under the pool arrangement, writers, photographers and television journalists made their work available to all news organizations. Some pool reporters complained about restrictions imposed by the Pentagon but praised the access they were given to on-the-ground operations. Most irksome was the Pentagon's initial prohibition on the use of soldiers' names and hometowns. On Aug. 25 the Pentagon lifted the ban, saying the military situation had relaxed. The Pentagon and the Saudi government still bar reporters from using exact locations when writing about military activities. Navy Lt. Cmdr. Gregg Hartung, the pool coordinator, said he thought the pool worked better than in the past. During the December invasion of Panama, for example, reporters were furious at being penned up away from any action for 24 hours. ``I think we still have room for improvement,'' Hartung said. For instance, he would have liked daily briefings with ``Operation Desert Shield'' commanders to give up-to-date details of the deployment. But that was impossible because the operation was run out of Riyadh, the Saudi capital, while the reporters were based 200 miles away in Dhahran, scene of the major deployment. The invasion of reporters has created a new set of headaches for American and Saudi officials. So many people are vying for limited space on official tours that the Pentagon has given first priority to American reporters. The Saudis have also been besieged by reporters trying to get on sponsored trips. A near riot broke out among reporters pushing to get on buses when the Saudis took a group to the border with Iraq. ``It's a media war. That's the main feature,'' said Alix Van Buren of La Repubblica of Italy. ``Bring in a couple thousand copies of `Scoop,''' said Time Magazine's Jay Peterzell, referring to Evelyn Waugh's satirical novel about covering an African war. ``A lot of people want to reread it.''
DOC.HEAD: Electronic Diplomacy in Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: Developments in the Mideast conflict have highlighted again the effect of news coverage on diplomacy. Diplomacy ``used to be by cable, and now it's by satellite,'' said Steve Friedman, executive producer of NBC's ``Nightly News.'' ``I think it's fraught with danger, in terms of television's `live' incapacity to really interpret some of these events,'' said Reid Collins, CNN anchorman in Washington. ``The problem is that communication is instant, reaction is instant, and everybody needs to just slow down,'' said anchorman Jim Lehrer of ``The MacNeil-Lehrer News Hour'' on the Public Broadcasting Service. Diplomacy by television was born in the Middle East when the 1967 Arab-Israeli war divided the principals behind battle lines. ``When you are unable to have diplomatic contact, the reporter is the one who is able to get the message,'' said Barbara Walters, who covered the Middle East for ABC in the '70s. ``I would go and interview (Egyptian President) Anwar Sadat, then I would have to go to Israel by way of Cyprus, because the two countries had no direct links and were technically at war, and I would talk with Prime Minister (Yitzhak) Rabin'' of Israel, she said. ``I remember the feeling of responsibility, and I would think how ironic and how sad it was that a reporter was going around delivering messages between people who could not speak.'' The role of television and the TV journalist as mediator reached its high point in 1977, when CBS anchorman Walter Cronkite simultaneously interviewed Sadat and Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin. On the ``neutral ground'' of television, Cronkite asked Sadat if he would visit Israel. Yes, Sadat would go to Israel. Would Sadat be welcome in Jerusalem, Cronkite asked. Yes, was the answer. The next day, Israel's invitation arrived in Cairo. It was, CNN's Collins said, ``the genesis of the Camp David accords'' and Egyptian-Israeli peace. ``Wire services and newspapers have been doing this for a long time, probably more than a century,'' said Robert MacNeil, co-anchor of ``The MacNeil-Lehrer News Hour.'' ``It's just that television has speeded it up.'' TV diplomacy can hinder the understanding of events, Collins said. And television's desire to know the end of the story and to summarize events that most often defy summarization can be dangerous, he said. ``If every man and woman in television who did a standup left off the last line, the world would be much better served,'' Collins said. ``This is not a television show. ... This is a real-world confrontation,'' said Lehrer.

DOC.HEAD: American Journalist Escapes After Being Trapped in Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Washington Post reporter Caryle Murphy willingly traveled to Kuwait in late July to cover an unfolding international news event. She escaped a month later, holding preciously to her stories and her life. When Murphy arrived in Kuwait City, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was amassing thousands of troops from his million-man army along the Iraqi-Kuwaiti border, but still promising he would take no military action against his tiny neighbor. In the early morning hours of on Aug. 2, a week after Murphy's arrival, Iraqi soldiers quickly rolled over Kuwait. One failed escape attempt and 25 days later, Murphy arrived in Saudi Arabia after a tense journey across the desert. The journalist related her trials in a lengthy article published in The Washington Post. Despite the turmoil in Kuwait after the invasion, Murphy said she hadn't expected to be trapped. ``... Like most foreigners, I assumed that in a few days time the borders would be open for those who wanted to leave, and that the exodus would start. But it never happened,'' she wrote. Murphy recalled that she and two other Western journalists spent the first week after the invasion conducting interviews on the streets, in hospitals and over the telephone, ``as if we were covering any story.'' However, she soon discovered that there was no way to dispatch material to her newspaper. After leaving her hotel to live with an American family, Murphy decided to flee the country as the two other journalists already had done. Murphy and two other Americans set out by car on the morning of Aug. 14. They were back in Kuwait City 90 minutes later after being turned back by Iraqi soldiers. But Murphy decided to try again after she learned of a convoy that was planning to leave. ``I decided in a minute, mostly by instinct. I reasoned that the worst that could happen was that I would be detained if the Iraqi's spotted me,'' she wrote. Nearly seven hours later, Murphy arrived at the Saudi border. There, she learned from a U.S. diplomat that she was the first American to arrive at the outpost in eight days.
DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Names New Press Spokesman
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev beefed up his press office Aug. 28 by naming a respected Soviet magazine editor as his personal assistant and chief spokesman. Vitaly N. Ignatenko is editor of the New Times magazine, which under his stewardship has played a significant role in Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, or openness. Ignatenko is expected to play a larger role in policy-making than either his predecessor, Arkady Maslennikov, or his American counterpart, Marlin Fitzwater. Ignatenko, 49, who speaks some English, is one of a handful of top Soviet journalists who reputedly have enjoyed regular access to Gorbachev and gained his confidence. One sign of his influence is his title: assistant to the president and head of the presidential press service. The assistant to the president designation is new. Maslennikov, whose performance was widely viewed as lackluster, has returned to his former position as press aide to the chairman of the Supreme Soviet legislature. Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov, who announced the changes at a news conference, said Maslennikov would begin working for Anatoly Lukyanov, Gorbachev's successor as Supreme Soviet chairman. Maslennikov developed a reputation among both Soviet and foreign reporters in Moscow for being difficult to reach and not returning phone calls. He also made some high profile mistakes _ such as failing to put down a rumor about Gorbachev's health during his June summit meeting with President Bush. Asked at a press conference in Washington whether it was true Gorbachev planned to undergo testing for diabetes in Minnesota, Maslennikov replied that there were many scientific experts in Minnesota with whom the Soviet leader might consult. His answer allowed the rumor to live for several hours before being firmly denied by other Soviet officials. Ignatenko has a reputation for accessibility and clarity. ``He is easygoing, with a very good sense of humor,'' said his deputy at Novoye Vremya (New Times), Aleksandr Pumpyansky. ``But he's also a professional journalist whose language is very precise _ he knows all the nuances.'' The weekly magazine, which is published in Russian and several other languages, including English, has published articles critical of the Soviet military and some of its allies, such as Cuba. This summer it carried a revisionist history of the Korean War, laying considerable blame on the North Korean side for the first time.

DOC.HEAD: Former Hostage Says Anderson Well When Last Seen
DOC.TEXT: Former Lebanon hostage Brian Keenan said he saw Terry Anderson in captivity about 11 months ago and the Associated Press correspondent was well. Keenan, a native of Belfast, Northern Ireland, was handed over to Irish authorities in Syria on Aug. 25. He described the 42-year-old Anderson as pacing the floor in tattered socks with a ``voracious appetite for intellectual conversation.'' He said Anderson sometimes kept him awake for hours. ``I think he debated with himself a lot while we tried to plug our ears,'' Keenan joked. Keenan said guards sometimes gave Anderson antibiotics during bouts of stomach trouble. ``Terry and myself would sit through those long nights and speak with great pain and remorse and longing for his first daughter, Gabrielle. With many tears he would elaborate his plans when he was finally back in the States to help her to shape and discover her future. ``In those confessional moments which were common to us all, a deep and enduring and unbreakable bond was formed.'' Anderson has never seen his second daughter, Sulome, born three months after he was abducted. Anderson, the AP's chief Middle East correspondent, was abducted March 16, 1985, and is the longest held of the 13 Westerners.
DOC.HEAD: Advocates Mildly Encouraged by Souter's First Amendment Views
DOC.TEXT: Defenders of First Amendment rights lament the retirement of Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan but say the views of his prospective replacement, David H. Souter, on freedom of speech and the press are somewhat encouraging. ``No one could conclude he has an ax to grind against the media or against First Amendment claims,'' Henry Kaufman of the pro-media Libel Defense Resource Center said of Souter. ``Arguably, we will get a fair hearing. But he's no Brennan.'' Brennan retired in July after a 34-year career as the high court's leading voice of liberalism. He wrote a 1964 landmark opinion giving the news media broad protection against libel suits by public figures and recently wrote opinions barring criminal prosecution of those who burn the American flag in protest. The Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to begin hearings on Souter's nomination Sept. 13. Most of what is known of his views have come from his writings as a New Hampshire state judge. President Bush named Souter to the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston this year. Some who have studied the handful of opinions Souter wrote on First Amendment issues during his seven years on the New Hampshire Supreme Court say they are heartened that Bush didn't choose someone with apparent rigid ideas that could limit free expression. ``I think he's been very balanced on free-press issues,'' said Claudia Haskell of the First Amendment Congress. ``He's in the mainstream.'' However, the advocates said they don't expect Souter to be an ardent defender of free expression if he wins confirmation. Kaufman said Souter's opinions seem to reflect more interest ``in the complexity of the law ... than a passion for the underlying rights at issue.'' Souter's ``decisions seem to reflect a cautious craftsman whose views are not expansive in protecting First Amendment rights,'' said Floyd Abrams, a New York lawyer whose clients include the news media. Some commentators said they were encouraged that Souter had expressed, in cases unrelated to the First Amendment, strong support for Supreme Court precedent. Jane Kirtley, head of the Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, said she was pleased that Souter appears to have little inclination to topple key rulings. ``Let's face it, we've got some good court decisions sitting up there right now,'' she said. ``I don't see anything that would suggest (Souter) would be anti-media.''
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Devoted to Arrest Reports
DOC.TEXT: Fed up with big-city newspapers' missing all but the most sensational crimes, a Florida man is publishing a tabloid listing every local arrest, including those for alleged shoplifting and drunken driving. The Informer plans to fight crime by filling pages with a blotter-style listing of every suspect _ even though they're innocent until proven guilty. ``This is going to be a deterrent,'' said Publisher Ray Aden. ``What is happening is the great majority of people violating our laws are not known _ to their neighbors, their bosses, sometimes even their family. ``But nobody wants to get their name in the paper.'' Some daily newspapers already print crime blotter information. There's nothing unlawful about printing arrests from the public record. But civil libertarians and attorneys say the tabloid is treading dangerous legal ground and could trample the rights of the accused. From a small office in this St. Petersburg suburb, Aden and a handful of employees are busy preparing for the Oct. 3 premiere of the twice-monthly, 89-cent publication. Aden, a 70-year-old marketing analyst, has spent nine months and more than $150,000 getting ready. The paper will be about half advertising and half listings of arrests, along with articles such as ``How To Deal With Obscene Phone Calls.'' The area's big dailies report only a few arrests a day, focusing on major murders and drug busts. But each issue of The Informer is designed to bulge up to 48 pages and list hundreds of arrests in St. Petersburg, Clearwater and surrounding Pinellas County communities. All of them list only the standard booking information: name, address, age and arresting charge. ``We're not crime reporting or editorializing _ that's not the concept,'' Aden said. ``We give the community information. ... It probably will evolve into more area crime watches, which will benefit the community.'' And on every page, beneath boldface headlines reading ``Domestic Violence'' and ``Shoplifting,'' disclaimers in the newspaper's tiniest type read, ``Note: being arrested does not mean the person is guilty.'' ``They have an absolute right to print arrests,'' said Robyn Blumner, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union in Florida. ``But I would only hope the public is smart enough to know that arrests by themselves are legally irrelevant.'' Patricia Anderson, a libel attorney whose clients include the St. Petersburg Times, said publishing arrests is fine, but they had better be accurate. ``One wrong first name or one wrong middle initial and you could have a big lawsuit on your hands,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Selected Details of Times-Bass Settlement Released
DOC.TEXT: A non-profit journalism school run by the Times Publishing Co. will not be hurt by a secret stock settlement between the newspaper company and a Texas billionaire, the school said Aug. 31 in a letter to state Attorney General Bob Butterworth. In the letter, the Poynter Institute of Media Studies released selected details of the Aug. 17 agreement between the owners of the St. Petersburg Times and an investment group led by Robert Bass. The institute is a beneficiary of profits from the newspaper company and had been a focal point of the bitter war between the Times and the Bass group. The details released by institute President Robert Haiman showed the settlement would improve the institute's finances, not hurt them. According to the newly released data, preferred stock held by the institute would be replaced by a $30 million debenture paying an annual interest rate of 13 percent and maturing in 2002. Annual income from the debenture would total $3.9 million, more than the $3.2 million in stock dividends the institute received in 1989, Haiman said. The release also said the institute could expect to receive dividends from the common stock it holds in the publishing company.
DOC.HEAD: Unions Asking Advertisers To Boycott Daily News
DOC.TEXT: Unions at the Daily News, working without a contract since March 30, said they were sending out letters Sept. 4 asking advertisers to immediately stop placing ads in the newspaper. The letters were being sent to all News advertisers and ad agencies that do business with the newspaper, George McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, told New York Newsday. If the advertisers refuse, ``We'll see how they like 500 or 600 people leafleting outside their doors,'' Richard Weiss, an Allied spokesman told the Daily News. The advertising boycott does not have full union support. The News said more than 90 Newspaper Guild members have signed a petition calling the boycott ``illogical and counter-productive.'' The printers union, one of 10 unions in the council, also said it will not support the boycott, according to the newspaper. The News has been running a series of radio ads in which advertisers praise the 1.2-million-circulation paper's drawing power.
DOC.HEAD: Chain Letter a Hit Among Media Executives
DOC.TEXT: A chain letter circulated since early this year among media executives in New York and Washington has some participants worried _ in a manner of speaking. The anonymous letter warns of bad luck for whoever breaks the chain. Arthur Sulzberger Jr., deputy publisher of The New York Times, sent copies of his letter to five friends, including Random House executive Peter Osnos. ``You'd think I would have more courage than to send it on to you,'' Sulzberger wrote. ``A man will do anything out of fear,'' wrote Benjamin Bradlee, executive editor of The Washington Post, who once tangled fearlessly with President Nixon over his newspaper's Watergate exposes. Bradlee received his letter from Shelby Coffey III, editor of the Los Angeles Times, who passed it along with a brief note asking, ``How can it hurt?'' Syndicated humor columnist Art Buchwald sent his copy to five women friends, including Cosmopolitan Publisher Helen Gurley Brown and columnist Ann Landers. ``I've been asked to send this chain letter on to my five dearest friends,'' Buchwald wrote. ``This is the best sex I ever had.'' He added a warning that ``the last person to break this chain was seated next to (talk show host) Morton Downey Jr. at a dinner party.'' Buchwald had gotten his copy from Pierre Salinger of ABC News, who wrote in June: ``Having received this letter on my 65th birthday, I have no choice but to send it on as ordered. I am getting too old to take a chance of breaking the chain.'' At least one media heavyweight has been brave _ or foolish _ enough to ignore the warning. Jack Nelson, Washington bureau chief of the Los Angeles Times, said he received the chain letter from two friends, but was too busy covering the Persian Gulf crisis and writing a book to pay any attention. ``So far my luck's been pretty good,'' he said. ``Maybe it's working the other way for me.''
DOC.HEAD: Postal Workers on Alert for Doonesbury Postage Stamps
DOC.TEXT: Cartoonist Gary Trudeau's popular ``Doonesbury'' characters are getting some unintended and unwanted circulation. U.S. Postal Service officials are complaining that Trudeau's characters, which were featured in a cartoon stamp album of political satire, are turning up on some mail. Art Shealy, a spokesman for the Postal Service in Washington, said Aug. 29 that postal employees were advised to be on the lookout for the bogus stamps. The 1990 Doonesbury Stamp Album is a collection of more than 140 stamps featuring characters from the Pulitzer Prize-winning strip. The $8.95 book is intended to raise money for the Writers' Voices program of the Literacy Volunteers of New York City, said Janet Kraybill, spokeswoman for the publisher. ``I don't see how anyone could look at this and think it's a postage stamp,'' said Ms. Kraybill. ``There are purple ones and pink ones, and some are even larger than a postage stamp.'' Genuine U.S. postal stamps have a phosphorus coating which canceling machines are supposed to detect. But Shealy said the machines don't catch all bogus stamps on the 530 million pieces of mail processed daily in the United States.
DOC.HEAD: Giago Again Plans National String of Indian Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: Lakota Times Publisher Tim Giago said he wants to start a national network of Indian-owned newspapers using his own paper as a training center. In 1987, Giago announced plans to open a Sioux Falls plant to print a chain of weekly newspapers for Indian reservations, along with plans to start a weekly on the Red Lake Chippewa Reservation near Bemidji, Minn. The printing plant was never built. The newspaper folded in 1988 after 48 issues. ``The lessons we learned with our attempted expansion into Chippewa country a few years back have not been lost to us,'' Giago said in a Times story Aug. 28 ``We went in undercapitalized and, in reality, underprepared, but that is how one learns in this touchy field of business.'' Giago said he will prepare himself for the new venture by enrolling in advanced business courses at Harvard while on a one-year Nieman Fellowship that begins this fall.
