Native American Publishing, Inc., the parent corporation of the Lakota Times, will be restructured with an eye to national expansion next spring, the Times story said. As part of the plan, the stock options of the company will be changed in order to offer shares for sale to a limited number of private investors.

DOC.HEAD: Lipstein Plans Men's Magazine Merger
DOC.TEXT: The publisher of Smart magazine said Aug. 30 he was near a final agreement to merge that general interest men's publication with a men's magazine that was being readied for launch next year. Publisher Owen Lipstein said he had agreed to buy the proposed magazine called Men and would incorporate some of the ideas being considered for Men into the 2{-year-old Smart. He declined to disclose the price. In addition, Lipstein said the co-founders of Men, Publisher Christopher Kimball and Editor Peter Kaplan, would join his New American Magazine Co. New American Magazine publishes Mother Earth News and Psychology Today as well as Smart. The company has been having financial problems, but got a cash infusion in August when a Japanese media company bought a 50 percent interest. The proposed merger of Smart and Men comes as a number of new or reworked magazines aimed at men are showing up on newstands. Murdoch Magazines is launching Men's Life, Capital Cities-ABC Inc.'s Fairchild Group has merged its fashion magazine M with Manhattan Inc. into a new magazine called M Inc. and Conde Nast Publications Inc. has redesigned its nightlife magazine Details. The deal also comes amid one of the weakest periods for magazine advertising in years. Magazine ad pages were off 3.3 percent in the first half of 1990 compared with a year ago, Publishers Information Bureau reports.
DOC.HEAD: Printing Company Clears Hurdle on Acquiring Meredith
DOC.TEXT: R.R. Donnelley and Sons Co. says it has cleared one legal hurdle in its $570 million acquisition of an Iowa printing company but is disappointed with continued opposition from federal regulators. The Federal Trade Commission wants the acquisition of Meredith Corp. of Des Moines blocked so it can conduct hearings aimed at determining whether the deal violates antitrust laws. U.S. District Judge Stanley Harris in Washington D.C. on Aug. 27 refused the FTC's request to halt the purchase. ``Donnelley was disappointed to learn that the FTC is appealing the court's decision,'' the company said Aug. 28 in a statement. ``Donnelley continues to believe that the acquisition is legally proper.'' Donnelley, with 1989 sales of $3.12 billion, has about 6 percent of the U.S. market for the magazine, catalog and newspaper insert business. Meredith has about 1 percent.
DOC.HEAD: The Home News Seeks Buyer for 51 Percent
DOC.TEXT: A majority interest in The Central New Jersey Home News is for sale, publisher William M. Boyd said. The New Brunswick-based newspaper founded by his great-grandfather 111 years ago is seeking a buyer for a 51 percent interest, Boyd said. The publisher told newsroom employees of the plan Aug. 23. Home News management reportedly told employees that it is still making money but needs a cash infusion from an outside investor. The newspaper had an average daily circulation of 54,393 and a Sunday circulation of 63,425 in the six months ended in March.
DOC.HEAD: Some Press Rights Upheld in Alleged Sexual Abuse Case
DOC.TEXT: Pennsylvania's Superior Court says a newspaper can attend hearings on sexual abuse allegations involving a priest and see some court papers, but not all of those produced in preparation for the case. The Aug. 28 ruling was the first by an appeals court in the state to uphold access to civil pleadings and proceedings, Pittsburgh Press attorney Scott E. Henderson said. ``This will make it easier for the public and press to view those parts of the judicial process,'' he said. The Superior Court decision said the newspaper does not have access to ``discovery documents,'' or information developed by the two sides in a case to prepare for trial. The case is based on a lawsuit filed by an Akron, Ohio, man who says he was 9 or 10 years old when he was first sexually molested by the Rev. Francis E. Luddy. The 21-year-old man says the abuse occurred for six to seven years. Luddy was assigned to the Altoona-Johnstown Diocese at the time and is now on a leave of absence. The diocese had requested that all documents in the case be sealed and all pretrial proceedings be held behind closed doors. A lower court judge denied both requests, and was reversed on the issue of discovery arguments. In doing so, the Superior Court referred to an earlier decision it issued that said there was no legal right for the public to inspect discovery materials.

DOC.HEAD: Singapore Tightens Grip on Foreign Publications
DOC.TEXT: Many foreign newspapers and magazines will need official permits to circulate in Singapore under an amendment to the press law passed by Parliament on Aug. 30. In tightening controls on overseas publications, the government served notice ``that it is a privilege and not a right for foreign newspapers to circulate in Singapore,'' said Mah Bow Tan, a minister of state. ``They do so as foreign observers of the local scene and should not interfere in the domestic politics of Singapore,'' Mah said. The amendment to the Newspaper and Printing Presses Act applies to publications circulating more than 300 copies at intervals of one week or less with articles ``pertaining to the politics and current affairs of any country in Southeast Asia.'' It is not aimed at a specific publication and not intended to prevent the free flow of information, Mah told Parliament. Until now, publications printed outside Singapore did not need distribution permits, unlike local newspapers and magazines. A permit, valid for one year and renewable, may be refused or revoked without explanation under the amended law. It will specify the number of copies to be sold and require the appointment of a local agent to accept any legal notices. The amended law also calls for a security deposit to be posted against any court costs or other legal liabilities incurred by the publication. The bill was introduced on July 18 and becomes law after it is signed by President Wee Kim Wee. It followed an announcement in April by Deputy Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong that the government was planning to make regional publications subject to the country's jurisdiction. Goh commented after the government reported difficulties in serving notices on The Asian Wall Street Journal over a recent contempt of court action and a defamation suit.
DOC.HEAD: Indian Parliament Passes Bill To Loosen Control on Television, Radio
DOC.TEXT: The lower house of Parliament passed a bill Aug. 30 to loosen state control of Indian television and radio. The bill proposes that control switch from the government's Information and Broadcasting Ministry to a 15-member board, which would include some government representatives. The measure must still be approved by the upper house of Parliament and President Ramaswamy Venkataraman before it becomes law, Press Trust of India reported. Television has been under state control since its inception in 1965. Radio broadcasting made its debut in 1927 and has been under similar constraints, by British colonial rulers for the first 20 years and then by the government of independent India. At least three-fourths of the population is reached by television. All India Radio, the radio network, can be heard all over the country.
DOC.HEAD: New Head of Official Polish News Agency Appointed
DOC.TEXT: Ignacy Rutkiewicz has been appointed the new head of the state-run PAP news agency, a newspaper said Aug. 30. The government daily Rzeczpospolita said in a brief announcement that Rutkiewicz will replace Bogdan Jachacz, who has served as PAP president and editor in chief since 1986. Rutkiewicz has been editor in chief of the Odra monthly, one of the most outspoken magazines that operated under official sanction in Communist Poland. Government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska said the appointment was a part of broader changes in the government-controlled agency expected to be announced this month. It is seen also as a part of the government personnel policy to replace the so-called nomenklatura, the officials previously loyal to the former Communist-led government.
DOC.HEAD: Case Dropped Against Police in Journalist's Death
DOC.TEXT: The attorney general dropped charges against four policemen accused of abducting and killing a correspondent for the Inter Press Service earlier this year. Colombo Magistrate Rohini Walgama discontinued the case Aug. 30 after the attorney general's counsel said there was insufficient evidence to prosecute the policemen. The attorney for the reporter's family claimed the killing was political and the investigation was improper. Richard De Zoysa, the Colombo correspondent for the Rome-based news agency, was taken from his home Feb. 18 by six armed men in a jeep similar to those used by the police, his family had said. His body was found with gunshot wounds washed ashore on the beach at Moratuwa, 10 miles south of the capital. The government denied the military or police were involved in the killing and ordered a police investigation. De Zoysa's mother, Manorani Saravanamuttu, said she witnessed his abduction. On June 1 she submitted affidavits identifying policemen she claimed were involved, including a senior superintendent. State counsel Anura Meddegoda said four affidavits produced by Mrs. Saravanamuttu contained several major contradictions and the attorney general was unable to act only on those affidavits.
DOC.HEAD: Publisher Says New Newspaper Exceeds Circulation Guarantee
DOC.TEXT: The European, a weekly newspaper launched in May, exceeded the circulation guaranteed to advertisers in June and July, publisher Robert Maxwell said Aug. 28. Maxwell said weekly sales in June were estimated to be 360,000, and 340,000 in July. Advertisers had been guaranteed circulation of 225,000. The paper, published in London every Friday, had average sales of 153,000 on the European continent in June, Maxwell said, adding that circulation for July through December will be audited by the Audit Bureau of Circulation.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Videotape Raises Journalistic Question
DOC.TEXT: Cable News Network's decision to air Iraqi satellite transmissions live, including one segment of tape that showed a meeting between Saddam Hussein and Western hostages, became the focus of journalistic debate. ``We would not do that under any circumstances,'' said Bob McFarland, NBC deputy director of news. ``We made that decision the first day they pumped it out. We decided it was pure propaganda.'' None of the big three American networks _ NBC, ABC and CBS _ aired the Iraqi transmission live on Aug. 28, as CNN did. Instead, they showed portions somewhat later. CNN said the meeting was important enough to show as quickly as possible. ``We make these decisions on a case-by-case basis,'' said CNN spokesman Steve Haworth, adding that CNN understood that Saddam would be speaking with American hostages. ``There was no question in our minds this would be newsworthy.'' CNN explained to viewers that the broadcast was an Iraqi TV feed. And afterward, CNN featured a debate over the wisdom of the decisions it had made. It's a decision the other networks see differently. At NBC, ``we would not put Iraqi TV on the air without first knowing what it was,'' McFarland said. ``We took every frame of it into the house, looked at it, and then selected two or three bites.'' ``Wherever there is a hostage videotape, a captive videotape, it's a decision we don't take lightly,'' said Sherrie Rollins, ABC director of news information. The president of ABC News has to approve the use of such video, she said. When Saddam appeared on television on Aug. 23 with Western hostages, ABC joined the Iraqi satellite feed live for a few moments after first viewing the transmission to gauge the content of the material. ``We did air the material; we did feel it was newsworthy,'' Ms. Rollins said. But when Saddam appeared with hostages again Aug. 28, ABC taped the material and showed only a brief portion during a special report by anchorman Peter Jennings, she said. After the first appearance on CNN, Pati Heath of Detroit, the sister of an American hostage, called the Atlanta-based network to say she had seen her brother on TV. CNN then put her on television, too. ``I'm just happy to be able to see my brother's face,'' she said. ``I hope Hussein sees me talking right now.'' The first U.S. interview with Saddam went to CBS news anchor Dan Rather, on Aug. 29. CBS said the taped interview lasted 90 minutes and began shortly after midnight in Baghdad. Rather was told there would be no interview that day, but suddenly was summoned to the presidential palace. There were no restrictions on what Rather could ask, said CBS spokeswoman Donna Dees. The only conditions were that Iraqi TV cameras be used and that it be a one-hour interview that would air as recorded, she said. He agreed to let the interview run longer so it could be cut for translation and minor editing, Dees said.
DOC.HEAD: TV News Gets High Ratings During Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis has created a thirst for news that has lifted the ratings of everything from ``Face the Nation'' to ``60 Minutes.'' CBS' ``60 Minutes'' was the most-watched show on prime-time television for the second consecutive week, the A.C. Nielsen Co. said Aug. 28. It was the program's first back-to-back No. 1 victories since 1983, when it was the top-rated show for the year. Viewership of six Sunday news and information programs _ ``Face the Nation'' and ``Sunday Morning'' on CBS; ``This Week with David Brinkley'' and ``Business World'' on ABC, and NBC's ``Meet the Press'' and ``Sunday Today'' _ rose 27.7 percent since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Nielsen reported. The most-watched nightly network news program belonged to ABC and Peter Jennings, with a 10.4 average. CBS and Dan Rather were second with 10.2 and NBC and Tom Brokaw was last with 8.9.
DOC.HEAD: Wayne Newton's $5.2 Million Judgment Overturned
DOC.TEXT: A $5.2 million libel damage award to singer Wayne Newton from NBC was overturned Aug. 30 by a federal appeals court. It said a broadcast suggesting mob ties in Newton's purchase of a casino was not shown to be deliberately or recklessly false. A jury in Las Vegas found that the television network's October 1980 story about a federal investigation of the singer's acquisition of the Aladdin Hotel and Casino had created a false impression that criminal organizations had helped in the purchase in exchange for a hidden share and that Newton had deceived Nevada gaming officials. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in a 3-0 ruling, said most of the factual statements in the broadcast were undisputed, and that any false impressions had not been shown to be deliberate or reckless. For example, the court said, citing evidence in the case, Newton had contacted a purported organized crime figure, Guido Penosi, about a problem; Penosi had arranged a solution, and Penosi and an associate later discussed the possibility of profiting from Newton's ownership of the Aladdin, a subject that came under federal investigation. Newton testified that he asked Penosi to stop organized crime threats against himself and his daughter. That subject was not mentioned in the NBC story. The court said Newton had testified falsely to the state Gaming Board about his relationship with Penosi. The court did not say whether the story as a whole was false _ an issue it did not have to address. Instead, it found a lack of evidence that the journalists had either deliberately lied or had been reckless with the truth. That standard must be met by public figures or public officials suing the news media for libel. The court said U.S. District Judge Myron Crocker, who reduced the jury's $19.3 million libel award to $5.2 million, erroneously allowed the damages to be based on a conclusion that NBC should have realized its broadcast would give a false impression. What journalists should have realized or foreseen is irrelevant in a libel suit by a public figure, which must be based on what a journalist actually knew and intended, said the appellate decision by Judge William Norris. He said Crocker also improperly ``substituted (his) own view as to the supposed impression left by the broadcast for that of the journalists who prepared the broadcast.'' Newton had argued that the story's failure to mention the threats against him as the reason he had contacted Penosi was a deliberate omission of the truth. But Norris said the reporters had reasons to doubt that threats had been made, noting that they had gotten a denial from Newton's lawyer. Norris said the broadcast's statement that Newton had financial problems at the time of the purchase was true. The broadcast had some ambiguities about his financial arrangements and testimony, which might have been cleared up by different wording, but ``editorial decisions about broadcasts are best left to editors, not to judges and juries,'' Norris said.

DOC.HEAD: Rodgers Named CBS Stations Division President
DOC.TEXT: CBS on Aug. 29 named Johnathan Rodgers, vice president and general manager of WBBM-TV in Chicago, as president of its television stations division. Rodgers will be in charge of the five TV stations CBS owns. He succeeds Eric Ober, who was named president of CBS News after the forced resignation of David Burke. Rodgers, 44, will be the highest-ranking black executive at any of the three major broadcast networks. He joined CBS in 1976 as assistant news director at WBBM. He later worked at what now is KCBS-TV in Los Angeles, from 1978 to 1983, serving successively as an executive news producer, news director and then as the station's manager.
DOC.HEAD: Garagiola Off Show for Surgery
DOC.TEXT: ``Today'' co-anchor Joe Garagiola will be off the NBC show for four weeks to have elective surgery for a problem that is ``not life-theatening,'' a spokeswoman for the show said Aug. 31. Garagiola, 64, declined to disclose the nature of the surgery, said spokeswoman Mary Neagoy, and his medical leave from the program starts Sept. 4. After changes that led to Jane Pauley's exit from ``Today'' after 13 years, NBC hired Garagiola, a former ``Today'' co-host, to return to the show as a third co-anchor with Deborah Norville and Bryant Gumbel. The gregarious former baseball catcher returned to the show in June, and has been appearing on Tuesdays through Thursdays.
DOC.HEAD: Chase Moving to `Prime Time Live'
DOC.TEXT: Former ABC News correspondent Sylvia Chase says she will return to the network in New York as a correspondent for ``Prime Time Live,'' the magazine show anchored by Sam Donaldson and Diane Sawyer. She said her interest in returning to reporting was sparked by last year's events in Tiananmen Square and later, the reunification of Germany. ``I felt almost this pain of wanting to be involved as a reporter every morning when I picked up The New York Times,'' said Chase, 52, who came to KRON-TV about five years ago from eight years on ABC's news program ``20-20.'' Though no specific dates were given in her Aug. 30 announcement, Chase is expected to leave her job as 6 p.m. news co-anchor at KRON this fall. Last year, KRON won the broadcasting's prestigious Peabody Award for Chase's report on homeless children.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Gives Green Light to TV Marti
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Aug. 27 that the Voice of America television station aimed at Cuban viewers has passed a five-month preliminary test and will become a permanent operation. TV Marti has been broadcasting news, movies and shows such as ``Cheers'' and ``Mission Impossible'' on a trial basis since March 27. Cuba has jammed the broadcasts since the first day and has said that effort has been virtually 100 per cent successful. Bush's announcement releases $16 million that had been withheld pending a presidential determination that the operation was both legal and technically feasible. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the testing period demonstrated that TV Marti did not interfere with Florida television broadcasting and did not violate international telecommunications agreements. Cuban President Fidel Castro has denounced TV Marti as illegal and a ``gross interference'' in Cuba's internal affairs.
DOC.HEAD: Werner Leaves ESPN
DOC.TEXT: Roger Werner, who solidified ESPN's dominant role in cable television by acquiring rights to major league baseball and retaining the network's contract with the NFL, quit Aug. 29 as president and chief executive officer. Werner will become president and CEO of Prime Ventures Inc., a new company being formed by Bill Daniels, who has interests in several regional cable networks. No successor was named immediately by ESPN, an 11-year-old venture that was one of the first major steps into cable television. The network, which has 56 million subscribers, is 80 percent owned by Capital Cities-ABC and 20 percent by RJR Nabisco. Herb Granath, president of Cap Cities video enterprises and chairman of ESPN, said that Werner was not fired and left on his own. Both Granath and Werner said money was not an issue but would not comment if equity ownership was. They also denied that losses in the baseball package were the reason for Werner's departure. ESPN said it will lose between $30 million and $40 million this year after projecting a $31 million loss. Last year, the network agreed to a $400 million, four-year contract with baseball that began this season. Its coverage is now dominated by baseball for half the year, with single games on Wednesday and Sunday and doubleheaders on Tuesday and Friday. A total of 175 games each season are being shown. Last March, the ESPN retained its rights to eight Sunday night NFL games each season, but the price went up from $150 million from 1987-89 to $450 million for 1990-93. Granath said that profits for ESPN would be down slightly this year, but that was anticipated because of the baseball startup costs.

DOC.HEAD: Jose Rios Named KCBS News Head
DOC.TEXT: Jose Rios, assistant news director at KCBS-TV the past three years, was named the station's news director Aug. 28. KCBS denied that pressure from a Hispanic group was behind the promotion. Rios, a 12-year veteran of KCBS, replaces Michael Singer, who will oversee the station's investigative reporting unit. The National Hispanic Media Coalition has threatened to challenge the station's license with the Federal Communications Commission over the company's hiring practices. The coalition says KCBS has not hired enough Hispanics in policy-making positions and that the station's number of minority hires is far below FCC standards. KCBS denies the charges.
DOC.HEAD: KSLA Accepts Offer for Station
DOC.TEXT: Viacom TV Group said Aug. 28 it has agreed to sell KSLA-TV to Imes Communications Group of Columbus, Miss. Terms of the agreement, which must be approved by the Federal Communications Commission, were not disclosed. When the station was offered for sale in March, Viacom President Pat Brady said the purpose was to raise funds to reinvest in a larger television market. Imes owns several newspapers, including the Commercial Dispatch in Columbus, Miss., and television stations in Columbus, Clarksburg, W.Va.; El Paso, Texas; and Manchester, N.H.
DOC.HEAD: Television Station WWL Sold
DOC.TEXT: WWL-TV was sold to a group of its employees on Aug. 27 after more than a year of negotiations. The station, which was owned by Loyola University, was sold to Rampart Broadcasting for $102,850,000, officials said. J. Michael Early, general manager of WWL-TV for 29 years, will remain as chief operating officer. He said the entire management team will stay with the station. ``That's the primary reason we put the deal together in the first place to assure that loyal employees who put decades of hard work into the station would not be displaced by new owners coming in with no knowledge of the market or of past employee loyalties,'' Early said. Loyola put WWL-TV on the air on Sept. 7, 1957.
DOC.HEAD: Notre Dame Reaches European Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Notre Dame, the first university to negotiate its own football contract with a major television network, is taking its act to Europe this fall. The school reached a tentative agreement Aug. 27 to have its football games televised in six European countries for three years, athletic director Dick Rosenthal said. The deal will allow London-based Screensport to use the feeds from Notre Dame games being televised in the United States. Screensport is an all-sports satellite channel that reaches most of northern Europe. Rosenthal declined to disclose terms of the agreement but said Notre Dame's earnings would be small. ``It's not a big market,'' he said. In February, the Irish, whose television rights were held by ABC and ESPN, broke from the 64-team College Football Association to sign a five-year, $37.5 million contract with NBC. NBC will have exclusive television rights to Notre Dame's home games for five seasons beginning in 1991.
DOC.HEAD: KQED Drops Auction Tradition, Cites Small Audiences
DOC.TEXT: Public station KQED-TV, which pioneered the annual auction as a fund-raising mechanism 36 years ago, said Aug. 30 it was ending the practice because of dwindling audiences. Jon Abbott, KQED's vice president for marketing and development, said the 1990 auction raised $550,000 on costs of $350,000, a narrower margin than in previous years. Abbott said recent audiences ``were so small as to be unmeasurable in the Nielsen ratings.'' Public stations in New York and Washington, D.C., have recently axed their auctions, too, said JoAnne Sutro, KQED's manager of television promotion.

DOC.HEAD: Watson To President of Consolidated Gannett Division
DOC.TEXT: Gary Watson, a 21-year veteran of Gannett Co. Inc., has been named president of a newly consolidated newspaper division in the company. Watson has been president of its 60-member community newspaper division for the past 4{ years. The division will be combined with Gannett's metropolitan newspaper group, whose current president, Brian J. Donnelly, will become executive vice president reporting to Watson. Watson will oversee all of Gannett's daily papers except USA Today after the change, scheduled for Oct. 1. In a story Aug. 30, The Washington Post said Watson's promotion fueled rumors that he was being groomed to become president and chief operating officer. Mimi Feller, Gannett's vice president for public affairs, denied speculation that he would become second-in-command to Gannett Chairman-President John J. Curley. Feller said the company's chief financial officer, Douglas H. McCorkindale, and USA Today Publisher Cathleen P. Black would remain in those positions. ``There have been no changes in Cathy Black's or Doug's positions. And there are no (additional) changes coming up in Gary's position,'' she said. Watson, according to the Post, said the consolidation was partly in response to the increasingly tough environment for newspaper advertising. Gannett's newspaper revenue fell 2 percent in the second quarter compared with a year ago and was down 1 percent for the first six months of this year. But Feller said the Post was ``off base'' when it implied that economics was the reason for the change. She said the consolidation and promotion of Watson ``just makes sense organizationally'' at this time. She said Gannett created the two newspaper divisions in 1985 when ``we were making some larger acquisitions of papers. ... But now we've found that it would be better to have it in one place. You don't need to have the overlap.'' She said the change would not mean any reductions in personnel. ``It's totally an administrative restructuring, not a reduction in personnel or savings in costs,'' she said, noting that both divisions previously had been operating under one corporate staff. ``The corporate staff stays the same. The folks running the papers in the field stay the same.'' Watson, 45, started with Gannett in 1969 at its Rockford (Ill.) Register Star. He held various editing and reporting jobs with the company, and later was named president of its Midwestern newspaper division and president of The Cincinnati Enquirer.
DOC.HEAD: Frank Daniels III Named News & Observer Executive Editor
DOC.TEXT: Frank Daniels III, former director of operations for The News & Observer, has been named executive editor of the newspaper. Daniels, 34, will succeed Claude Sitton, who retires Nov. 1. He is the son of Frank Daniels Jr., publisher of the newspaper and president of The News & Observer Publishing Co. Daniels has worked as a reporter for the St. Joseph (Mo.) News-Press and as a reporter and copy editor for The Ledger-Star in Norfolk, Va. As operations director for The News & Observer, he supervised display and classified advertising, circulation, production and planning.
DOC.HEAD: Cogburn Named Executive Editor
DOC.TEXT: Kenneth L. Cogburn, managing editor of Puerto Rico's San Juan Star the past three years, was named executive editor of The News-Herald of Willoughby on Aug. 31. Cogburn, 40, previously worked at the Fort Worth (Texas) Star-Telegram as copy editor, copy desk chief, news editor and suburban zone editor.
DOC.HEAD: Caperton Named Managing Editor of The Indianapolis Star
DOC.TEXT: Frank Caperton has been named managing editor of The Indianapolis Star, succeeding Lawrence S. ``Bo'' Connor, who is retiring. Caperton has been managing editor of the Star's sister newspaper, The Indianapolis News, since 1984. He was executive editor of The Virginian-Pilot and Ledger-Star in Norfolk, Va., for six years before coming to Indianapolis. Before that he was executive editor of the Macon (Ga.) Telegraph and News, and held editing and reporting positions with The Miami Herald, Tampa Tribune, St. Petersburg Times and The Richmond (Va.) News Leader. Connor, who became managing editor in 1979, announced his retirement in July after 41 years with the Star. Caperton's successor at the News was not immediately named.
DOC.HEAD: Nancy Woodhull Goes to Time Warner's Southern Progress
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Woodhull, president of Gannett News Services, has been named executive vice president and editor in chief at Time Warner Inc.'s Southern Progress Corp. The Aug. 27 announcement said Ms. Woodhull will oversee the editorial direction of the magazines Southern Living, Progressive Farmer, Southern Accents, Travel South and Cooking Light. Ms. Woodhull, 45, was a founding editor and the first managing editor-news at USA Today. In 1984, she was named vice president of Gannett New Media, which has explored new products and technology with an emphasis in spinoffs from USA Today. In 1988, she became president of Gannett News Services, which operates a national wire, radio and TV service available exclusively to Gannett's 83 newspapers, 10 television stations and 16 radio stations.
DOC.HEAD: Barr Named London News Editor
DOC.TEXT: Robert Barr has been appointed as news editor for The Associated Press in London, succeeding Marcus Eliason, whose promotion to chief of bureau in Jerusalem was announced earlier. Barr, 43, a newsman on the London staff since 1988, joined the AP in 1971 in the Honolulu bureau. He transferred to New York in 1977, first to World Services, and then to the General Desk, where he worked as a supervisor before moving to London.
DOC.HEAD: Hollinger Appointed Ad Network Director
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Sun-Times has appointed Sherry Hollinger director of sales for its advertising network covering the newspaper and its suburban chains. Mrs. Hollinger, 31, will coordinate sales for the Sun-Times, its south suburban Star Publications and its north and west suburban Pioneer Press. The network gives advertisers the chance to buy ads in the Sun-Times, the 46 Pioneer papers and 19 Star papers with a single advertising order.
DOC.HEAD: NBC Hires Daily News' Herbert
DOC.TEXT: NBC News has hired New York Daily News columnist Bob Herbert as a contributing correspondent. Herbert starts at NBC in January but will continue working for the Daily News, the network said Aug. 29. Herbert joined the newspaper in 1976 and has worked as a reporter and city editor.

Rex Bodenhamer, a former co-owner of the Baxter Bulletin, died Aug. 28. He was 93. Bodenhamer began his career as a Linotype operator at the Bulletin and eventually bought the newspaper. He was a past member of the Mountain Home School Board and a past chairman of the Baxter County Democratic Central Committee. Survivors include his wife, a daughter, two grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

Newscaster Paul Lockwood, who spent 15 years on the CBS radio network, died Sept. 1 at Central Suffolk Hospital. He was 51. Lockwood had worked for the past year as news director at WBAZ-FM on New York's Long Island. Witnesses said he collapsed Aug. 23 after getting out of his car to do a remote broadcast. He never regained consciousness. He had a history of heart disease. Highlights in his career included coverage of Ronald Reagan on the campaign trail and of Hurricane Alicia, which hit Texas in 1983. Lockwood broke into New York City broadcasting in 1964 on the former WPIX-FM, followed by jobs at WNEW-AM, WHN and WINS. He is survived by his mother, his wife, a daughter and two grandchildren.

Carl P. Miller, a retired executive of The Wall Street Journal and former president of Rotary International, died Aug. 30 of cancer at his home here. He was 92. During his career, Miller owned, managed, edited and published more than 30 newspapers. In 1929 he became the first executive director of the Journal's Pacific Coast edition, a position he held until his retirement in 1964. He was international president of Rotary International in 1963 and 1964. He studied journalism at Kansas State University. In 1989, he donated $1 million to the school in the name of his father, A.Q. Miller Sr., for whom the journalism school is named. In 1985, he established a $1 million endowment in the Rotary Foundation to fund service projects around the world. Survivors include his wife, son and daughter.

Richard E. Pearce, a reporter, editor and novelist, died Aug. 25. He was 80. Pearce spent 36 years with the San Francisco Examiner, retiring in 1975. Besides writing news and editorials, he wrote six novels. Pearce attended the University of Oklahoma and at 26 became political editor of the Oklahoma News. Survivors include his wife, two daughters and three grandchildren.

Ellen Fitzgerald, senior staff photographer with the Athens Banner-Herald and Athens Daily News, was killed in an automobile accident Aug. 25. She was 36. The accident occurred east of Athens as Ms. Fitzgerald returned home from a vacation in Charleston, S.C. Ms. Fitzgerald joined the Athens newspapers in 1980 and won dozens of awards for her work with the papers. She specialized in sports photography and was on the sidelines for most University of Georgia football and basketball home games. She was also a stringer for The Associated Press at those events. Survivors include her parents, three sisters and three brothers.

The Rev. Jesse Jackson's interview with Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein and some former hostages will be shown in a four-part series starting Sept. 4 on ``Inside Edition.'' Iraqi officials cut from the tape a warning by Saddam that foreigners hiding from Iraqi forces in Kuwait could be treated as spies, said producer Ken Walker. It was Jackson's debut as a reporter. He was paid $125,000 for the costs of getting himself and his 14-member crew to Iraq, the show's representatives said.
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: President Bush is sending two high-level delegations on a global search for billions of dollars to support the economic and military campaign against Iraq. But given the puny response before the missions even left, some observers wondered whether getting the allies to contribute money will prove almost as tough as persuading Iraq's Saddam Hussein to leave Kuwait. To emphasize the importance of the mission, Bush selected two of his closest Cabinet advisers, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, to head the delegations. Brady was leaving today for Paris and meetings with top French officials in a globe-trotting trip that in four days also will take him to London, Seoul, South Korea; and Tokyo.

Defenders of First Amendment rights lament the retirement of Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan but say the views of his prospective replacement, David H. Souter, on freedom of speech and the press are somewhat encouraging. ``No one could conclude he has an ax to grind against the media or against First Amendment claims,'' Henry Kaufman of the pro-media Libel Defense Resource Center said of Souter. ``Arguably, we will get a fair hearing. But he's no Brennan.'' Brennan retired in July after a 34-year career as the high court's leading voice of liberalism. He wrote a 1964 landmark opinion giving the news media broad protection against libel suits by public figures and recently authored opinions barring criminal prosecution of those who burn the American flag in protest. The Senate Judiciary Committee is scheduled to begin hearings on Souter's nomination Sept. 13. Most of what is known of his views have come from his writings as a New Hampshire state judge.

Bread, one of the few foods Soviet consumers have been able to obtain easily, is now in short supply in Moscow for the first time since the early 1960s. Despite a record grain harvest this year, many of Moscow's bread stores were empty on Monday, and there were long lines at others. Some irate consumers blamed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic reforms. ``That's perestroika _ we're not moving forward, we're going backward,'' said Viktor Lyubeznov, a 52-year-old electrician who went to four Moscow bread stores before finding a loaf. Russians have long been accustomed to shortages of fresh vegetables, fruits and meat. They have no microwave foods, and no 24-hour convenience stores. But heavy Russian bread, baked in central factories and sold at subsidized prices, has always been fresh and plentiful. The last time people remember long bread lines was under former Premier Nikita Khrushchev, who was ousted in 1964.

College students headed back to class today in this fear-stricken town as investigators said the killer stalking young women seemed to be taunting authorities by the way he arranged evidence at the scene. ``In the scene, the set-up, there was a message _ to law enforcement, to whoever,'' police Capt. R.B. Ward said Monday. ``He was very calculated, very methodical in the way the person did things, as well as left things.'' Authorities would not elaborate on how evidence was arranged. Classes for more than 40,000 students were to resume at the University of Florida and Santa Fe Community College today after the Labor Day weekend.

Democrat Rudy Perpich says his major contribution over the last eight years as governor has been to restore confidence in Minnesota. Next week, Perpich himself faces a crucial vote of confidence. Backers say the 62-year-old incumbent is a visionary leader who deserves an unprecedented fourth term, while critics call him ``Governor Goofy'' or say he's simply been around too long. If voters endorse the latter view in the Sept. 11 Democratic-Farmer-Labor primary, former state Commerce Commissioner Mike Hatch will be the party's standard-bearer in November. The race is a dead heat, according to a recent public opinion poll, and political observers say it could turn on any last-minute mistakes by either campaign.

DOC.NOTE: For release Wed PMs, Sept. 5, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Three American Films to Profile Performer Josephine Baker
DOC.TEXT: Singer Josephine Baker was black, danced naked and reveled in her sexuality. From the 1920s until she died 15 years ago, most Americans shunned her. Yet Europeans loved the performer and her skin color, and found little risque in her blatant exposure of it. When Baker was penniless toward the end of her life, Princess Grace of Monaco cared for her. Suddenly, eight decades after her birth, she now is the focus of three American films. But it hardly denotes a surge in social consciousness. The story of these movies is mostly about money, big-name stars and rushing to capitalize on a very marketable story _ and how that process escalates once someone makes the first move. Home Box Office has the only completed version: ``The Josephine Baker Story'' will debut on the pay cable channel in February 1991. The HBO version, starring relative unknown Lynn Whitfield, cost $8 million and is the most expensive movie ever made by the 18-year-old network. In March, rival media mogul Ted Turner promised to deliver ``a major announcement'' during a press conference held the day after the Academy Awards ceremony. At the Beverly Hills gathering, Turner giddily presented singer-actress Diana Ross and proclaimed the former Supremes leader would be the executive producer and star of a three-hour cable movie about Baker for Turner Network Television. Almost six months later, the project has no script, no director, no shooting schedule and no casting outside of Ross. Dolly Parton's Sandollar company is planning a $20 million feature film covering one year in Baker's life. The project will be directed by Hugh Hudson, whose 1981 ``Chariots of Fire'' won the Oscar for Best Picture. But this big-screen version has no finished script and no release date. Although the latter two versions are far behind HBO's ambitious schedule, make no mistake about the intent of all three filmmakers. Not one has considered shelving the product. And all claim theirs is the best. HBO cites the mammoth scope of its film, which covered Baker's life from age 19 to 68, employed 6,000 extras and shot for nine weeks on 100 locations in Hungary. It is produced by David Puttnam and directed by Brian Gibson, who also made the Emmy-winning ``Murderers Among Us: The Simon Wisenthal Story'' for HBO. For now, Turner is content to hang all project credibility on Ross's involvement. ``Until we have a wonderful script, we really just have to bank on Diana, and I think she's pretty bankable,'' said Linda Berman, TNT's head of development. Howard Rosenman, one of five co-producers on the big-screen Sandollar version, said he doesn't take the cable movies seriously. ``There's no challenge between the director of `Chariots of Fire' and the guy who did `The Simon Wisenthal Story,' '' Rosenman said. If most Americans were scandalized by Baker in the early part of this century, few today know the enormity or impact of her life abroad. Her infamous banana dance, in which she appeared naked save for a belt of fake bananas, became the trademark of European revues. She did more, however, than sing and dance in the nude. Baker was a tireless advocate of civil rights. In World War II, she was a spy for the French resistance, carrying intelligence information about German troop concentrations scrawled in invisible ink on her sheet music. It was a long way from St. Louis, where as a child, she lived in an abandoned railroad car. As a young woman in the early 1920s, Baker wanted to be famous. Americans wanted her to scrub their floors. She fled to Paris, where color was less a discriminatory factor. At the height of her Paris glory, she returned to New York and appeared in the 1936 Ziegfeld Follies with Fanny Brice and Bob Hope. But the American public still was not ready for Baker. Critics panned her in racist reviews. Humiliated, she returned to Europe. In the 1950s, her body ravaged by numerous surgeries that left her sterile, she adopted 12 children from around the world, calling them her ``Rainbow Tribe.'' Tragedy, illness and several marriages took their toll. Once the richest black person in the world, Baker was destitute shortly before her death. She died in her sleep on the second night of a phenomenally successful comeback show in Paris. ``It's a classic story,'' said Robert Cooper, senior vice president of HBO pictures. ``The first thing I asked was `If this is true, why hasn't it been told?' '' The reason? ``I think people just didn't know how to do it,'' he said. Why now? ``Once one person decides to do it, it forces everyone else to finalize their plans,'' Cooper said. ``I think he who comes out first has a big advantage.''
Elsewhere in Television... PEAKS, PEAKS: ``Twin Peaks'' director David Lynch and theme composer Angelo Badalamenti will spotlight a segment of ``VH-1 to One'' on Sept. 29.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wed PMs, Sept. 5
For release Thurs PMs, Sept 6, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Forest Whitaker: Man of Many Parts Appearing in HBO Movie
DOC.TEXT: A burly, good-natured Texan, soft-spoken and a little shy, Forest Whitaker doesn't exactly stand out in a crowd. But in Hollywood, where unemployment is the rule, not the exception, he does OK. Whitaker has been one of the kids in ``Fast Times at Ridgemont High,'' the dude who pool-hustled Paul Newman in ``The Color of Money,'' a rock-steady ``Platoon'' grunt, and Robin Williams' sidekick in ``Good Morning, Vietnam.'' Two years ago, he got a best-actor award at the Cannes Film Festival as the tortured modern jazz pioneer Charlie Parker in Clint Eastwood's ``Bird.'' There was no Oscar nomination, but many good reviews, which tided him over. ``I guess the reward is to be appreciated for your work,'' Whitaker says. On Saturday, he's in a Home Box Office movie, ``Criminal Justice,'' as a fundamentally decent ex-con trying to stay straight but wrongly accused of slashing and robbing a crack-addicted prostitute in Brooklyn. It is a horrifying trip through what singer Tom Waits once called ``the bowels of due process.'' Whitaker, a methodical man, researched it before and while making the film in Pittsburgh five months ago. He hung out in the courts and in prison, observing, listening to prisoners talking with their families, trying to make bail. He even did a little time behind bars, he said, trying to get the moves, the look right. A lot of prisoners didn't know who he was. Those who did, he said, would say things like, ``Well, what are YOU doing here? What did YOU do?'' But it was similar in a way, he said, to the time he hung out with people in the medical profession, taking notes for the plastic surgeon he played in the film ``Johnny Handsome.'' ``The people are sometimes pretty helpful,'' he said. ``Because they want their stories to be told properly.'' Whitaker has been lucky enough to work fairly often since ``Fast Times'' in 1982. He once planned to sing opera, but switched to theater while in college. But his musical background has helped, notably in ``Bird.'' He didn't actually play the alto sax heard in the film, but he learned enough to fake it, then to get sounds from it, and then ... music. But until recently, he hadn't touched the horn. The reason: He was too deeply affected by what he'd gone through portraying Parker, a junkie genius who died in 1955 at age 34. ``When I played the horn, it reminded me of a lot of emotions that I was dealing with when I played the part,'' said Whitaker. ``So I avoided playing for a while. ... It took a while to wash it off, to get rid of it.'' The actor also has been having a go at writing, putting together his first screenplay, ``Pick a Card,'' over the course of seven years. It's a comedy about a con man and a three-card monte dealer who works the streets. There's no deal for that yet, and none is imminent, he said. Two weeks after making ``Criminal Justice,'' he proceeded to yet another new role, this one in a film comedy, ``Rage in Harlem.'' In that one, due out next year, he co-stars with Danny Glover and Gregory Hines, playing a mortician's accountant. He also, at 29, is making his debut as a co-producer, having served in that capacity on ``Rage.'' He laughed when asked if Whitaker the actor ever argued with Whitaker the producer. No, he said, but he's now a bit more sympathetic to producers. ``They have to think about stuff I never would think about before,'' he said, ``things I would just ignore and say, `Well, I'm an actor.' '' He knows that for an actor to be sympathetic towards producers constitutes heresy in some quarters. ``Yeah, but they have a pretty difficult job sometimes,'' he said. ``But as long as you're working toward the same goal, it works out.''

Elsewhere in television ... POST-LABOR DAY PEEKS: CBS, deciding to join NBC in pre-season games with new series, is offering what it calls ``sneak previews'' of three new sitcoms before the start of regulation play on Sept. 17. It will offer viewers an advance peek at ``Uncle Buck'' and ``Lenny'' Monday, Sept. 10, and ``The Family Man'' the next night. The excitement continues ...
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Thurs PMs, Sept. 6

DOC.SECOND: PM-Another Look: The Posse Now, Adv10,0924
DOC.NOTE: For release Mon PMs, Sept 10, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: ANOTHER LOOK: White Supremacist Posse Comitatus Fades Into History
DOC.TEXT: Delbert Larson scanned the empty woods where the Posse Comitatus once envisioned a paramilitary settlement for white supremacists, a haven from government regulations and taxes. ``Americans are blind and deaf,'' he says, explaining why the settlement failed. ``We tried to do what we thought was a job to alert the people.'' Larson, 66, is one of the few remnants of the Posse. Just a decade ago, they trained with guns, built underground shelters, vowed to rebel against government and caused a stir in this tiny central Wisconsin town. He now lives alone in a makeshift home on the rolling countryside just east of Tigerton, a white-haired man with steely blue eyes who cuts wood for heat and reads the Bible for spiritual comfort. Most of the Posse's militant leaders, including flamboyant businessman James Wickstrom and Tigerton farmer Donald Minniecheske, are sitting in prison after a government crackdown in the mid-1980s. Townsfolk have pronounced the Posse dead since 1985, when officers swooped onto the hundreds of acres of property the group had assembled and removed some trailer homes that violated county zoning laws. But Shawano County District Attorney Gary R. Bruno isn't convinced. Some evidence indicates hate groups in the United States are becoming ``bigger and badder,'' Bruno said, adding the Posse epitomized such groups with its loathing of Jews, blacks, taxes and government. The group's activities petered out in Wisconsin because the leaders were silenced, the prosecutor said. ``You cut off the head of a snake and the rest of the snake can worm around, but it can't bite you anymore,'' he said. The government considered the Posse dangerous lawbreakers, hatemongers and potential killers, something akin to organized crime. At least six Posse members have been convicted of crimes ranging from theft to tax evasion. Wickstrom, 47, was sentenced Aug. 7 in Pennsylvania to 38 months in prison for conspiring to distribute $100,000 in counterfeit money. He left Wisconsin in 1985 shortly after serving 13 months for impersonating a municipal official in the Posse's self-created Township of Tigerton Dells. Minniecheske, 56, upon whose farm land the Posse's compound was to flourish, is serving a nine-year prison sentence in Wisconsin for destruction of property, possession of stolen property and transfer of stolen property. Gordon Kahl, a North Dakota tax protester linked to the Posse, was killed June 3, 1983, during the second of two shootouts with police seeking to arrest him for tax evasion. Those shootouts left three federal marshals dead. Residents link the origins of the Posse to a day in the late 1970s when Minniecheske dumped two loads of sand along a river for a swimming beach, said Tigerton Police Chief Charles Gehrman. State officials objected _ he had no permit _ and his outrage against the government interference fueled a movement. Some residents said the Posse had legitimate complaints about government, but the wrong approach to solving them. ``They had support until they started going crazy with stuff, when they started flashing those guns,'' said Kevin Maas, a logger who remembers seeing at least one Posse member in town with a pistol strapped to his hip. The Tigerton Dells Bar and Ranch _ the Posse's headquarters and home for the Minniecheske family _ still displays a large picture of the late U.S. Sen. Joseph McCarthy, the anti-Communist crusader of the 1950s. ``That's been here since 1964,'' Minniecheske's wife, Sally, explained. ``He was a good friend of Donald's dad.'' Up the road, the driveway to the former Posse compound is marked with ominous signs _ ``Private Property,'' ``No Trespassing,'' ``Keep Out.'' A mailbox labeled ``Life Science Church; Christian Liberty Academy'' provides the only hint of the church building that once nestled in the trees. The government has alleged the church was nothing more than a front used by the group to evade taxes. Relatives visit Donald Minniecheske twice a week in prison. ``I don't think they have broken him. Not at all,'' said Minniecheske's son, James. ``Prison will never change him.'' Meanwhile, his wife, children and grandchildren host the church in their tavern. ``We survive,'' Mrs. Minniecheske said, shrugging her shoulders. ``The church takes care of what we need.'' Mrs. Minniecheske estimated 30 to 40 Posse members still live in the Tigerton area, farming and sharing financial resources. The government, however, is seeking to foreclose their property for back taxes. Jeremy Erickson, 13, one of Mrs. Minniecheske's 19 grandchildren, remembers the military maneuvers and survival training at the compound. ``When the Posse was here, it was kind of fun,'' the boy said. ``These guys used to line up, in camouflage, and shoot their guns in the river. They really didn't scare us. All of them were pretty nice. They didn't want to hurt anybody. They were all against the government because our government is corrupt,'' he said. James Minniecheske, 33, wonders whether the Posse should be revived. ``If it keeps my kids free from all this tyranny, let's do it,'' he said. But the jailing of Posse leaders ``scares people from trying to do anything,'' he said. ``I think guns are the only way to get our freedoms back.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon PMs, Sept. 10
For release Tues PMs, Sept. 11, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Yiddish Daily Begets English Weekly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Friday reference in 10th graf is Sept. 14
DOC.TEXT: The venerable Yiddish newspaper Forward, tutor and friend to generations of immigrants, is taking a giant step out of the Lower East Side with a national, English-language weekly. Faced with diminishing readership of its Yiddish edition, the 93-year-old Forward is braving a depressed newspaper market and ignoring widespread opinion that there is no need for a national Jewish newspaper. Its owners are confident they've located a niche among their competition, and believe their publishing legacy will give them the powerful boost needed to succeed. ``Yiddish readers are very loyal and have an emotional tie with the paper historically,'' said Harold Ostroff, co-chairman of Forward Publishing Co. ``They feel it's a part of the family, in a sense.'' The Forward traces its heritage back to 1897 when it emerged from the socialist labor movement to take up the cudgel of the Yiddish-speaking working class. The paper, initially a daily, served as teacher, political advocate, spiritual guide and psychiatrist for its readers, mostly Jewish immigrants to the United States. It published everything from a famous advice column _ ``A Bintel Brief,'' a bundle of letters _ to the writings of Isaac Bashevis Singer. During the early part of the century, its readers numbered more than 250,000. But as the immigrants were assimilated into American society, the number of Yiddish speakers declined and so did the newspaper's circulation. The paper went weekly in 1983 and began to publish an English-language supplement. Its circulation is now about 17,000. Recognizing the need to shore up its readership and attract descendants of readers past, the publishers have expanded the English-language insert into a paper in its own right. The first few issues of the paper, which was first published May 25, were distributed in the New York area only. National circulation will begin Friday, with a projected circulation of 30,000. Like the Yiddish Forward, the new paper combines news with social and cultural commentary. About 40 percent of the paper will be hard news and analysis, 40 percent cultural coverage and fiction, and 20 percent editorial pages, said Seth Lipsky, editor of the Forward and president of Forward Publishing Co. But Lipsky said he realizes that reputation alone will not carry the fledgling paper. The Yiddish paper already has a deficit, so the papers will share material, along with circulation and advertising programs in some markets, to ease costs. The Forward is entering a specialized market in which more than 100 Jewish publications are jostling for position. The toughest challenge among them will come from the regional Jewish presses. New York City, where Lipsky expects half of his circulation, has three established weeklies. Lipsky, though, believes there is room for his publication in each of the nation's major cities. His niche, he said, is in providing international and national Jewish news coverage beyond what the larger metropolitan dailies and regional Jewish papers offer. His paper already has opened bureaus in Jerusalem, Moscow, Paris, Washington and New York, and will supplement the offices with stringers, freelancers and news wire services. There are plans to open bureaus in other cities, including Miami, Chicago and Los Angeles. Lipsky believes there are enough major Jewish stories now to launch a paper. He cites the rise of a anti-Semitic movement in the Soviet Union, the prevailing conflict in Israel and the democratization of Eastern Europe. But Jewish editors around the country and observers of the Jewish press are less certain it will find a market. ``I have a philosophy that our readership is much more interested in the news of the local Jewish community than in news of the international Jewish community,'' said Marc Klein, editor and publisher of the Northern California Jewish Bulletin, which has a circulation of about 27,000. Klein, who also is president of the American Jewish Press Association, said 70 percent to 80 percent of his paper is devoted to local stories. Gary Rosenblatt, editor of the Baltimore Jewish Times, agrees. ``In Baltimore, they want to know from who's getting married to who's having a bar mitzvah to more weightier issues,'' said Rosenblatt, whose paper has a circulation of about 20,000. Abraham H. Foxman, national director of the Anti-Defamation League and a self-described ``news junkie,'' believes the Forward's association with the Yiddish Forward will at least draw attention to the new paper. ``The name `Forward' has history, has meaning in Anglo-Jewish life,'' he said. The national paper won't survive on Forward's readers, he said, ``But there is a nostalgic element. Jews feel sensitive to tradition and continuity and history. That will help the Forward initially.''

DOC.HEAD: Dolphin Deaths May Be Caused by Viral Epidemic
DOC.TEXT: Dead dolphins are washing up on Spain's eastern Mediterranean coast in unusually high numbers, causing marine biologists and ecologists to suspect a viral epidemic is killing them. Many scientists and environmental activists believe the deaths are the inevitable outcome of large-scale dumping of toxic pollutants in the Mediterranean by petrochemical plants. Esteve Grau, a University of Barcelona biologist, said preliminary results of autopsies on three of the dead mammals showed extremely high levels of polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCBs. ``We're working on the hypothesis that the dolphins ate PCB-contaminated fish and that this severely weakened their immune systems, making them susceptible to a still-unidentified virus,'' Grau said in a telephone interview. PCBs are liquid, resinous or crystalline organic compounds used in industrial processes as lubricants, heat-transfer fluids or to give strength or flexibility to wood, metal or concrete. ``We believe the scientists' hypothesis to be correct,'' said Xavier Pastor, head of the Greenpeace environmental group's office in Palma, capital of the Spanish island of Majorca in the Mediterranean. He said the toxicity of PCBs and their resistance to decomposition make them especially dangerous to mammals. ``The epidemic appears similar to others that killed up to 800 seals in the North Sea off the Netherlands in 1988 and in another case under study in California,'' Pastor said. He said some of the dead dolphins had been found on beaches near Palma, in the Balearic archipelago 150 miles south of Barcelona. Grau and other scientists from the Barcelona Zoo, the Marineland Aquatic Park and the University of Valencia have conducted 10 autopsies on dolphins. They are trying to determine why only striped dolphin, and not fish, have been killed, he said. Dr. Joaquim Piza of Marineland said doubts remained about whether PCBs caused the dolphins to die. ``If that were the case, it's most likely dolphins of other species would have been affected,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``The autopsies have not produced conclusive evidence that the PCBs are the cause. The only thing we have been able to determine so far with certainty is that the dolphins suffered a weakening of their immune systems.'' Piza said there was some speculation the dolphins had contracted a herpes-type virus that attacked their immune systems. Between 12 and 20 infirm or aged striped dolphins are found washed up every summer on Spain's eastern beaches and on Majorca, Grau said, but there have been more than 100 this year. He said the striped dolphin is not an endangered species and is abundant in the Mediterranean. Scientists fear the presence of PCBs eventually may reduce the number of dolphins by affecting reproduction in addition to killing the weaker ones, Grau said. ``We estimate that only 1 percent of affected dolphins have washed up,'' he said, ``which means the total number that have succumbed to the viral epidemic could be as high as 10,000.'' Pastor noted that industrial and chemical companies continue dumping tons of toxic waste, including PCBs, into the Mediterranean from plants along Spain's Mediterranean coast from Barcelona to Algeciras, adjacent to Gibraltar. ``We've called on Spain's autonomous regional governments and the central government in Madrid to set up a plan to gradually, but definitively, end all industrial toxic waste dumping into the Mediterranean by the end of 1991,'' he said. ``We've tried to work with industrial companies directly, but they have refused to acknowledge how much they dump into the Mediterranean, saying it might reveal industrial secrets to competitors.'' He said Greenpeace had found it difficult to develop estimates of the amount of PCBs companies in Spain dump into the Mediterranean.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Commander, a Former Army Captain, Has Unique Perspective on War ^LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: When Capt. Francisco Mena deserted the army and joined El Salvador's guerrillas, they greeted him with tentative embraces, hard stares and skepticism. For a year, a veteran fighter known as Fredy never let Mena walk behind him. ``There was a ceremony that was a bit awkward,'' Mena, who changed sides in 1981, told an interviewer. ``I gave a talk and afterward the guerrillas began asking questions.'' Some of those questions, he said, were: ``Why did you stay so long in the army? How many operations did you take part in? How many of us have you killed? `` `Damn,' I thought. `What have I gotten myself into? Here I came to help these guys, and they're busting my chops','' Mena said. He smiled at the recollection and brushed one hand through his wavy black hair. The 47-year-old rebel commander was in the delegation that, on Aug. 22, ended a fruitless round of peace talks here with the government of Alfredo Cristiani, the Salvadoran president. A nearly 11-year-old civil war between the leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front and a succession of U.S.-backed governments has killed an estimated 72,000 people, most of them civilians. The trip to Costa Rica was Mena's first involvement in the monthly negotiations and his first respite from the fighting in years. He was included because the exclusive subject of the talks this month was a rebel demand that the armed forces be purged of corrupt officers and reformed. That issue is the main sticking point in the negotations. Col. Mauricio Vargas, as a member of the government delegation, protects the military's interests at the talks. Officially, the Salvadoran military holds Mena in contempt. In the words of Col. Orlando Zepeda, vice minister of defense: ``That traitor and murderer has no moral right to make accusations or demands on us.'' Classmates at the military and some other officers, however, have demonstrated a camaraderie with Mena that could help promote eventual accord. Lt. Col. Mauricio Duke shook hands and chatted amiably with Mena, his former superior, when they met in the lobby of the hotel where the talks were held. Mena gave a copy of his book, ``From the National Army to the Guerrilla Army,'' to Duke, who responded with a sly smile: ``Gracias, my captain.'' The copy, like another sent to Vargas, was inscribed: ``Let's not forget the 15th of October.'' That is the date in 1979 when young officers _ Vargas, Mena and Duke included _ overthrew the rightist dictatorship of Gen. Carlos Humberto Romero. A broad-based government whose objective was national reconciliation resulted, but a purge of the military old guard faltered. Repression and death squads followed, and the result was civil war. Mena traces his change of heart to a year as an officer of the National Guard, a militarized police force. He described counterinsurgency tactics that included torture, rape and murder of alleged leftists, and told of an initiation rite during which he declined an invitation to drive a bayonet through the heart of a suspect. While he pondered such brutality later in his air-conditioned office, Mena said, the suspect and 11 others were killed in the gymnasium of the National Guard headquarters. ``That kind of thing consolidated my change of thinking by making me profoundly question the role we military men were playing,'' he said. ``It became denigrating for me to wear the National Guard insignia.'' The proclamation issued by those who carried out the 1979 coup promised respect for human rights, an end to corruption and modernization of a semifeudal economy that left most Salvadorans destitute. Peace is possible if military authorities honor those goals, Mena said, but added: ``The picture is this: We're getting nowhere in negotiations, so let's have at it with the irons.'' Fredy, the guerrilla fighter so wary of Mena, was killed in combat in 1985. Just before he died, Mena said, they had a conversation in which Fredy told him: ``In those early days I didn't trust you a bit, like you were still the enemy. Who ever would have believed that we'd come to be like brothers, that I'd gladly give my life for you?''
