DOC.BYLINE: Aging Population Poses New Problems for Spain ^By BEN STOCKING
DOC.TEXT: Fernando Carrillo vows he will never end up in a nursing home. ``Families should live together,'' said the 78-year-old retired military man who shares an apartment in the Spanish capital with his 46-year-old daughter. ``It must be sad to have your kids send you off to live in exile in a place like that.'' Carrillo's feelings are shared by the dozens of elderly Spaniards playing cards, chatting or sharing a beer in the sunny patio of the neighborhood senior citizen community center. But as the country's population of 39 million ages rapidly, fewer and fewer elderly Spaniards will be able to live with their children, the traditional way of dealing with aging in most Spanish families. This is just one of the changes resulting from the acceleration of the graying of Spanish society, according to doctors and activists who work with the elderly. They say more nursing homes will be needed, the health care system will have to adapt, and new programs will have to be developed to help the elderly live independently as long as they can. According to official statistics, 5 million Spaniards are 65 or older, up from 4.6 million four years ago. That is projected to rise to 6.1 million by 2000. As their numbers grow, Spanish senior citizens are beginning to unite to fight for their interests. In 1988, they formed the Council for the Elderly, banding together dozens of small groups with a combined membership of more than 1 million. The rapid aging of Spain's population is partly due to medical advances that have extended life-expectancy around the world. But it is also the result of two peculiarly Spanish events: the 1936-39 civil war and the end of the dictatorship of Gen. Francisco Franco in 1975. Because an estimated 1 million people died in the war and its aftermath of reprisals, the current generation of senior citizens is smaller than it would have been otherwise. As the remaining members of the war generation die, and as the members of the larger, postwar generation become senior citizens, the elderly population will continue growing. In 1970, the death rate was 8.41 per 1,000 people. In 1986, the last year for which comprehensive statistics are available, it had fallen to 8.04. Meanwhile, the birthrate has been falling dramatically, from 19.55 per 1,000 residents in 1970 to 11.37 per 1,000 in 1986. The Roman Catholic Church wielded great influence during the Franco years, and couples were encouraged to have large families. But since the restoration of democracy in 1977, the influence of the church has waned, and families are having fewer children. ``In the last 10 years, Spain has changed as much as a normal country changes in 30,'' said Juan Manuel Martinez Gomez, secretary general of the Spanish Society of Geriatrics and Gerontology. Manuela Jimenez Carrera, director of a small, private residence in Madrid that is home to nine elderly women, said more and more women are working outside the home and no longer have time to care for their elderly parents as they did in the past. Francisco Verdu, president of the Council for the Elderly, said a lack of housing is one of the most serious problems facing Spain's elderly. According to the Ministry of Social Affairs, 24,000 people are on waiting lists for public housing for the elderly. The problem is expected to worsen, and the ministry estimates 107,000 nursing home or group residency beds will be needed in the year 2000. Ministry officials say that the government will not be able to build enough housing to meet demand and that some of the new beds will have to be built by the private sector. But critics say the government needs to tighten regulation of private nursing homes that are often nothing more than hotels, ill-equipped to meet medical, dietary and psychological needs of senior citizens. Spaniards were shocked recently by television images of malnourished elderly women covered with bedsores being removed from a private Barcelona nursing home shut down following complaints from relatives of the residents. According to Martinez Gomez of the Spanish Society of Geriatrics and Gerontology, Spain has no more than 100 specialists in geriatric medicine, which has only been offered in medical school since 1978. ``We are far, far below where we should be,'' he said. Complicating the problem, Verdu said, is the tendency of elderly Spaniards to swallow pills on their own because there is not sufficient control of the over-the-counter sale of drugs.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Sept. 6, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: 300,000 Spaniards Suffer from Alzheimer's Disease
With BC-PRI-Spain-Elderly, b2023
DOC.TEXT: As Spain's population rapidly grows older, one of the country's most serious medical problems will be Alzheimer's disease. Few people here know much about it. ``There's very little practical information for families to explain how to deal with the problem,'' said Manuel Martinez Gomez, secretary general of the Spanish Society for Geriatrics and Gerontology. He said 250,000 to 300,000 Spaniards now suffer from Alzheimer's disease. And with Spain's older population expected to increase 20 percent to 6.1 million by the year 2,000, the number of victims is likely to follow the curve. Alzheimer's disease was discovered in 1906 by Alois Alzheimer, a German neuropathologist. It is a progressive brain disorder that causes the slow deterioration of the victim's mind. It causes changes in the nerve cells in the brain and usually results in death within two to 20 years. There is still no cure for the disease, and the cause is unknown. It results in severe memory loss, confusion, inability to perform routine tasks, personality changes and, eventually, total physical and mental incapacity. Martinez Gomez said he knew of no medical centers in Spain that specialize in treating Alzheimer's patients, most of whom are cared for at home.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Sept. 6, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Prescription Medicines Need Careful Use
DOC.TEXT: People over age 65 make up 13 percent of the American population, yet they take 30 percent of all prescription medicines sold in this country. One billion times each year, Americans 65 or older take over-the-counter drugs. While these medicines offer many benefits, they carry some risks. Almost everyone has a favorite story about the number of pills, potions or elixirs taken by an older relative or friend. While most of these stories have a happy ending, some do not. When taking any medication, caution and common sense are necessary. Some basic rules for safe use of medicine: _ Take exactly the amount your doctor prescribes and follow the dosage schedule as closely as possible. Contact your doctor or pharmacist immediately if you have unusual reactions to medications. _ Make sure to ask your doctor for the specific name of the medicine prescribed. Ask why the drug is necessary, how long the drug will have to be taken, and if there is a good generic substitute. _ Tell your doctor about all other medicines (prescription and over the counter) you are taking. Interactions between medications can cause serious complications. _ Keep a daily log. It should include the name of the medicine, the doctor who prescribed it, and the schedule for taking it. Include a space to check off each dose. _ Be sure to tell your doctor about past problems _ such as rashes, indigestion, dizziness, lack of appetite _ that occurred when you took other medicines. _ Be sure to ask your doctor about side effects, the best way to store the medicine, and any special rules _ for example, should the medicine be taken with foods or beverages, should you limit your activities while taking the medicine. _ Make sure the directions printed on the medicine container are clear. Ask the pharmicist to use easy-to-open containers if child-proof ones are hard to handle. The pharmacist can use large type on the label to help people with vision problems. _ Do not ``share'' your medicines with friends or relatives; do not save medicines for use at another time. _ Do not stop taking a medicine prescribed by your doctor suddenly _ even if the symptoms go away. _ Ask your doctor from time to time to review the medications you take. New information about medicines and how they affect older people is coming to light daily. For more information on the safe use of medications, contact: Elder-Health, University of Maryland School of Pharmacy, 20 North Pine St., Baltimore, Md., 21201, 301-328-3243. The Elder-Health program offers free publications such as ``You and Your Medicines,'' ``Choosing the Right (Not Wrong!) Non-Prescription Medicine'' and ``Aging and How it Affects Your Response to Medicine.'' Also, the Food and Drug Administration Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, Consumer and Professional Affairs (HFD-365) _ 5000 Fishers Lane, Rockville, Md., 20857, 301-295-801 _ will provide information on specific drugs and their side effects. Keep in mind that a chemical agent strong enough to cure an ailment is also strong enough to cause harm if not used wisely. Although people should never stop taking medecine without medical advice, if a drug seems to be causing more harm then good, don't be afraid to discuss the matter with your doctor. She or he may be able to prescribe a different drug that will be just as effective.

T. Franklin Williams, a geriatrics physician, is director of the National Institute on Aging, one of the 13 institutes that comprise the National Institutes of Health of the Department of Health and Human Services.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Sept. 6, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Budgeting Takes Planning But Is Not Impossible
DOC.TEXT: Think of a budget as a forecast, a measure, an estimate, a plan, a projection, or cash flow management. Budgeting is a balancing act that requires planning and goal setting. In the simplest sense, budgeting involves matching your outflow with your income in timing and amounts. Successful cash flow management is based on being aware of the unique pattern of inflows and outflows that make up your financial life. For most people, it's relatively easy to list the sources, amounts and timing of income. Because income usually does not fluctuate from month to month, the main challenge for salaried employees is to gather and analyze information about the outflow categories. If your income is erratic, say you are in sales and on commission, you'll encounter difficulty projecting and matching inflows for the coming year. Use your earning history and your plans for the present year as your guide. Even though your income fluctuates, you can still focus on patterns emerging over time. Tracking where your money goes will be your next step. Refer to your checkbook registers, receipts, statements, tax returns and floppy disks. Unless you inadvertently hide the nature of all your transactions by writing checks to ``cash'' and using automatic teller machines for cash advances, you should have some kind of financial records. If the task of determining where your money goes seems overwhelming at first, paint the picture in broad strokes. Develop amounts for expense categories, i.e. housing, meals, auto, etc. If you find that you have to guess at most categories, even after gathering all the records you have, you'll have to conduct an experiment in which you observe your spending habits. Keep a spending journal. For three to four months, keep track of all the money you spend. Yes, that means tallying up amounts for coffee and doughnuts, magazines for plane trips, new windshield wipers, and gadgets from the hardware store. Before you throw your hands up in dismay, realize that you are not alone. Very few people can accurately quote the amounts they spend on clothing, taxis, lunches, pet care, hobbies, household supplies and other items. Your goal is to develop a list of monthly expenses. You will discover some expenditures occur every month and are relatively fixed. Others will vary in amount and-or timing. Budgeting involves matching your income with your outflow. When there is a mismatch (i.e., the outflows are projected to exceed the inflows), you can (1) build up an adequate cash reserve to cover those times, (2) modify the timing of the inflows or outflows, (3) increase the size of the inflows, and-or (4) reduce the size of the outflows. _ Build an emergency reserve. It is important to build up a cash cushion of at least six months' worth of expenses. As with every rule of thumb, there are exceptions. For example, if you are able to cover the critical monthly living expenses from another income source, you might consider a smaller reserve. However, the best preparation for a financial pinch is an adequate reserve. When outflow requirements exceed inflow available, all you'll need to do is dip into the reserve. _ Modify the timing of inflows or outflows. Keep your money in an interest-bearing account and pay bills close to due dates. If necessary, contact creditors to rescedule payments. They may allow you to miss a few payments or stretch the time over which you make the payments. Unless you are in control of how you use your credit cards, you might want to make all purchases by cash or check. However, judicious use of credit can allow you to delay making payments. It's a good idea to pay for existing purchases before going into debt for new items. And, instead of making only the minimum payments required by the company, make the payment larger to take care of interest and reduction of principal. _ Increase inflows. To do this, you can liquidate assets or borrow money. In extremely tight situations, you can rent out a room in your house or find ways to earn extra money. Depending on your mindset, borrowing may be a workable option. Some financial planners say you should always try to borrow against assets before selling off those assets. Disrupting your investment program by selling valuable assets may not be in your best interest. Also, borrowing will result in yet another fixed outflow. _ Reduce outflows. Reduce certain outflows until the financial crunch subsides. Wherever an outflow is variable, determine how you can reduce the outflow. Consider the pros and cons of refinancing an expensive mortgage. Cut back on magazine subscriptions or decrease spending on gifts. Modify plans for wardrobe purchases; take care of the lawn yourself. Finally, if necessary, set your survival standard of living and stick to it. When the financial crisis passes, don't automatically return to your previous standard; instead, increase your emergency reserve first. Even when your income increases, resist the urge to immediately upgrade your standard of living. As the motto says, ``Plan Ahead.'' Start today, so you'll be able to take control of your financial life through cash flow management.
Cynthia Foreman is a member of the academic staff of the College for Financial Planning.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Sept. 6, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Beans Offer Variety, and Don't Require Much Savvy
DOC.TEXT: A gardener feeling jaded might get a lift with a different bean _ go French, perhaps, with filets and flageolets. Countless varieties exist of this ancient food plant of the Aztecs and Incas. And breeders keep creating new ones. Next year's catalogs, for example, will introduce a pole bean called ``Kentucky Blue.'' Winner of an All America Selections Award, the new bean combines traits of two already superb pole beans, ``Kentucky Wonder'' and ``Blue Lake'' _ something like crossing a Mercedes with a Cadillac. The breeder was Calvin Lamborn, an Idaho horticulturist who won a previous award for a sugar snap pea. In 40 years of gardening, the most attractive bean I've met is a super-slim Frenchie called ``haricot vert'' (ah-ree-co vair), probably best known as ``filet bean.'' This sweet and tender bean is as fussy as it is elegant. If you don't pick it at the right moment _ when it's shoelace-thin and no seeds have formed _ the pod toughens and the flavor goes ``off.'' A single day can make a difference. A gourmet shell bean becoming popular in American gardens is the flageolet (flah-joh-lay), celebrated in French cuisine as an accompaniment to roast lamb. I've grown this tiny bean and admired its taste and looks, but it takes a lot of them to make a meal. This year I grew soybeans for the first time. Of probably Asian origin, the soy was practically unknown in America until Commodore Matthew Perry brought some back from Japan in 1854. This shell bean contains high-quality protein (and also some fat), but breeders still are working to improve its flavor. In my garden a variety called ``Butterbeans'' took 90 days to mature, producing small, fuzzy pods _ about 2 inches long _ which were tough to pry open. Inside were two to three seeds as green as peas. They kept their nice color in cooking, but I found the taste on the bland side. The soy and another shell bean, the fava, known in Europe since Homeric times, are the only beans of non-Amerindian heritage. Unlike other beans, the fava withstands frost. Sown in mid-March, it matures in June, the earliest bean in my southern New York garden. The fava, also known as broad bean and Windsor bean, is delicious raw. It's still a favorite of picnickers in Rome, where, in ancient times, it gave its name to a prominent family, the Fabii. But some people get an anemia called ``favism'' by eating raw or partly cooked favas. Bean pods, of various shades of green, yellow and purple, contain some vitamin C and A and their taste is a summer delight. But it's the seeds that pack the protein. Hence the importance of shell beans in the human diet _ they're meat substitutes. Meals of beans and rice, beans and corn, or beans and pasta, combing proteins and carbohydrates, are classic fare. Lima beans have been found in Inca digs dating to 7000 B.C. In North America, the colonists saw Indians growing corn and beans together, using the cornstalks for the beans to climb on. You don't need much savvy to grow beans. Just be sure the soil is thoroughly warm when you sow them or they'll rot. Climbing beans need supports, of course, tripods being the best to resist high wind. In this day of the freezer, a gardener can store fresh shell beans, saving himself the labor of drying them. The fresh ones taste better than the mealy-prone dry ones, I think, and they cook much faster. Seeds keep excellently in the freezer, unlike pods, which emerge from the ice limp and practically tasteless. A shell bean called ``Limelight'' gave me an abundant harvest in early August of light green beans resembling baby limas in looks and flavor. Each easy-to-shell pod contained six or seven seeds. Pole lima beans yield the biggest seeds of all _ some as large as quarters _ and with a taste far superior to the dried ones. Their long-maturing time makes them unfeasible for the coldest parts of the country. In my borderline area, I push the season by starting them indoors in pots, like tomatoes. By late May, when I put them in the ground, they're sturdy plants. With favorable weather, I begin harvesting these big limas late in August, more than a month before frost. A helpful practice in growing limas is to sow the seeds with the ``eye'' _ the tiny notch _ facing down. This makes them germinate easier. In crusty soil, some growers even leave the top of the seed uncovered. I've had fine results with a variety of pole lima called ``King of the Garden,'' but now I'm ready to diversify. Next time I'm planting highly recommended lima called ``Christmas.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: George Bria retired from the AP in 1981 after 40 years.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, Sept. 6, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Maggie Kuhn Gets Award for Sticking Her Neck Out
DOC.TEXT: Gray Panther founder Maggie Kuhn celebrated her 85th birthday recently, and is living up to her lifelong pledge of doing ``something outrageous'' at least once a day. ``Today, I'm sending a telegram to Mr. Bush about Kuwait,'' Ms. Kuhn said last week. ``We should get the hell out of there.'' The whole thing is over oil, she said. ``We have the wind and the sun. We don't need that messy stuff,'' she said. ``And, oh, before I forget it, I'm writing another book. But I'm not quite ready to discuss it. I'm meeting with the editors tomorrow,'' she added in a quick change of pace that is characteristic of the woman who started the Gray Panthers as a voice for those not ready to give in to age. Ms. Kuhn turned 85 on Aug. 3. For her work over the years, the New York-based Giraffe Society recognized her as a member, one of the people who ``stick their necks out.'' Along with the recognition came some Ben and Jerry's ``light'' ice cream, a special award called the ``1,000 Pints of Lite,'' a play on Bush's ``thousand points of light'' campaign. The truck that brought the ice cream from Vermont couldn't make it the short way to Ms. Kuhn's Germantown home because of a low railroad trestle. It did make it, however, and the neighborhood was invited to eat and carry away all they could. ``There was rain and Ben and Jerry put up this enormous yellow tent,'' Ms. Kuhn said in describing the giving away of the pints of ice cream. ``We had a wonderful time.''
DOC.HEAD: Visiting Nurses Get $1.5 Million Grant
DOC.TEXT: The government is awarding a $1.5 million grant to the Visiting Nurse Association of America for a national demonstration program in an effort to increase home health care to frail older people. The association is seeking aid from foundations and corporations to match the grant provided by ACTION, the federal domestic volunteer agency. The project is intended to get the private sector involved in helping people live independently. With the matching financing, the Visiting Nurse Association will organize volunteer jobs for 200 senior citizens who will visit with 400 frail elderly and help them remain in their homes rather than be moved to institutions. Known as Senior Companions, the program will provide the low-income volunteers aged 60 and older with training, a small allowance, reimbursement for transportation and meals, insurance and an annual physical examination. The three-year project will be conducted in 18 communities throughout the country. Locations are to be announced later.

DOC.HEAD: Journal: Iacocca Boosts Cost-Cutting to $2.5 Billion, Up $1 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. is adding a half year and $1 billion to its cost-cutting program, boosting the target to $2.5 billion by June 1991, Chairman Lee Iacocca says. Iacocca said in an interview in today's edition of The Wall Street Journal that the company is near the $1.5 billion target set for the end of this year. Without the cuts, Chrysler would not be profitable, he said. Wall Street analysts and Chrysler officials expect the company will post a substantial loss in the third quarter, mainly because of an interruption of minivan production at two plants. During the first half of the year, Chrysler earned $251 million, down 64 percent from last year. In October 1989, Chrysler began its cost-cutting program with an initial target of $1 billion by the end of 1990. That was raised to $1.5 billion, and now Iacocca says it will be $2.5 billion by next June. ``If we can get $2.5 billion, I'll give our guys a lot of credit,'' he told the Journal. ``The last $1 billion obviously gets a little harder.'' Also in the interview, Iacocca said: _ The company hoped to find ``a good European partner'' to help with vehicle development and production, first probably with minivans and Jeeps, Chrysler's two biggest moneymakers. Previously, he acknowledged that Chrysler and the Italian industrial giant Fiat SpA have been talking about a business deal. _ Former Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald's departure last May was ``a bit of an emotional jolt for me.'' He wanted Greenwald to succeed him as chairman. Greenwald left Chrysler to head a three-union bid to buy United Airlines. _ Chrysler will maintain its current 30-cents-a-share stock dividend despite recent quarterly profits insufficient to cover the payments. ``But all good companies go through some periods where they don't earn the dividend but continue to pay it,'' Iacocca said. Chrysler's $4.5 billion in cash reserves should remain largely untouched unless the Mideast crisis escalates and new car and truck sales plummet.

DOC.HEAD: GTE Breaks Off Talks with Thorn EMI on Lighting Business
DOC.TEXT: GTE Corp. has ended discussions with Thorn EMI of Great Britain after being unable to agree on terms for GTE's proposed purchase of the British company's lighting business, GTE said. The discussions were initiated in May and at the time both companies had said the worldwide demand for lamps and fixtures of advanced technology required increasingly high levels of investment. The two companies had said the discussions were the result of a growing pressure to cut costs by scaling down research and development, manufacturing and marketing to develop strong positions in the world's key lighting markets. GTE announced Monday in a brief statement that the talks had ended. Thorn EMI, based in London, is an international company operating in the music, light and technologies industries. It generated sales of more than $5.1 billion in the year ended March 31, 1989. GTE is a telecommunications, lighting and precision materials company based in Stamford. It had sales of $17.4 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: GPA Orders 25 MD-11s
DOC.TEXT: GPA Group PLC has placed orders and options for 25 McDonnell Douglas MD-11 wide-body aircraft, the manufacturer says. The order was worth approximately $2.5 billion, McDonnell Douglas announced Monday at the Farnborough International Air Show. GPA, an aircraft leasing company based in Shannon, Ireland, had previously placed orders and options for 20 of the tri-jet aircraft. The latest order boosts GPA's total commitment for the MD-11 to 45 aircraft. GPA will receive its first two MD-11 aircraft in 1991 for lease to the Brazilian airline Varig. The company has also announced leases with Air Outre Mer and Garuda Indonesia Airlines, with whom it has formed a joint venture company for the acquisition and leasing of as many as eight aircraft. McDonnell Douglas said it has received 379 orders and commitments for the MD-11 from 32 customers, including the latest order.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed
DOC.TEXT: A modest rebound in soybean futures prices helped support the corn market but wheat futures were lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybeans quickly recovered the ground they lost Friday and continued to rise slowly in modest trading. Corn prices were barely changed in early trading despite the negative influence of favorable growing weather for the corn and soybean crops. Traders will get an update on crop conditions when the Agriculture Department releases its weekly progress report after today's close. Commodity and other financial markets were closed Monday in observance of Labor Day. Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., attributed last week's across-the-board decline in grain prices to an easing of inflation fears related to perceptions of a diminished threat of war in the Middle East. In early trading, wheat futures were 1\ cents to 3\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.59\ a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to 1} cents lower with September at $2.41{ a bushel; oats were { cent to 1} cents higher with September at $1.06\ a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 4 cents higher with September at $6.02{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .07 cents to .33 cents higher with the contract for delivery in October at 76.62 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .12 cent lower to .15 cent higher with September at 86.65 cents a pound; live hogs were .20 cent lower to .55 cent higher with October at 48.85 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .10 cent to .53 cent higher with February at 50.40 cents a pound. Cattle futures advanced Friday, the last trading day before the three-day Labor Day weekend, and pork futures retreated.

DOC.NOTE: For release Wednesday, Sept. 11, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Higher Mathematics: Buying and Selling in Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: After surviving a decade of civil war, Nicaraguans face inflation of 80 percent a month and three-tiered pricing that turns a shopping trip into an exercise for number crunchers. Many people tuck a calculator into purse or pocket before leaving home. ``I have to think twice before going out to buy anything,'' said Susana Montenegro, a middle-class housewife encountered in a supermarket. ``And not just because everything is so expensive. It's the conversions back and forth. They give me a headache.'' A new currency, called the gold cordoba, and the rules governing its value have made a confusing economy even more so. Gold cordobas officially trade at par with the dollar and are supposed to replace the old cordobas, which Nicaraguans have christened ``chancheros,'' or ``piggies,'' to set them apart from the new ones. When Mrs. Montenegro buys a 5-pound bag of beans she can pay in either gold cordobas or dollars and get change in piggies at the official exchange rate, or she can pay the entire amount in piggies. Into her decision and calculations, she must factor the principle that a piggy in hand should be a piggy spent quickly, because it will buy less next week. Devaluations of the piggy, which occur each Monday, make last week's black market rate this week's official exchange rate, erasing what advantage there had been in trading with the ``coyotes'' who deal in currency. In response, the coyotes change their own rate. Francisco Mayorga, president of the central bank, hailed the gold cordoba as the cornerstone of the economic revival promised by the new government, but it has been a mild flop. Only $4 million worth have been released into the market since the gold cordoba's debut Aug. 13, about 5 percent of the total money in circulation, and much of that is back in the bank vaults. Few people use the gold cordoba. Suspicious consumers prefer dollars, or even piggies, although 900,000 of them were needed to buy a dollar at the end of August. The government says it will issue only as many gold cordobas as it has dollars to back them up. Official parity remains in effect, but real parity began dissolving when the government stores that sell foreign goods only for dollars added a 1 percent charge for anyone paying with gold cordobas. Coyotes won't touch the new currency. ``Most people who buy dollars from me are merchants who go to Honduras and Guatemala to buy, and the gold cordobas are not accepted over there,'' said one, who would not give his name. ``The dollar is the dollar anywhere. The gold cordoba is something that only Panchito (Mayorga) likes.'' Public employees, who received 50 gold cordobas each as part of their pay, can use them to pay utility bills, which are higher now that subsidies have been ended. Restaurants, supermarkets and other businesses have converted prices to gold cordobas, but accept piggies at the official rate and dollars. To cope with the rising cost of living, people usually change their gold cordobas at banks for dollars and trade the dollars for piggies with street-corner coyotes, who pay about 10 percent above the official rate. Mrs. Montenegro tries to keep up with exchange rates because there have been 40 devaluations this year, 33 of them under President Violeta Chamorro's government since it succeeded the Sandinistas four months ago. If she receives dollars from relatives in the United States, as many Nicaraguans do, she is better off changing them on the black market and paying bills in piggies. Many Nicaraguans feel the higher rate on the black market offsets the risk of a police raid during the transaction.

DOC.NOTE: For release Monday, Sept. 10, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Foreign TV Unwelcome Intrusion in Parts of Asia
DOC.TEXT: Asian governments that want to control what their people see on television are fighting a losing battle with satellites and receiving dishes. Direct broadcasts from foreign countries into private homes via satellite are spreading rapidly. Some officials fret over the impact on their people's values and way of life. Western diplomats say others fear their social and political control might be questioned if citizens have wider freedom of choice. Ever smaller and cheaper receiving dishes and the launch of a major telecommunications satellite make it increasingly difficult for governments to deny viewers direct access to foreign television. ``We may not be able to check foreign TV intruding into our lives for much longer,'' Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore said in 1988, but he has done a pretty good job so far. The only known satellite-reception dish not in his government's hands that is capable of receiving foreign programs sits on the roof of the U.S. Embassy. Installation was permitted ``strictly for embassy use'' two years after an application was filed. Others in this prosperous city-state are prohibited by law from owning or selling such dishes, except for export. Foreign programs for the three Singapore Broadcasting Corp. channels are screened to ``filter out unacceptable and harmful values and lifestyles,'' said communications official Mah Bow Tan. One official said full access to foreign TV shows, permissive American offerings especially, could harm a young nation composed of different races, religions and cultures. He said censorship of foreign movies, magazines and TV was necessary to repel cultural subversion. Not everyone agrees. Lim Boon Heng, a member of Parliament, said the government should consider broadcasting to the surrounding region by satellite and stop trying to control the use of receiving dishes. Compact new receivers are small enough to fit into a suitcase, and Lim said: ``When dishes get to that size, the authorities will have a hard time to control the use of satellite receivers . . . so why fight it?'' A major enemy in this information war is positioned slightly to the east and 22,753 miles up. AsiaSat-1 was launched from China in April by a Long March III rocket and is in orbit near the Equator. Telecommunications satellites are not new to the region. Indonesia was the first country in Asia and third in the world, after Canada and the United States, to have a domestic satellite. Japan and Australia also have communications satellites. AsiaSat-1, the first privately owned satellite, has the potential to beam signals to and from the Middle East, Singapore and Tokyo, and could offer a dozen new channels to an area with more than 2 billion potential viewers. The owner is a consortium led by Hutchison Whampoa (Holdings) Ltd. and based in Hong Kong. In Indonesia alone, where reception from the government's Palapa series of satellites was established in 1976, an estimated 25,000 dishes can pick up AsiaSat-1. Hong Kong officials announced in early August that individuals could own and operate dishes for personal use without licenses, lifting a ban that had been widely ignored for years. Broadcasters and operators of dishes that serve more than one viewer must have licenses. Elsewhere, the picture is equally mixed. Satellite dishes are legal in the Philippines upon approval of an application, but few applications are approved. Those who can afford it put them up anyway, apparently assuming the government has more important rules to enforce. Direct reception of satellite television still is forbidden in Thailand, which maintains close control over telecommunications, but pressure against the policy is increasing. ``We cannot stop technologies from growing,'' Joompol Rodcumdee of Chulalongkorn University in Thailand told a regional seminar on the socio-economic impact of broadcast satellites. ``Today we may say we will not use them, but tomorrow we may not be able to get away from them,'' he said. Vijay Menon, secretary-general of the Asian Mass Communication Research and Information Center, said the estimated 150,000 satellite dishes in South Korea were ``not viewed as a blessing or even as a sign of progress.'' ``Journalism professors have been filling local newspapers with letters denouncing the impact of foreign TV on Korean society,'' he said. ``Foreign programs, they feel, are making viewers in Korea adopt alien ways of thinking, life and customs and deepening the dependency of Korea on alien culture.'' Malaysia bans private satellites for direct TV reception, and Madzhi Johari of the government broadcast training institute said: ``Direct access to broadcasting satellites means direct import of norms and values of the developed countries and will result in stress and conflict in our society.'' Indonesians seem relaxed about the impact of numerous private dishes, which fall into a legal no-man's land, neither permitted nor forbidden. ``There is no need to be alarmed over the possible unfavorable consequences, be they cultural, political or economic,'' said a senior executive at TVRI, the government network. Diplomats in Jakarta attribute the lack of concern to the fact that most foreign programs are in English or other languages relatively few Indonesians understand.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturing Economy Slows Again, Purchasing Managers Report
DOC.TEXT: The manufacturing sector of the economy slowed during August for the second straight month as production and new orders dropped, according to a survey of purchasing executives across the country. The National Association of Purchasing Management, which tracks the manufacturing economy through a monthly poll of its members, said its overall index of business activity fell to 47.0 percent from 47.4 percent in July. When the index registers below 50 percent, it indicates the economy is weakening. The drop in the index was the second consecutive decline. The index stood at 51.1 percent in June. News of the purchasing managers report contributed to a decline in the stock market. At 11:30 a.m. EDT, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 16.59 at 2,597.77. The purchasing managers reported a drop in production, the first in seven months, and attributed the slowdown to a sharp drop in new orders in July. Twenty percent of the purchasing managers said production was up in August, while 54 percent reported it was unchanged and 26 percent said it was down. That compared with 19 percent reporting higher production in July, 58 percent reporting it was unchanged that month and 23 percent saying it had slowed. Meanwhile, new orders dropped for the second straight month. Twenty-one percent of the purchasing managers said new orders rose during August, while 49 percent reported they were stable and 30 percent reported they had declined. In July, 19 percent reported growth in new orders, 53 percent reported they were the same and 28 percent said they had declined. Export orders also dropped. Sixteen percent of the purchasing managers said new export orders were up, while 74 percent said they were the same and 10 percent said they were down. The previous month, 24 percent said they were up, 66 said they were the same and 10 percent said they were down. Imports declined, with 7 percent of the respondents reporting an increase in imports, 81 percent reporting they were the same and 12 percent reporting a decline. In July, 9 percent reported imports were up, 78 percent said they were the same and 13 percent said they were lower. Prices for raw materials rose during August, a reflection of higher energy prices resulting from the Persian Gulf crisis. Twenty-two percent of the purchasing managers said they were paying higher prices, 68 percent said they were paying the same amount, and 10 percent said prices were down. That compared with 12 percent reporting higher prices in July, 77 reporting stable prices and 11 percent reporting lower prices. Employment fell for the 18th straight month during August and at a slightly faster rate than in July. Nine percent of the purchasing executives said employment was up at their companies, 68 percent said it was the same and 23 percent said it was down. In July, 13 percent said employment was up, 70 percent said it was the same and 17 percent reported a decline. Supplier deliveries slowed in August, a sign of some economic strength as it indicated companies had more orders than they could fill. Seven percent of the purchasing managers surveyed said supplier deliveries were slower, 87 percent reported they were the same, and 6 percent said they were faster. That compared with 6 percent who said they were slower in July, 83 percent who said they were the same and 11 percent who said they were faster. Inventories continued to decline in August, but at a slowing pace. Sixteen percent of the respondents said their inventories were larger, 57 percent said they were stable and 27 percent said they declined. In July, 10 percent reported they were up, 55 percent reported they were the same and 35 percent said they were down. The National Association of Purchasing Management is a research and education organization with more than 33,000 members. Its monthly survey queries purchasing executives at more than 300 industrial companies across the nation.

DOC.HEAD: PacifiCorp, Pinnacle West Reach Accord
DOC.TEXT: PacifiCorp is dropping its pursuit of Pinnacle West Capital Corp. but is getting the power exchange it wants. PacifiCorp, an electric utility based in Portland, Ore., has been trying to buy either Pinnacle West or its Arizona Public Service Co. subsidiary for several months. Pinnacle West, based in Phoenix, has rejected several offers. On Friday, the companies announced an agreement that allows PacifiCorp to buy part of the Cholla power plant and exchange power during the utilities' differing peak use seasons. Under the agreement, PacifiCorp, at an initial cost of $220 million, will buy part of the Cholla plant and other facilities. The total cost may reach $260 million, Pinnacle West Chairman Richard Snell said Friday. PacifiCorp said it would cease attempts to acquire APS or Pinnacle West. ``We wanted the merger, but this is the next best thing,'' said Al Gleason, president and chief executive of PacifiCorp. ``The primary reason we went into this was for the power system benefit. The agreement is contingent upon approval of the companies' boards and regulatory agencies.

DOC.HEAD: Subaru Announces Management Changes
DOC.TEXT: Harvey Lamm resigned as chairman and chief executive officer of Subaru of America, which merged last week with Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., the companies announced Tuesday. The joint announcement came four days after the merger that made Subaru of America a wholly owned subsidiary of Fuji Heavy Industries, the Japanese manufacturer that builds Subaru cars. Lamm, one of the founders of Subaru of America who became its chairman in 1986, resigned effective last Friday. Lamm has been succeeded by Takeshi Higurashi, Fuji's managing director in charge of Subaru's overseas business. Masaharu Masumitsu, appointed in July as vice chairman of the board, was named chief executive officer Tuesday. Subaru also announced the early retirement Oct. 31 of Marvin S. Riesenbach as executive vice president and chief financial officer.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Extends Life of St. Louis Car Plant
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. on Monday again extended the life of its carmaking plant in St. Louis, putting off the scheduled closing until late May 1991. There are about 2,300 hourly and salaried workers at the factory, which makes Chrysler LeBaron coupe and convertible and Dodge Daytona cars. Chrysler also operates a minivan assembly plant in St. Louis. The life of the St. Louis plant now has been extended twice. Originally, the plant was to close Sept. 21. That date was later pushed back to Nov. 9. Chrysler said the extension of the St. Louis car plant's life until May 24 gives added production time for its Newark, Del., and Sterling Heights, Mich., plants. The two plants were to get the St. Louis factory's products. The company also said the extension would allow the Newark factory to increase production of Dodge Spirit and Plymouth Acclaim cars for fleet and retail sales. Sterling Heights would have more time for added production of an America series of Dodge Shadow and Plymouth Sundance entry-level cars.

DOC.HEAD: McBirney Trial Delayed
DOC.TEXT: The federal bank fraud trial of former thrift executive Edwin T. McBirney III has been delayed until early February, federal court officials said Tuesday. The trial was to start Tuesday for McBirney, who was indicted in July on 17 counts of bank fraud, misapplication of funds, making false entries and making false statements. McBirney, 37, has pleaded innocent and is free on his own recognizance. No new trial date has been set, U.S. District Judge Robert Maloney's office said. The indictment accuses McBirney, former chairman of Sunbelt Savings Association of Texas, of promising another thrift a $6 million profit on one transaction in return for help in financing a $700 million real estate deal in California. Investigators say the deal was one of the reasons Dallas-based Sunbelt failed in 1986, starting a bailout regulators estimate will cost $2 billion. He faces up to 85 years in prison and a fine of $4.5 million if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: EDS, New Century To Acquire Westwood Equities Corp.
DOC.TEXT: Electronic Data Systems Corp. has reached agreement with an affiliate of the billionaire Pritzker family to acquire Westwood Equities Corp., whose holdings include one of the nation's largest title insurance companies, it was announced Tuesday. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. EDS said it reached an agreement in principle with New Century Enterprises Inc. to acquire Westwood, owner of the Ticor Title Insurance Cos. of California. New Century was described as an affiliate of Pritzker family interests. Fortune magazine recently estimated the wealth of the Chicago-based Pritzker family at $4.5 billion, including the Hyatt Corp. hotel and resort chain. Ticor Title Insurance employs 4,500 employees in 348 offices nationwide. Ticor Realty Tax Services is the nation's second largest provider of tax reporting services on mortgaged property. Westwood and both Ticor companies are headquartered in Los Angeles. Ticor Title has been hurt by real estate problems associated with the savings and loan crisis. In 1988, the holding company also liquidated a mortgage insurance unit that had become insolvent. Under a separate agreement, EDS will furnish all information technology services to Westwood's corporate and operating subsidiaries, the news release said. ``EDS is pleased to be working together with the Pritzkers. Their distinguished record of success in managing and growing businesses makes them the ideal partner for this transaction,'' said EDS chairman, president and chief executive officer Les Alberthal. ``This relationship is exactly what Ticor needs to promote its subsidiaries' service capabilities into the next century,'' said Winston Morrow, president of Westwood Equities. The acquisition is subject to satisfactory financing arrangements, and the approval by creditor banks, state and financial regulators and shareholders.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Maker Cuts Prices Of Vectra PCs
DOC.TEXT: Hewlett-Packard Co. said Tuesday it has reduced its U.S. list prices on three of its Vectra personal computers by up to 24 percent because of lower manufacturing costs. The reductions on the HP Vectra 486, HP Vectra RS@25C and HP Vectra QS@20, ranging from $300 to $4,600, took effect Saturday. Hewlett-Packard, an international manufacturer of measurement and computation products and systems, also cut the prices of the 330MB and 670MB enhanced small-device interface (ESDI) disk drives. ``Recent price declines were driven by lower manufacturing costs for the high-performance ESDI hard-disk drives and by lower costs for components, including memory,'' said Pradeep Jotwani, the company's North American PC marketing manager. The HP Vectra 486 PC is the most powerful model in the Vectra group and is used for computer-aided design, multi-user computing and local-area-network server applications. Previous prices for the HP Vectra 486 ranged from $10,499 to $19,499; new prices range from $8,999 to $14,899. Price ranges for the HP Vectra RS@25C, a deskside model intended for the same markets, were reduced from $7,349-$12,499 to $6,299-$11,699. Price ranges for the HP Vectra QS@20, designed for desktop publishing and office applications, dropped from $3,499-$8,399 to $3,199-$5,299.

DOC.HEAD: United Technologies Sued for Hazardous Waste Violations
DOC.TEXT: The federal Environmental Protection Agency on Tuesday charged United Technologies Corp. with failing to comply with federal laws on the management of hazardous waste at six production plants. The EPA said inspections of five Pratt & Whitney Aircraft manufacturing plants and one Hamilton Standard plant revealed more than 100 violations of the federal law that mandates cradle-to-grave management of hazardous waste. The alleged violations include improper handling of hazardous waste, storage of hazardous waste without a permit, inadequate record keeping, inadequate training of personnel, and inadequate monitoring of groundwater. In addition, the EPA said UTC violated the terms of a 1989 consent agreement it had entered into with EPA. The suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Hartford, seeks a court order forcing UTC to comply with environmental laws and unspecified fines. ``It's the number of violations, as opposed to the severity, that we're concerned with,'' said U.S. Attorney Stanley A. Twardy, who filed the civil suit on behalf of the EPA. Julie Belaga, the EPA's regional administrator in New England, said UTC faces fines and penalties ``in the millions'' of dollars. Between 1985 and 1989, the company paid $210,000 in penalties to the EPA. She said the alleged violations do not pose any direct threat to human health and safety. The facilities named in the suit are all in Connecticut. ``The violations at the UTC facilities are serious and persistent,'' she said at a news conference. ``UTC has not implemented corporate management systems that would ensure environmental compliance at all its facilities.'' EPA officials said the waste at issue in the UTC case is byproducts from the production of jet engine parts. Peter Kowalchuk, a spokesman for UTC, said the company was reviewing the lawsuit and had no immediate comment. UTC, based in Hartford, is a major government contractor that designs and makes Pratt & Whitney jet engines, Otis elevators and escalators, Carrier air conditioning equipment, Sikorsky helicopters, Hamilton Standard jet controls, and Norden Systems radar systems for battlefield operations. The company employs about 50,000 people in Connecticut and 200,000 worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Expands Incentives
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. on Tuesday modified its customer incentive program by expanding the number of 1991 vehicles qualifying for cash rebates or low-interest financing. Current incentives on 1990 and 1991 models range from $500 to $1,500 cash back or loans with interest rates as low as 4.8 percent. Specific incentives depend on the model of the car or light truck and expire Sept. 26. Exempted from the program are 1991 Mercury Capri and 1991 Lincoln cars and the 1991 Explorer sport-utility vehicle.

DOC.HEAD: McTeer to Head Dallas Fed
DOC.TEXT: Robert D. McTeer, Jr., has been named president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas effective next February. McTeer, 47, replaces Robert H. Boykin, who is retiring after 37 years with the Dallas Reserve Bank. McTeer is senior vice president in charge of the Baltimore branch of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond. He joined the Richmond Reserve Bank in 1968 as an economist in the research department and began his present job in 1980. The Dallas Reserve Bank serves the Eleventh Federal Reserve District, which includes Texas and portions of northern Louisiana and southern New Mexico.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Surge, Wheat Slide Continues
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices surged Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade, rebounding from levels that some analysts had viewed as excessively low after a week-long decline. Meanwhile, wheat futures retreated for the sixth consecutive session and hit new life-of-contract lows across the board. Victor Lespinasse, an assistant vice president in the grain-trading division of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said the steady drop in wheat prices reflects abundant supplies of the grain due to large harvests in the United States, Argentina, India and the Soviet Union. Corn futures were mostly higher, following soybeans. The September corn contract was pressured, though, by slack near-term demand and the nearness of the corn harvs later this month. DOC.HEAD: Bank of New England Selling Rhode Island Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: A subsidiary of a Scottish banking group agreed to buy most of Bank of New England Corp.'s Rhode Island operation for $75 million Tuesday, buying a little hope for the troubled bank's prospects. The deal will sell most of the best of Bank of New England-Old Colony assets to the Citizens Financial Group of Providence, R.I. Citizens is a subsidiary of The Royal Bank of Scotland Group, a financial services holding company. Selling off its Rhode Island interest is the last major move in Bank of New England's efforts to boost its capital and restructure its operation. ``This sale virtually completes our program to downsize the company and to concentrate our efforts on our strong franchises in Connecticut, Maine and Massachusetts,'' BNE chairman and chief officer Lawrence K. Fish said in a prepared statement. ``It happens to fit our franchise well,'' said Kenneth E. Hogberg, chief financial officer of Citizens, in an interview from Providence. ``We think the franchise will continue to carry a lot of value.'' With the disposal of the Rhode Island subsidiary, Bank of New England will be left with three major subsidiaries: Maine National Bank, Connecticut Bank and Trust and Bank of New England. They employ about 14,000 people, a bank spokesman said. The bank has been shedding assets and its work force since it came under increased government scrutiny when the region's economy began to slide and the real estate market exposed piles of bad loans. The bank lost more than $1 billion in 1989. It has lost $46.6 million in the first quarter that ended March 31 and more than $30 million in the second quarter of this year. Analysts said the sale of Old Colony is good for Bank of New England, but can't be looked upon as the transaction that will start the company's turnaround. More important will be reducing its non-performing assets, the analysts said. That in turn depends on whether the New England economy recovers soon. ``Picture a guy crossing a desert, dying, and they find a small oasis with a little bit of water,'' Don J. Kauth, an analyst at First Albany Corp. said of the sale of Old Colony. ``The question is, will they make the rest of the way across the desert? It depends on how wide the desert is. ``Unless the economy improves, the Bank of New England is going to run out of capital before they run out of non-performing assets,'' Kauth said. Bank of New England bought the 70-year-old former Old Colony-Newport National Bank in 1986. Under the agreement, Citizens will acquire $600 million of selected Old Colony assets while Bank of New England keeps $550 million in assets. It will also acquire more than $900 million in deposits while Bank of New England keeps about $250 million in deposits, liabilities and capital. Also under the terms, Citizens will acquire and operate the Old Colony branch network as part of Citizens Bank, while Bank of New England keeps the BancNew England Mortgage Co., a subsidiary of Old Colony, based in East Providence. The deal would increase Citizens' assets to $3.7 billion, making it Rhode Island's second biggest bank. The Bank of New England fell victim to the rumor mill last week, its stock falling 62{ cents a share to $1 Thursday after a congressional candidate erroneously suggested federal regulators had recommended a takeover of the bank. The Comptroller of the Currency in Washington, the chief regulator for the Bank of New England, as well as the bank denied and denounced the rumors. Confidence apparently restored, the bank's stock rose again Friday and closed at $2.12{ a share. In afternoon trading Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange, Bank of New England was selling for $1.87{ a share.
