DOC.HEAD: Fujitsu Introduces Fastest Mainframe Computer Series
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Fujitsu, Japan's largest computer maker, announced a powerful new mainframe computer Tuesday that it says is the fastest in the world. The news came a day before rival IBM is expected announce its new top-of-the-line models. Both companies are depending on their new-generation mainframes to maintain their technological and competitive leadership in high-end computers. International Business Machines Corp. has refused to release details of its new computer line before its announcement scheduled for Wednesday. Fujitsu officials said the top model in their new M-1800 series is capable of executing up to 600 million instructions per second, or mips, in scientific calculations. Analysts say the new IBM top-of-the-line computer, code-named the Summit, will run at a maximum speed of about 230 mips. The most powerful current IBM mainframe can handle about 112 mips. However, IBM, the world's largest computer company, is expected to announce that customers will be able to link several of the new models together to boost power dramatically, perhaps exceeding 600 mips. Toshio Hiraguri, general manager of Fujitsu's Computer Systems Group, said the 600 mips figure doesn't adequately represent typical operating conditions, under which he said the M-1800 series would run even faster. Unlike supercomputers, which are designed to make repetitive scientific calculations, mainframes must be able to handle a wide range of general business, data base and communications information _ often at the same time. ``We believe Fujitsu's mainframe will be competitive not just today, but also tomorrow,'' a company official said, referring to IBM's expected announcement. NEC in July announced a mainframe that it says is capable of 500 mips. But it uses a different operating system than the system shared by IBM, Fujitsu and Hitachi, making a direct comparison of processing speeds difficult. The operating system is the base layer of software that controls internal computer functions. Hitachi in June announced it will build a mainframe capable of 155 mips. Fujitsu's M-1800 series' speed comes in part from special high-speed logic and memory chips, high-capacity fiber-optic interconnections and sophisticated batch processing of data, the company said. The top-of-the-line model 85 also will be the first mainframe in the world with eight processors, it said. The new IBM computers will have similar features, except the top model will have only six processors, analysts say. Fujitsu officials denied that they timed their announcement Tuesday to reduce the impact of IBM's news conference in the United States. ``We've been planning to begin shipments next April, and our customers have been asking us to make the announcement as soon as possible,'' a Fujitsu official said. ``So it's just a coincidence that IBM decided to announce its computer at about the same time.'' IBM officials declined to comment Tuesday on Fujitsu's announcement. The U.S. company depends on sales of mainframes and associated software and equipment for about half its annual profit. Fujitsu said it plans to sell about 300 of the multimillion-dollar systems over the next three years, with most sales likely to be in Japan. The computers also will be sold overseas under the nameplate of Siemens AG, the West German computer company, and their technology is likely to appear in mainframes produced by Amdahl Corp., a U.S. maker of IBM-compatible mainfames that is 45 percent owned by Fujitsu. Amdahl and Hitachi generally have undercut IBM's mainframe prices and have eaten into its sales in recent years, although IBM still has about 87 percent of the U.S. high-end mainframe market, says Computer Intelligence, a California research firm. Some industry analysts have predicted a declining market for large general-service mainframes, saying customers would be better off buying increasingly sophisticated smaller computer workstations that can be tailored to specific functions. Several of the new Fujitsu machines, however, can be linked together, with each handling separate functions such as data base processing, communications and application processing to customize and maximize performance, the company said. ``With this announcement, we want to say that the mainframe business is not dead,'' said a Fujitsu official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``They will continue to be the main anchor for customers, whether they be researchers or businesses.'' Fujitsu said it expects to sell most of its M-1800 systems to financial institutions, research institutes, government organizations and engineering facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Number of Working Rigs Increases by 10
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS four grafs after 2nd pvs, A week, with Baker Hughes comment on rig increase; EDITS to conform. Picks up 4th graf pvs ``At the ...''
DOC.TEXT: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States rose again this week, climbing by 10 to 1,012, Baker Hughes Inc. reported. A week ago, the count had increased by 15 to total 1,002. The count a year ago this week was 936, Baker Hughes said Tuesday. The Houston-based oil toolmaker company has kept track of the rig count _ the widely watched index of drilling activity _ since 1940. The count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not those producing oil. Ike Kerridge, keeper of the count at Baker Hughes, said Tuesday that the increase in oil prices caused by the Middle East crisis probably is beginning to have some positive impact on the rig count. ``Some of (the count increase) may be a reflection of higher prices _ although it is the season when (the count) goes up anyway,'' Kerridge said. ``And the increase have been modest. But if (the Middle East crisis) hasn't begun to affect it yet, I think it will very shortly.'' Kerridge said there is no absolute way to judge exactly how rising oil prices affects the domestic rig count. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986. Among major oil-producing states, Kansas added seven rigs to its count, followed by California and Wyoming, which each gained five. Colorado's count was up four, Ohio was up three, Texas gained two rigs and Pennsylvania added one more. Louisiana lost eight rigs, Oklahoma's count was down by six and North Dakota lost two.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Surge On Fading Hopes
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures prices surged Tuesday as fading hopes for a settlement to the Middle East crisis helped turn traders' attention to the prospects for tight supplies in the last three months of the year. The October contract for light sweet crude oil rose $1.80 a 42-gallon barrel to settle at $29.12 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The contract had risen 55 cents on Friday, the last trading day before the Labor Day holiday. Contracts for petroleum products also posted sharp advances. October contracts for unleaded regular gasoline jumped 8.34 cents a gallon to settle at 94.52 cents. The September contract had risen 7.25 cents before expiring at the close of trading Friday. Home heating oil for October delivery settled at 82.39 cents per gallon, up 5.83 cents. The expiring September contract had gained 0.35 cent on Friday. Higher oil prices, which are a harbinger of higher inflation, sent bond prices lower. In other markets, stock prices were mixed with the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials falling less than a point. In currency dealings, the dollar slumped. Even in the absence of significant developments in the Persian Gulf, analysts had expected energy futures prices to spike higher following a sharp advance in London on Monday. Traders turned their attention to the basic ``supply and demand balances,'' said oil analyst Jim Murchie of Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. ``Things are quiet enough now for people to go back and do the basic work.'' Present oil supplies may not meet demand for the chilly fourth quarter, Murchie said, adding that half the world's oil is used for heating. In the last quarter of the year, oil stocks are typically drawn down to meet heightened demand. ``Before the crisis we were expecting a 1 to 1.5 million barrel a day drawdown, now we're projecting a 2 to 2.5 million barrels a day to meet fourth-quarter demand,'' Murchie said. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries' recent agreement to increase its daily crude production quota to 22.5 million barrels daily still falls short of projected fourth-quarter demand, Murchie said. During a crisis, those who hold oil contracts are reluctant to sell, which pushes the price higher. Experts said there was a lack of sellers on Tuesday, which was responsible for the rise in prices amid moderate volume. The market also was weighed down by disappointment over the slow release of hostages by Iraq and the unsuccessful attempts by United Nations Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to mediate the crisis. ``People are a little more pessimistic . . . and war is a little bit more on their minds today,'' said James Fiedler, a vice president at E.D.&F. Man International Inc., in explaining the advance in oil prices. But he also said the market's behavior was unusual in light of last week's action, when crude contracts opened $1 a barrel lower after a weekend also devoid of major developments.

DOC.HEAD: American, United Table Disagreement Temporarily
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines and United Airlines have tabled their dispute at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport, pending a decision from the Federal Aviation Administration. A hearing had been scheduled Tuesday over whether to bar United from operating under new flight schedules at O'Hare. U.S. District Judge John McBride last month ordered United to make changes in its schedule. Fort Worth-based American contends United's proposed schedule is misleading to passengers. But the airlines requested a postponement of Tuesday's hearing to Sept. 17 while they await the FAA decision, American spokesman Tim Smith said. ``What happened is that we have not as yet heard any decision from the FAA and both parties have agreed to essentially postpone the hearing in federal court for a couple of weeks because we did not want to be in the middle of that and get some kind of decision from the FAA,'' Smith said. If the FAA ruling favors American, Smith said the lawsuit likely would be dropped. ``Obviously, if the FAA ruled in United's favor we would continue our legal pursuit of the matter,'' he said. United schedules starting Oct. 1 reflect not-yet approved deviations from federal guidelines on takeoffs and landings at O'Hare, American said. The high-density slot rules are intended to regulate traffic at four of the nation's busiest airports by designating times for takeoffs and landings. United contends the schedules were ``carefully designed to reduce congestion and delay at O'Hare.'' United, based in Chicago, earlier this year replaced American as the nation's largest carrier.

DOC.HEAD: Hachette Unit Suspends Regular Publication of Memories Magazine
DOC.TEXT: Memories magazine is cutting back its publication schedule because of the weak advertising climate, its publishers announced Tuesday. Diamandis Communications Inc., a U.S. subsidiary of France's Hachette SA, said that regular publication of Memories will be suspended with its October issue. It said Memories will appear twice a year starting in 1991. The magazine has been published every other month since early 1989 and plans had been to make it a monthly this fall. But Peter Diamandis, president and chief executive of Diamandis Communications, said ``the current softness in the advertising marketplace makes it imprudent to continue the current rollout plan.'' Hachette made the move after efforts to sell the magazine failed. Memories was launched in the spring of 1988, and sought to tap readers' fascination in the past by taking another look at major events of the past 50 years. Among the stories it updated were the Battle of Britain, the Kennedy assassination, the March of Dimes crusade and baseball slugger Ted Williams. But it ran into a tough ad environment. Ad pages in magazines were down 3.3 percent in the first half of 1990 compared with a year earlier, according to Publishers Information Bureau, and no signs of a pickup in demand are evident. So far this year, the ad slump has figured in the closing, suspension, consolidation and redesign of several magazines. Woman, 7 Days and Southpoint magazines have folded. Psychology Today suspended publication in January but hopes to reappear in January. Manhattan Inc. magazine ceased publication and merged with the fashion magazine M under the new title M Inc. The nightlife magazine Details was converted into a general interest men's magazine. Didier Guerin, president of Hachette Publications Inc. which oversees Diamandis Communications, said Memories was up for sale for a couple months and that a deal was nearly reached with Mortimer Zuckerman, the real estate baron who is chairman and editor in chief of U.S. News & World Report and chairman of The Atlantic Monthly magazine. Zuckerman said in a telephone interview that he talked with Hachette about Memories but said ``we never made a formal proposal to buy the magazine.'' ``We came to the conclusion that the economy was so bad and getting worse that it wasn't good time to be excessively adventuresome,'' he said. Guerin said the deteriorating economic climate is prompting advertisers to cut back on ad spending. ``The last thing they need is a new publication that is not established,'' he said. Nonetheless, he said Memories would be published twice a year because ``it's still a good concept, still a strong name and we should be able to keep it alive'' at that rate. If the economy improves, he said the magazine could be published more often. It has promised advertisers a circulation of 600,000. The magazine had a staff of 27 and Guerin said efforts would be made to find jobs for them at other Hachette magazines. Those other titles include Boating, Car and Driver, Elle and Popular Photography. Guerin said there were a ``few others'' in addition to Zuckerman who expressed interest in Memories, but he declined to identify them. He said none of the other Hachette magazines are on the market. Earlier this year, Hachette put its Woman's Day magazine up for sale to trim the company's debt, but pulled it off the market in July after bidders failed to show up with the price it wanted. The magazine's demise comes less than two week's before the premiere of a weekly television show that has licensed the magazine's name, ``Memories . . . Then and Now.'' The show is being produced by NBC News Productions, a unit of the National Broadcasting Co., and will be carried starting Sept. 15 on more than 120 stations serving more than 80 percent of the nation's households with TV. Therese Byrne, head of the unit, said there was no editorial link between the magazine and the television show, however, and that the reduced frequency of the magazine should have no impact on the show.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturing Economy Slows Again, Purchasing Managers Report
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This incorporates material from Washington-datelined AM-Construction Spending and AM-Productivity.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's purchasing managers said Tuesday that manufacturing slowed in August, providing more evidence of a looming recession and signs that the Persian Gulf crisis is taking a toll on the economy. The National Association of Purchasing Management, which tracks the manufacturing economy through a monthly poll of its members, said its overall index of business activity at 300 industrial companies fell to 47.0 percent from 47.4 percent in July. When the index registers below 50 percent, it indicates the economy is weakening. The drop in the index was the second consecutive monthly decline. The index stood at 51.1 percent in June. The purchasing managers report contained few surprises, but still was ``evidence that the economy is slowing down, and slowing down fast,'' said David Wyss, chief financial economist for DRI-McGraw Hill in Lexington, Mass. The report said production and new orders were down in August, prices for raw materials moved sharply higher and employment was down. Prices and employment appeared to be affected by the month-long Persian Gulf crisis. Wyss said the employment component, in particular, ``suggests quite frankly that businesses are quite scared by the Mideast. ... They taking on fewer people.'' Economic news from Washington Tuesday also was less than encouraging. The Commerce Department reported construction spending edged up 0.4 percent in July for its first gain in four months, but the government revised downward its estimate of spending in May and June. Despite the July gain, analysts expect the industry to remain weak due to consumer caution, high interest rates, tight lending requirements and, in some areas, overbuilding. A report on productivity was equally downbeat. The Labor Department said the productivity of American workers improved for the first time in more than a year, climbing in the second quarter at an annual rate of 1.5 percent. But the advance was well below the level needed to significantly boost Americans' standard of living. Furthermore, the productivity report contained figures showing steep labor cost increases, which elevated concerns that inflation is accelerating, especially in light of the Middle East oil crisis that threatens to step up price increases. The purchasing managers, noting production was off for the first time in seven months, attributed the slowdown to a sharp drop in new orders in July. Twenty percent of the purchasing managers said production was up in August, while 54 percent reported it was unchanged and 26 percent said it was down. That compared with 19 percent reporting higher production in July, 58 percent reporting it was unchanged and 23 percent saying it had slowed. New orders dropped for the second straight month. Twenty-one percent of the purchasing managers said new orders rose during August, while 49 percent reported they were stable and 30 percent reported they had declined. In July, 19 percent reported growth in new orders, 53 percent reported they were the same and 28 percent said they had declined. The purchasing managers said export orders also dropped, as did imports. Prices for raw materials rose during August, a reflection of higher energy prices resulting from the Gulf crisis. Twenty-two percent of the purchasing managers said they were paying higher prices, 68 percent said they were paying the same amount, and 10 percent said prices were down. That compared with 12 percent reporting higher prices in July, 77 reporting stable prices and 11 percent reporting lower prices. Employment fell for the 18th straight month during August and at a slightly faster rate than in July. Nine percent of the purchasing executives said employment was up at their companies, 68 percent said it was the same and 23 percent said it was down. In July, 13 percent said employment was up, 70 percent said it was the same and 17 percent reported a decline. The lone bright spot in the August report was a slowing in supplier deliveries, which indicated companies had more orders than they could fill. Seven percent of the purchasing managers surveyed said supplier deliveries were slower, 87 percent reported they were the same, and 6 percent said they were faster. That compared with 6 percent who said they were slower in July, 83 percent who said they were the same and 11 percent who said they were faster. The purchasing managers also said inventories continued to decline last month. The National Association of Purchasing Management is a research and education organization with more than 33,000 members.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Buyers Scarce Despite Rise With Oil
DOC.TEXT: Investors burned by last week's gold collapse were reluctant to re-enter the precious metals market Tuesday despite surging oil prices and a lower stock market, two factors that typically spur strong gains in gold. Gold futures prices rose only slightly on New York's Commodity Exchange while silver futures retreated. On other commodity markets, grain and soybean futures were widely mixed; orange juice futures fell sharply; and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher. Gold futures settled $1 to $1.40 higher on the Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in September up $1.40 at $383.70 a troy ounce. Silver futures ended 4.1 cents to 5.4 cents lower with September at $4.719 a troy ounce. Light sweet crude oil soared more than $1.80 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid reports the U.S. Navy had stopped and boarded a tea-laden Iraqi-flagged freighter in the Gulf of Oman as part of the trade blockade against Iraq. Any sign of rising tension in the Middle East is likely to prompt an increase in both crude oil prices and inflation fears, which is ordinarily bullish for gold. But after gold prices dropped last week from more than $415 to less than $385 an ounce, investors are leery about buying the metal, said Fredric Tordella, president of MTB Banking Corp., a New York-based dealer of precious metals and foreign currency. He said the market's Aug. 27 plunge of $26.70, its steepest decline in seven years, ``really shook a lot of people up _ not only their pocketbooks but their faith in the metals market and how it's going to react to the current situation.'' Anne Orton, a vice president of the precious metals and currency dealer Deak International Inc., agreed that last week's big drop ``took a lot of steam out of the market. ``I don't see it totally collapsing under the current circumstances but I don't think there's really much to go on the upside,'' she said. On the New York Merc, light sweet crude oil futures finished 61 cents to $1.80 higher with the October contract at $29.12 a barrel; heating oil was 4 cents to 5.83 cents higher with October at 82.39 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 4 cents to 8.34 cents higher with October at 94.52 cents a gallon. Soybean futures surged on the Chicago Board of Trade, rebounding from levels that some analysts had viewed as excessively low after a week-long decline. But wheat futures retreated for the sixth consecutive session and hit new life-of-contract lows across the board, reflecting abundant supplies worldwide. Corn futures were mostly higher. The corn and soybean crops moved rapidly toward maturity last week, accoring to the Agriculture Department's weekly crop-progress report, which was released after the close. The report showed 81 percent of the corn crop in the dough, or kernel-forming stage as of Sunday compared with 91 percent at the same time last year and a 94 percent average. Soybean plants were setting pods in 90 percent of the crop as of Sunday compared with 91 percent a year ago and a 93 percent average, the USDA reported. Wheat futures settled 1} cents to 6\ cents lower with September at $2.56\ a bushel; corn was 2{ cents lower to 1\ cents higher with September at $2.40} a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 2} cents higher with September at $1.07} a bushel; soybeans were 2{ cents to 11 cents higher with September at $6.08 a bushel. Orange juice futures fell sharply on the New York Cotton Exchange for the fourth straight session amid expectations that Brazilian juice processors will announce further price cuts. Frozen concentrated orange juice settled 2.5 cents to 3.35 cents lower with September at $1.567 a pound. Livestock and meat futures ended mostly higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting strong retail demand for beef and perceptions that the hog market is about to enter a seasonal uptrend. Live cattle futures settled .30 cent to .80 cent higher with October at 77.02 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .25 cent to .45 cent higher with September at 87.02 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .62 cent higher with October at 48.92 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .30 cent lower to .47 cent higher with February at 50.20 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Saunders' Fall Prompts Comparisons With Tragic Icarus
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Denis in 5th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Like the mythical Icarus with his waxen wings, Ernest Saunders was a high flier who crashed. The former chief executive of Guinness PLC, who earned $740,000 the year he engineered what was then Britain's largest corporate takeover, has lost his job, his wealth and, finally, his freedom. His wife suffered a nervous breakdown and remains far away in Switzerland. All he has left is the loyalty of his three children _ and an unshakable insistence that he is innocent. References to Icarus cropped up in several newspapers late last month as Saunders began a 5-year jail term for organizing an illegal operation to ensure Guinness' successful takeover of Distillers Ltd., a Scottish whisky and gin maker. Judge Sir Denis Henry summed up Saunders as ``a very determined and single-minded man, used to getting your own way and relentless in pursuit of it.'' Gerald Ronson, 51, chief of Heron International PLC, and former stockbroker Anthony Parnes, 44, were given 12 months and 2{ years respectively for their part in the affair. Ronson also was fined a record $9.85 million. Financier Sir Jack Lyons, 74, convicted with them, will be sentenced Sept. 25. The four were found guilty of 19 charges ranging from stock manipulation and theft to false accounting in Guinness' hard-fought $5.04 billion takeover bid for Distillers in 1986. The court found the four had illegally inflated the price of Guinness stock, making the company's bid more attractive than a rival offer from the Argyll supermarket group. During the six-month trial at Southwark Crown Court, Saunders, 54, denied knowing about any illegal payments to buyers of Guinness stock. But he said he had encouraged ``people, institutions, anyone I met'' to sell Distillers shares to Guinness rather than to Argyll and to buy Guinness shares, ``because that was my job.'' During seven days of testimony, Saunders testily defended his integrity, characterizing the government's allegations as ``scurrilous,'' ``disgraceful'' and ``disgusting.'' Benjamin Guinness, the chairman of the family brewing enterprise founded in Dublin in 1759, had hired Saunders in 1981 to reverse the company's falling fortunes. And that's just what he did. Starting in June 1984, Guinness expanded vigorously, buying a chain of newsagencies, the Champneys group of health clubs, Nature's Best health products and the Cranks health food restaurant chain. In 1985 Guinness quietly took over the Scottish whisky makers Arthur Bell and Sons. Between 1981 and 1985 Guinness' pre-tax profits rose to $170 million from $82.3 million. James Saunders said Guinness' value on the stock market jumped to $5.6 billion by 1986 from $168 million in 1981. But within a year of clinching the takeover of Distillers in 1986, Saunders was out of a job and in police custody, charged in Britain's biggest financial scandal. He had been known in ``the City,'' London's financial district, as a brilliant marketing man. And when trouble broke, observers say, the marketing man came to the fore. ``So was born Saunders the Scapegoat,'' said the Observer, a London Sunday newspaper. ``Innocent Ernest Saunders, the chairman and chief executive who knew nothing, heard nothing and most certainly did nothing that could have caused him to face a trial.'' This was the hero of ``Nightmare,'' a 270-page book written by his 24-year-old son James. The book depicts Saunders suffering a ``living hell'' after his arrest in May 1987. The man accustomed to limousines rode the subway to court, lived in a small flat and relied on legal aid to pay for his attorney. James and his sister Joanna, 25, often came to court with their father. Saunders' co-defendants were supported by glamorous wives, but Carole Saunders stayed in Switzerland, where she and her husband had gone in 1987 to recover from psychological stress. ``The man I knew as energetic, logical and lucid, a perfectionist, had changed into an intellectually broken man,'' testified Dr. Eric Rochat, who treated Saunders. Saunders' colleagues at Guinness portrayed him as ambitious, single-minded, sometimes domineering and even ruthless. Olivier Roux, former Guinness finance director, said Saunders was willing to delegate, but in the Distillers bid, ``where it was never comfortable, he was involved in all aspects and overseeing all aspects.'' According to The Times of London, Guinness workers had a nickname for Ernest Saunders. They called the boss ``deadly Ernest.'' Two inches taller than 6 feet, he was every inch the gray-haired patrician with steady gaze and studied courtesy. His club was the Carlton, the traditional hideaway for leaders of the Conservative Party. The image obscured the roots of the man. Born Ernst Walter Schleyer in Vienna on Oct. 21, 1935, he was the son of Uly and Hanni Schleyer, a Jewish couple who fled from the Nazis to England in 1938. In Britain, they determined that Ernst and his brother Peter should ``be brought up as English boys,'' according to James Saunders. Ernst Schleyer became Ernest Saunders at age 12, when he entered the prestigious St Paul's School in London. After t. (AP) _ A line of boys' clothes that carry an anti-hunting message is being yanked from the shelves at J.C. Penney Co. Inc.'s 1,330 stores, the company said. Duncan Muir, public relations manager for the Dallas-based retailer, said it took the step after complaints about the clothes nationwide. ``It is our company policy not to take a position one way or the other on these sorts of issues. This is taking a position and an anti-position,'' he said. ``Obviously, this was pointed out to us and frankly we feel we've made a mistake. All we can do is just withdraw it from the stores,'' he said. Michigan United Conservation Clubs, a sportsmen's group, was among those criticizing Penney last week for carrying the clothing. Penney bought the ``Environmental Protection Department'' line of clothing from a New York company, H. Cotler Co. The head of the company, Howard Cotler, was in a meeting Tuesday and did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment. A card attached to each shirt in the line shows a sketch of a bird hunter aiming a shotgun over which a large red ``X'' has been marked. Under that are the words: ``Absolutely No Hunting of Wild and Free Animals While Wearing This Garment.'' A similar message is stitched into an inside panel of the garment. Pants have a larger card with the message: ``Wild life protected by man surround the world with pure thoughts.'' Tags in the clothes indicate it was made in Hong Kong. In a letter to the National Rifle Association last week, Cotler said the anti-hunting message was a marketing tool that had been discontinued. He wrote that his company ``neither condemns nor supports anti-gun or anti-hunting legislation'' and it was trying to appeal to the environmental awareness of young people. Muir said he didn't know how many pieces of clothing were being taken off Penney store shelves. ``It's in various stages of shipment. A lot of it is still on its way and stores order on their own, so it's hard to say how many pieces are out there.'' He declined to place a dollar figure on the Penney order to Cotler, saying that was an internal inventory matter. Muir also said the retailer had not decided yet what to do with the clothes.

DOC.HEAD: Digital Announces Voluntary Severance Program
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp. said Tuesday it hopes to reduce its work force by 5,000 to 6,000 jobs by offering employees a voluntary severance program. The severance packages will reduce costs and overstaffing in some of the computer company's departments, said Digital spokeswoman Nikki Richardson. ``No layoffs are planned at this time and no closings are planned at this time,'' she said. The packages include medical and life insurance for a year and assistance in finding other jobs, Richardson said. The packages will be implemented in September and should be completed by the end of the year, she said. About 3,000 Digital employees accepted a similar severance program in 1989. Digital announced in July that it had lost $256.7 million in the final quarter of its fiscal year, citing $400 million in costs related to a restructuring program. Digital, a Maynard-based international provider of computer systems and services, has 124,000 employees worldwide, including 71,400 in the United States.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices ended mixed in extremely light trading Tuesday as oil prices continued to climb and a report indicated further erosion in the economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks fell a marginal 0.99 point to 2,613.37. Earlier, the key index was down as much as 30 points before a late-day rally. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by about 6 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 673 up, 814 down and 473 unchanged. But other figures registered a slight gain. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.16 to 177.13, Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 0.82 to 382.85, and S&P's 500-stock composite index rose 0.53 to 323.09. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to a scant 92.94 million shares for the lowest volume of the year, down from 96.48 million Friday, the year's previous low. Traders said many market participants apparently extended the Labor Day holiday weekend an additional day. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 114.44 million shares. Analysts said continued concern about the inflationary effect of rising oil prices helped send stock prices lower. The October contract for crude rose $1.80 a 42-gallon barrel to settle at $29.12 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Investors also were troubled by weakness in overseas stock markets and signs that the U.S. economy is continuing to slow, traders said. In one such sign, the National Association of Purchasing Management said its purchasing managers index declined in August for the second consecutive month, to 47.0 percent from 47.4 percent in July. A reading below 50 indicates the manufacturing sector of the economy generally is declining. The market's movements were exaggerated by the low trading volume, said Steven VanBrunt, a trader with Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. in New York. He said the market's late-day rally was sparked by a rise in the stock futures market. Other traders said bargain-hunting spurred the upswing. Earlier, continuing pessimism over the Middle East sent prices plummeting on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 512.79 points, or 2.20 percent, closing at 24,907.64. Prices also closed lower in London, but the key index, the Financial Times Stock Exchange 100-share index, fell only 0.86 percent. Pinnacle West was the most-active NYSE issue, falling 3} to 12] as 2.2 million shares changed hands. PacifiCorp ended its struggle to acquire the utility holding company in exchange for an agreement to swap electricity. Among most-active blue chip issues on the NYSE, Boeing rose ] to 48|, General Electric fell } to 61\, Philip Morris was unchanged at 45[ and IBM was up | at 102{. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market grew $2.055 billion, or 0.07 percent, in value. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 0.46 to 381.67. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell 0.65 to 322.74.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed in domestic trading after rising overseas Tuesday, but analysts were at a loss to explain the U.S. currency's strength. Gold prices were also mixed, rising in New York and dropping in Europe and Asia. The dollar was up in early trading in New York, following the trend sent on foreign markets, but then lost some ground. Dealers said they had no explanation for the dollar's healthier tone, and shied away from predicting what course the U.S. currency would take. ``We're trying to decide whether it's a reversal of direction or what, and we just don't know,'' said Robert Ryan, chief foreign exchange dealer with Bank of New York Co. The dollar has slumped in recent weaks because of pessimism about the U.S. economy and the effect the Persian Gulf crisis could have on it. Dealers said the markets were looking toward the scheduled release Friday of the Labor Department's employment figures for August. The markets expect the report to confirm that the economy is slowing down and reinforce arguments that U.S. interest rates must come down. Many economists say the U.S. economy is headed into a recession and the Federal Reserve will move to encourage lower rates. But such a move would be a negative for the dollar, which is supported by higher interest rates and has struggled lately to compete against currencies of nations with higher rates. The dollar fell to 143.40 Japanese yen in New York, compared with 143.785 late Friday. U.S. financial markets were closed Monday for Labor Day. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose to 144.05 yen from 143.55 at Monday's close. Later, in London, it was quoted at 143.55 yen. The British pound was down against the dollar when compared with late Friday's price, falling to $1.8810 from $1.8905. In London, sterling rose to $1.8750 from $1.8730 late Monday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.58115 German marks, up from 1.5755; 1.3135 Swiss francs, up from 1.30835; 5.2965 French francs, up from 5.2865; 1,179.00 Italian lire, up from 1,170.00; and 1.16075 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15625. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.5843 German marks, up from 1.5837; 1.3170 Swiss francs, up from 1.3158; 5.3105 French francs, up from 5.3080; 1.7860 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7840; 1,182.25 Italian lire, up from 1,179.00; and 1.1623 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1535. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold rose $1.40 to $383.70. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $384.60, up $1.85. Overseas dealers said gold's slide was partly triggered by a French newspaper report quoting a Palestine Liberation Organization official as saying Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was willing to negotiate Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait in return for certain undertakings from the West. Gold is seen by some investors as a haven in times of international tension, and its price often falls when tensions subside. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $382.50 a troy ounce from $387 late Monday. In Zurich, it fell to a closing bid of $382.25 an ounce from $387.50 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.74 an ounce to $388.35. Silver fell in New York and London. On the Commodity Exchange, a troy ounce of silver slipped 4.1 cents to close at $4.719. In London earlier, silver fell to a late bid of $4.75 a troy ounce, down from $4.83 late Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Healthco Merging With Hicks Muse Affiliate
DOC.TEXT: Healthco International Inc. will be acquired by an affiliate of the investment firm Hicks Muse & Co. Inc. for about $250 million in cash, the companies announced Tuesday. Healthco will be merged into HMD Acquisition Corp., a unit of Hicks Muse and Ray C. Davis, a former senior executive with Colt Industries. The price paid for Healthco will be $19.25 a share in cash, bringing the total value of the deal to about $250 million. The transaction is expected to be completed in the late autumn. M. Myer Cyker, Healthco chairman, said the transaction with Hicks Muse will benefit the dental supply company's growth and development. He said Healthco chose Hicks Muse because the Dallas-based investment firm has a strong record in building companies for the long term. The agreement is subject to financing and the approval of Healthco stockholders. Healthco is a major provider of equipment and services to dentists, dental schools and labs. The company has operations in the United States, Canada and Western Europe, and had revenue of about $437 million in 1989. Hicks Muse has completed about $6 billion of acquisitions since 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Last of 16 Linked to Revco Insider Trading Settles Charges
DOC.TEXT: An Ohio investor, the last of 16 people charged with passing or trading on inside information about the leveraged buyout of Revco Drug Stores Inc., has settled civil charges, federal regulators said Tuesday. Howard Passov of Pepper Pike, Ohio, settled with the Securities and Exchange Commission without admitting or denying wrongdoing. He was among eight people charged in July 1989 in two separate SEC complaints with trading on confidential information before a management group's 1986 leveraged buyout of Revco was made public. All but Passov settled the charges shortly after they were filed. Passov, however, settled in the middle of his trial at federal court in Cleveland last week. He agreed to return $40,000 in profits from his alleged illegal trading. ``We felt under the circumstances it was a fair settlement,'' said Passov's attorney Marvin Karp, adding ``We felt the case involved unusual legal and factual issues and that's why we pursued it to litigation. And the SEC acknowledged the validity of our position and that's why they settled.'' Another eight people, including the head of a Cleveland investment banking concern, Golenberg & Co., settled various securities law charges without admitting or denying wrongdoing. Glenn Golenberg, head of the firm, was not accused of insider trading. Passov was accused of buying Revco common stock and options while in possession of confidential information that a management group led by Revco's chairman, Sideny Dworkin, planned to acuire the drug store chain.

DOC.HEAD: Customs Service Reaches Lawsuit Agreement with K mart
DOC.TEXT: K mart Corp. has agreed to pay $6 million in import duties and penalties for evading textile import quotas, the government said Tuesday. The U.S. Customs Service said the payment would settle a civil case against the Troy, Mich.-based retailer and its subsidiary, K mart, Taiwan. The settlement includes $3 million in unpaid duties and a penalty. A Customs Service investigation found that K mart and its Taiwanese affiliate manipulated prices of various textile articles imported from Taiwan and South Korea to ``evade the quota controls on certain classes of those articles,'' the agency said in a statement. The alleged infractions occurred between 1982 and 1985. Federal law limits quantities of many textile articles that can be imported from certain countries during a given period of time. K mart spokesman Robert Stevenson said the dispute with the government centered on whether the company sufficiently disclosed its pricing practices ``during four years of very mixed regulatory signals from Customs.'' ``K mart at all times never intended any wrongful or mistaken activity,'' Stevenson said. ``Above all, K mart intends to keep its record with the Customs Service clean of lengthy disputes and therefore agreed to settle this case.''

DOC.HEAD: Philips Announces 4,000 Layoffs, Scrapping Of Personal Computer Chip R&D
DOC.TEXT: The troubled Dutch electronics giant NV Philips said Tuesday it would discontinue several activities in its unprofitable components division and lay off 4,000 workers mostly in Europe. The company will halt further development of a large memory computer chip that it planned to use in a new portable computer series, said Philips spokesman Jack Reemers. Over the past few years, Philips has spent the equivalent of $842 million on a ``mega-project,'' much of which was devoted to developing the technology needed to make the one-megabit static random access memory (S-RAM) chip. Reemers said Philips would also suspend research on the S-RAM chip being carried out with Siemens of West Germany and Thomson SA of France in the cooperative ``Jessi'' project. However, Philips will remain active in other Jessi projects. Philips said it had committed itself to spending $42.1 million a year for eight years to support Jessi research on S-Ram chips. ``We are still very much involved in the Jessi project,'' said Reemers. Philips president Jan Timmer warned at a special shareholders meeting in July that he planned to restructure several operations at Philips' including the components division. He predicted losses for the year of more than $1 billion and 10,000 layoffs. Philips also announced Tuesday it would end production of direct driven liquid crystal display (LCD) boards which are used as screens for portable computers. The moves have led analysts to speculate that Philips is preparing to close down its computer operations. But Reemers did not say whether the company has such plans. Philips has unsuccessfully tried to save its ailing computer operations by linking its business with a partner. Reemers said Philips will also halt work on semiconductor lasers in the Netherlands and in Taiwan. Dutch analysts gave mixed reactions to the news that the electronics giant was halting development of the S-RAM technology. ``Cost-wise, it is a good idea but strategy-wise I am not sure. They used to regard development of memory chips as crucial to their products,'' said an analyst who asked to remain anonymous. ``What is the value of a giant electronics company that can't develop its own technology?'' he added. In 1989, Philips' components division had sales of about $6.2 billion and employed a total of 75,000 people. Of those, 35,000 worked in Europe where most of the job losses will occur, according to company spokesman Reemers.

DOC.HEAD: President and CEO of CBS Records Steps Down
DOC.TEXT: Walter Yetnikoff, president and chief executive of CBS Records Inc., announced Tuesday he was stepping down as head of the company immediately. Yetnikoff, 57, said in a statement he will take a few months off before working on long-term projects with Norio Ohga, chairman of CBS Records and president of its parent, Sony Corp. The label of Michael Jackson, New Kids on the Block and Bruce Springsteen has grown to the world's largest record company under Yetnikoff's leadership. ``We understand and respect his decision, and are grateful that he will make himself available as a special adviser to me,'' Ohga said in a statement. Last month, The Wall Street Journal reported that unidentified people close to Yetnikoff said he wasn't being forced out of the company and had in part initiated the move. Day-to-day operations of the company will be directed by Tommy Mottola, president of the label's domestic business; Robert Summer, international chief, and Neil Keating president of Columbia House, the company said. The three will report directly to Ohga as the company's board of directors considers naming Yetnikoff's successor. Yetnikoff, a native of Brooklyn, N.Y., started at CBS in 1961 as an attorney and rose to president of CBS-Records Group in 1975. Yetnikoff is credited with steering CBS Records' climb to world prominence and engineering its $2 billion sale to Sony Corp. in late 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Hearing Taken off Calendar
DOC.TEXT: A hearing on the Office of Thrift Supervision's attempts to extend a partial freeze on the assets of Charles Keating Jr. was taken off the calendar in federal court here Tuesday. There were no operators on duty after hours to take calls at Kirkland & Ellis, the Chicago firm representing Keating. The OTS would say only that it might have a statement on the matter Wednesday. U.S. District Judge Stephen V. Wilson had already granted a request by the OTS for a temporary restraining order against Keating, who controlled Lincoln Savings & Loan Association in Irvine through his Phoenix-based American Continental Corp. The OTS wanted Wilson to convert the temporary restraining order to a preliminary injunction. Wilson had indicated he probably would. There was no immediate rescheduling of the hearing. Keating already has complied with a key provision of the order. That was to hand over to the OTS an accounting of his personal finances, in essence proving that he is broke, as he contends. A sticking point has been the OTS' order that he give notice 48 hours before spending $5,000 or more. He's also been ordered not to transfer money out of the country. Regulators say Lincoln's failure may cost taxpayers $2 billion. They are seeking about $42 billion from Keating and five associates in connection with soured business deals at Lincoln. Keating says that Lincoln's losses were compounded and exaggerated by the regulators who seized it. He accuses them of making him a scapegoat to cover up their own bungling supervision of the thrift industry.

DOC.HEAD: NASD Fines Paine Webber, 2 Employees
DOC.TEXT: A Paine Webber Inc. account executive was fined $125,000 and barred from dealing with members of the National Association of Securities Dealers, the NASD announced Tuesday. The NASD, a self-regulating organization empowered by Congress to oversee the over-the-counter securities market, also fined Paine Webber and the executive's superviser $30,000. Both the company and the two individuals settled the charges without admitting or denying wrongdoing. In an unrelated matter, the Securities and Exchange Commission upheld an NASD disciplinary action against W.N. Whelen & Co. a Georgetown, Del., brokerage for numerous securities rule violations. In the Paine Webber case, Nilda Rubiera Zim, a New York City account executive, was accused of recommending and executing securities transactions without considering if they were suitable for her customer's financial situation and investment objectives. In addition to the $125,000 Zim was barred from ``association with any member of the NASD in any capacity.'' The NASD also found that Zim's superior, Joseph Patrick Tota, of Flower Hill, N.Y., and the firm itself, failed to supervise her properly. The company and Tota were fined a total of $30,000 and Tota was suspended from NASD association for five business days. In the Whelen action, the SEC, which has veto power over NASD actions, upheld a previous decision fining the firm $25,000 and suspending William N. Whelen Jr., the firm's president, for 10 business days. The NASD found that the firm misappropriated assets, violated rules on net capital and protecting customers' investments, improperly extended credit and other violations. In upholding the sanctions, the SEC noted that the firm had a history of prior violations and had shown an unwillingness or inability to follow the rules.

DOC.HEAD: American Express Names CFO, Subsidiary Chairman
DOC.TEXT: American Express Co. Tuesday promoted the president of its IDS Financial Services subsidiary to chairman and named a chief financial officer for the parent company. Aside from the chairmanship of IDS, Harvey Golub was elected vice chairman of American Express, the company said in a statement. Michael P. Monaco has been acting chief financial officer at American Express since howard L. Clark Jr. became chairman and chief executive of Shearson Lehman Brothers earlier this year. Aside from taking over as head of corporate finance, Monaco was elected an executive vice president of the company. Jeffrey E. Stiefler takes over Golub's title of president at IDS. Stiefler was executive vice president of sales and marketing at IDS.

DOC.HEAD: Johnson & Johnson Takes on Bristol-Myers in Court Over New Ad Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Johnson & Johnson sued rival Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. on Tuesday to halt an ad campaign that claims aspirin-free Excedrin is a better pain reliever than Johnson & Johnson's extra-strength Tylenol. In a lawsuit filed in federal court in New York, the New Brunswick-based pharmaceutical giant charged that Bristol-Myers' claims were false. The first commercial in Bristol-Myers' new ad campaign aired Thursday, said Robert Kniffin, Johnson & Johnson's director of public relations. Because both drugs contain the same dose of the pain reliever acetaminophen, the products are equivalent pain relievers, Kniffin said. The lawsuit challenged Bristol-Myers' assertions that the 65 milligrams of caffeine in Excedrin increase the effectiveness of acetaminophen, he said. It also accused Bristol-Myers of publishing misleading conclusions from three studies in which patients were asked to compare the effects of extra-strength Tylenol versus aspirin-free Excedrin. Officials at New York-based Bristol-Myers were not in their offices early Tuesday evening and could not be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Owner of F.D. Roberts Pleads Guilty to Racketeering Charge
DOC.TEXT: An owner of a defunct Paramus-based penny-stock firm accused of bilking customers of more than $60 million pleaded guilty Tuesday to a federal racketeering charge. Leonard Tucker, 30, of Boca Raton, Fla., faces up to 20 years in federal prison and millions of dollars in fines for his part in the F.D. Roberts Securities Inc. scam, according to a release issued by U.S. Attorney Michael Chertoff. Tucker was among eight top-level F.D. Roberts officials indicted by a Newark federal grand jury on March 26. The indictment alleged the eight derived $67 million in illicit profits while associated with the penny-stock brokerage firm, which shut down in February 1989. Tucker said he and his co-defendants controlled the sale of stock, placed stock in illegal accounts, controlled the public companies whose stock they sold and used collusive brokerage firms, according to Chertoff. Tucker also said he recruited individuals with little or no securities experience to be salespeople and condoned the use of deceptive and misleading telephone sales techniques, Chertoff said. Also charged in the March indictment and awaiting trial are Fred Galiardo of Daytona Beach, Fla.; John Perfetti of Bayville, N.Y.; Alan Lieb of Pine Brook; John Montondo of Boca Raton; and three of Tucker's relatives, brothers Daniel Tucker of Boca Raton and Gary Tucker of New York, and step-father Richard Thaw of Boca Raton.
